She didn’t move, but the pull was visceral, dragging her forward in spirit if not in flesh- like a lamb to slaughter, holy and doomed, too far gone to pretend she wouldn’t kneel.

 

A tiny, unbidden whimper clawed its way out of Agatha’s throat before she could stop it.

 

This was fine. Normal. Agatha could exist in the same zip code as that ass without losing her grip on reality. She could be cool. Casual. Normal.

 

Agatha should really look away. 

 

She didn’t. 

 

She needed a minute. Maybe several.

 

Rio finally settled into one of the loungers, legs stretched out and Agatha had never been more jealous of a goddamn piece of furniture in her life.

 

Agatha didn’t look. Not at first. She busied herself with nothing- adjusting her sunglasses, smoothing the hem of her shirt, pretending the view didn’t exist.

 

But she could feel it. She always could.

 

Agatha kept her eyes low as long as she could, but the weight of it pressed against her until she caved and glanced up- 

 

Rio was already looking at her.

 

Sunglasses slid halfway down her nose, brows arched just enough to ask a question she had no intention of saying out loud. Her mouth twitched, not quite a smirk. Relaxed. Confident.

 

Oh fuuuuuuuck.

 

Agatha could’ve ignored it. Looked away. Played dumb.

 

She didn’t.

 

Instead, she reached for the hem of her shirt and started to peel it off, slow and methodical. Not for effect. Not to flirt. Just to prove she could. The fabric clung to her for half a second before giving way, sliding over her ribs, her chest, her shoulders.

 

By the time the shirt cleared her head, Rio’s gaze was glued to her chest.

 

Agatha’s breath caught.

 

Then Rio licked her lips.

 

It wasn’t purposeful. It wasn’t a move. Just instinct. A flash of tongue, barely there, quick and unconscious and somehow worse because of it. That single flash of tongue had Agatha’s brain shorting out entirely.

 

Agatha wanted to press her palms against untouched skin that had haunted her for years. To stake some long overdue claim on what always should’ve belonged to her. To make sure no one else ever- 

 

Get a grip. Get a fucking grip.

 

She dragged her gaze away from Rio and started toward the lounger beside her, trying not to trip over every thought currently screaming inside her head.

 

Agatha dropped into the lounger with a dramatic grunt, limbs sprawled,  surrendering to the sun instead of the situation.

 

“You good?” Rio asked.

 

“Yep,” Agatha said, eyes pinned to the sky.

 

Agatha could feel Rio’s brown eyes boring holes into the side of her skull. The full turn of her head, the deliberate silence- it was all so pointed it might as well have been spoken. Agatha could practically hear the smirk forming. Tongue against cheek. That stupid fucking tell Rio had never grown out of.

 

“I didn’t see you put on sunscreen.”

 

Here we go. 

 

Agatha’s mouth pulled into a smirk before she could stop it.

 

Of course that was the first thing out of Rio Vidal’s fucking mouth.

 

Agatha had put it on at home -alone, in the bathroom, twisting to reach her back like an idiot- because it had felt like the smart thing to do. Her brain had made that call hours ago- before Rio’s face, her voice, and her insane ass had entered the equation. Now she was sitting here, half naked, bathed in sunlight and suddenly regretting every responsible decision she'd made before walking out the door.

 

She didn’t glance over. Just let the silence hang between them- almost daring Rio to fill it.

 

Let her look, Agatha’s brain whispered. 

 

Agatha slid deeper into the lounger, arms stretching overhead, spine arching just slightly as she adjusted her weight. One leg bent at the knee, casual. Thoughtless. A move meant to get comfortable, except she knew exactly what it looked like.

 

Just enough to make Agatha feel a little less stupid for doing everything right and still wanting to be touched.

 

Then Agatha turned her head and looked at Rio, tight smile, “Already applied.” her voice light and immediately looked back up at the sky.

 

Before Rio could say anything else, Agatha tipped her head back and looked up at the sky again- casual, dismissive, pretending the conversation bored her.

 

It didn’t.

“I think I’m good.”

“You sure?” Rio asked.

 

“Positive.”

 

Rio nodded. “Right. Of course.” She crossed one ankle over the other. Her jaw worked. Like she was chewing on the words she wasn’t saying.

“I mean, not to brag,” Rio said, voice lighter again, “but I am exceptionally talented with sunscreen. It’s a skill, actually. Artful. Controlled. Even coverage.”

 

Agatha hummed in response, not trying to hide her amusement. She turned on her side to face Rio, one arm tucked beneath her head. 

 

She didn’t say anything.

 

Just looked at Rio. Let her talk. Let her fill the silence with nonsense and jokes and whatever this nervous energy she was trying to cover.

 

And maybe Agatha should’ve cut it off. Should’ve made a comment. Should’ve protected herself.

 

But she didn’t.

 

Because maybe, for once, she just wanted to stay here. Inside a world where Rio was allowed to want her. Where Rio looked at her like that and didn’t try to hide it. Where Agatha didn’t have to shrink or laugh it off or be the one who wanted more.

From the angle -and the muttering- Agatha could tell she was playing Connections, the New York Times word game where you grouped words into sets of four. Simple in theory. Mostly designed to piss people off.

You know. Seniority.

That was the only reason. Or it was the easiest one to reach for. The sun was still high, the water warm, but her skin prickled anyway. Something about the breeze, maybe.

Her gaze climbed, slow, until it met Agatha’s eyes.

Stuff people say when they want you to keep trying, she thought.

Swim!  Her brain screamed it. Swim, now. Swim fast. You’re drowning.

Agatha didn’t mean to make a sound, but she did. The smallest whimper, slipping out before she could catch it.

But this- 


This was slower.

 

This was intentional in every way that made Agatha ache.

Her breath hitched in her throat, and she caught Rio’s bottom lip between her teeth and licked across the full length of it shamelessly, before diving back into her mouth.

 

This time, Rio fought her for it. She kissed Agatha harder, rising onto her toes, shifting her body closer until every part of her was speaking loud and clear.

 

Her hips tipped forward again, pressing into the space Agatha refused to take, and stayed there. Agatha could feel the invitation in every inch of her. The way Rio pushed close and held still. It was patient. It was a body that had nothing left to prove, and still chose to ask.

 

And Agatha’s hands were burning with the answer.

Unbelievably close. Her thumbs swept along the top, pressed in, gripped harder. Her fingers flexed. Agatha felt the shift of muscle, the curve she’d memorized with her eyes but never her hands.

Instead, Agatha pulled Rio closer.

 

Their hips met with more force, water sloshing between them, and Agatha moaned into her mouth, helpless and grateful and furious with how long they had waited to do this.

She wasn’t sure she could.

 

Rio was the one who pulled away. Barely. Just enough to breathe. Her hands stayed where they were, cupping Agatha’s face, fingers warm against her cheeks. Her thumbs brushing just under her eyes like she needed to know this was real. She didn’t step back. Didn’t try to move. She just looked at Agatha.

 

Their breathing was ragged. Sharp and uneven, and comes only after you’ve gone too deep, stayed under too long, and come up with no grace at all.

 

Agatha’s lungs burned.

 

Not just from the lack of oxygen, but from everything else- what she’d been holding back, what she’d finally let herself have. Her grip on Rio didn’t loosen. Her hands were still firm around her ass, submerged and certain, fingers aching from how tightly she’d held on.

Her breath escaped on a laugh. It wasn’t loud. It wasn’t smooth. It caught in the middle like it surprised her. The corners of her mouth pulled up into a smile that looked too big for her face.

Rio stayed there, breathing through the smile, not pulling away.

Rio had invited her up to her apartment casually. Agatha had said yes. Told herself it was because she was nosey. Because she wanted to see where Rio lived now. Where she went home to at the end of the day. She wanted to know if Rio still flipped light switches with the back of her knuckles, if her taste in furniture had changed or if Agatha’s absence still lived in the negative space.

 

They walked in silence for a bit, the wet heat of the afternoon still clinging to their skin. Rio broke it by pointing out the landscaping along the path, listing off the types of bushes the complex had planted- dwarf yaupon holly, viburnum, some kind of ornamental grass she couldn’t name but claimed was “a diva about sunlight.”  

 

Agatha let her talk. She was too busy cataloging everything: the curve of the path, the way Rio’s hand hovered at her lower back when they crossed the parking lot, and the click of the lock as Rio scanned her key fob and held the door open.

 

Inside, the building was cool and quiet. They stepped into the elevator, and Rio stood closer than necessary. Their shoulders touched, and Rio didn’t shift away. Neither did Agatha. Her eyes were fixed upward, watching the floor numbers tick.

 

Sixth floor.

 

The doors opened with a soft ding. Rio stepped out first, her gait loose but purposeful, and Agatha followed. The hallway was long and clean, lined with muted gray carpet and identical white doors. They turned a corner, and Rio came to a stop.

 

Unit 69.

 

Agatha snorted.

 

Rio grinned and kissed two fingers before tapping them against the number plate. “Requested this one specifically,” she murmured, pushing the door open with her other hand. “For the vibes.”

 

Agatha rolled her eyes. “Of course you did.” But she was smiling.

 

Agatha held her breath as she stepped inside. The entryway was narrow and spare- just a long runner stretched across the hardwood floor, a slim table against one wall, a key hook above it, and a tall mirror that caught their reflections in pieces.

 

Rio kicked off her flip flops by the door and gestured wordlessly. Agatha followed suit, toeing hers off beside Rio’s with the reluctance of someone who wasn’t sure how long they were staying but didn’t want to track in dirt. 

 

Agatha didn’t say anything. She was too busy trying to listen for ghosts.

 

The first time she’d been to Rio’s old place, it had been a disaster- crickety floorboards, a window that wouldn’t close all the way, plants too ambitious for the single patch of sunlight that came in sideways from the fire escape. The couch had been lopsided. A leak in the kitchen ceiling had made the light fixture unreliable. It was falling apart, but it had been full of Rio- clean, particular, always reorganizing a drawer one minute and trying to fix a cabinet hinge the next, which somehow made the whole door crooked. That apartment had felt like a stubborn kind of survival. Like Rio had carved it out with her teeth and dared anyone to call it permanent.

 

Rio hung her keys on the hook with a casual flick of her wrist and padded down the hall like she didn’t need to explain anything. Agatha followed, noticing how clean the floor was beneath her feet, how the walls were unmarked by thumbtack holes or leftover tape. No signs of makeshift fixes or chaotic repairs. This place held itself up without effort.

 

At the end of the hall, Rio turned right into the kitchen and flicked the light on with the back of her knuckle.

It was warmer than she expected.  A rust colored couch sat pushed against a wall, its cushions deep and worn. A quilt was draped over the back, hand stitched by someone who cared enough to match the colors but not obsess over symmetry. Lilia, if Agatha had to guess.

 

There were mismatched coasters on the coffee table, a glazed ceramic bowl full of bottle caps, and a half melted candle in a jar labeled 'tobacco flower.'

 

The shelves above the couch were floating, wooden, staggered along the wall like stepping stones. One held a stack of books so dog eared they could’ve been reread a dozen times. Another, a row of small clay pots, each one housing a different kind of plant- some trailing, some upright, all reaching toward the soft light above.

 

A hanging light glowed in the corner, shaped like a basket turned upside down, wicker suspended by a coiled rope that was tacked into the wall. It cast a dappled amber light over the room, warm as fire without the flame. Below it, a monstera stretched its leaves outward, broad and glossy.

 

It didn’t feel staged. It didn’t feel aspirational. It felt… settled.

 

And that was what knocked the wind out of Agatha most.

 

The Rio she remembered had always been a little at war with her surroundings. Always compensating, always adjusting. Making do, never making permanent. And now, here she was- clearly not just living but rooted. Not fighting the space, but shaping it. Choosing softness. Keeping it.

 

Agatha blinked. Her hands hung uselessly at her sides.

 

This wasn’t the kind of place you crashed at. It was the kind of place you came home to. The kind of place you could miss.

 

And somehow, that realization hit harder than anything that happened all day.

The first photo that caught her eye was of Rio and Sage, standing in front of the wall outside Lilia’s house. Sage looked twelve, arms crossed with a dramatic scowl, backpack on. Rio stood behind her, arms slung around her neck, grinning like an idiot.

 

It was a first day of school photo- Agatha could tell by the backpack, the timing, the wall. Even though Rio hadn’t been in school for almost a decade at that point, she still showed up for Sage, still stood there with her like it was her own first day too.

 

She looked younger in it- too young. Like the version of Rio from the year Agatha left.

Next to it, a photo of the three of them -Rio, Sage, Lilia- smiling around what looked like Sunday dinner. Then another. That same dining table, but this time Sage was older. Alice and Jen were in that one too, all of them squeezed into frame, laughing at something that had already passed.

 

Agatha’s chest went tight.

The first: Agatha, Jen, and Rio. They were in Rio’s old apartment- sitting on her old janky couch. Jen was on Agatha’s right, flipping off the camera. Agatha sat in the middle, knees tucked up, practically curled into Rio’s side. Her nose scrunched at the camera. Rio sat forward, bearing her teeth in a snarl, an unlit cigarette between them and Agatha’s old purple lighter gripped tightly in her hand. Natty Light cans cluttered the coffee table. She remembered that night. Neither of them had been wearing shoes. The air smelled like rain and burnt toast from someone else’s kitchen. They were stupid and loud and close.

A decade later, it was still there. In pictures. In her old stupid lighter Rio still carried around. Like some part of her had always known Agatha would come back.

She turned to find Rio standing there, arms crossed loose over her chest, her expression caught somewhere between regret and exposure- like she'd been seen too clearly. Like she knew Agatha had noticed the quiet ways she'd been held onto by Rio, and didn’t know what to do with it.

“Oh yeah. Like two years ago. It was fun.”

The record player. Same one from Rio’s old place. But it was the stand it sat on top of that really stopped her- walnut, mid-century style, still scratched in the front from when Rio had scrapped it trying to get it out of the trunk. They’d found it together in the furniture section of a thrift store, sitting perfectly between a broken dresser and a glass coffee table. 

 

Rio had spotted the stand instantly, crouched like she was in a museum, checking the joints and the grain, already in love. She’d said, “Mine,” without looking back. Agatha had just sighed and gone to find someone to help them carry it while Rio stood beside it like someone might try to steal it from her.

“Uh, towels are in that cabinet,” Rio said quietly. “Soap and stuff’s already in the shower.”

She wasn’t sure why her voice sounded hoarse. Only knew she suddenly couldn’t stand the damp cling of her t-shirt, or the cold swimsuit underneath, still wet from earlier.

 

Rio nodded back. “Cool.” She breathed the word out. Then she stepped back and pulled the door halfway closed behind her.

 

Agatha heard the soft shuffle of her feet retreating, the creak of a drawer opening, the quiet hush of movement as Rio crossed her own bedroom. A moment later, her footsteps padded down the hall toward the guest bathroom. 

 

Agatha stood there for another second, alone with the echo of a scratched record and her own heartbeat.

 

-

 

Showering at Rio’s was a terrible idea.

 

Eucalyptus hung in a bunch from the shower head, slightly browned at the edges, still fragrant in the steam. Agatha tried not to stare at it. 

 

She stood under the water, chest turned to the spray, hair still dry- no point washing it. She hadn’t gone under water in the pool- at least not physically. That, and she couldn’t stomach the idea of using Rio’s shampoo.

 

The soap had been a reflex. Agatha didn’t think about it until the scent hit her- too clean, too sweet, familiar in a way that scraped at her ribs. It clung to her, buried itself in her skin, and the towel only made it worse. 

 

Agatha had grabbed the first one she saw, thick and worn from use. The fabric reeked of Rio’s detergent, warm and chemical and so distinctly hers that Agatha nearly gagged on it. She tried not to think about how often Rio had used this exact towel, how many times she’d wrapped it around herself with dripping hair and bare shoulders. It was inescapable. Even after she got dressed, her own clothes couldn’t smother it. She still smelled like Rio. It had worked itself into every seam.

 

They ended up on the couch, neither of them saying much. They sat close, but not touching, a careful few inches of space between them.

 

Agatha had picked the movie- Little Shop of Horrors . She told herself it was because it was there, because it was safe, because she hadn’t thought it through until it was too late. Halfway in, she regretted it entirely.

 

Rio used to play it on a loop until Agatha knew every line by heart. And now, with it playing softly in front of them, she wanted to vomit.



Not at the movie itself, but at the mushiness of it all. The softness. The stupid, sentimental instinct that made Agatha put it on in the first place. She could hear Rio mouthing along to “Skid Row (Downtown)” beside her without even thinking and it made her stomach turn.

 

Agatha hadn’t picked it to be kind. Or maybe she had. She definitely had. And that was the problem. It was so unlike her. Or maybe it wasn’t, maybe it was exactly like her. Maybe that’s why she hated it.

 

Too earnest. Too exposed. Too obvious.

 

She kept her eyes on the screen, jaw tight, fists curled in her lap like she could wring the weakness out of her palms. Rio scrolled through her phone like nothing had changed, humming the tune under her breath, still loving the same things. Still taking up space like she always had- quietly, relentlessly, without asking.

 

And Agatha had let her. Had invited it. Hit play like it meant nothing. Like she wasn’t hoping Rio would notice.

 

Like it wasn’t, in some fucked up way, a love letter.

 

“I’m gonna ask you this,” Rio said finally, still looking at her phone. “And I fucking hope your answer’s changed in the last decade… What pizza do you like?”

 

Agatha couldn’t help the way her lips curled and her hands relaxed. 

 

It was always this- pizza wars and smug grins and a total refusal to compromise. They had never once shared a pizza. Rio refused. Said Agatha’s choices were a war crime. Said she couldn’t stomach the idea of her own slice so much as brushing against the sludge Agatha ordered. They used to get two different pizza’s just to keep the peace, and even then, Rio would make a show of sealing Agatha's box closed like it was a biohazard.

 

Agatha didn’t flinch. “Hawaiian.”

 

Rio recoiled like she’d been physically slapped. “No. No, no, no. Agatha. Pineapple? You’re still- Jesus. You’re still doing this?”

 

“It’s good,” Agatha said, smug now. “It’s sweet and salty. It’s balanced. Like… culinarily. It’s science.”

 

“It’s fruit on cheese. That’s not science, that’s a hate crime.”

 

“Tomatoes are fruit. Pizza sauce is fruit. You're already eating fruit, asshole.”

 

“Tomatoes are barely fruit. They don’t count.”

 

Agatha snorted. “You just don’t like it because you’re a coward. You fear flavor.”

 

“I fear soggy crust and betrayal. Pineapple leaks juice, Agatha. It leaks. It seeps into everything. I used to taste the betrayal on my half when you ordered that garbage.”

 

“That’s why we got separate pizzas every time.”

 

Rio nodded. “Because I don’t believe in cross contamination.”

 

“You’re so dramatic,” Agatha muttered.

 

Rio glanced at her, unimpressed. “I’ve had pineapple flavored crust trauma. I’m allowed to be dramatic.”

 

Rio was still fiddling with the order, tapping her thumb against the phone screen like she was pretending this didn’t feel familiar. Like they hadn’t done this exact dance a dozen times before.

 

“Same place?” Agatha asked.

 

“Obviously.” Rio tossed her phone onto the cushion between them and leaned back, arms crossed. “Forty minutes.”

 

Agatha nodded.

 

They both looked at the screen again. The movie was still going- bright and absurd, soaked in sentiment.

 

-

 

The pizza showed up sometime after the second song in the credits, and they ate it straight from the boxes with cold beers and tired limbs. It was comfortable. Easy in the way old things sometimes were. Rio made a dramatic show of nearly retching every time Agatha reached for another slice of Hawaiian. Agatha rolled her eyes and kept eating. They talked. Nothing heavy. Only conversation that looped and meandered, full of jokes and interrupted stories.

 

When they were done eating, neither of them moved. Agatha grabbed the quilt from the back of the couch and threw it over both their legs without comment. They still weren’t touching, not exactly, but they were close enough that it wouldn’t have taken much. Close enough that her bare knee kept brushing against Rio’s thigh whenever she adjusted. They kept talking. Kept laughing. Rio kept being fucking annoying.

 

At some point, Rio stood and stretched, lazy and smug. “I’m stepping out for a cigarette,” she said, already walking toward the door. “Care to join?”

 

Agatha didn’t answer. Just stood and followed.

 

The sun was nearly gone by the time they stepped onto the balcony. It was narrow but well used- two old metal chairs, a small round table with a single dead cigarette crushed into the ashtray. 

 

Bulb lights were strung overhead, screwed into the siding and the overhang, uneven and slightly drooping between bolts. One flickered every few seconds like it couldn’t make up its mind.

 

There was only one hanging plant, a long, leafy thing by the sliding door that swayed in the breeze.  The rest were arranged along a simple wooden bench on the far end, nestled in mismatched pots- ceramic, clay, chipped enamel. 

 

Agatha leaned her back against the railing, ashtray balanced beside her, cigarette lit and resting between two fingers. She took a slow inhale, letting it settle in her chest before she exhaled.

 

Rio stood beside her, bent over the railing, elbows resting against the rusted metal. She had a cigarette in one hand, smoke curling past her lips as she talked about how her old shithole apartment had somehow paid off. How she’d saved and waited and waited some more. How this place was finally hers. She liked it. 

 

Agatha nodded along, eyes drifting.

 

Black hoodie. Black plaid boxers she wore as shorts. Rio’s hair was still in a loose bun at the nape of her neck, still slightly messy. Her gaze traveled up. The pieces that had fallen loose were tucked back into place, framing her ears.

 

Agatha’s eyes caught on small black diamonds.

 

Agatha didn’t register whatever Rio was saying by then. She cut in quietly, “Let me see how your piercings are healing.”

 

Rio didn’t hesitate. She moved to step in front of Agatha. “They’re healing fine,” Rio said, offhand, but still turned her head to each side so Agatha could see.

 

Agatha reached up and traced the shell of Rio’s right ear, fingertips gentle, eyes locked on the tiny black diamond she’d placed there herself. They suited Rio. Of course they did. 

 

Her hand fell without thought to Rio’s shoulder. Agatha took another inhale from her cigarette, turned her head, and blew the smoke out toward the sunset before flicking ash into the tray. 

 

“Any brawls or marriage proposals happen at work when you debuted them?” Agatha asked, lips curled into a smirk. Her fingers remained where they’d landed on Rio’s shoulder, slow, unmoving, and then, with barely any pressure, she tugged. Just once.

 

Rio nodded like she was answering the question, even if she wasn’t. She took one last drag from her cigarette and hummed around it, then leaned past Agatha to stub it out. Her hands came to rest on the railing, one on each side of Agatha’s body, and she stepped in. Closer. A few inches between them now. Not even that. She blew the smoke to the side, her voice low. “So many, Agatha. I was fighting women off all night. It was vicious. Bloody.”

 

Agatha fake pouted, lips curved. “Poor baby.” Her fingers moved along the seam of Rio’s shoulder lazily.

 

“Yeah. Poor me.” Rio’s voice dropped a little, teasing. “I was promised backup, and someone bailed.”

 

“I was working,” Agatha said, amused. “Keeping babies from trying to crawl toward the light.”

 

“Mm.” Rio squinted like she was pretending to weigh that. “Valid. But I’ll have you know it got dicey out there. I almost died.”

 

 “Eh. You survived.” Agatha shrugged.

 

“By the skin of my teeth.” Rio grinned and snapped her teeth in Agatha’s direction like she might actually bite her.

 

The gap between Rio's teeth had never once stopped being endearing, not even when Agatha tried to pretend it had.

 

Agatha snuffed her cigarette in the tray beside her and shook her head. “Weirdo.” She was still smiling, cheeks aching from it.

 

“I don’t see you complaining,” Rio said, nodding between their bodies like their closeness was all the proof she needed.

 

Agatha didn’t respond. Instead, she let her hand drift from Rio’s shoulder, fingers trailing up to the back of her neck.  She didn’t think about whether it was a good idea. She didn’t calculate the fallout. She just did what she wanted to do. For once. Without justifying it.

 

Agatha leaned in and kissed her.

 

Their mouths met gently, and Agatha held there- without urgency, without force. Just the soft, certain press of her lips to Rio’s.

 

Rio didn’t flinch or fall back. She breathed out against Agatha’s mouth and kissed her again. This time longer. This time with more certainty.

 

Then again.

 

And again.

 

Each one a little fuller than the last. Each one asking a question and receiving the same answer.

 

Agatha let it happen. Let herself want it. She didn’t rush or overthink it, didn’t try to force meaning onto the moment, but she felt the way her body stilled into it. The way her hands softened where they touched Rio. The way the air around them seemed to narrow until all she could feel was Rio’s breath, her mouth, the way she kept coming back like it was the most natural thing in the world.

 

When Agatha finally pulled back, she didn’t go far. Her hands found their way to Rio’s waist, resting there for a beat before curling under the hem of her hoodie. She glanced down at the space between them and how little of it there was. The fabric gave easily, and her palms slipped beneath, coming to rest against Rio’s bare back.

 

Rio exhaled when Agatha touched her like that- fully, soundlessly. When Agatha pulled her in, arms wrapped around her like she had every right. Rio went without resistance.

 

Agatha let herself explore. Her fingers traced the familiar shape of Rio’s spine, nails lightly dragging as if to mark her place. She didn’t know why she was doing it except that she could. Rio’s arms closed around Agatha’s shoulders like a sigh. Agatha felt the brush of lips against her hair.

 

Agatha closed her eyes. She had to. Everything in her felt like it was turning inside out. The closeness. The stillness. The goddamn kindness of it. Not just now, but all day. Every stupid softness she'd let herself accept. She breathed out shakily, trying to reel herself in. Her voice, when it came, barely cleared her throat. “I should probably go home.”

 

Rio didn’t move at first. Then she shifted back just enough to meet Agatha eyes. “I want you to stay,” Rio said softly.

 

Agatha’s eyes slammed shut this time, too fast, trying to block out the words by refusing to look at them.

 

Once, she would’ve done anything to hear that. Would’ve set the world on fire to be wanted like that. And now here it was, handed to her plain and unadorned.

 

And she couldn’t even look at Rio.

 

Rio must have seen it- the way Agatha’s body stilled, the way her hands gripped tighter like she was bracing for the impact of something unspoken. She pulled back even more, softening her tone like she could smooth it over.

 

“Just to hang out,” Rio added quickly, eyes flicking down and then back. “That’s all. If you want.” A pause. Then quieter: “You should stay.”

 

“Okay,” Agatha whispered. 

 

That would’ve always been the answer. No matter the time. No matter the cost. If Rio ever asked, the answer would always be yes. It had never been anything else.

 

But still, Agatha played at indifference. Still, she pretended her heart hadn’t just fallen out of her mouth and landed -whole and stupidly willing- in the hands of the one person she’d never been able to take it back from.



Chapter End Notes

thank you for the music (kudos, comments, bookmarks, all of it)

i hope y'all ENJOYED this chapter. lmk what ya think!

Chapter 6: not strong enough

Chapter Notes

Howdy, ladies, gays, and theys. Before y’all dive in, a quick note:

It seems I may have… mathed incorrectly. Not that I’m surprised, but it turns out that not only am I terrible at math but also remembering what year it is, which is why I’ve kept most dates and ages vague on purpose. That said, I did go back and make a few small adjustments- Agathario’s “fifteen years of knowing each other” is now seventeen, and I also tweaked the year Wagatha got married/Sage got adopted. Will the timeline still make perfect sense? I can only hope for the best. But the beauty of fanfiction is that it doesn’t have to.

So if you notice the math isn’t mathing, I beg you! look away! And please forgive me! I knew not what I was doing (iykyk hehehe).

Lastly, there is now a Pinterest board for this fic. It’s entirely unhelpful and all vibes, but my gf told me to make one and because I am her bitch… I did. Happily. Here’s the link, if you want to check it out: https://pin.it/4472qG25I

Hope it works.

See the end of the chapter for more notes

It had been two weeks since Agatha kissed Rio on the balcony and then, for reasons she hadn’t fully justified even to herself, decided not to kiss her again.

 

They hadn’t talked about it. Which, in Agatha’s opinion, was technically different from how things would’ve gone ten years ago. It was just easier to let it exist somewhere else. This was different. It was space. Breathing room. A mutual pause. Acknowledged, if only by the fact that neither of them pretended it hadn’t happened. And that, Agatha told herself, was something. 

 

She’d stayed the night, that first time. On the couch. With Rio. Which wasn’t romantic so much as logistical… and incredibly stupid. They'd both insisted it was fine, and then promptly not slept. At some point, Rio’s arm had ended up across her legs, the blanket twisted halfway off the couch, and Agatha had woken up sore, annoyed, and still not ready to leave.

 

Agatha hung around the next morning. Rio made her coffee, which she begrudgingly admitted was leagues better than the sad, watery excuse her Keurig had been churning out for months. Then Rio made breakfast like it was no big deal -eggs, toast, something green Agatha absolutely refused to identify- and somehow, neither of them commented on the fact that she hadn’t left yet.

 

Agatha didn’t end up leaving until sometime after one. On her way out, she hovered by Rio’s curved bookcase, pretending not to stare at the photo of her, Rio, and Jen in Rio’s old apartment. 

 

Agatha glanced toward the hallway. Rio was still in her room, on the phone with Sage, her voice was muffled.

 

Without thinking, Agatha reached for the frame and slipped it into her bag.

 

It wasn’t a power move. Or petty. She just… wanted it. Like how people steal rocks from beaches or pens from restaurants. Except this one had her face on it, so she figured that made it fair game.

 

Rio came out just as Agatha was sliding the photo into her bag. Agatha looked up and offered her best no, I did not just commit mild sentimental theft smile.

 

If Rio noticed the empty space on the shelf, she didn’t mention it.

 

Rio walked her to her car. And Agatha got in. Drove off. Didn’t look back.

 

The photo stayed tucked in her bag, pressing lightly against her side the whole way home.

 

After that, they kept seeing each other.

 

Not every day. But often enough that it stopped feeling incidental. The thing they’d fallen into didn’t feel like a return to the past- it felt like a negotiation. Like Agatha was learning what it meant to let someone back in without forfeiting ground.

 

She’d been to Rio’s place three times since that morning. Once for dinner. Once while Rio did laundry and Agatha pretended to read. And once for no reason at all- just to be there. That one sat with Agatha the longest.

 

Rio had come over, too. Helped her put together a shelf, though it was less collaborative and more Agatha watching while Rio quietly did all the work. They ate takeout on the floor and put on a movie neither of them cared about. Agatha could barely remember the title. What she remembered was the way their knees stayed pressed together the entire time.

 

They didn’t kiss again.

 

But there were touches that didn’t excuse themselves. Glances that lingered a second too long. A knee brushing hers under a table. Fingers grazing across a countertop. Rio’s palm resting between Agatha’s shoulder blades when she leaned forward to say something in a loud room.

 

They went to game night separately. Sat next to each other anyway. Agatha laughed too hard at something Rio said and had to excuse herself.  She didn’t come back until her face stopped betraying her. She avoided the pointed stares from Jen and Alice for the rest of the night, both of whom looked ready to extract confessions through physical force if necessary.

 

One Sunday, there was a special breakfast with coworkers. Agatha had invited her on the walk to Agatha’s car. It was a passing offer, barely even a sentence but Rio’s face had lit up so entirely unfiltered and stupidly honest. Rio tried to smother it, tried to play it cool, but Agatha had already seen it. 

 

Agatha had to look away. Her chest was too full. Rio’s face alone had nearly taken her out.

 

Rio ended up across from her at the table, then next to her when someone else wanted the seat so they could talk to Jen. Their knees touched under the table. Neither of them moved.

 

And still, they hadn’t kissed again.

 

It would’ve been easy. That was the thing. It would’ve been so goddamn easy to lean in. To let it happen again, under the right conditions, with the right excuse.

 

But Agatha didn’t.

 

And this wasn’t because she was spiraling. This wasn’t slipping back into a version of them that had already failed once. She’d kissed Rio three times- once would’ve been forgivable, twice unfortunate, but three? That was a pattern. That was admitting she wanted more. So she didn’t do it again. She didn’t ask. Didn’t lean in. She told herself she was being careful. Smart.

 

But some days, the panic still curled around her spine- hot, insistant, hard to ignore. Not about the past but about what this might be turning into. About the terrifying possibility that they were actually doing something right this time.

 

So she kept space in her life on purpose. Made time for herself. Said yes to drinks with Jen. Spent her evenings at the gym, earbuds in, volume high. She didn’t cut herself off from Rio, but she didn’t disappear into it either.

 

Agatha needed to believe she had kept something of herself untouched. Just so there’d be something left of her to walk away with incase this ended. 

 

Then maybe Agatha could say it hadn’t meant everything. 

 

Even if it had.

 

But deep down, beneath every lie Agatha could almost believe, something quieter lived: the certainty that what was untouched had already been seen. And worse- welcomed.

 

-

 

Agatha sat cross legged on the bed, the bottle of black nail polish uncapped on a towel between them. She had just started painting Rio’s left hand, holding it gently as she dragged the brush across each nail. The other hand, already finished, rested on her knee. It had been there for a while. Neither of them mentioned it.

 

Rio was still, suspiciously still, as she painted.

 

Agatha said nothing. She kept her eyes down, painting each nail with careful, practiced strokes.

 

Rio, of course, couldn’t let that last.

 

“Let’s play twenty questions,” Rio said, casually. 

 

“No,” Agatha said without looking up.

 

 “Cool. I’ll go first.”

 

Agatha exhaled through her nose. “That’s not-”

 

“Am I bad kisser?”

 

The brush paused, mid air. Agatha blinked once, then looked up, “Why?”



Rio shrugged, eyes sliding to the side.  “Oh, well. You know. Someone asked, and I thought- hm. Why don’t I ask Ag-”

 

“Who the fuck is wondering about your kissing skills?”

 

Rio blinked, caught off guard. “What? No- no one important. And that wasn’t the question.”

 

Agatha’s jaw locked. Her vision whitened at the edges. She wasn’t jealous. That would have required giving a fuck. It was just ridiculous. Who asked something like that? Who thought they could?

 

“You don’t get to skip mine,” Agatha said flatly.

 

“I asked first! It’s a yes or no question. So… yes or no. Am I a good kisser?”

 

“I just don’t get why someone needs to know. Like is there a follow up planned? Are they trying to kiss y-”

 

Agatha caught the end of the question as it twisted out of her mouth. She didn’t stop because she lost her nerve. She stopped because she finally heard how she had sounded. The edge in her voice wasn’t neutral. It was personal, and it was obvious. Her own question wasn’t about the game anymore.

 

Rio said nothing. Only looked at Agatha, shoulders loose, lips pressed together like she might smile, like she might say more if Agatha gave her an inch.

 

Agatha turned back to the bottle. Tapped the brush once against the rim.

 

“I didn’t know it was up for peer review,” she muttered, and moved on to Rio’s middle finger. 

 

“No one’s asked,” Rio admitted quietly. 

 

Agatha felt something in her shoulders let go. She pressed her bottom lip between her teeth, held it there, and didn’t say anything. It was a stupid thing to feel relieved about. She felt it anyway.

 

Rio shifted. and Agatha could feel her staring.

 

“I just… think maybe you aren’t answering because… I don’t know.”

 

Agatha exhaled through her nose and kept her gaze locked on Rio’s hand.

 

“We haven’t, you know. Since-”

 

Agatha didn’t take the bait. Just moved on to the next finger. Perfect strokes. Steady hand. Her face, however, was getting warm.

 

Rio cleared her throat. “It’s fine if you don’t want to. I just… figured if it was because I sucked, I’d rather know.”

 

Agatha squeezed Rio’s hand with more pressure than necessary. It wasn’t a mistake. It was a warning. 

 

“Ow,” Rio said lightly, trying to make a joke of it. “Cool. Torture me in silence.”

 

“You’re the one who brought it up,” Agatha muttered. 

 

“Because we kissed.”

 

Agatha finally looked up, brows raised. “And now you want me to give you a grade on it?” 

 

Rio flushed and looked away. “Forget it.”

 

Agatha went back to painting, jaw tight. The next nail came out smudged. She wiped it clean and started again.

 

Fuck, she was annoyed. Annoyed that for one stupid second, she thought someone else had wanted to kiss Rio. Annoyed that it got to her. Annoyed at the way Rio’s big, miserable brown eyes burning a hole straight through her forehead. And most of all, she was annoyed because the hand resting on her knee had gone slack -like Rio had pulled away, or was about to- and that ache in her chest wasn’t subtle anymore.

 

Agatha hated the whole thing. The look. The silence. The part of her that cared. She knew she was being unfair. 

 

“Just so you know,” Agatha said flatly, not looking up, “you’re not bad at it.”

 

“Oh,” Rio said, trying and failing not to sound too pleased. “Okay.”

 

Two seconds of silence.

 

“Are we gonna kiss again?”

 

Agatha looked at her then.

 

Of course she wanted to kiss Rio again. She always had. That had been the problem from the very start. It wasn’t just once, or twice, or the last time. It was every version of her. Every glance across a room. Every time they got too close to saying something they shouldn’t. Every silence that squeezed tight like a hand around a throat.

 

There had never been a version of Rio Agatha didn’t want.

 

That was the part Agatha could never quite make peace with. It never dulled, never gave her room to outgrow.  And somehow, it still caught her off guard. Every single time.

 

She looked down at the last nail and corrected a smudge that wasn’t there. It gave her something to do. Something to control.

 

“If I say yes, will you stop talking?”

 

“Yes.”

 

Agatha narrowed her eyes. “Fine. Then yes.”

 

Rio smiled. “That a real yes?”

 

Agatha stood. “It’s a shut up before I change my mind yes.”

 

“Still counts.”

 

Agatha didn’t look back. But her ears were warm. And she absolutely knew it still counted.

 

She took the bottle of black polish and walked into the bathroom.

 

The drawer was already open. Everything inside was lined up- nail files, cotton pads, cuticle oil, everything in its place. The polish had a designated spot.

 

Agatha stared at it for a second too long, then set the bottle down and closed the drawer quietly.

 

When she came back, Rio was leaned back against the headboard, legs stretched out, watching some documentary about the ocean.

 

Agatha sat beside her. Not too close. Not far either. She tried to focus on the screen.

 

A narrator droned on about migration patterns and instinct. Something about the way certain fish followed the same path every year, even when they didn’t know why.

 

Agatha crossed her arms.

 

“You know,” Rio said, eyes not leaving the screen. 

 

Agatha kept her gaze forward, but every part of her had turned toward the sound of Rio’s voice. It always did. 

 

“I quite like kissing you.”

 

And Agatha hated how her pulse reacted.

 

For years, everything between them had existed in what they didn’t say. That was how they survived it- through silence, through the comfort of what never had to be spoken. That was the one thing Rio had always understood. She used to live inside it with Agatha, as if the quiet was sacred.

 

But lately, Rio had started breaking the rules. She had started letting the quiet fill up with real words. Saying things out loud that were never supposed to be spoken. Things they used to leave alone.

 

Agatha hadn’t figured out how to stay intact when that happened. She could manage silence. She was built for it. But this left her exposed in ways she didn’t know how to cover.

 

Though Rio had figured it out, hadn’t she? That if she talked enough, Agatha wouldn’t have anywhere left to hide.

 

And if there was nowhere left to hide, it got harder to move anywhere that wasn’t toward Rio. 

 

Agatha thought about answering. She thought about denying it or joking or acting like she hadn’t heard. But none of those options felt available anymore. Not when Rio said things like that without fear.

 

So Agatha stayed where she was, her posture careful, her jaw set.

 

“Okay,” Agatha said, as evenly as she could manage.

 

A moment passed. Rio reached over and rested her hand on Agatha’s thigh, fingers splayed gentle and careful, mindful not to smear the half dry polish on her nails. Her thumb pressed into Agatha’s thigh. 

 

Agatha didn’t move. She didn’t breathe too hard. She told herself not to react.

 

Then Rio spoke again.

 

“Do you want me to keep talking?” she asked, softly.

 

Agatha let her gaze drop to Rio’s hand resting on her thigh. She followed the shape of it- the curve of Rio’s knuckles, the pale blue veins running up her wrist, the black polish Agatha had painted there. It was perfect. Hers.

 

She shouldn’t have cared about that detail. But she did.

 

It was proof of something. Another mark that was Agatha’s. Another small thing added to a life that hadn’t felt like hers in a long time. Not when she was married. Not when she was making decisions that belonged to other people. But this- this was different. Agatha had put that color there. Her hands had made it so.

 

Agatha swallowed hard and looked back at the screen. She forced herself to breathe evenly. 

 

Agatha nodded once.

 

Because yes. She wanted Rio to keep talking. She wanted to hear every word she’d missed, every thought Rio hadn’t said until now. She wanted it so badly it made her ache. But the only thing she could give her was that single, careful nod.

 

Rio didn’t look at her, kept her eyes fixed on the screen. Her thumb stayed still, pressing into Agatha’s skin. “I want to kiss you again,” Rio said softly. “I think about it all the time. More than I probably should.” 

 

Agatha inhaled, eyes fluttering shut.

 

Rio was a siren, and Agatha would follow her straight into the ocean if it meant that voice was the last thing she ever heard.

 

Rio’s thumb began to move, brushing gently back and forth. Agatha’s skin rose to meet it- goosebumps followed instantly. Rio must’ve noticed; her hand paused, lifted slightly. Agatha imagined her studying the reaction her touch had caused.

 

A moment passed, Rio’s fingers returned, tracing a path up and down Agatha’s thigh. 

 

Agatha bit the inside of her cheek to keep quiet. But her body didn’t cooperate. Her thighs shifted, parted slightly, unthinking. She forced her eyes open, needing to see it. The way Rio’s hand moved. The shape of it.

 

“I think about it in line at the store, walking to my car, sitting at work with nothing to do,” Rio said, voice even. She paused, exhaled a shaky breath, then added- quieter this time, “Pretty much anywhere I exist.”

 

She felt the shift when Rio turned toward her, subtle but unmistakable. Her hand left Agatha’s thigh, and for a second, Agatha mourned the loss of it- right up until her other hand found her cheek instead. Warm. Undeniable. A soft tug, asking without words for her to look. So Agatha did.

 

Her eyes landed on Rio’s mouth before they found anything else.

 

Rio’s thumb traced lightly across her cheek as she tilted her head, eyes a darker shade of brown than usual. “I’d like to kiss you now,” she murmured. “If that’s okay.”

 

“Fuck yes,” Agatha breathed.

 

Rio pulled her in without hesitation.

 

There was nothing tentative about it. Rio’s tongue pressed for entry instantly, and Agatha gave it to her willingly. 

 

The moment she let Rio deepen the kiss, Agatha moaned- helpless and so fucking desperate. It felt like Rio needed to taste every part of her, like she’d been starved of it. There was no room for doubt in the way Rio’s mouth moved against hers.

 

Agatha barely had time to catch up before Rio’s hand slipped from her cheek and found her hip. Her fingers toyed with the hem of Agatha’s shirt before slipping underneath, nails dragging lightly across skin. She found the curve of Agatha’s hip bone and anchored herself there, thumb pressing firmly.

 

Rio didn’t go further. She just held her there, thumb stroking once, steady, like that single point of contact was enough.

 

And maybe it was.

 

Because for all the fire in Rio’s mouth, her hand stayed still. Grounded. Rooted. Like she was reminding them both this wasn’t about rushing. It was about having. About being allowed to want, and finally -finally- getting to touch. 

 

And the feeling crept in slowly.

 

The realization of what would happen if Agatha didn’t stop this. If Agatha let it keep going. If she let herself believe there was a version of this that could last longer than the kiss.

 

Agatha didn’t mean to. Her hands moved without her. Just enough pressure against Rio’s shoulders to make her stop.

 

Rio paused, lips still close, breath brushing Agatha’s skin. She hadn’t pulled back fully. Her eyes were still on Agatha’s mouth, and she looked like she’d follow it anywhere.

 

Agatha’s chest ached. She had spent so long knowing absence that presence -real, safe, offered freely- felt almost violent.

 

“I think…” Her voice caught. She cleared her throat, tried again. “We should probably move to the living room.”

 

There it was.

 

The softest escape route Agatha could find.

 

Rio’s eyes snapped up, finally meeting hers. There was a flicker of something there, hurt, maybe, or understanding, but it passed quickly. She nodded once, careful.

 

“That’s okay,” she said, barely above a whisper.

 

Rio didn’t push. She didn’t ask why.

 

But Agatha heard the rest anyway- unspoken but deafening.

 

I’ll try again tomorrow.

 

And beneath all her restraint, beneath all the armor she hadn’t meant to put back on-

 

Agatha hoped she would.

 

-

 

They did move to the living room. And true to form, Rio didn’t make it awkward. She steered away from the moment entirely, settling Agatha in the smallest, most deliberate ways. She turned on trash reality television. She made space for Agatha on the couch. She kept the mood light. There was no pause in her laughter, no dimming in her eyes. She was still herself and somehow that made it easier for Agatha to follow. To laugh. To pretend nothing had happened, at least for now.

 

At some point, Agatha’s eyes drifted toward the curved bookshelf. She had avoided it until now. That wall of Rio’s apartment had become a quiet threat. She hadn’t wanted to see the empty space where the photo used to be. The one she stole. She hadn’t wanted to risk a question Rio might ask.

 

But the space wasn’t empty anymore.

 

A new frame had taken its place. This time it was a group photo from a game night at Jen and Alice’s rental over a decade ago. Jen was in Alice’s lap, beaming. Agatha sat on the couch, mid laugh. And Rio was on the floor between Agatha’s legs, flipping off the camera with both hands.

 

Agatha’s fingers twitched. The urge to steal it hit fast and familiar. She wouldn’t. Or at least not yet.

 

-

 

Agatha had practically launched herself out of the apartment. She told herself it was casual but the truth was she couldn’t sit there any longer without doing something she’d regret. They’d only been watching TV, but that hadn’t stopped her brain from drifting somewhere else entirely.

 

It kept drifting, circling back to the bedroom, to Rio’s voice, to the memory of her mouth. Not even the show could distract her- though Rio had looked genuinely entertained by middle aged women throwing wine at each other, cool as a fucking cucumber.

 

Agatha, meanwhile, couldn’t focus on a single damn word.

 

It was infuriating.

 

She wanted Rio’s attention so badly she could feel it buzzing in her teeth. Every time she looked over, her eyes snagged on black nail polish and her brain would spiral again. Just glancing at them felt like they were taunting her like a fucking billboard:

Best Hands on the East Coast- Declared by Agnes, Confirmed by Vibes.

 

Her whole body burned with it. She hated how easy it was for her mind to go there. She hated how much she wanted to be touched, how badly she wanted it to be Rio.

 

It was humiliating, the way her body responded to absolutely nothing but possibility.

 

Which was exactly why Agatha had to leave.

 

And now here they were. Rio walking Agatha to her car.

 

Agatha felt the sharp edge of the picture frame digging into her side through the fabric of her canvas bag. Good. Let it hurt. She needed the distraction. 

 

When they got to the car, Rio lingered with her arms crossed, tongue pressed into her cheek. Not the usual smug, flirty look- this was different. Thoughtful. Cautious. Agatha knew Rio was turning something over in her head but hadn’t decided if it was worth saying out loud.

 

“Tomorrow’s Tuesday,” Rio said.

 

Fuck. 

 

Of all the things that could come out of Rio Vidal’s fucking mouth. It had to be that.

 

Lilia’s Sunday night dinners- now Tuesday night dinners.

 

Agatha didn’t answer right away. She stared out across the parking lot, jaw tight, shoulders tense. She gave a small, noncommittal hum, just enough to acknowledge she’d heard. Not enough to engage.

 

She already knew what her answer was going to be. But she would let Rio try. That much, at least, Agatha could give her.

 

“Lilia misses you,” Rio said. “You should come.”

 

“No.”

 

It wasn’t cruel. It wasn’t defensive. Just… simple. Honest.

 

Lilia… well. Fourteen years was a long time to let bitterness sink into your bones. Agatha knew that feeling. She had nurtured it herself.

 

Even if Lilia did hate her -which, deep down, Agatha knew wasn’t true- she couldn’t walk back into that house and pretend the walls didn’t remember her. The chairs. The table. The way everything would look the same, but not.
Sage would be there now. Maybe others.

 

Agatha didn’t want to witness how easily the world stitched itself back together around her absence. Lilia’s house had once been a salvation, the first place that had ever truly felt like a home to come back to. She had spent two years of holidays, of Sunday dinners, cradled in that warmth because she had nowhere else to go.

 

More than anything, Agatha didn’t think she could survive seeing a seat at the table saved for her.

 

She saw it sometimes in her dreams, always the same: an empty table, stripped of food and noise and life, just one chair pulled out like an offering. A light that would fall only there like a spotlight on a stage. The chair didn’t beckon. It didn’t accuse. It just existed- quiet and certain, like it still believed she might return.

 

And every time, Agatha woke up feeling like she’d left something behind she was never meant to.

 

“No,” Agatha said again, quieter this time. Rio hadn’t repeated the invitation, but Agatha still had to say it.

 

“Yeah,” Rio said, with a nod. “No worries. Maybe next week.”

 

She didn’t sound hurt. She didn’t sound surprised. She sounded like she understood.

 

And just like before, Agatha didn’t hear the words exactly, but they echoed anyway.


I’ll try again tomorrow.

 

Agatha didn’t bother saying her answer would still be no next week.

 

“I should probably get home,” Agatha said.

 

“Okay. I’ll see you soon?”

 

That question Agatha could answer without thinking. She’d see Rio again. She didn’t know when or how or under what excuse, but it didn’t matter. It would happen. Of all the things in her life that felt uncertain, Rio wasn’t one of them.

 

Not anymore.

 

“Yes.”

 

Rio nodded and stepped forward to open her car door for her.

 

Agatha tossed her bag into the passenger seat and started to climb in. She didn’t look at Rio because nothing had changed. She still wanted her. Still ached for her. It was the easiest thing in the world.

 

But if Agatha let it happen there’d be no pretending left. No careful pacing. They’d have to talk. About everything. About the years they lost and the silences they built and the ways they both let it happen. She’d ask why Rio never said anything. Why she didn’t. Why it took them this long to get here.

 

And then what?


If they finally gave in and it didn’t work?

 

They’d ruin it for real. Not like before. Before was passive. Before was silence. Before was a slow forgetting.


But this would be active. Final. Something they couldn’t take back.

 

They managed to destroy their friendship without ever touching the truth and Agatha wasn’t sure she’d survive watching it die because they finally did.

 

“Hey.”

 

Rio poked her- two fingers to her shoulder, light and annoying on purpose. It was a touch that said ‘ I could be serious, but I’d rather let you decide.’ Her other hand rested on the edge of the car door. “Are you okay?”

 

Agatha turned fast, startled by the break in silence. It took her a second to register the question. Her mind was still tangled in whatever she hadn’t let herself say. When she did, her eyes flicked up, catching the way Rio’s fingers tightened just slightly on the top of the door, the way she held her posture like she was bracing for impact. But none of it showed in her expression. Her face stayed soft, unreadable. Like she was waiting to be told what came next and had already decided she wouldn’t fight it.

 

Agatha exhaled. “Yeah, I’m just-” She huffed a short, breathy laugh, then shook her head.

 

Two seconds. 

 

That’s all Agatha gave herself before defaulting to the biggest lie she’s ever told herself. 

 

And she had always been a bit wicked.  

 

“We’re friends. Right?”

 

A reminder. 

 

Agatha was trying to say it before someone else could forget. A line being redrawn- not to punish, but to protect. Maybe not even Rio. Maybe just herself.

 

Rio’s eyebrows lifted slightly, and her mouth pressed into a thin line. But other than that her expression didn’t change much.


 “Yeah.” 

 

A pause.  

 

Rio’s voice softened, “Of course.”

 

Whatever Agatha needed to believe in this moment, Rio would give her.

And Agatha didn’t regret saying it. Not exactly. It was the only way she knew how to pull back. However, beneath all that carefully managed distance, she hoped Rio heard the space between Agatha’s words and would wait for her there.

 

Because Agatha already knew- by the time morning came, she’d want to take it back.

 

And maybe again the next day.

 

And probably the day after that, too.

Fortunately for Rio, Agatha had always had a soft spot for invasive species- the type that take root quietly, spread without permission, and somehow make the place feel more alive once they’ve ruined everything else.

 

Didn’t mean she wouldn’t fight them every inch of the way. Rip them out. Pretend she hadn’t watered them. Act surprised when they kept coming back.

 

Some things thrive under neglect.

 

Rio, apparently, was one of them.

Just as Agatha opened her mouth to affectionately threaten Rio about closing her damn door before she floored it and peeled off-

 

Rio moved.

 

Closed in, actually.

 

At a pace far too fast and nowhere near fast enough. One of those agonizing, unmistakable trajectories that gave Agatha ample time to react, deflect, maybe even mock. But she didn’t. Couldn’t. Wouldn’t.

 

Rio’s hand found her cheek and tilted her mouth up- gentle, weirdly practiced, utterly self assured. Their mouths collided like an argument neither of them wanted to win.

 

And Agatha, the brilliant, miserable idiot that she was, met her halfway like a girl starved. No pause. No restraint. Just opened her mouth for Rio, wide and warm and easy.  Honestly. She didn’t even try to make Rio work for it.

 

Her right hand slid into Rio’s hair, fingers curling at the nape to pull her closer, deeper. Rio hummed into her mouth, low and pleased. Agatha felt it in her teeth, her throat, somewhere ancient in her ribcage that hadn’t stopped aching since they were stupid and younger and ruining everything by doing absolutely nothing about it.

 

It was obscene. Awkward angle, too much tongue, entirely too desperate. It wasn’t graceful. It wasn’t gentle. It wasn’t even supposed to happen.

 

And still-

 

When Rio finally pulled back, Agatha stayed frozen- fingers still tangled in the back of her hair hoping her grip might keep time from moving forward. Rio’s lips were pink and swollen, her breath puffing against Agatha’s mouth, and then because god has no mercy and hated Agatha Harkness:

 

Rio’s face split into that maddening grin- white teeth, gap toothed, eyes bright with victory.

 

Smug. So fucking smug.

 

And then, to make matters exponentially worse, Rio opened her stupid fucking mouth.

 

“See ya later. Friend.”

 

The word hung there, deliberate and poisonous. 

 

Rio punctuated the insult with a kiss pressed to the corner of Agatha’s mouth like a signature. Then lingered there, just long enough to make sure Agatha leaned into before whispering in her ear:

 

“Klepto.”

 

Then she was gone. Door shut. Tapped the window like some kind of post heist flourish. A thief of breath and reason and time. Confident as ever.

 

Agatha sat motionless behind the wheel, mouth slightly parted, eyes locked on Rio’s ass in the side mirror until it disappeared from view.

 

“What the fuck,” she muttered to herself.

 

She glanced at the passenger seat. Half the picture frame had slid out of her bag. 

 

It wasn’t the new photo. Not the fresh one Rio had clearly just added to the shelf- an obviously replaced snapshot from game night at Jen and Alice’s rental house from years ago. That one had been carefully placed, practically staged, so conspicuous in its positioning that Agatha hadn’t dared touch it. She knew Rio well enough to recognize bait when she saw it. That frame hadn’t lived in the apartment long enough to gather dust. It was too new, too self aware, too obviously asking to be taken.

 

And if Rio expected her to take it… if she’d left it out like some sort of offering? Then Agatha couldn’t possibly accept it. That would make it a gift, and Agatha had never stolen anything freely given. She had principles. Or pride. Or maybe just spite.

 

So, instead, Agatha had taken the other one.

 

The one Rio wouldn’t expect her to go for.

 

Just the two of them, curled up on that rusted fire escape with their cheeks squished together. That photo had lived in Rio’s apartment long enough to matter. It had survived different eras. Different silences. Different versions of themselves.

 

And that, as far as Agatha was concerned, made it fair game.

 

Of course, it also made it personal.

 

Which is exactly why she took it.

 

Because Rio had baited her. And Agatha, naturally, had refused to bite. She had standards. Which is why she responded with equal pettiness and more precision. She didn’t steal what Rio wanted her to steal. She stole the thing Rio would actually miss.

 

That felt earned.

 

And fine, maybe she hadn’t thought about her history with petty theft in years. It had never come up in conversation, mostly because she had never needed to explain it. Not to Rio. Certainly not to herself. But that didn’t mean the impulse had disappeared.

 

It had always been specific. She didn’t have sticky fingers in general- just when it came to Rio’s things. It started as a joke. A spoon gone missing. Then another. Rio had exactly four of silverware, and Agatha made it a point to disrupt the symmetry. Eventually it became a habit. A sweatshirt. A hoodie. A paperback. A pen. Trinkets. Lots of trinkets. 

 

Then two full boxes of Rio’s stuff never made it to Chicago, not by accident. One last sweatshirt survived the culling, and even that, eventually, had disappeared.

 

It wasn’t about sentiment. Not entirely. It was about the comfort of possession. The power of keeping a piece of someone without having to ask.

 

Agatha stared at the frame a moment longer, then shoved it deeper into her bag and adjusted the mirror like it might help her regain composure. It didn’t.

 

Agatha let her head fall back against the headrest.

 

“She’s never letting that go,” Agatha muttered under her breath, voice flat.

 

Another beat.

 

“God, I hate her.”

 

That wasn’t true. Not remotely.

 

But Agatha still wasn’t giving the picture back.

Agatha woke to a low, mechanical sound that took several seconds to register. It wasn’t a car. It wasn’t the AC kicking on. It was steadier than that, with the rough churn of something deliberately cutting through resistance. She turned over and groaned into her pillow, hoping she could drown out the sound. 

 

It persisted. 

 

Fully awake now, her brain pieced it together with increasing dread. A lawn mower. Not distant. Not someone else's problem. It was coming from her own yard.

 

She reached for the clock on her nightstand and squinted. 7:34. On a Wednesday. Which ruled out Lucas, the neighbor kid, who should have been putting on his sneakers for school, not mowing her fucking lawn. Which meant-

 

Oh no.

 

Agatha closed her eyes.

 

Rio had made good on her promise.

 

After one very long exhale, Agatha pushed herself upright, threw her comforter back, and trudged toward the window. She yanked her blackout curtains open and peeled apart the blinds.

 

There she was.

 

Not in some lazy excuse for yard work attire. Rio didn’t do anything half ass. She wore brown duck bib overalls, already streaked green at the knees. A black tank top was tucked beneath them, high at the neckline and sleeveless, showing dirt smudged arms. Her boots were scuffed, her hair was pulled back in a low bun, and her earbuds were tucked neatly in place. Every inch of her posture radiated focus. She pushed the mower with even, deliberate rows, pausing to turn only when the geometry demanded it.

 

Her gaze drifted toward the curb. Rio’s 4Runner was parked alongside the sidewalk with a full size U-Haul open trailer hitched to it. On it, everything was packed with purpose: gardening tools, a neatly rolled tarp secured with clips, several bags of soil stacked evenly, and a full flat of nursery plants arranged by height. Even edging stones had been strapped into place with bungee cords. A clipboard propped against the back tire of the trailer, probably covered in notes and underlines and god knows what else.

 

Of course Rio brought a U-Haul. God forbid she show up to flirt without honoring at least one lesbian stereotype.

 

Of course Rio brought a fucking clipboard. 

 

Of course Rio showed up to her fucking house trying to make Agatha forget that she was in the middle of a seventeen year long slow burn powered exclusively by emotional repression, catastrophic timing, and spite.

 

And now Rio was out there being soft and stupid and useful, like that would fix it.

 

It was excessive. It was overthought. It was thorough in a way that couldn’t be passed off as impulsive.

 

It was perfectly Rio.

 

Agatha stood there, silent, unwilling to admit how attractive it was to watch someone do something well. She watched as Rio continued mowing with precision, not stopping to stretch or check her phone. She didn’t glance up. Didn’t acknowledge Agatha’s house. Her jaw was tight, her brows drawn, her pace unwavering.

 

Agatha exhaled through her nose, then muttered under her breath.

 

“Well. Fuck.”

 

This was not a quick favor. This wasn’t a twenty minute trip with a borrowed mower. This was a full scale project, an entire day of Rio Vidal applying manual labor to every corner of Agatha’s neglected yard. A renovation plan. An execution. A statement made through soil and sweat and painfully competent hands.

 

And Agatha would be forced to witness it. Every hour. Every choice. Every quiet act of order being imposed on a space Agatha had long since stopped believing deserved care.

 

And the worst part was how clear it already was that Rio hadn’t done this out of compulsion or obligation. She had planned it. She had sourced it. She had chosen every item with intention and brought it here.

By mid morning, the mowing had stopped. Rio wheeled the mower back into the trailer and pulled out the weed whacker. She started it without fuss and worked her way along the sidewalk. She paused only once, her back to the house to pull out her phone. It took her all of five seconds before the thing disappeared back into her pocket and the weed whacker started humming again.

 

Agatha’s phone buzzed against the side of her coffee mug she was holding.

 

She let the blind fall back into place. Set the mug down and unlocked her phone.

 

A photo. The top half of Rio’s face, clear plastic safety glasses smudged with dirt, her eyes squinted from the brightness of the sun.  A sliver of sky above her. And behind her, just visible in the background, the front of her house and the unmistakably lifted blind in the window where Agatha had been watching.

 

The message underneath:

 

Rio: come say hi, friend. maybe toss in a kiss if you’re feeling generous... i hear friends do that now👀

 

Agatha stared at it. Then at the window. Then back at the screen.

 

She didn’t respond.

 

She also didn’t throw the phone across the room, which felt, under the circumstances, like a remarkable act of restraint.

 

What Agatha did do, however, was throw herself back into bed and open her Ring app. The front yard camera came up immediately- installed by Alice when Agatha moved it. 

 

There she was. 

 

Rio. Weed whacking. Hair pulled up, biceps flexing just enough to piss Agatha off, and wearing brown overalls and safety glasses that had no business being that fucking attractive.

 

Agatha watched in silence. Not lurking, exactly. Just… observing. Just using what was available to her.

 

She zoomed in.

 

Just a little.

 

Then closed the app and dropped her phone on the bed next to her.

 

She wasn’t going down there. That would be encouragement.

 

Let Rio work. Let her sweat. Let her wonder.

 

Agatha would stay exactly where she was.

By the time noon rolled around, the noises outside had stopped, and Agatha peeled herself off the couch to check the window.

 

Rio wasn’t alone anymore. Parked in front of her car was the ugliest thing Agatha had ever seen, a faded yellow 1978 Subaru Brat. It used to belong to Lilia, and as far as Agatha knew, it hadn’t run in years. Rio had talked about fixing it up once, and evidently she had, because now Sage seemed to be the one driving it. The two of them were perched on the open tailgate, legs swinging, sharing a greasy paper bag of food and absolutely zero decorum.

 

Sage chucked a fry at Rio’s face.

 

Rio didn’t flinch. She just reached over and dragged a greasy hand down the front of Sage’s face.

 

Sage recoiled in horror. Rio laughed maniacally.

 

Agatha blinked. Because apparently this was normal. Apparently it had been, for a long time.

 

And Agatha had missed it.

 

Not just Sage. Not just the story of how she fit into Rio’s life. But this . This new version of Rio.

 

Agatha had spent years knowing Rio in the most specific way a person could know someone else. Reading the silences. Interpreting what was withheld. They’d built an entire friendship on implication and unsaid things. 

 

Rio had always been a fortress, and Agatha, somehow, had been the only one ever allowed past the gates.

 

She hadn’t realized how much she’d clung to that fact. How much she’d built her idea of Rio around it.

 

And now, from across a window, she was watching a different version entirely. One that laughed without restraint. One that let herself be messy. Affectionate. Known.

 

She hadn’t imagined Rio like that.

 

And she hadn’t been there to see the change, hadn’t been invited into the process of it. No warning. No bridge. Just a new Rio, fully formed, sitting where the old one used to be.

 

Agatha let the curtain fall, slowly. Then stood there for a moment longer, unsure what to do with the heat crawling under her skin.

 

It wasn’t jealousy. She didn’t want what Sage had… obviously.

 

She just hated that it had happened without her. That Rio had crossed some invisible threshold, became someone more whole, more open and Agatha, who had once been the closest person to her in the world, hadn’t even been a footnote in that transformation.

 

That absence felt louder than anything.

Thirty minutes later, Sage was gone. Rio stood alone, leaned back against her trailer, one boot crossed over the other as she looked over whatever was attached to that stupid clipboard. A cigarette burned between her fingers. She looked focused -annoyingly so- and entirely at ease.

 

Agatha watched her from the peephole for longer than she’d admit. The unopened water bottle in her hand was sweating, slipping slightly against her palm. She took a breath that didn't do anything, then opened the door and stepped outside.

 

Rio glanced up, her expression unreadable except for the faint twitch at the corner of her mouth, a smile she clearly wasn’t giving Agatha the satisfaction of seeing. Her eyes dropped back to the clipboard, mouth pursed.

 

Once she was close enough, Agatha reached for the cigarette in Rio’s hand and took it without asking, placing the water bottle directly on top of the clipboard in a gesture that was neither generous nor polite.

 

A mason jar sat on the trailer beside Rio, half filled with sand and already hosting a few used cigarette butts.

 

Agatha took a drag and leaned against the trailer beside her, mirroring Rio’s position without thinking.

 

Rio, unfazed, set both clipboard and water bottle on the edge of the trailer behind her. Then she reached into the chest pocket of her overalls and pulled out a single cigarette. She slid it between her lips, crouched to rifle through one of the lower leg pockets, and came back with Agatha’s purple Zippo.

 

While Rio lit the cigarette, she mumbled around it, “Fired your neighbor’s kid this morning,” she said. “Figured you’d want that handled.”

 

Agatha hummed. “And how did he take that?”

 

Rio pocketed the lighter and took a slow drag, nodding.  “Great. Said you were terrifying. Claimed you were lowballing him for, and I quote, ‘the disastrous monstrosity that is your yard.’” She exhaled slowly, aiming the smoke up and away through a grin she didn’t bother hiding this time. 

 

Then Rio turned to face her fully, shifting her stance so she was squared toward Agatha now, shoulder brushing the trailer, the mason jar sitting between them on the ledge.

 

Agatha raised a brow. “That right?”

 

“He actually looked really heartbroken about it.” Rio said, immediately. She flicked ash off the end of her cigarette into the jar, adding, almost offhand, “I gave him a hundred bucks just to get out of my face.” She took another drag and muttered looking away from Agatha,  “And then I hissed at him.”

 

Agatha barked a laugh. She tried to smother it behind her hand, but it was too late. It cracked straight through her irritation and landed somewhere in the middle of her chest.

 

“He ran away so fast,” Rio said, smirking. “Made me feel less bad about firing him.”

 

“You should feel bad,” Agatha shot back. “What if landscaping was his dream?”

 

“Then I did him a favor. He’s objectively shit at it.”

 

“He’s thirteen!”

 

“And?” Rio asked, full offense. “Fuck that kid. He shouldn’t be out here mangling the lawn of an incredibly hot woman anyway.”

 

Agatha snorted, “You’re awful.”

 

Rio turned her head slightly, exhaled smoke through her nose, and shrugged.

 

Agatha tried to stay annoyed. Really, she did. But then her eyes dropped, against her better judgment, and lingered. First to Rio’s throat, damp with sweat. Her collarbone. The curve of her shoulder. Grass clung to her forearms, and flecks of dirt stuck to the skin around her neck.

 

Her mouth went dry. She blinked, once, slowly.

 

By the time she looked back up, Rio was already grinning- wide and unbearable, her teeth too white against the sunburn starting to creep up her face.

 

Agatha looked away fast. “You’re disgusting.”

 

“Huh,” Rio said, dragging on her cigarette. “I don’t think you actually believe that.”

 

“Don’t flatter yourself.”

 

“I don’t have to,” Rio said, blowing smoke off to the side. “You’re doing a great job of it for me.”

 

Agatha shook her head, jaw tight, lips threatening to betray her again. “I hate you.”

 

“I miss you.”

 

Agatha scoffed. “That doesn’t even make sense.”

 

Rio dropped her cigarette into the mason jar and crossed her arms. “Would you like me to be more specific?”

 

She was baiting Agatha. Intentionally, unmistakably. And Agatha- Agatha walked right into it without meaning to.

 

Because her eyes had already dropped to Rio’s mouth. Because her brain, already working against her, had filled in the blanks before she could stop it.

 

“Yes.”

 

“I miss your mouth,” Rio said, flat as fact. Her eyebrows lifted, daring a reaction. “Clear enough?”

Chapter 7: sorry i'm late

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Some kind of blissed out, post orgasmic daze that made her forget how to pretend she didn’t want this exact outcome. That she hadn’t spent just three years short of half her life trying not to want it.

 

No. Not quite… actually, it was much worse than that:

She would always want Rio.
