-

 

The rest of the morning passed without urgency. Time didn’t stall. It just moved differently after. Slower. Warmer. A little too easy.

 

At some point, they dozed off- barely an hour, not long enough for Agatha to stop feeling everything. She woke up warm and sore and unreasonably aware of the fact she HAD stayed curled into Rio’s side the entire time.

 

When Rio slipped out of bed, Agatha didn’t follow. Didn’t look. Didn’t ask where she was going or what she needed. She wasn’t listening for answers. She stayed exactly where she was, sheets tangled at her waist, the air still thick with whatever was happening between them.

 

Rio wandered back into her bedroom barefoot, two mugs in hand, wearing nothing but Agatha’s old Westview U t-shirt, and not a trace of shame. Her tongue was tucked into her cheek as she glanced at the coffees, then back up at Agatha with a glint that said, ' look what I brought you.' She walked in to Agatha's bedroom, looking entirely at home, and Agatha let her. 

 

Rio climbed onto the bed and crossed her legs, her knee pressing into Agatha’s thigh. Agatha, still naked, shifted upright against the headboard with an ease that suggested familiarity, even if none of this had ever happened before. She wasn’t overthinking it. Her body just responded, unbothered, as if this was always how the morning was supposed to go. She watched as Rio took a sip from the mug and held it in her mouth for a moment, staring at Agatha unblinking. Then, without a word, she leaned forward and spit the coffee back into the mug in a slow, steady stream, the sound of it dribbling loud and vaguely offensive in the quiet of her bedroom. Agatha didn’t even blink. She’d expected exactly that. Rio muttered something dry about it being impressive for it being entirely water, and Agatha let out a quiet laugh, took the mug from her hand, and drank from it without looking away. Rio stared at her, wide eyed and trying not to grin. 

 

Eventually, Rio took the other cup and chugged it just to get the caffeine in her system, obviously not for taste. At some point after that, Agatha decided she wanted her shirt back. No reason. No real one, anyway. She just tugged the shirt up and off Rio and tossed it across her room. If she had to sit there exposed, then so did Rio. She told herself it was about fairness. Equal exposure. Civilized nudity. Feminist logic. Whatever.

 

They stayed like that for hours.

 

Not touching, but always touching. Elbows, knees, a foot curled under a thigh. They talked. Not about anything that mattered. At some point, Agatha had her phone in hand, scrolling through her work schedule for the month that had just been uploaded to the hospital’s portal- only half paying attention when Rio pulled a face, wild and obnoxious in the middle of her story. Agatha raised her phone and took a picture of Rio without really meaning to. It was too close, all teeth and blurry movement, the edge of Rio’s bare shoulder suggesting more than it showed. Agatha didn’t delete it.  She also didn’t explain it.

 

At some point, Rio mentioned that everyone was going bowling tonight instead of game night at Jen and Alice’s. Agatha barely processed it at first. Bowling? As in- rented shoes that had been on hundreds of strangers’ feet and the smell of cheap beer and frozen pizza baked into the walls ? The word dropped into the room like it belonged to someone else’s afternoon. She didn’t respond right away. Mostly because her brain refused to process the idea of anything existing outside the four walls they were in.

 

Agatha blinked. 



The thought of a bowling alley -sticky floors, fluorescent lights, other people talking- felt violently offensive and so far removed from the bubble they were in. 

 

Agatha didn’t want to put clothes on. She didn’t want to see anyone. She didn’t want to leave her house. She didn’t want to wash her sheets. She didn’t want to put a bra on and pretend she hadn’t spent the last twelve hours letting Rio do whatever she wanted to her. She didn’t want to be perceived. By anyone.

 

Rio said something about only going if Agatha went. Something she had heard before, in what felt like a hundred different lives. Back when they were too proud and too scared and too unwilling to admit they were following each other into places just to be close. It meant more now. Or maybe less. Maybe it was just habit. Agatha couldn’t tell. Only that something small and traitorous inside of her liked the sound of being followed. Of being chosen.

 

She ended up agreeing, eventually. Of course she did. Because that was the problem with bubbles- they always popped.

 

But before that, before reality returned, she let herself enjoy the moment for what it was. It was domesticity, she guessed. Or a version of it that involved two naked idiots drinking terrible coffee in bed and pretending it wasn’t a big deal. 

 

What Agatha didn’t say though -what she wouldn’t dare speak into existence- was how much she liked this. Not just the sex, though that had been… a lot. But the after. The stillness. The dumb things. The way Rio kept touching her thigh absentmindedly. The way they didn’t flinch when their skin brushed. The ease of it. The lack of disaster.

 

And Agatha, against all better judgment, believed she could handle it. Really. As long as they didn’t talk about it. Not the past, not what it meant, not how good it felt. If they avoided eye contact during any and all emotionally charged moments, if they stuck to jokes and coffee and maybe kept the shirtless photography to a minimum- this could work. She was sure of it.

 

And maybe, maybe , no morning sex again. Because this morning’s had been really intimate. Like ruin your life intimate. Which was fine. Once. Briefly. But doing that twice would set a precedent Agatha wasn’t prepared to manage. Not yet. Probably not ever. Definitely not before bowling.

 

Which seemed like a reasonable boundary.

 

Maybe.

 

As long as they didn’t talk about it.

 

But Agatha was ready for bowling. 

 

Probably.

 

-

 

They were at Rio’s apartment. Rio didn’t have a single piece of clothing at Agatha’s place, and Agatha had made the executive decision that she would not be seen in public, least of all at a bowling alley, escorting Rio around while she wore Agatha’s clothes and looked freshly fucked. That was not going to happen. She had limits.

 

After Rio had showered in Agatha’s bathroom -without saying a word about the stupid eucalyptus she definitely saw hanging from the showerhead. Agatha had, for reasons still unclear to her, decided they could show up to bowling together. Together, like a unit. One arrival, one exit. Same car, same time, same breath. 

 

Agatha didn’t know why. The only explanation she could come up with was that her brain had melted and was now dripping out of her ears.

 

“I swear to god, if you don’t stop moving, I will beat you with this beauty blender,” Agatha muttered, digging her thumb into Rio’s cheek, dabbing concealer on her jawline with more force than necessary.

 

Rio, who was currently sitting on her own bathroom counter with her fingers curled into Agatha’s belt loops, had been swinging her feet like an overstimulated child for the past ten minutes. Agatha was close to snapping.

 

The hickeys weren’t subtle. There was one under her jaw, two along her throat, and another blooming up the edge of her chin like a badge. The worst of them was lower, pressed into the skin over Rio’s sternum, right above her heart. That one was safely hidden under her shirt, but Agatha couldn’t stop thinking about it. She tried to pretend she was relieved it didn’t need makeup. She was not. She was the opposite of relieved.

 

Agatha wasn’t even mad at the marks themselves. She was mad that they existed in the first place. Mad that she had let herself fall into this so easily. Mad that she still hadn’t figured out what she was doing or why she cared so much about how it would look when they walked in together.

 

They hadn’t left Agatha’s house all day. They’d had sex the night before. Then again after the movie. Then again before terrible coffee. Then again before they had left and Rio had bent her in half and turned her into something that could only be described as spiritually unwell. And now here Agatha was. Doing her makeup. Fixing her shirt. Pretending she wasn’t crawling out of her skin.

 

They had left their bubble, and Agatha hated it. Every second of it. She hated the thought of stepping into a bowling alley and pretending this wasn’t real, pretending she hadn’t spent the last twenty-four hours touching someone in every way that mattered and still couldn’t say out loud what any of it meant.

 

Agatha hated how it had never once felt like a mistake.

 

“I think you should try breathing,” Rio murmured, maddeningly amused, like she could hear every thought screeching through Agatha’s skull.

 

Agatha froze, blender still in hand, and gave Rio a murderous look. “They’re everywhere,” she hissed, jaw tight. As if the evidence wasn’t the loudest thing in the fucking bathroom.

 

Rio, absolutely unfazed, leaned in until their faces were inches apart. She smiled, slow and smug, and entirely too aware of what she was doing. “And whose fault is that?” she murmured, gaze dropping to Agatha’s mouth.

 

Agatha’s jaw locked. She forced herself to stay still, to keep her eyes where they belonged, to not replay what that mouth had done to her. “Some idiot who didn’t think about you having to show your face in public,” she muttered, voice rough.

 

Rio’s grin stretched wider, all teeth and sin, like she was proud of herself.

 

Agatha tried to ignore it. She didn’t need this right now. She needed to finish hiding the proof of her own bad decisions and somehow pretend she wasn’t seconds away from climbing back into Rio’s lap just to shut her up.

 

There was still bowling to survive. 

 

-

 

Rio had driven. Parked in the farthest, most forgettable corner of the lot, shaded and empty, like she was doing them both a favor. Like she already knew Agatha wouldn’t be able to keep her hands to herself.

 

What followed was a blur.

 

Fast, messy, and completely her own fault. Not in a guilty way. Just in the technical sense. Her hand had ended up on Rio’s thigh. Her mouth had found Rio’s neck. She’d said something, maybe nothing, and then Rio was in her lap, straddling her. Agatha’s hand was down the front of her jeans. Their mouths pressed so tightly together it felt like trying to breathe underwater. Rio was riding her fingers like the only thing that mattered was how fast she could come. Which, apparently, was very. Faster than Agatha wanted. Faster than felt fair. But they were already late.

Then Rio was gone.

Not metaphorically- literally. Off her lap, out the door, already standing in the parking lot like her bones hadn’t melted over Agatha’s hand two seconds ago. Like nothing had happened at all. 

 

“Ready?” Rio asked.

 

Agatha blinked.

 

She hadn’t moved. Her fingers were still wet. Her hand still hung awkwardly in the space Rio had left behind. She didn’t know what she was supposed to do next. Rio’s come still clung to her knuckles. She could still feel it. On her skin. Under her nails. Rio. 

 

Rio glanced down, clocked the pause, and reached across to the console. She pulled a pack of wipes from the glove box. Because of course she had them. Rio had everything figured out, always. Agatha had used to hate that about her. She hated it more in this moment than ever before.

 

She dropped the pack into Agatha’s lap and peeled a few out, but didn’t hand them over. Instead, she took Agatha’s hand gently, offering her service. First, her mouth- slow, deliberate, obscene. Rio’s tongue dragged along her fingers, cheeks hollowed, jaw tight with effort. It made Agatha’s skin felt hotter than it already was. Her lungs felt wrong. Agatha whimpered. 

 

Embarrassing .

 

Then the wipes. Cool. Sterile. Functional. Erasure.

 

And just like that the evidence, it was gone.

 

Agatha could feel it happening. The return to the real world. The pop in the bubble. The crawl of something colder up the back of her neck. She could see the bowling alley from the car windshield. The people, the lights. She could feel the words clawing up her spine, burning their way out of her mouth:

 

“We’re still frien-”

 

“Friends,” Rio said simply. “Yeah. Of course.”

 

Rio was zipping her jeans, reaching for her baseball cap in the floorboard Agatha had knocked off somewhere between moaning and forgetting her own name. Rio settled it back onto her head, kissed the corner of her mouth like she was sealing something shut for Agatha’s sake, and gave her a tight lipped smile that didn’t touch her eyes.

 

It wasn’t hot. It wasn’t cold. It was... polite.

 

A thank you.

 

A goodbye for now. 

 

Agatha swallowed around the knot in her throat.

 

“Rio,” Agatha said and her throat burned hot. 

 

Just her name, but Agatha packed every plea she could into it.

 

Slow down. Look at me. Take this seriously.

 

“I won’t say a word. No screaming from the rooftops that I finally fucked Agatha Harkness. I promise.”

 

Agatha almost said thank you. She bit down on her tongue hard enough to taste blood.

 

“I don’t want anyone to say anything,” Agatha said. 

 

Rio nodded. “They won’t.”

 

“You can’t promise that.”

 

“No,” Rio agreed. “But I can tackle whoever tries.”

 

That startled a laugh out of Agatha. Brief, sharp, ugly. “Yeah, because that wouldn’t make it obvious.”

 

Rio smiled. “Then I’ll make sure it’s worth it.”

 

Agatha didn’t say anything else. She couldn’t. Her tongue felt too thick. Her brain couldn’t hold all the parts of her trying to split open. She’d wanted Rio to act like it was nothing, and Rio had. Perfectly. Respectfully.

 

And she hated how much comfort she took in it. Hated how badly she needed Rio to treat it like nothing so she wouldn’t have to admit it had been everything.

 

Now Agatha had to sit with what that felt like.

 

She wiped her palms on her jeans and got out of the car, pretending that the ache in her chest was just leftover adrenaline. 

 

-

 

Agatha tightened her jaw and followed Rio in silence. The parking lot was loud. A bass line from somewhere inside was already thudding through the pavement, vibrating up through Agatha’s shoes. She rolled her shoulders back, tried to remember how her face was supposed to work. Neutral expression. Mild interest. Like she hadn’t just fucked Rio in her car. 

 

At the entrance, Rio held the door open without looking at her. Agatha stepped into a rounded atrium glowing with soft pink light, casting a sheen over polished concrete floors and curved metal trim. At the center stood a circular desk with staff in black polos moving quickly behind it- scanning people in, handing out shoes, pulling up pre-booked lanes on mounted tablets.

 

Rio headed straight for the counter without hesitation.

 

Agatha followed. She kept her gaze moving, scanning the layout- instinct. To the right, the arcade sat behind a pane of tinted glass, pulsing with retro lighting and what looked like a trillion different arcade games. To the left, past a velvet rope and an arched hallway, there was an outdoor lounge tucked under string lights and heat lamps, like the place hosted live music or influencer birthday parties on the weekends. 

 

The whole thing was too nice. Too designed. It left Agatha weirdly alert.

 

When they reached the counter, Rio leaned forward slightly, already speaking to the attendant. She rattled off something about a reservation under Kale. The attendant nodded, tapping quickly at the screen, and asked about shoe sizes. 

 

“Eight,” Rio said. “And seven.”

 

Agatha glanced at her, but didn’t say anything.

 

The attendant nodded again, turned, and pulled their sizes from the shelves, sliding the shoes across the counter. A total was given. Before Agatha could reach for her purse, Rio had already pulled out her wallet, slipping her card into the reader. A receipt was handed over. A lane number. No questions. No discussion. It was all handled before Agatha even remembered she might’ve offered to split it.

 

Rio turned and handed her the shoes, brushing the edge of Agatha’s fingers. Her hand was warm. She kept the other under her arm.

 

“You good?” Rio asked, softly.

 

Agatha nodded. It wasn’t a lie, but it also wasn’t not her mutely acknowledging the fact that Rio had just handled the entire interaction without even checking in.

 

She could’ve been annoyed. Should’ve been, maybe. But instead, she felt the smallest, sharpest relief. Like she hadn’t realized she’d been holding her shoulders that tight until Rio made space for her to breathe. 

 

Which was horrifying. 

 

Together, they stepped away from the desk, shoes in hand, and headed toward the lanes.

 

It felt like she was walking into a fucking fever dream. Pink Pony Club was playing over the speaker system, the bass thumping through the floor like it was trying to rearrange her spine. Neon spilled across every surface- walls pulsing magenta, bar lights rotating in slow blues and purples.

 

They rounded the corner toward their assigned lane, and the first thing Agatha saw was Sage.

 

Standing on a couch. Not sitting. Standing. In socks with a beer bottle in one hand, her back to them, throwing her ass around with full dedication as she shouted the lyrics loud enough to drown out the speakers. Not one ounce of shame anywhere in her body.

 

Billy nursed a violently pink cocktail with three straws, somehow managing to look both horrified and enchanted. Alice clapped along like she was front row at a drag show. Jen stood off to the side, filming the chaos with a grin. Yelena stood near the bar, completely ignoring whatever Nat was saying in her ear. Her attention hadn’t moved once from Sage, a stunned grin tugging at her mouth.

 

Their section was a mess of half finished drinks, abandoned shoes, and the quiet thrum of too much energy too early in the night. Everyone else seemed to take it in stride.

 

Agatha did not.

 

She wasn’t panicking, exactly. But she was absolutely aware of every single choice she had made in the past twenty four hours, and how they had all led, very directly, to this moment. 

 

Rio stopped beside her and brushed their arms together. Let her elbow linger against Agatha’s. And when Agatha didn’t move, she turned her head slightly, just enough that her voice could reach her.

 

“I’ve seen her do worse,” Rio said. “This is actually pretty tame, considering.”

 

It was stupid, how effective that was. Agatha felt her body start to unwind without permission. Her shoulders dropped. The static in her chest eased. She could still hear Sage yelling over the music, still see Jen grinning with her phone out, still feel the dozen pairs of eyes that might eventually swing her way. But none of it carried the same charge it had a minute ago.

 

This was ridiculous. Absolutely, unarguably absurd. But it was also fine.

 

She had stepped into it willingly- into the noise, the chaos, the weird orbit of people who clapped when Sage got up on furniture. She had invited it. She’d opened the door and let Rio back in, and maybe she hadn’t planned for what came after, but she was here now.

 

And strangely, impossibly, she didn’t feel out of place.

 

Let the music play. Let Sage keep dancing on furniture. Let the whole night spiral into chaos if it wanted to. None of it mattered- so long as no one said her name and Rio Vidal’s in the same goddamn sentence.

 

Because if they did, Agatha was going to jail. 

 

When Sage turned around and spotted them, her eyes lit up like someone had just handed her fire.

 

“Well, well, well,” Sage shouted over the music, pointing her beer bottle directly at them. “Look who finally decided to show their faces.”

 

It was an announcement that made the entire group turn. Heads swiveled. Conversations paused. Jen lowered her phone, grinning already. Alice let out a dramatic gasp. Even Billy perked up, eyes locked on Agatha with a cartoonish smile. 

 

Agatha considered turning on her heel and walking straight back out the door, but she knew better. That would only draw more attention.

 

Rio leaned in slightly, elbow still touching hers. “Too late to run,” she murmured, entirely unbothered.

 

Before Agatha could respond, Rio was already peeling away from her side, heading toward the couch like she didn’t feel every single person in the room watching her go.

 

Sage hopped down with zero concern for physics or beer spillage. She barely landed before setting her beer down and launching herself at Rio with both arms outstretched like she was aiming for a tackle. Rio, instead of ducking, caught her and promptly dragged her into a chokehold, arm looped loosely around her neck.

 

Sage shouted something unintelligible and shoved at her ribs, but Rio only tightened her grip a little and muttered something into her hair that made Sage bark out a laugh. Sage broke free and shoved Rio with both hands, grinning.

 

Agatha watched from where she stood, utterly still.

 

They were absurd. Loud, physical, tangled up in each other’s space without apology. It was juvenile. It was annoying.

 

 It was exhausting just to look at.

 

Agatha had come here for bowling. For shoe rentals and hoping for low stakes small talk and something that didn’t ask her to feel anything she couldn’t walk away from. And now here she was, pretending she could stand at the edge of Rio’s life without wanting to be pulled all the way back in. 

 

She wanted access to it. Full fucking access. She wanted to know the version of Rio that didn’t belong to her anymore. The one that kept showing up in pieces she didn’t recognize- comfortable, rooted, known by people who weren’t her. That was all. Nothing serious.

 

Agatha didn’t let the thought linger. She couldn’t. And besides, Teen was already headed her way, pink drink in hand, eyes lit up like he was about to say something she didn’t have the patience for. She stepped forward before he could say anything, cutting him off with pure efficiency, and dropped onto the couch to deal with the shoes. They were hideous. She tied them with the precision of someone preparing for combat.

 

Whatever else was happening tonight, she was still here to win. 

 

Winning was the only thing that made any of this tolerable. It always had been. Bowling, cards, trivia- she didn’t care. The sooner she got on a lane, the sooner she could stop thinking about Rio.

 

Or, failing that, at least pretend wanting to sit beside her had something to do with strategy.

The next hour passed without incident. She was in the lead, obviously. Rio was close behind her, which felt both predictable and vaguely offensive in its irony. Of course she was chasing her. Agatha didn’t bother keeping track of the others. They existed purely as background noise. Her focus was fixed, single minded, and competitive enough to be borderline pathological. Stay ahead. That was the game. That was always the game.

 

To her surprise, Jen hadn’t pounced the second they were alone. She hadn’t asked about Rio, hadn’t pried, hadn’t so much as raised an eyebrow about how they’d shown up together. And that, somehow, was worse. Jen knew her too well not to notice and Agatha knew better than to mistake it for oversight. This was Jen throwing Agatha a bone, and Agatha snatched it like she hadn’t eaten in weeks.

 

They were wedged together on the couch now, Jen deep in the trenches of workplace gossip while Agatha sat rapt, drinking in every petty detail. She didn’t care if it made her a terrible person. Gossip was currency, and she wanted to be rich. Jen had just started in on a particularly scandalous rumor about one of the newer residents when Jen’s name was called, and she stood with a groan, muttering that she’d finish the story later.

 

Agatha barely had a second to process the absence beside her before she felt the shift. That brief, eerie stillness like the top of a rollercoaster. Across from her, Sage and Billy were seated on the opposite couch, both their eyes had snapped to the newly vacated seat and then immediately to each other. 

 

Agatha sighed. “Jesus Christ.”

 

They moved in tandem, limbs clashing as they scrambled to beat the other across the short distance. Billy led with his shoulder, aiming to brute force his way in, but Sage was faster, meaner, and had clearly come prepared to humiliate him. She shoved him backward with enough force to send him crashing back into his seat, then stepped onto the low table between the couches, using it as leverage to hurl herself into the empty spot. She landed hard next to Agatha, planted and smug, barely breaking a sweat. 

 

The whole thing unfolded in less than five seconds. It was insane. Absolutely uncalled for. But at this point, not remotely surprising.

 

Billy flailed dramatically across from them, scowling as he adjusted his shirt. “You’re insane,” he snapped.

 

Sage didn’t even look at him. “You were in my way.”

 

“Jesus, you’re so aggressive-”

 

“Oh, I’m sorry, do you want me to be gentler next time? Maybe write you a poem while I kick your ass?”

 

Billy scoffed. “You’re gonna die alone.”

 

Sage smiled. “Maybe. But at least I’ll die a winner.”

 

Sage turned to her just as Agatha watched Jen’s ball roll straight into the gutter, hopeless from the moment it left her hand.

 

Agatha hadn’t really spoken to Sage since the adopted sister reveal. That particular bomb had been dropped with no warning and even less tact, and Agatha still wasn’t sure what to do with it. Sage kept trying- always cheerful, always conveniently nearby. She showed up in the NICU with x-ray orders and thinly veiled small talk, acted overly casual at game nights.

 

Agatha rarely gave her anything back. It wasn’t personal. Or maybe it was. She wasn’t sure. The whole situation felt like a trick she hadn’t realized she was falling for until the pieces were already in place.

 

“Billy’s starting to think you like him more than me.”

 

“I don’t like either of you.” Agatha glanced at her, then immediately looked away.

 

Sage hummed under her breath, unconvinced. “You’re upset with me.”

 

“That’s ridiculous.” Agatha scoffed, unwilling to look at her. 

 

“You won’t even look at me.”

 

Agatha’s jaw tightened. “Maybe that’s because you bamboozled me.”

 

Sage let out a soft laugh. “Bamboozled you?”

 

Agatha finally turned to face her, eyes sharp. “Yes. Bamboozled. Hoodwinked. Strategically misled,” she hissed, the words clipped and fast. 

 

Sage blinked, obviously thrown. “What are you even talking about?”

 

“Game night.” Agatha snapped. “You knew exactly what you were keeping from me. Was that the plan? Get in first, play nice, make it easier to stomach the fucking info bomb she dropped on me? I don’t fuck with being played.”

 

Sage nodded along, dragging out the sound. “Ohhh.” It was theatrical. Mock realization. Then, flatly- 

 

“No.”

 

Agatha narrowed her eyes, waiting for more. 

 

Sage only shrugged. “I’d heard a lot about you. I wanted to see for myself what all the fuss was about.” Her tone wasn’t defensive- it was honest, maybe even a little proud. “Didn’t say anything because I figured you’d write me off before I got a word in.”

 

“So you thought deception was the best way to introduce yourself.”

 

“I didn’t deceive you.”

 

“You didn’t correct me.” Agatha shot back. 

 

“Was I wrong to do that?”

 

Absolutely yes. But also no. If she’d known then what she knew now, it wouldn’t have been silence- it would’ve been scorched earth. She would’ve stayed long enough to ruin the energy, to make sure they both understood exactly how fucked it was.

 

Or maybe not. Maybe she would’ve done nothing at all. At this point she doesn’t really care.

 

Agatha pressed her lips together, considering. “I don’t know.”

 

She didn’t clarify. She wasn’t offering more. It was just the truth- ugly and incomplete.

 

Sage nodded. “Cool. Great talk. Can you stop being weird now?” 

 

“I’m not being weird.”

 

“You’re absolutely being weird. And it’s making me weird, which I don’t like.” She nudged her heel against Agatha’s foot. “So let’s move on before it gets anymore awkward and I have to light myself on fire.”

 

Agatha huffed, “You wouldn’t.”

 

“I would. I’ve got matches in the car. Let’s bowl and pretend none of that happened. For your sake, not mine. Oh, and tell Billy you like me more than him… Strictly for morale.”

 

It pulled a laugh out of Agatha before she could stop it- brief, involuntary, too real to take back. Sage caught it and didn’t gloat, just nodded like that was the outcome she’d been aiming for all along.

 

Then Sage stood, grabbed a ball off the rack, and as she turned toward the lane, she tossed over her shoulder, easy-

 

“Lilia keeps asking about you, by the way. It’s starting to get sad. Don’t make the woman beg, Agatha.” Sage didn’t wait for a reply. Just lined herself up at the edge of the lane, eyes locked on the pins.

 

No pause for effect. No fishing for a response.

 

Just a hit and run. The way Rio would’ve done it.

 

And Agatha sat there and watched, dumbfounded- like a fucking fool.

 

Infuriating. Effortless. Entirely intentional. Undeniably related to Rio fucking Vidal.
