She just needed something to do that didn’t involve throwing a bowling ball at someone’s head. Not anyone in particular. Just… in the general direction of Rio.

 

Nothing about Rio’s behavior was overtly wrong. She hadn’t been cold. She hadn’t been distant. She had been polite. Friendly. Reasonable. Fucking normal. 

 

It was psychotic.

 

And fine- Agatha had wanted her to keep it quiet. She’d set the boundary. That was fair.

 

But did Rio have to be so fucking good at it?

 

Agatha crossed her arms and shifted her weight, and clenched her jaw. She imagined grabbing Rio by the collar and demanding to know why she hadn’t even bothered to flirt with her tonight. Why she hadn’t been insufferably up Agatha’s ass. Why she had stopped acting like Agatha was the most interesting person in the room.

 

Rio had decided to behave. Which was apparently the worst thing she could have done because Agatha hated her for it. 

 

Not really. But enough to stand in this stupid line and stew about it. She wasn’t going to look for Rio. She wasn’t going to say anything. This was exactly what she wanted.

 

So why did it feel less like control and more like loss?

 

Agatha took one step forward in the line. She could feel her own expression curling into something unpleasant. She knew she looked mad. She didn’t care.

 

And then she felt that familiar presence she couldn’t ignore even if she tried behind her. 

 

Agatha straightened automatically, but she didn’t turn around. She didn’t say anything. She just stared at the menu and reminded herself that throwing a tantrum in public was generally frowned upon.

 

For a moment, Rio said nothing. She just stood there, close enough to be a presence but not enough to push it. Then her voice came, low and maddeningly casual.

 

“Sweetheart.” Rio said.

 

Agatha’s eyes didn’t move from the board. She could feel the heat in her neck immediately, the pressure building behind her eyes and in the tight corners of her jaw. She didn’t want to respond. She wanted to keep pretending she had the upper hand, that she was the one who had walked away unaffected, that she hadn’t been mentally screaming since the moment Rio stopped paying attention to her.

 

“I’m not mad,” Agatha muttered, voice stiff and entirely unconvincing.

 

“Sure,” Rio said simply.

 

“I’m not,” Agatha repeated, now fully aware of how juvenile she sounded but too deep in it to stop.

 

“Okay.”

 

That was it. That was all she got. 

 

Agatha half turned her body, whipped her head around, and stared at Rio fucking stunned.

 

Rio was just standing there. Relaxed. Polite.

 

Agatha turned back slowly, jaw clenched, pulse thrumming in her throat. She wanted to scream.

 

“You’re pissing me off,” Agatha snapped.

 

“I’m doing what you wanted,” Rio replied, calm as anything.

 

“Well, it’s pissing me off.”

 

Rio hummed, like that amused her. “Come smoke with me.”

 

“No.” She folded her arms tighter. “I don’t think I will.”

 

“Agatha.”

 

And just like that, Agatha’s body betrayed her. Her shoulders eased, barely, as though they’d been waiting for permission. That tone. That inflection. No one else ever said her name like that. She didn’t answer. She let her eyes close, slow and controlled, maybe if she moved carefully enough she wouldn’t have to acknowledge what it did to her.

 

Rio stepped in, too close now, her breath warm at the shell of Agatha’s ear. Not touching, but close enough to feel it.

 

“I miss you,” Rio whispered.

 

Agatha’s lip curled. That was better.

 

“I know.”

 

Rio hadn’t moved. Was still standing there, probably poking her tongue against the inside of her cheek the way she always did when she didn’t know if she was losing or winning.

 

Good. Let her wonder.

 

Agatha didn’t say anything else right away. She let the silence stretch, let the tension settle again. She liked the way Rio was holding still, like any sudden movement might ruin it.

 

“You gonna say something else that’ll make me feel better, or just stand there breathing on me?”

 

“You want me to beg?” Rio said, voice infuriatingly steady.

 

“I don’t care what you do,” Agatha shot back, adding a shrug for effect. Unbothered. Not insanely aware of how turned on she was. Not at all.

 

There was a pause. Then Rio leaned in, closer than she had all night, her body leaning in just enough to press up against Agatha’s back. Not hands. Not hips. Just the faint pressure of crossed arms brushing against the middle of Agatha’s back- light, contained, like she was trying not to touch her at all and failing on purpose.  

 

“Stay at my place tonight,” Rio said, soft. 

 

Agatha smirked.  She could feel Rio straining under all that self control, her body betraying her in the smallest, most satisfying ways. And fuck, it felt like winning.

 

“Oh, I don’t know,” Agatha said lightly, loading it with just enough condescension to make herself feel powerful. “We have work tomorrow.”

 

And she expected that to be the end of it. Expected Rio to back off. To take the hit and behave, like she’d been doing all night. Good girl. Gold star.

 

But then- 

 

“Please.”

 

It wasn’t even a word. Not really. Just breath, hot against her ear, low and dangerous and too fucking soft.

 

“Please, baby. I’ll do anything.”

 

Agatha made a sound. It wasn’t intentional. Wasn’t dignified. It punched out of her in a pathetic little gasp- high in her throat, half a whimper, half a groan, fully, irreparably fucking humiliating.

 

She went still.

 

Fully frozen. Eyes wide, chest locked, brain freshly wiped by the horny wrath of god.

 

Alright. Wrap it up. Wrap it the fuck up, Agatha. 

 

“Fine,” she snapped, too loud and too fast, already turning away like the sound hadn’t come from her at all. Because if she didn’t walk off right then -immediately, with purpose- she was going to do something catastrophic. Something irreversible. Something she would absolutely not be able to explain to security.

 

She stormed back toward their group with her jaw tight and her hands clenched into fists at her sides, walking like she hadn’t just nearly collapsed because a woman said please.

 

It was fine.

 

She was fine.

 

Totally calm. Totally in control. Definitely not seconds away from hauling Rio into the nearest disgusting bowling alley bathroom and dropping to her knees. 

 

Jesus Christ.

 

Agatha needed a Diet Coke and a fucking lobotomy.

 

-

 

Agatha was standing, grabbing the last of her shit, counting down the seconds until she could get out of this godforsaken neon lit purgatory with Rio.

 

Rio was on the far side of their section, leaned up against the plastic high top counter. It was one of those built in setups, too high to sit at comfortably, with stools and the open racks underneath for bowling balls, like some bastardization of a bar and a storage unit. She had her arms crossed loosely, talking to Sage and Alice like nothing was out of place. Like she hadn’t whispered ‘ please, baby. I’ll do anything.’ against Agatha’s ear earlier and then gone right back to looking like a smug, patient son of a bitch.

 

Agatha had tried - tried - desperately not to notice her. Not to track every change in posture, every glance, every small movement that reminded her exactly how far she was from losing control in public. It hadn’t worked. Of course it hadn’t. Rio was right there, in the same goddamn bowling alley, being hot and polite and pretending like she didn’t know Agatha was one more breath away from losing her shit.

 

Teen was on the couch beside her, talking at length about… Agatha doesn’t fucking know. But she was nodding along like she could hear it. She couldn't. She was too busy focusing on the clock, on her breath, on the promise of being done with this place and in Rio’s car. The night was almost over. She was almost free.

 

And then- 

 

“Agatha?”

 

She felt her stomach drop so violently she was sure she had just shit it out of her own asshole. 

 

It came from the wrong direction. It came from a voice that should not, under any circumstances, have been here.

 

Agatha turned slowly, already knowing what she would see and still unprepared for it.

 

Wanda.

 

Not in Chicago.

 

Here.

 

In the middle of a bowling alley in fucking Westview, New Jersey.

 

Agatha stared at her ex-wife, eyes locked and expression neutral, even as her brain started screaming: No, I want more time!

 

It was grief, like something sacred being ripped out by its roots. A primal, internal protest against the inevitability that nothing Wanda touched ever survived. Even permanence learned to wilt beneath it. 

 

“Can we talk?” Wanda asked, soft.

 

Agatha stared at her, mouth dry, heart shredding through her chest. She didn’t have an answer.

 

Still, her fingers twitched -just barely, just once- in the direction of Rio Vidal, who was not looking at her. Of course. Classic. Same reach as before. Still pathetic. Still unanswered. And yet, apparently, her body hadn’t gotten the memo, because here it was again. Subtle. Stupid. Waiting around like a little idiot, just in case Rio fucking Vidal wanted to notice this time.

 

This was what it looked like when the universe put a hand between her shoulder blades and whispered, ‘You don’t get to have that.’

 

But Agatha saw it in her periphery- a blur of motion veering straight toward her ex-wife. She didn’t bother looking. Just let her eyes fall shut and waited.

 

A shout followed. Wanda’s voice, loud with disbelief. 

 

When Agatha opened her eyes, Rio was standing in front of her. A little out of breath from crossing the room. Or maybe from thirteen years of trying to get here in time.

 

“Hey,” Rio said, still a little winded. “Sorry I’m late.”

 

Rio turned to look behind her. Agatha followed her gaze- Wanda, soaked. Sage crouched beside the fallen pitcher, scrambling, mouthing a series of apologies that couldn’t have sounded less genuine. Beer everywhere.

 

Rio looked back at Agatha, a small smile pulling at her mouth like she didn’t regret a single second of it.

 

“Had to improvise.” Rio said, with a shrug that felt too easy to be innocent. She reached out slightly, a fingertip grazing the back of Agatha’s hand. “Let’s go back to mine, yeah?”

 

 

Chapter End Notes

the way i wanted to end this chapter at 'you don't get to have that' but literally could not stomach the idea of even teasing that Rio wasn't paying attention... literally made me sick.

anyway, writing this chapter fucking sucked and i feel a bit meh about it. this entire story was supposed to be far angstier than it is but every time i sit down to write, my gf is whispering into my ear: 'you will not hurt them' (threat)

Chapter 8: i love you, i'm sorry

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

“Rio?” Agatha whispered.

 

None of it felt real. The sounds, the lights, the clatter of pins- it all fell away. All she could feel was the flood in her chest, unasked for but absolute, at the sight of her. That dumb, beautiful face Agatha had been pretending to outrun, while tracing its outline in every life that never felt like hers.

 

“Yeah,” Rio breathed. “I’m sorry it took me so long.” She said it again, quieter this time, as her pointer finger reached out and curled around Agatha’s.

 

“I-“ Agatha started, but stopped. She swallowed, glancing over Rio’s shoulder. Sage was making an absolute scene, and somehow, Wanda looked genuinely rattled by it.

 

Good. 

 

She looked back. Rio hadn’t looked away.

 

“Get me the fuck out of here.”

 

“My fucking pleasure,” Rio said, a breath of relief slipping through her grin as she grabbed Agatha’s hand fully. 

 

Rio’s hand tightened around her own, her thumb brushed across her knuckles, and tugged gently, coaxing Agatha to follow.

 

They wove through the mess of rental shoes and drunk adults. Rio didn’t stop. Not even when someone shouted “Hey! Private party!” 

 

They’d just made it to the carpet when Agatha heard it. It came from behind them, cutting through the noise with an ease that made Agatha’s stomach turn.

 

“Didn’t think you had it in you, Vidal! Honestly, I’m impressed. After our last conversation, when you slunked off with your tail tucked, I figured you’d have the sense to stay gone.”

 

Rio stopped cold.

 

Agatha walked directly into her back and startled at the contact, but Rio didn’t budge. For a second, she thought she had misheard.

 

Last conversation.

 

The word landed like a misstep on a staircase- ordinary until it wasn’t, until her stomach dropped and nothing made sense.

 

What the fuck was Wanda talking about?

 

Agatha blinked, trying to make sense of it. Wanda’s words didn’t fit anywhere. They bounced and bumped against her skull like that old 3D Space Cadet pinball game she used to play on her mother’s computer. Flashing lights and endless dings, where once the ball started moving, you just sat there and watched it spiral out of control.

 

Agatha’s chest tightened. Her skin went cold.

 

And then Rio’s hand was no longer in hers.

 

Agatha turned because she always did. Because she had learned to chase the silence without ever meaning to. A reflex. Her heart, stupid and unrelenting, lurched after Rio like it always did- clawing, screaming, desperate to be held by the only hands it had ever called home.

 

She looked, just in time to see Rio moving straight toward Wanda. Her jaw was locked. Her fists were curled. Her shoulders were squared in a way Agatha had never seen before.

 

That was the part that rattled Agatha most.

 

She had spent years trying to get a rise out of Rio for fun. She had pushed her, cornered her, just trying to get her to react. To snap. To yell. Anything. But Rio had always been infuriatingly calm. Even in their worst moments, she never looked like this.

 

There was no mask left. Just a fury so sharp it looked like it didn’t belong to her.

 

Agatha stood frozen, caught in utter disbelief. 

 

Wanda’s shirt was soaked through, clinging to her chest. She looked wrecked and triumphant, like someone who had nothing left to lose and had decided to aim carefully.

 

“Rio!”

 

Agatha saw Sage scramble upright, already moving before Rio could take another step.

 

“Don’t!” Sage shouted, and then she crashed into Rio with her full weight, arms hooking around her shoulders, with a force that made Agatha flinch.

 

A thud, a breath knocked loose, the squeak of shoes. They staggered back, off balance for a second, but didn’t fall.

 

“You stupid, miserable fucking cunt!” Rio yelled over Sage’s shoulder, her voice loud enough to draw attention.

 

Pins clattered somewhere in the distance. A child near the snack counter started crying. Music still played overhead, far too cheerful for what had just been said.

 

It was the first time Agatha had ever heard Rio raise her voice like that.

 

Sage shoved Rio. Hard. “Hey- get a grip,” she snapped.

 

“Rio!” Agatha shouted.

 

That single word pulled Rio’s gaze immediately. She looked at Agatha, breathing hard. Still furious. Still shaking.

 

Her eyes were wild- glassy, burning, like she was barely holding herself together. And for a heartbeat, Agatha didn’t recognize her.

 

Not this version.

 

This was not the person who used to tuck every feeling away behind a mask, who could disarm with a glance and disappear behind silence before anyone got too close.

 

That Rio was gone. Burned through, actually.

 

Who stood in front of Agatha now was raw and exposed, rage crackling beneath her skin and carved into the lock of her jaw.

 

Agatha held her gaze.

 

“You’re done,” Agatha said softly. “Come with me.”

 

For a breath, nothing.

 

And then Rio exhaled and gave a single nod.

 

Agatha lifted her arm and signaled Rio forward.

 

Rio moved.

 

They walked together, shoulder to shoulder, past stunned faces and spilled beer, past the blur of noise behind them. Agatha heard Wanda call her name. She didn’t turn around. She kept her eyes ahead, her pace steady.

 

Two security guards brushed past them, heading toward the noise. Somewhere behind, Jen’s voice rang out, sharp and clear. Then Alice, angrier, more direct. Agatha didn’t look back. Her friends had it handled.

 

“Agatha!” Wanda again, louder now. “Don’t you dare leave with her!”

 

Rio was at her side, then slightly ahead of her. She was breathing hard.

 

“I’m your wife!”

 

Rio’s stride lengthened. Her jaw was still tight. Agatha didn’t need to see her face to know what that voice was doing to her. She could feel it. Every part of Rio’s body was tense, she was holding herself in check, every step a decision not to turn around and make it worse.

 

They rounded the corner.

 

The sounds behind them dulled. The light changed. The entrance’s atrium was quieter, colder. Rio kept moving. She was several steps ahead now, walking fast, like her body was trying to outrun her mind.

 

Whatever Wanda had meant by ‘ last conversation’, Agatha had no idea. It didn’t make sense. Rio and Wanda had barely ever spoke. That much Agatha knew. If anything ever happened between them, it happened when Agatha wasn’t looking because she hadn’t thought she needed to look.

 

Agatha didn’t know what was true. She didn’t know what Rio had kept from her.

 

And now wasn’t the time to find out.

 

Priorities , Agatha reminded herself. First: out. Then: Rio.

 

Because right now, Rio was still walking ahead of her because she needed to be somewhere else before she could breathe properly.  She needed distance. From the building. From the shouting. From whatever scar had torn open inside her and started to bleed.

 

Agatha would wait. She would walk behind her, through this ugly stretch of silence, until the shaking in Rio’s hands stopped.

 

Rio barreled through the double doors, her stride relentless, but even then, she paused just long enough to hold the door open for Agatha. A gentleman, to the last. Not that Rio waited for thanks. The moment Agatha stepped through, Rio turned away and cut across the parking lot with purposeful steps that didn’t once falter or look back. 

 

They reached the car. Agatha slowed, arms folding loosely over her chest as she watched Rio. 

 

Rio flung the driver’s side door open and ducked inside.  Her hand reappeared with a battered pack of cigarettes, one of which she shoved between her teeth before slamming the door shut behind her. She leaned back against the car like it was the only thing keeping her upright and brought the purple zippo to her mouth, fingers trembling so violently the flame refused to catch. Once. Twice. Three times. Still nothing.

 

“Fuck,” Rio snapped. Her voice had gone hoarse somewhere in all of this.

 

Agatha approached slowly. She set her purse beside Rio’s feet and moved in front of her. The streetlight caught the edges of Rio’s face, but she  refused to look at Agatha. She kept trying to light the cigarette with growing frustration, her jaw tight, her focus narrowed to the task.

 

“Rio,” Agatha said quietly.

 

No response. Just the click of metal and a flicker that never turned into flame.

 

She reached out and gently took the lighter from Rio’s hand, expecting a protest, a scoff, a flinch- anything. But Rio let her. Her fingers uncurled so easily it made Agatha ache. She flicked the lighter once. The flame caught instantly. Rio leaned forward, inhaled, and let the smoke fill her lungs. Again. And again. She pulled the cigarette away, dropped her head back against the car, and exhaled into the sky with her neck exposed and her jaw clenched.

 

The skin of Rio’s neck caught the light- some of the concealer Agatha had aggressively applied earlier had worn thin. Not all of it, but just enough for Agatha to see what was underneath.

 

And oh, how Agatha wanted to reach out and wipe the rest away. Strip it down to truth. To Rio’s truth. To hers. And God, part of Agatha wanted to rewind time to this morning. To yesterday. To every moment before their bubble popped. But it wouldn’t help. Wanting never did.

 

So, Agatha did the next best thing and stepped forward until their bodies touched. Until she could feel Rio flinch in surprise. Her head snapped down and suddenly brown eyes locked onto Agatha’s- endless, pleading without asking for anything.

 

Agatha let her own body soften, tension draining from her frame because, somehow, Rio’s pain had always made more sense than her own. 

 

She reached up and took the baseball cap off Rio’s head, let it fall with the lighter on top of her purse. Then both hands lifted to cup Rio’s face. Softly. Carefully. Tender in a way that made herself want to cry. 

 

Rio’s free hand flew up to clutch Agatha’s wrist, as if she were afraid this was a dream she’d wake from too soon.

 

Agatha tucked strands of Rio’s hair behind her ears. Her fingers found their way into the roots, lifting to the back of her head, guiding her in. She pulled Rio into a hug. One arm curled around her shoulders, the other cradling the back of her head. 

 

Rio didn’t fight it. She gave in completely- slackening against Agatha’s chest and letting her breath shudder out against her skin.

 

Agatha felt the press of Rio’s mouth against her shoulder first- soft, seeking, not quite steady. One arm wrapped firmly around Agatha’s waist while the other remained limp at her side. 

 

Then came the faint sound of a dull hiss of ember meeting pavement. The cigarette. Rio let it go. 

 

A moment later, both arms were circled around Agatha’s back, drawing her closer with desperation.

 

Agatha melted into Rio. Pressed every part of herself forward until there was no space left between them. Her face leaned into the side of Rio’s head, and for a moment they stood like that, almost swaying.

 

Eventually, Agatha finally pulled back, it wasn’t much, barely an inch, just enough to see Rio’s mouth, her eyelashes, the tiny tremble in her lip. Her hand found the side of Rio’s face, her thumb grazing her cheek. Agatha dipped her head, slow and cautious, letting the tip of her nose brush against Rio’s.

 

Rio nodded. Fast. Breath catching in her throat like it hurt.

 

Agatha kissed her.

 

She pressed her mouth into Rio’s with no force, no urgency. It didn’t come with heat or hunger, only stillness. 

 

Agatha didn’t want anything from her. She didn’t need anything. She only wanted to erase whatever her ex-wife had ripped open and remind Rio, gently, that Agatha was here.  

 

She pulled back slightly, just enough to breathe, and then kissed Rio again- softer this time. Then her mouth found the corner of Rio’s lips. Then her cheek. Then the place just beneath her ear, where her jawline gave way to her throat. Each kiss pressed with a purpose.

 

When Agatha’s lips found Rio’s again, she stayed for a moment. Then pulled back just far enough to whisper, “I’m sorry.”

 

Another kiss.

 

“I’m so sorry.”

 

Another.

 

Each apology landed between them as if Agatha’s mouth knew how to beg better than her voice ever could.

 

Rio didn’t speak. She leaned in every time, chasing Agatha, her hands clenched behind Agatha’s back, holding tight, nodding faintly between kisses. Her breath hitched every time Agatha pulled away. Her grip never loosened.

 

And Agatha kept going. She only wanted Rio to stay here- to let go, even if only for a moment. 

 

To let herself be cared for. 

 

And Agatha would stay. As long as it took. As long as Rio needed. 

 

Agatha would stay. 

 

-

 

The drive back to Rio’s apartment was quiet, but not awkward. Rio drove one hand on the wheel, her other hand curled around Agatha’s in her lap, thumb brushing the inside of her palm now and then, like she needed to make sure she was still there. 

 

Agatha had offered to drive but Rio gave her a look so wild and immediate that it bordered on offended. A silent absolutely not paired with an unspoken I’m not letting you kill us before we get home . 

 

Which, fair. Agatha wasn’t exactly known for her driving. It was probably their second longest running joke, right after whatever punchline they’d always been.

 

By the time they got inside, neither of them had said much beyond the necessary. Rio showered first. Agatha followed after, rinsing off everything except the weight that had settled across her chest the second she saw Rio’s body still in that god forsaken bowling alley. 

 

Rio had on a t-shirt, underwear, and socks. Always with the socks. She’d been weird about that for as long as Agatha had known her. Something about not being able to stand the feel of crumbs or dirt on her feet, the horror of some invisible particle touching skin. If she was home, she’d change into a clean pair right before getting into bed, even if the ones she had on were practically new. It wasn’t optional. She never slept without them. Agatha never understood it. Still didn’t. But she’d watched it for so many years, the ritual stopped needing a reason. It was just Rio.

 

Agatha chose to wear one of Rio’s sweatshirts- oversized, soft, lived in, absolutely would be coming home with her- and nothing else but underwear.

 

When Agatha wandered out into the living room, Rio was already sunk into the couch, phone to her ear, murmuring some half distracted responses. “Mm. Uh-uh.” Her eyes flicked up, and without missing a beat, she reached out an arm toward Agatha like she was just getting home- expected, familiar, wanted. Not even a question.

 

Agatha huffed a breath through her nose and moved toward her without a second of hesitation. She sank into the space Rio had made, leaned into the warmth waiting there. 

 

Rio, still on the phone, murmured a quick, “Love you, Petal. Thanks again,” before hanging up and tossing the phone onto the coffee table like it had never existed.

 

She didn’t say it was Sage. Didn’t have to. Agatha already knew.

 

Rio curled into her, one arm slung across Agatha’s stomach, remote in hand, flipping through channels. Agatha mumbled something half hearted about Housewives , and Rio, without protest, put it on.

 

They got maybe fifteen minutes into the episode before Agatha started chewing at her thumbnail. 

 

Not subtle. Not pretty. It was a nervous habit she never quite managed to break. Her eyes stayed on the screen, but her mind had already left the room.

 

Agatha didn’t want to ask. That was the truth of it. She didn’t want to know what Wanda had said to Rio. Not because she was afraid of the answer, but because she already had too many. Too many versions of their story, too many angles on the same wound. The past didn’t need clarifying- it had been clear enough when it hurt. She didn’t want the knife turned again under the excuse of context.

 

Surprisingly, Agatha was good at holding her tongue. Especially about things that mattered. Especially when silence kept her from doing damage. 

 

When it came to pain, Agatha tended to be precise. Efficient. Her cruelty was rarely accidental. She knew exactly how to find the soft spot and press- except with Rio. That was the one place she never quite managed to fully weaponize. And somehow, Wanda had pulled it off in a single conversation. A few words. A single glance. Whatever prior conversation she had referred to, it landed.

 

Agatha felt the question rising again. It had been sitting at the base of her throat since the parking lot. Waiting for any moment to sneak out. But she didn’t give it the room. She swallowed it back down. She didn’t want to drag it between them. Not now.

 

She didn’t want to drag Wanda into this room. Not into Rio’s apartment, not onto this couch, not into the strange, careful space the two of them had managed to build without even directly saying they were trying.

 

It wasn’t until she felt Rio’s fingers gently wrap around her wrist that Agatha had realized she was still biting her nail. Rio gently guided her hand down and didn’t let go. Just held it, thumb tracing over the back of Agatha’s fingers.

 

Then, without even looking away from the TV, she lifted Agatha’s hand and kissed it. Soft. Barely there. Like breathing.

 

And that was it.

 

Agatha’s chest eased without her permission. Her jaw unclenched. Her shoulders finally dropped. It didn’t fix anything, didn’t undo the knot in her stomach, but it quieted her mind. 

 

She let Rio keep holding her hand. Let herself settle. Let the question drift back down to where it came from.

 

It could wait.

 

This couldn’t.

 

-

 

“What if we called out of work this weekend,” Rio murmured. Her cheek was mashed flat against Agatha’s shoulder, as she traced lazy shapes into the back of Agatha's hand.

 

“You don’t call out.” Agatha said, while her other hand moved automatically, smoothing down Rio’s back, fingertips tracing the hem of her t-shirt, eyes fixed on the TV.

 

“I could,” Rio said, slower now. “For a good enough reason.”

 

Agatha let out a small, skeptical laugh. “That so?”

 

Rio didn’t laugh with her. She just nodded into her neck. “Yeah. I don’t know. I thought maybe we could get out of town for a bit… just us.”

 

At first, Agatha hadn’t been sure Rio was serious, but there was something careful in the way Rio said it, like she didn’t want to ask for too much. And that, more than anything, made Agatha answer.

 

“What did you have in mind?”

 

“Swartswood Lake.”

 

Agatha breathed out slowly through her nose. 

 

That made sense. Remote. Quiet. Not too far, but far enough. It wasn’t about the lake. Or the weekend. Or the idea of calling out of work. It was about space. Distance. A place Wanda wouldn’t be. A place where Rio could breathe without checking over her shoulder, and where Agatha wouldn’t have to pretend she was unaffected.

 

“Swartswood,” Agatha repeated.

 

“Never mind,” Rio mumbled. “Dumb idea.” She pressed in closer, burying her face into Agatha’s shoulder like she wanted to disappear there, to make a home out of her and stay hidden.

 

“I didn’t say that,” Agatha replied softly. She slid her hand under the hem of Rio’s shirt, her fingers skimming warm skin before her nails lightly dragged downward.

 

“Oh.” The breath left Rio in a soft puff, barely audible, but Agatha felt it against her collarbone.

 

Genuinely, Agatha didn’t mind the idea. A getaway. Just them. Somewhere far enough that the world couldn’t follow. Somewhere Wanda wouldn’t show up. No group hangouts. No coworkers. No expectations.

 

It sounded... simple. And simplicity had started to feel like luxury.

 

But it also felt like a threat to everything Agatha had so carefully built. Time alone meant space to speak. And space invited honesty. It dismantled excuses. She knew how it would go: long silences, then the questions- first quiet, then louder. And beneath it all, the risk that one of them might actually answer honestly.

 

“I’m not participating in any outdoor activities,” Agatha said finally, voice dry. “No fishing. No glizzy roasting. If you even think about handing me a metal skewer and tell me it builds character, I’ll drown myself in the lake.”

 

Rio’s laugh was sudden, surprised- beautiful. Agatha startled slightly at the sound, bit her lip to kill the smile that tried to follow.

 

“I wouldn’t dream of it,” Rio said, her voice already softer from laughing.

 

“I don’t do tents or any other camping bullshit,” Agatha added flatly, her fingers dragging a little rougher at the base of Rio’s spine as penance for even putting the image in her head.

 

“No tents,” Rio promised. Agatha could hear the grin in her voice. “There’s a lakehouse. Sybil’s place. She bought it a few years ago, rents it out sometimes. It’s beautiful. On the lake. You’d like it.”

 

Sybil.

 

Lilia’s younger sister. Agatha remembered her vividly- silver hair down to her waist, always barefoot, always rich, with no discernible source of income. Looked like she wandered out of a 1970s music video.

 

She was hot. Undeniably so. And Agatha, being twenty-four and chronically annoying, may have announced that within five minutes of meeting her.

 

Rio had lost her mind. Not in any useful, productive way- just sulking and theatrics. Spent the entire weekend accusing Agatha of betrayal and dramatically refusing to pass her things. At one point she even called her a homewrecker, which didn’t even make sense.

 

Anyway, Agatha never took it back. And she didn’t regret it. Sybil had that whole barefoot-witchy-goddess thing going on and… it was a confusing time for everyone involved.

 

“And what makes you so sure I’d like it?” Agatha asked.

 

A pause.

 

“Because the second I saw it, I thought of you.”

 

Agatha’s hand stilled for a beat against Rio’s back. She closed her eyes for a second.

 

She could pretend it didn’t affect her. She’d always been good at that- at arching an eyebrow and swallowing every ache behind the guise of a joke. But there was something deeply unfair about being remembered like that. About being imagined into spaces she’d never seen or been to before. About being the first person Rio thought of when she found somewhere beautiful.

 

But there was something cruel about it, too. God, she ached for the version of herself who might’ve seen it too. The one who might’ve gone with Rio the first time. If either of them had known how to be brave.

 

“Is Sybil still hot, by the way?” Agatha murmured eventually, keeping it light. Barely. “I assume she’s only gotten sexier with age.”

 

Rio groaned, muffling it against her shoulder. “I will suffocate myself in your tits. I’m so serious.”

 

Agatha smirked, amused. “What do you want me to say? She smelled like jasmine and was a real sight for sore eyes. If I remember correctly, you were very dramatic about the whole thing.”

 

“Dramatic?” Rio asked, clearly offended. “You were in love with my aunt.”

 

“Okay, now that…” Agatha waved a hand. “That is not true. You were just jealous.”

 

That made Rio lift her head and look at her.

 

“Of course I was,” Rio said, like it was obvious. Like it wouldn’t have taken a full federal investigation to get her to admit that fifteen years ago.

 

Agatha studied her for a beat.

 

“So just to clarify… we’re staying at your hot aunt’s sexy magical lakehouse, and I’m not allowed to acknowledge that she’s hot?”

 

Rio smiled, and for the first time since the Wanda disaster, Agatha saw the gap in her teeth again and her heart kicked hard at the sight.

 

“Correct,” Rio said.

 

Agatha gave a slow nod, eyes stuck on her mouth. “Right.” She swallowed, looked back up. “And have you taken other women to this sexy magical lakehouse?”

 

Rio raised her brows, practically glowing at the opportunity. “Ohhh, now look who’s jeal-”

 

Agatha pinched Rio’s calf with her toes. Hard.

 

“Oh! Fuck- what was that?” Rio yelped but didn’t pull away, laughter in her voice now. “Did you just- did you pinch me with your feet?”

 

“Mm,” Agatha shrugged. “Maybe.”

 

She reached behind Rio’s head and tugged her back down. Rio landed with a soft grunt, cheek back against her shoulder. 

 

“To answer your question,” Rio said, voice calm now, “no. I haven’t taken anyone else there.”

 

Agatha let out a breath. “Lucky me.”

 

Rio shifted again, settling in like she was always meant to be there. Her voice came quieter this time, “I’d like to take you.”

 

Agatha turned her head slightly, just enough that her words would land where Rio could feel them.

 

“I’d like that.”

 

-

 

Agatha was back at home and packing clothes into her duffle. She’d just gotten off the phone with the day shift charge nurse, who now believed, with zero suspicion, that Agatha was far too sick to work the entire weekend. It had been an Oscar worthy performance, complete with fake coughing and a mumbled ‘probably something viral.’ She hadn’t even needed to sell it that hard. Everyone knew the hospital was a germ factory. 

 

She had left Rio’s early this morning. Not because she wanted to. Rio had woken her up with espresso in a mug and kissed the corner of her mouth before pulling back like it hadn’t happened. That had been it. No follow up. Nothing else, which shouldn’t have bothered Agatha as much as it did. But it had. She didn’t bring it up. Just drank the coffee, told Rio she’d see her later, and tried not to make it weird.

 

Still, they ended on a good note.

 

Pulling into her driveway and seeing no sign of Wanda only made it better. No car, no notes, no weird passive aggressive clues that she'd been by. Nothing.

 

Now her bag was packed, zipped, and sitting by the door. No trace of her ex-wife. No shift waiting to be clocked into. Just a weekend ahead, and Rio, and maybe the smallest chance to pretend things could be simple.

 

Agatha had about an hour to kill before Rio was supposed to pick her up. Enough time to deal with the few dishes still sitting in the sink and grab the mail she hadn’t checked in… honestly, who knew how long. Once that was done, she could rot peacefully on the couch until Rio got here.

 

The dishes were easy enough, except she somehow managed to soak herself halfway through. Her shirt clung to her stomach by the time she finished rinsing the last plate. She peeled it off, muttering under her breath, and changed into something dry before heading to the door to finally grab the mail.

 

She swung it open and immediately wished she hadn’t.

 

Of course.

 

Of fucking course.

 

Because Agatha hadn’t expected it. Because she was in a good mood. Because the universe had the worst sense of fucking humor.

 

“Agatha,” Wanda said, breath catching like she’d been holding it. Her smile was small and nervous, and she sounded too relieved for someone who shouldn’t have been here in the first place.

 

Agatha blinked. Then she blinked again. Then she said, flatly, “Nope.”

 

She started to close the door, but Wanda was faster. One hand pressed to the edge of the door, the other braced against the frame like that would somehow earn her the right to stay.

 

“Wait- Agatha, please,” Wanda said quickly. “Just give me a second.”

 

“No,” Agatha said, pushing back with more force. “Let go of my door frame.”

 

“I didn’t know how else to reach you,” Wanda said. “You blocked me.”

 

“Right,” Agatha said. “I blocked you. And instead of taking that as a hint, you flew across the country to corner me.”

 

“I’m not here to corner you.”

 

“Look at my front door! This is the definition of cornering!”

 

Wanda’s expression shifted, only slightly but Agatha didn’t miss it. That flicker of indignation masked as calm.

 

“Can I come in?” Wanda asked.

 

Agatha barked a laugh that didn’t sound amused. “Absolutely not.”

 

“Please,” Wanda said, voice dipping. “I know you don’t owe me anything, but I just want-”

 

“Wanda,” Agatha said, firmer now, “move your hand.”

 

“I just need five minutes.”

 

“You’re about to need a hand surgeon if you don’t move it.”

 

Wanda didn’t move.

 

“I was your wife, Agatha. You owe me a conversation.”

 

“I don’t owe you shit according to the miserable state of Illinois.” Agatha snapped. “And if you’re smart, you’ll buy the fastest plane ticket back there before I break your hand in this door.”

 

Agatha saw the fury gather behind Wanda’s eyes and bit down on a grin. It was still satisfying. Still fucking thrilling. No matter how far they’d fallen, no matter how clear the line was now, Agatha never got tired of watching Wanda lose it. 

 

“You told me nothing happened between you two,” Wanda snapped, voice pitched and rising. “I let you convince me I was paranoid. Do you know how fucked up that is?”

 

Agatha didn’t flinch. “I didn’t lie to you. You were paranoid. That’s your default setting.”

 

“You’re unbelievable.”

 

“Correct.”

 

Wanda’s nostrils flared. “You let that girl spill beer all over me-”

 

Before Agatha could register what was happening, Wanda shoved past her, shoulder first, and crossed the threshold into her house.

 

It didn’t hit Agatha right away. The violation of it. The complete fucking audacity. She blinked, stunned for half a second, then turned fast, slamming the door behind her.

 

 “Are you out of your fucking mind?”

 

Wanda whirled around, voice already climbing, eyes wild. “And then you left with Rio Vidal. Jen’s got pictures of you all over Facebook like you’re some happy little couple. What the fuck am I supposed to think?”

 

Agatha stepped closer, jaw tight. “You’re not supposed to think anything because, again, I don’t owe you shit. We’re divorced!”

 

Wanda laughed, bitter and ugly. “You’re not even denying it.”

 

“I don’t have to. It’s none of your business.”

 

“I asked you,” Wanda hissed. “Over and over. You told me there was nothing between you and-”

 

“And there wasn’t,” Agatha snapped, cutting Wanda off. “There was nothing because I chose you. Every time, I chose you. Even when I didn’t want to. I never fucking wanted to.”

 

“You’re lying.”

 

“Am I?”

 

“Then why the hell did you even marry me?”

 

“Because she didn’t stop me!” Agatha shouted.

 

“Maybe she should’ve,” Wanda spat. “Would’ve saved me years of coming in second to someone who didn’t even want you.”

 

Agatha smiled then- slow, ugly, and dangerous. “You must’ve been so lonely,” she crooned, head tilted, mouth curled. She stepped closer, closing the space between them. “All that time, playing house. Lying next to me. Watching me shut my eyes and pretend. Knowing who I was thinking about. Knowing who I really wanted.”

 

“Stop it, Agatha.”

 

“I thought about her every single day I was with you. While I kissed you. While I fucked y-”

 

“You’re fucking evil,” Wanda spat.

 

They were close now, too close. Agatha could feel the heat of Wanda’s breath against her chin.

 

“So. Are. You.” Agatha didn’t raise her voice- just let the words rot in her mouth as she gave them to Wanda, slow and vicious.

 

Then Wanda leaned in and kissed Agatha.

 

Their mouths met and Agatha didn’t stop it right away.

 

She kissed Wanda back. Only for a second. Only because some ugly part of her wanted to ruin it. Wanted to prove she was still that person- the one who pushed good things away and reached for whatever would hurt most. But even in the thick of it, her body knew better. Nothing fit. Not the mouth, not the memory. Her hands stayed still at her side. Her heart didn’t move at all. 

 

Agatha broke the kiss and shoved Wanda away hard enough to make her stumble back.

 

“Get out.”

 

Agatha didn’t wait for a response. She turned her back, walked to the front door, and opened it. She stepped aside, one hand braced on the edge of the door. Then she tipped her chin toward the porch.  “I don’t want you here.”

 

Wanda stood frozen, blinking. “Agatha, wait- I didn’t mean to- ”

 

“You did.”

 

Wanda didn’t argue. She didn’t try again. She looked at Agatha once, brief and unsure, then walked out the door. 

 

Agatha slammed it behind her.

 

And no amount of shame on Agatha's lips could make her forget the ones she'd meant to taste.

 

-

 

Agatha paced the kitchen, barefoot, arms folded tight against her chest. The house was quiet except for the sound of her own steps- short, uneven, reversing back on themselves every few seconds.

 

She was trying to figure out how to explain kissing her ex-wife without sounding delusional.

 

That wasn’t a defense. She knew how it would sound. She’d rehearsed it three times already and still couldn’t get past the part where she admitted it had happened at all.

 

Agatha didn’t hear the knock. She barely registered the sound of the door opening.

 

She froze at the sound of Rio’s voice.

 

“Agatha?” came the call from the foyer, casual but edging toward concern. Footsteps followed and then: “Why did I just see Wanda pulling out of-”

 

Rio turned the corner into the kitchen and stopped cold.

 

Agatha didn’t move.

 

For the second time in twenty-four hours, she had to scrape her heart off the floor from where it had violently dropped out of her goddamn asshole. 

 

Everything Agatha could say sounded worse in her head. Excuses stacked on top of explanations she didn’t believe in. She hadn’t kissed Wanda because she wanted to. She hadn’t wanted to at all. She just… did. Out of instinct. Out of panic. Maybe out of some dying, desperate part of her that thought it would feel like something that wasn’t constantly screaming for Rio.

 

But boy, did Agatha learn her fucking lesson.

 

Rio’s gaze fell immediately to her mouth. Her jaw shifted, tongue pressing into her cheek. Then she gave a few small nods like she had just added something up and didn’t love the answer.

 

Now why the hell was Rio doing that? How did she even know?

 

Agatha hadn’t said a word. Hadn’t explained. Hadn’t confessed. Jesus- was she leaking guilt out of her pores? She felt herself start to sweat. She still smelled faintly like someone else’s perfume, and the realization made her sick.

 

Rio walked to the sink without a word.

 

“Rio-”

 

Rio didn’t answer. The water ran steady, too loud in the silence. She stood with her back turned, hands braced on the edge of the counter, posture rigid. Her knuckles tightened until they went pale, a subtle shift that gave away more than anything she might have said.

 

Agatha couldn’t look away. She wasn’t sure what Rio had reached for, wasn’t paying attention to the movement. Her focus had narrowed to the slope of Rio’s shoulders, the way her body held tension like a loaded spring. There was no outburst. No slammed drawers or raised voice.

 

And then, because Agatha’s body had no sense of occasion, her stomach swooped- and turned over in a way that was absolutely not helpful. Definitely not the time to feel anything that even slightly resembled arousal. 

 

The worst possible moment, the most inexcusable timing and still, Agatha’s body reacted.

 

The water stopped.

 

Rio turned, slow and deliberate, her expression unreadable. There was no heat in her eyes, no demand for an explanation, no trace of anger Agatha could cling to and argue against. The stillness Rio carried did all the work. Every part of Agatha felt seen, cornered, and aching to be touched.

 

She crossed the kitchen and placed a hand flat against Agatha’s chest. The contact wasn’t rough or confrontational. There was no pressure behind it. Only a direction, guiding Agatha backward until her hips bumped against the edge of the counter.

 

Agatha’s breath caught. 

 

Then Rio lifted her other hand. A paper towel, damp and trembling between her fingers. She wiped Agatha’s mouth, slowly. Like removing a stain. Like she couldn’t stand the sight of it.

 

When she was done, she pressed the crumpled paper towel into Agatha’s palm and whispered it- low and lethal:

 

“Her lipstick is still on your fucking mouth.”

 

Fuck. Fuck. Fuck. 

 

The paper towel in her hand felt damp and useless, and her fingers stayed curled around it and she had no idea why she was still holding it. Her fingers just wouldn’t let go. Her mouth opened. Closed. Her voice barely came out. “It didn’t mean-”

 

“Don’t.”

 

Agatha snapped her mouth shut. She bit down hard, lips pressed tight, because anything she said now would make it worse. Would sound defensive. Would sound pathetic.

 

Rio turned and walked away without another word. She leaned back against the far counter, arms folded, her body loose in a way that looked practiced. Her eyes were glassy, but not in a falling apart kind of way. Just enough to make Agatha feel like shit.

 

“Let me ask you something,” Rio said, voice even. “If I went out and kissed someone I used to fuck, would you be okay with that?”

 

Agatha swallowed hard. “No.”

 

Rio nodded slowly. “Didn’t think so.” Her gaze dropped- slow, dragging over Agatha like she was memorizing her just to make herself sick with it. “Don’t fucking do that again.” Rio said it so softly it was barely a warning. There was no bite in it. No fight. A tear escaped down Rio’s cheek. She wiped it away fast, almost impatiently. Like it embarrassed her more than anything.

 

Agatha’s chest caved in on itself. The paper towel slipped from her hand and hit the floor without a sound.

 

She crossed the kitchen in a heartbeat, closing the distance. Her hands found Rio’s face, fingers trembling as she cupped her cheeks, pulled her in, pressed their bodies together. The second her fingers touched skin, Rio’s hands flew up- gripping her wrists, holding Agatha there.

 

“I won’t,” Agatha whispered, leaning in until their foreheads touched. “I swear I won’t. I promise.”

 

Her voice shook. Her chest was too tight. She could hear how desperate she sounded, how stupid and frantic- and she didn’t give a single shit. Not right now. 

 

“Please don’t be upset with me. I hate this,” Agatha’s words tumbled out too fast, all at once. “I hate when you look at me like this. I’m sorry. I’m so fucking sorry.”

 

Rio didn’t say anything. She just stood there, gripping Agatha’s wrists like she needed the contact more than she wanted to admit, brown eyes locked on hers and full of that same awful sadness Agatha had never known how to deal with.

 

It was the worst thing about Rio. Always had been. The way her sadness lived in her eyes -wide, glassy, too still- like she didn’t understand why it hurt so much, only that it did.

 

And Agatha hated it. Hated how that look always made her feel so unbearably sick she could barely breathe. It didn’t matter what started it, didn’t matter who was to blame. That look on Rio’s face always gutted her.

 

“I didn’t mean to hurt you,” Agatha whispered.

 

Rio let out the softest breath.

 

“I know.”

 

Rio pulled Agatha into a hug. Her arms wrapped around her with that strange mix of care and exhaustion that only Rio seemed capable of. Agatha went without resistance, sinking into it, chest pressed to chest.

 

She felt Rio’s breath against her ear before she heard the words.

 

“I need a cigarette.”

 

Agatha huffed, the sound muffled against her. “Me too.”

 

They stood like that a moment longer. Then Rio shifted slightly, her voice quieter, barely above a breath now, “Do you still want to go to Swartswood with me?”

 

Agatha pulled back just enough to look at her, brow furrowed. “Do you still want to go with me ?”

 

Rio blinked. “Yeah.”

 

“Well, I still want to go with you.”

 

“Good.”

 

They stared at each other for a beat too long.

 

“If you try to kiss me with ex-wife breath, I swear to god- ”

 

Agatha shoved her lightly. “Don’t make me regret saying yes.”

 

-

 

The drive to Swartswood is quiet.

 

Not uncomfortable, just... muted. Like they’re both trying not to breathe too loud.

 

They don’t talk much. Rio keeps the radio low, some soft, moody playlist. Every so often she hums, off tune and under her breath. Agatha catches herself listening for it.

 

About forty minutes in, Rio pulls off the highway and stops at a gas station without saying a word. Agatha doesn’t ask. She knows Rio wants to smoke by the way she taps the steering wheel sometimes, like she’s counting the minutes until she can.

 

Rio disappears inside. Comes back with a new pack of American Spirits, two waters, and a bag of violently sour candy that Agatha’s pretty sure is designed to hurt people. She doesn’t argue. She eats three and immediately regrets it.

 

The rest of the drive is soft around the edges. They don’t talk about Wanda. They don’t talk about what happened. But something eases. Slightly. Enough.

 

-

 

Agatha had expected the lake house to be beautiful.

 

The house stood tucked into the hill, anchored in the slope just above the lake, with a wide wraparound porch and wood siding turned soft gray with age. No clutter. No mess. Just thoughtful touches- glass wind chimes turning slowly, sun catchers hanging in the windows, a driftwood mobile suspended beneath the eaves.

 

The back lawn rolled down toward the water, soft and freshly cut, with wide stone steps leading to a dock that extended clean and straight into the lake. There were two chairs at the end of it, angled just slightly, waiting for people who hadn’t arrived yet.

 

Closer to the shoreline, black willow branches leaned low over the bank, their leaves whispering against the surface. A single sycamore stood to the right of the dock, its pale bark flaking in broad patches, casting shifting light through its canopy.

 

A fire pit was set into the ground with smooth stones and mismatched chairs arranged in a circle- old Adirondacks, some painted in sun faded colors, one with a tye-dye throw draped over it. There was a small iron rack stacked neatly with firewood.

 

It was beautiful.

 

Agatha stood still for a long moment, feeling the wind move across her shoulders, lake lapping steady against the dock, and thought about Rio’s words from the night before.

 

“Because the second I saw it, I thought of you.”

 

-

 

The inside of the house smelled like incense and citrus peel. Not a scent pumped out of a diffuser- real smoke, steeped into the wood grain over time. It felt warm.

 

The floors were wide-planked and bare except for a few worn rugs, deep reds and washed out ochres, the kind that held onto heat and stories. Plants hung from macramé slings in the windows, leaves brushing glass. The light filtering in was soft and low, catching on floating dust.

 

There was wood everywhere. Old wood. Tables, chairs, shelves -none of it matching, all of it solid. On one wall, a turntable sat beneath a mounted shelf of records. The speakers were tall and heavy and clearly mattered. There was a stack of books on the floor -alchemy, plant medicine, astrology- next to a sculpted brass ashtray and a bundle of half burned sage.

 

A drift of dried flowers hung from a beam near the kitchen, tied with twine. The kitchen itself was open and spare.

 

There were crystals on the windowsill. A hand carved tarot box on a side table. A glass bowl of matchbooks from places that might not exist anymore.

 

“You like it?” Rio’s voice came from behind Agatha.

 

“I love it.” Agatha turned her head. Rio had kicked her shoes off by the door and was setting her duffle down gently. 

 

Agatha let the weight fall off her shoulder and set her own bag down next to Rio’s.

 

“Allegedly, like, a trillion years ago she and Lilia went on some witch cult retreat and tripped absolute balls on shrooms. Lilia swears the lake spoke to her and told her to tell Sybil to buy property here. And obviously Sybil took that completely seriously.”

 

 “That tracks.”

 

“Right?” Rio moved past her toward the kitchen, moving like she belonged there. “She considered Atlantic City, but said it was too noisy- spiritually and otherwise.”

 

“God forbid.”

 

Rio grinned. “She’s in Portugal right now.”

 

“Of course she is,” Agatha said, exhaling. “Parading barefoot through a vineyard, yelling about sacred geometry to a man who doesn’t care.”

 

“Probably seducing him too.”

 

Agatha snorted. “Disgusting.”

 

She glanced down at their bags, then at the hallway that led to the bedrooms. Before this morning, she’d figured they’d be sharing a room. That had been the assumption. Now she wasn’t sure. She didn’t want to ask, didn’t want to assume anything. Especially not now.

 

Rio leaned against the counter, watching her. “Wanna sit on the dock for a little?”

 

Agatha nodded, her voice quieter than before. “Yeah. Sure.”

 

She followed Rio toward the door, unsure whether the ache in her ribs was something she’d carried in, or something the house had reached in and touched.

 

As they stepped out onto the porch and started down the stairs, Agatha spotted a blue heeler tearing up the long gravel driveway at full speed- barking, ears back, paws kicking up dust. 

 

Agatha halted, one foot hovering above the next step, already calculating if she had enough time to turn and sprint back inside before she could get mauled by a fucking farm dog. 

 

“Jasper!” Rio called, bright and unbothered, picking up speed as she took the steps two at a time, speeding up to meet the dog at the bottom.

 

Right. So the dog was friendly. Probably.

 

A faded baby blue truck followed up the drive behind him -old and sun worn, rattled more than it drove- but Agatha barely glanced at it.

 

Her eyes were on Rio.

 

Always on Rio.

 

When Rio hit the gravel, she dropped to her knees, and the dog crashed into her- barking, spinning, licking her face with all the energy in the world. She laughed. Giggled, even. Stupid and bright and real.

 

Agatha stared, helpless. She wanted to kiss her. Right there. Dog breath and all. It didn’t matter. Nothing mattered except the sound of her laugh and the curve of her smile.

 

She’d fucked everything up. So bad. And now she just stood there, hands useless at her sides, watching Rio- because what else could she do?

 

Her throat tightened. She wanted to cry. She wanted to throw up. She hoped Wanda’s plane got stuck on the runway forever with no air conditioning and a child behind her screaming and kicking the seat.

 

“Vidal!”

 

The voice was unfamiliar. Agatha blinked, tore her eyes away from Rio, and finally noticed the woman climbing out of the truck and walking straight toward her.

 

“Charlie!” Rio shouted, too excited for Agatha’s liking.

 

Agatha watched her jog across the gravel, meeting the woman halfway, arms already out. Then they were hugging.

 

Not a polite hug.

 

A real one.

 

Agatha narrowed her eyes, the back of her neck going hot. Rio hadn’t looked that relaxed all morning.

 

What kind of fuckery is this?

 

The woman had curly red hair under a crooked baseball cap. Messy, effortless, unfairly good. Better than her ex-wife’s, not that it mattered. 

 

She was wearing pinstriped pants and a cut up band tee, one side tucked in like she hadn’t meant to but left it anyway. Rings on nearly every finger. A bunch of layered necklaces that didn’t match, but somehow made sense. The hat looked stolen from a gas station. 

 

The whole look screamed I don’t try that hard and I still look better than you.

 

Agatha moved before she could think too hard about it. Bolted down the steps, cut across the gravel.

 

“Hello!” Agatha said, loud and pointless, stepping right into the middle of whatever the fuck was happening. Both women turned to look at her.

 

Good.

 

Let them look.

 

“Who’s this?” Charlie asked. Her voice was raspy and confident and instantly fucking irritating. Or maybe just irritating to Agatha.

 

“Who are you?” Agatha shot back, not bothering to soften it.

 

Charlie blinked, then gave an easy smile. She glanced at Rio and muttered, “Sheesh,” under her breath, clearly entertained.

 

Rio rolled her eyes, tone light. “Agatha, this is Charlie. She lives down the road, keeps an eye on the place when Sybil’s off doing Sybil things.”

 

Charlie gave a small nod. “I’m the unofficial groundskeeper and the highly recommended weed dealer. Sybil and Rio keep me in business.”

 

Rio huffed out a laugh. Agatha clenched her teeth.

 

Rio pressed on, eyes flicking between them. “Charlie, this is Agatha.”

 

Rio paused for just a second too long. Looked right at Agatha before turning back to Charlie.

 

“My very best friend, Agatha.”

 

Okay. Maybe Agatha deserved that. Fine. She gets it.

 

Because It hurts. It fucking hurts to be called that when it’s so clearly not the whole truth.

 

Agatha’s an asshole. The biggest fucking asshole. And she regrets every single time she ever threw that term at Rio like it didn’t matter. Like it wasn’t loaded.

 

Charlie laughed. “Ahh, okay, that tracks. When Sybil said Rio was coming up here and bringing someone, I thought I was hallucinating. Rio Vidal? Settling down? Dating someone? Yeah, right.”

 

Agatha gave her the tightest fucking smile she could manage. She was about five seconds from tearing this woman’s throat out with her teeth. 

 

Charlie and Rio kept talking. Laughing. Something about garden pests or deer or fuck knows. Agatha couldn’t hear a thing over the ringing in her ears.

 

Then Charlie shoved at Rio’s arm -playfully, familiarly- and Rio laughed, full body, head tipped back, the gap between her teeth showing. Charlie’s hand landed on Rio’s shoulder and stayed there.

 

Agatha saw white.

 

“We fuck!” Agatha blurted.

 

Loud. Too loud. It came out before she could stop it, and the second it left her mouth, a whole flock of birds exploded out of the trees. 

 

Both women snapped their heads to look at Agatha, eyes wide, like she had fired off a gun into the air. The silence that followed stretched long enough to make her want to crawl into the ground and die.

 

Perfect.

 

Agatha cleared her throat, tried to act like that hadn’t just exploded out of her. “Me and Rio,” she said, a little stiffly. “We… yeah.”

 

Rio looked stunned. Charlie looked entertained, still grinning, her hand very much still on Rio’s shoulder.

 

“Ah. Got it,” Charlie said, drawing out the words. “So, like… friends with benefits?”

 

“We’re not friends,” Agatha snapped, before she could stop herself. “We’re-“ She glanced at Rio, who was just staring at her now, eyebrows up like she couldn’t wait to hear how this ended. “It’s complicated,” Agatha muttered, finally, wiping her nose with the back of her hand. “So that means…” She gestured vaguely to Charlie’s hand. “Paws off.”

 

Charlie smirked, stepping back with both hands lifted. “Alright. Message received.”

 

Rio was staring down at the ground now, mouth pulled tight like she was trying not to laugh, and Agatha could feel her ears burning.

 

“Well, I just came to say hi. Rio, good seeing you. Agatha, pleasure. And good luck with…” Charlie gestured between them, “…whatever this is.”

 

“Eat my ass,” Agatha said, deadpan.

 

Charlie barked a laugh and patted Rio lightly on the arm as she turned. “I like her, Vidal. Feisty. Try not to screw it up.”

 

“Oh, believe me,” Rio said, under her breath, “I’m not the one screwing it up.”

 

Charlie just gave a wave and called out, “Jasper!” The blue heeler tore across the gravel from wherever he’d disappeared, already barking and lined up to leap into the truck before the door even opened.

 

As Charlie drove off, gravel kicking up behind her ugly truck, Agatha turned to Rio and snapped, “I’m sorry, okay?”

 

Then, softer. “I’m really sorry.”

 

And it wasn’t just about Wanda. It was about everything. About the way she’d said the wrong thing too many times, the way she’d acted like it didn’t matter when it clearly did. She didn’t even know what part she was apologizing for. 

 

She just wanted Rio to look at her the way she had when she woke Agatha up this morning. She wanted to be back in Rio’s bed. Wanted her mouth. Her hands. Wanted Rio, fully, without the ache of this in-between place they kept landing in.

 

Rio didn’t say anything right away. Just watched her, careful and quiet, then finally gave a small nod. “I know.” Then Rio reached out her hand. “Come on.”

 

Agatha didn’t hesitate. She took it, tangled their fingers together, and let Rio lead her toward the dock.

 

And somehow, just holding Rio’s hand made it easier to breathe.

Chapter 9: lover, you should've come over

Chapter Notes
