See the end of the chapter for more notes

The dock reached across the water like a held out hand- sun bleached, splinterless, too perfect. The lake below barely stirred, all glassy surface and small betrayals of wind that never quite made it ashore. Trees lined the far shore like sentries, branches curling inward, as if they, too, were leaning in to listen.

 

They sat at the edge in silence.

 

Rio’s skin looked warmer out here, her hair pinned back, and her sunglasses pushed onto her head. Her legs dangled over the side, toes skimming the surface. 

 

Agatha sat beside her, legs pulled to her chest, arms wrapped tight around them. Her chin rested on her knees. She didn’t know what to do with her hands. Or her mouth. Or any of the thousand thoughts buzzing through her.

 

“I’m not good at this part,” Agatha said, breaking the silence. “The whole… having a conversation where I don’t pretend everything’s fine.”

 

Rio’s voice is quiet, “Try.”

 

“I’m not-” Agatha’s voice catches. She tries again. “I don’t have anything to say.”

 

Rio’s voice is so even it makes her nauseous. “Why were you so angry?”

 

Agatha laughs under her breath, bitter. “Take a wild guess.”

 

“I want to hear you say it.”

 

“No, you don’t.”

 

“I do.”

 

“What was Wanda talking about at the bowling alley?” Agatha shot back.

 

She asked because she knew Rio wouldn’t answer. That was the point.

 

This version of Rio was harder to outrun. So Agatha reached for the instincts that had always protected her. A quick jab, a change of subject, a question she didn’t want answered. Anything to drag them back into a language she understood, where silence counted as control and no one had to say what they meant.

 

It wasn’t fair.

 

But it was familiar. And familiarity, even at its worst, had always felt safer than hope.

 

Rio finally looked at her, and for a flicker of a moment, she looked caught, like she hadn’t expected Agatha to aim there, not so directly.

 

Her mouth parted. Then closed again. Her jaw tensed, throat working around whatever answer she wouldn’t give. She turned back toward the lake, eyes cast low, lashes fluttering. Her grip on the dock edge tightened- quiet, controlled, but Agatha saw it. The strain in her knuckles. The flush rising on her cheeks… Rio looked embarrassed.

 

“It’s not important,” Rio said, her voice barely carrying. She said it to the water. Not to Agatha.

 

Bingo.

 

“That’s not fair,” Agatha said, too quickly. “You can’t ask me to sit here and try, and then pull that.”

 

Rio let out a short huff, a sound that might’ve been a laugh, but came out bitter and hollow. “We’ve never been fair to each other.”

 

She said it simply. Not as an excuse, but as fact. As if to say, ‘ I see what you’re doing. And I’m not going to play along.’

 

Rio saw straight through Agatha. That much was expected. She had long since run out of disguises Rio couldn’t see past. What actually unsettled Agatha was that Rio didn’t follow her into the space she had created. She didn’t take the bait or meet her where it was safe and familiar.

 

She was giving Agatha the honest result of a dishonest question, leaving her to rot alone in the echo of her own avoidance. 

 

Agatha clenched her jaw. “Right.”

 

Rio didn’t speak right away. Just sat there, still as ever, watching the water move.

 

“I came back.”

 

Agatha turned fully toward her. “You- what are you talking about?”

 

The words flew from her mouth fast. She said it without thinking, but the second she heard Rio say that her stomach dropped.

 

Agatha had a feeling this was the moment right before the raft she’d been floating on for years gave out. The one she’d patched, ignored, convinced herself would hold. She could feel it splitting underneath her. And all that water was about to come rushing in.

 

Rio’s jaw tightened. Teeth half bared, like she was daring herself to keep going. The noise she made was almost a laugh, except it sounded like it hurt coming out.

 

“The night we said goodbye in your kitchen-”

 

“Rio.”

 

Agatha cut her off. No reason, except that the truth was circling like sharks in the water, and she suddenly wanted to throw up.

 

Rio looked at her. Lip caught in her teeth, brow slightly drawn, torn between saying it and protecting them both from what might come next.

 

Agatha’s hand found Rio’s thigh. Her fingers dug in, not gently, but to anchor herself to the present so that maybe it could keep the past from rewriting itself.

 

“Wanda answered the door,” Rio said, quietly. “And, uh… said you were in the shower.” She looked away. Her hand reached for the back of her neck, tugged once, then dropped to cover Agatha’s.

 

Agatha had been in the shower. She remembered because she had queued Back to Black’s entire tracklist on full volume like it was a war hymn. She had just wanted to mourn and cry without an audience, which was ambitious considering her then wife was in the next room and pretending not to notice that her spouse was openly having a breakdown to Amy Winehouse.

 

At the time, she had told herself it was heartbreak. Normal, platonic, I’m-losing-my-best-friend-to-the-abyss-of-time heartbreak. Not the other kind. Not the kind that might’ve been avoidable if either of them had just said one honest thing out loud.

 

Agatha had spent years convincing herself there was nothing to be embarrassed about. That Rio had walked away, and she’d let her. It wasn’t a tragedy- only what happened when someone doesn’t want you and you finally believe them.

 

Except now Rio was sitting here saying no, actually. It was a tragedy. Just a very quiet one.

 

“You came back?” Agatha whispered. The words didn’t feel real even as she said them, but the desperation that laced through every one rang loud and clear.

 

Rio’s eyes flicked up to meet hers, and there was no room left to pretend. She gave the smallest, tightest smile, and a little hum caught in her throat.

 

Agatha shook her head, quick. “No.”



It came out all breath. This wasn’t how the story went. It couldn’t be. She needed Rio to say she was wrong. That she’d misunderstood. That this was actually just some bitter, elaborate twist- one final joke played by a universe that never seemed to get tired of making one out of them.

 

Rio gave her a look so tender it hurt. It held no defense, only apology. Not for what she was saying now, but for rewriting the version of them Agatha had protected for so long. For not keeping it safe.

 

“I sat in the parking lot for a while,” Rio said quietly. “I told myself to leave. Over and over. I tried. But the second I put the car into drive, something in me fought it. My whole body felt wrong-”

 

“Like gravity had broken,” Agatha whispered, cutting her off.

 

The words came without thinking, pulled from somewhere deep and buried. She hadn’t thought about them in years, hadn’t even let herself revisit that night with any real honesty. But she remembered the sensation so clearly now… the hard pull in her chest as Rio walked out the door, the way the world tilted, the way nothing had felt right after.

 

“Yeah,” Rio breathed out.

 

‘After our last conversation, when you slunked off with your tail tucked. ’ Wanda’s words echoed in Agatha’s ears, sickening now in what little context she had been given.

 

And it left Agatha burning. Anger. Theft. Something that had been stolen from Agatha before she even realized it was hers.

 

“What did she say to you?” Agatha asked.

 

Rio’s mouth opened, then closed again. She shook her head, frustrated. “It doesn’t matter. You were married and I was a fucking idiot to even-” She cut herself off, looked away, pressed her fingers hard to the bridge of her nose. She inhaled deeply, like she was trying to shove the rest of it, then turned back to Agatha. Her face was tight. Her voice came out through clenched teeth. “It’s fucking humiliating, okay?”

 

“I don’t care. I want to know.”

 

“What difference does it make now, Agatha? I was a coward. I let her say something I should’ve ignored- and look at what it did to us. Look at what we became!” Rio said, voice breaking on the words. “It’s taken us seventeen years to get here. What someone said to me a decade ago isn’t going to change that.” 

 

“I’m sorry- do you think you can just drop something like that and move on? Ten years, Rio. I thought you left. I thought I let you leave. Do you understand how fucking insane that is?”

 

Rio’s head snapped toward her, eyes dark. “She said you called me deadweight. That I was some obsessive freak you kept around out of guilt. That people who actually care don’t choke on the truth for years. And if I actually gave a fuck, I’d stop showing up just to dump all my mental garbage on you.”  

 

Agatha jerked back, eyes wide.

 

The idea that Rio had believed it -that Agatha would ever say something like that, to Wanda of all people- made her stomach turn. That Rio had been walking around with that version of Agatha, for years, made her want to crawl out of her own skin.

 

Agatha would have bitten through her own tongue before giving Wanda anything real about Rio, especially something so cruel.

 

Wanda had never understood Rio. She hadn’t needed to. All it took was one slip. Agatha going still for half a second too long when Rio’s name came up and Wanda locked onto it.  From then on, it was constant. Weird. Possessive. Like Rio had pissed all over her territory once and Wanda could smell it years later. There became this conviction that Rio had touched something in Agatha that Wanda never could.

 

And maybe Wanda wasn’t wrong.

 

But just because Wanda had seen it didn’t mean Agatha admitted it. She hadn’t. She’d denied it so thoroughly, called her paranoid, delusional, jealous. 

 

But that was the problem, wasn’t it?

 

Nothing had happened. No kiss. No confession. No proof. Just silence and tension and whatever lived in the space between. There was nothing Wanda could point to, and Agatha made sure to keep it that way. 

 

Any time it came up, Agatha saw white and would lash out. And Wanda, always so sure of herself, took that as proof. She mistook Agatha’s fury for confession, when really it was the opposite.

 

Wanda gave them so much weight. Too much credit for what it actually was. She talked about it like Agatha had actually gotten to have Rio. Like the thing Agatha wanted most had been real enough to ruin.

 

But it wasn’t. It never was.

 

Everyone else seemed so sure she’d had Rio when all Agatha ever did was want her.

 

Now Rio thought she’d handed her over to Wanda like a secret worth selling.

 

That was worse than any of it. That was the part Agatha couldn’t stomach.

 

“And you believed her?” Agatha asked, horrified.

 

“You were fucking her. How could I not?” Rio muttered. 

 

Fucking.

 

That was all Rio saw it as. An entire chapter of Agatha’s life, reduced to one single, contemptuous word. 

 

And yet, some sick part of Agatha liked it. She found it obscenely attractive that Rio boiled her whole marriage down to something crude and forgettable. That even saying ex-wife would’ve made it sound more important than it ever was.

 

But Agatha digresses. 

 

The point is, she chose Wanda. She built a life with her. And in doing so, she stopped being Rio’s person. And to top it off,  Rio believed that she went and sold whatever they did have -regardless of how incomplete- to the fucking devil.

 

Valid , Agatha supposed.

 

“Well I’m telling you now. Whether you think it still matters or not… I never fucking said that about you. Ever. Especially not to her.”

 

“I know that now.” Rio’s voice dipped, almost petulant. 

 

Agatha watched Rio try not to squirm.

 

She could tell Rio hated admitting it at all, embarrassed that she had believed it in the first place. 

 

“How long did it take you to figure that out?” Agatha asked. What she meant was: how long did you think I was capable of something like that.

 

Rio looked down, rubbed the heel of her palm over her thigh. “A while.”

 

“How long is a while?”

 

“I don’t know.” Rio exhaled slowly, eyes on the water. “I was angry for a long time. It felt easier than being confused. And I already felt… lost, I guess.” Rio swallowed hard. “Like I didn’t know who I was when you weren’t looking at me.”

 

The air stilled. There was no self pity in her voice. Only fact. As if she’d accepted a truth she couldn’t outgrow. 

 

Rio started to fidget with Agatha’s fingers, which still rested against her thigh, tugging gently.

 

“I always felt so at war with everything,” Rio said, quieter now. “I thought staying still was safer. I thought that was me trying.” She glanced at Agatha quickly then, almost sheepish. “Obviously it backfired.”

 

Agatha heard her heart shatter, clean and sharp, like glass on tile.

 

“I tried. I tried to show you I was- God, I don’t know- actually interested. I even-” Agatha broke off, breath catching. “I tried to kiss you. Do you remember that? Because I do. You looked at me like I’d set the room on fire.”

 

All the signs had been there. Rio looking at her mouth, not with a teasing glint, but with something quieter, something almost afraid. And Agatha, stupid, hopeful, starving for it, hadn’t pulled away. So Agatha had leaned in. Let her nose graze Rio’s cheek. Let herself feel the warmth of her breath, let herself believe, just for a second, that all the circling, all the almosts, all the years of aching tension had finally, finally led to that moment.

 

Agatha had let herself believe she wasn’t alone in it.

 

And then Rio had pulled her head back and those wide, terrified brown eyes were locked on Agatha like she had just broken something forever. So Agatha had left. Immediately. With haste. Never turned around, not even when she heard Rio call after her.

 

It was humiliating -spectacularly, irreversibly humiliating- and Agatha did what any sane person would do: shoved the memory into the furthest corner of her brain, slammed the door, and pretended it never happened. Ideally, it should’ve stayed there forever, gathering dust next to every other brilliant decision she’d ever made. 

 

“You think I forgot? That I didn’t think about it every night for months?” Rio asked, defensive. 

 

“How would I have known that, Rio? We never talked about anything. You could’ve said something. Literally anything and you didn’t.”

 

“You met someone the next day.”

 

Wanda .

 

Agatha shook her head. “No. That’s not fair.”

 

“You gave up before I even had the chance to say anything,” Rio said, frustrated. “I went after you, Agatha. And you didn’t stop long enough to look back.”

 

“I didn’t give up,” Agatha snapped. “I got tired of waiting for someone who didn’t have the balls to want me back.” The words came too fast, too loud. She hated how breathless she sounded. Hated that she was even talking about this. “I waited for you,” She said, harsher now. Her face flushed hot, shame hitting right behind anger. “You have no idea how long I waited for you.” It slipped out quieter, like the fight had gone out of it but not the disbelief. Not the anger curled tight in her chest, still burning from shit that happened over a decade ago.

 

Agatha had waited. Pathetically. Furious with herself. Even when she was someone else’s wife. Even in a life she’d built without Rio in it. She waited. For Rio to knock, to call, to barge in uninvited and say it - ‘ Sorry I’m late’ - like she had in the bowling alley. Like nothing had changed. Like everything had.

 

From the moment Agatha met Rio, her life had split clean down the middle. Not by years. Not by cities. Not by marriage. By her. There was before Rio, and there was after. And Agatha had spent every moment since trying, and failing, to pretend that wasn’t true.

 

Agatha looked Rio dead in the eye.

 

“And you gave me nothing.” 

 

Rio blinked. Her face didn’t change, not really, but her hand tensed ever so slightly over Agatha’s. Then: 

 

“You never let me.”

 

It wasn’t a defense. It wasn’t even angry. It was soft. Broken in places. 

 

Agatha turned away, eyes fixed on the lake. Her jaw was tight, her chest was still burning, but she didn’t move her hand from where it rested on Rio’s thigh.

 

They just sat there, still tethered. Wrecked. Holding on, even now, to what neither of them had the language for a decade ago.

 

“I’m so sorry.” Rio whispered. “I didn’t mean for it to feel that way.”

 

“I’m sorry too. That was a shitty thing to say,” Agatha said, not looking at her. “I’m sorry… for all of it. I know I made it hard.”

 

It wasn’t just about the events of the day. It was everything before that too- how she ran, how she waited without ever saying it, how she made herself impossible to reach. 

 

They’d both ruined it, in different ways. Rio had been too scared to move and Agatha had never stopped running, even when she wanted to. They both had blood on their hands. Different mistakes, same loss.

 

“Will you look at me?” Rio asked, barely above a whisper.

 

Agatha didn’t look away from the water- still, sunlit, unbothered. If she turned now, the salt behind her eyes might spill into it, and she couldn’t bear to muddy something that calm.

 

She felt Rio’s hand slip away from hers.

 

Agatha almost pulled back on instinct, but didn’t. Not when Rio shifted closer, not when her hands gently cradled Agatha’s face and turned her toward her.

 

“Agatha, I…”

 

Agatha’s eyes slammed shut, and her hand flew to Rio’s wrist- reflexive, trembling. She already knew what was about to be said. What Rio meant. What had been sitting between them for nearly two decades, untouched.

 

But Rio didn’t say it.

 

Instead, her thumb brushed softly across Agatha’s cheek, and she leaned in, barely breathing the words:

 

“Won’t you just let me?”

 

Agatha opened her eyes. 

 

“Yeah,” she breathed.

 

She heard Rio’s breath catch, the smallest hitch like she hadn’t expected the answer so easily. Her voice caught a little when she said it back, almost laughing through it. “Yeah?”

 

Agatha nodded. “Yes.” She was already leaning in before she finished saying it.

 

Her lips found Rio’s without apology- mouth open, breathing against her, catching and pulling and chasing. 

 

Rio kissed her back instantly, hands framing her face. She tilted her head and pressed deeper, matching every movement with one of her own. 

 

They kissed like they’d been interrupted a million times and this was the first time no one was going to stop them.

 

Agatha let her hand fall from Rio’s wrist and slid it around her back, pressing her closer until their bodies were as flush as they could be sitting on the dock. She felt Rio’s chest press against hers with each breath, every inhale a little shakier than the last.

 

Tongues slid together, again and again, mouths breaking and returning, as if they hadn’t been allowed to miss each other but had anyway. Her hand slid up Rio’s spine, slow, deliberate, just to feel the way she breathed.

 

And Agatha didn’t know how long they stayed like that, hands wandering, mouths meeting in that same soft rhythm over and over. She only knew the sun was setting- bleeding color into the lake, staining the sky with gold and pink and orange so rich it didn’t look real. She only knew the light caught in Rio’s hair, in the lines of her face, in the corners of her eyes when she opened her own between kisses, just to be sure it was all still there. It was. Rio was. She was.

 

She wasn’t thinking about what would come after. She wasn’t thinking about what they were, or what they weren’t. She wasn’t bracing herself for an inevitable ending.

 

She was just kissing Rio. Still, for what felt like the first time. 

 

And the sun was setting.

They had made out on the dock for what felt like hours, tangled in some pathetic imitation of a romcom Agatha would have rolled her eyes at if it weren’t happening to her. The whole thing had been stupid. Or sweet. Or both. Agatha hadn’t decided yet.

 

At one point, they’d tried walking across the length of the dock with Agatha’s feet planted on top of Rio’s. Her back against Rio’s chest. Rio’s chin hooked over her shoulder and her arms around Agatha’s waist. Giggling like idiots. Testing how many steps they could manage that way, drunk on nothing but each other. They made it a few clumsy steps before Agatha called it, breathless from laughing, too warm, too aware of the way Rio hesitated before letting go.

 

Now they were standing on the porch, each with a cigarette in hand. Rio had Connections pulled up on her phone, the screen tilted slightly toward Agatha, who was tucked into her side, shoulder against her, quietly looking on.

 

“You’re just clicking things,” Agatha said, smoke curling from her lips as she leaned in closer, not bothering to hide her amusement.

 

“I’m following my instincts,” Rio muttered, eyes narrowed at the grid.

 

“You’re guessing,” Agatha said.

 

Rio shrugged with one shoulder. “Same thing.”

 

Agatha hummed and brought her cigarette to her mouth. Rio got another group wrong, grumbled under her breath, then locked the screen and set the phone down on the railing beside the ashtray.

 

“You’re bad at that game,” Agatha said, almost gently.

 

“You were distracting me,” Rio said as she reached for the hem of Agatha’s shirt and tugged.

 

Agatha stepped in front of her without a word. She took a final drag of her cigarette, stubbed it out in the ashtray next to Rio, then took one more small step forward, closing the space between their bodies.

 

“Distracting you?” Agatha said, voice low. “That’s the excuse you’re going with?”

 

Rio took a slow drag from her own cigarette, hummed and nodded, and turned her head to exhale. When she looked back at Agatha, her eyes were steady.

 

“You’re very pretty,” Rio said simply, and one arm slid around Agatha’s waist, holding her there.

 

“You think calling me pretty is going to make up for how bad you are at that game?” Agatha asked.

 

“It should,” Rio said. “Because I’m sweet.”

 

Agatha huffed under her breath, but she didn’t pull away. Her fingers had found the collar of Rio’s shirt, idle and unthinking.

 

Just as she was about to open her mouth to respond, a dog barked in the distance.

 

Jasper. 

 

And suddenly, she was remembering how familiar Rio and Charlie had seemed. Charlie’s hand resting on Rio’s shoulder. The way she’d laughed too easily. The way it had made perfect sense for her to assume Agatha was just a friend.

 

Agatha’s jaw clenched before she could stop it.

 

When she looked back at Rio, she had her cigarette raised to her mouth, eyes narrowed- not in confusion, but like she was waiting. Like she wanted Agatha to ask.

 

Agatha pressed her tongue into her cheek, looked away, then back at Rio. Her chin tipped up slightly. “You told me you didn’t bring other women here.”

 

Rio didn’t answer right away. She turned just enough to stub out her cigarette, but her arm stayed where it was, resting around Agatha’s waist like it belonged there.

 

“She lives down the road.” Rio said. “You made a hell of a first impression.”

 

Agatha already knew that. And Rio knew she knew.

 

Fine. She’d spell it out.

 

“Have you fucked her?”

 

“No.”

 

Agatha nodded once, slow. “Good,” she said. “Because that would’ve made you a liar.”

 

“And what would that make you?”

 

“Drop it,” Agatha muttered.

 

“No.” Rio’s hand slipped under the hem of her shirt, nails dragging slow down the curve of her lower back. “Say it,” she whispered.

 

Agatha looked at her. Jaw tight. Mouth set. Furious at how much she felt.

 

“You want me to say I was jealous?”

 

Rio said nothing.

 

“Fine. I didn’t like her touching you.” Agatha rolled her eyes. “Happy now?”

 

Rio pulled her lip between her teeth, shook her head slightly. The smugness was gone. The momentum shifted. And Agatha suddenly felt like she was standing on the edge of something else entirely.

 

Shit.

 

She didn’t move. Didn’t breathe. Just stared at Rio’s face, waiting for it.

 

Rio’s hand stayed right where it was, low on her back, thumb brushing once against bare skin like a quiet warning.

 

Then, softly- 

 

“I’d like to know what happened this morning.”

 

Agatha didn’t pretend not to understand.

 

“I didn’t ask before,” Rio continued, eyes steady. “But I want to know.”

 

Agatha inhaled. “She kissed me.”

 

She felt Rio’s fingers press harder into her back, firm, like she was holding herself in place.

 

“I didn’t stop it right away,” Agatha said. “It lasted two seconds. Maybe less. And I shoved her off.”

 

“You kissed her back?”

 

Agatha winced. “Barely.”

 

The word hung there. She hated how small it sounded.

 

“We were arguing. I was pissed. I don’t know-” Agatha exhaled, short and hot. “I think I let it happen because some part of me wanted to ruin this. All of it.”

 

“Why?” Rio whispered.

 

Agatha let out a bitter breath. “Because that’s what I do.” She shook her head. “You said it yourself- I make myself impossible to reach. I shut down, run, and then get pissed when you don’t come after me.”

 

Rio’s voice was quiet. “I never said that.”

 

“You didn’t have to,” Agatha glanced past her, out at the lake, jaw tight. “You know it’s true.”

 

Rio didn’t say anything.

 

“I felt out of control. With you. And for half a second, it felt easier to ruin it than deal with what it actually meant.” She met Rio’s eyes again. “But I stopped it. I didn’t want her. I wanted you. I’ve always wanted you.”

 

Rio’s eyes were darker now. They dropped to Agatha’s mouth, then lingered.

 

When her gaze lifted again, slow and deliberate, Agatha felt her stomach flip.

 

“Okay, Agatha,” Rio said, voice low, nodding.

 

Agatha’s mouth went dry. “Okay?”

 

Rio slipped her hand out from under Agatha’s shirt. Reached up. Found Agatha’s wrists still resting against her chest and wrapped her fingers around them, gently pulling them away.

 

Then she stepped to the side.

 

Laced their hands together.

 

And without saying another word, guided Agatha inside.

 

-

 

Rio led them inside, grabbing only her duffle on the way. Agatha didn’t say anything. Words felt useless now. She just followed, pulse high, throat tight.

 

She let Rio guide her down the hallway and into a bedroom.

 

The bedroom was dark, lit only by the silver spill of moonlight through the window. Rio dropped her bag near the door, then brought Agatha to the center of the room. She let go of her hand and turned away, kneeling to dig through the duffle.

 

Agatha stood where she was, breath shallow, nerves buzzing. She didn’t look at the room. She didn’t need to.

 

Rio pulled something out, tossed it onto the bed, and turned to face her.

 

Then she started undressing.

 

And Agatha understood.

 

She reached for the hem of her shirt and tugged it over her head, let it fall to the floor. Her fingers slid behind her back. She unhooked her bra, slipped it off, and dropped it with the rest. She unbuttoned her jean shorts. Pushed them down.

Chapter 10: doomsday

Chapter Notes

Meant to say this last chapter, but apologies to any locals of the Garden State as the version of New Jersey I've depicted in this fic is probably not entirely biblically accurate.

Here’s the link to the Pinterest board I made for this, if you want to check it out: https://pin.it/4472qG25I

Good luck. This chapter will rot your teeth🧍‍♀️

See the end of the chapter for more notes

“You’re staring,” Agatha mumbled, her voice thick with sleep.

 

Her eyes stayed closed. She didn’t need to see the look on Rio’s face to know it was there- soft, stupid, probably smug. She could feel it in the way Rio’s body pressed into hers, warm and bare and close. Her arm was flung over Agatha’s waist like she was trying to keep her there. Sometime in the middle of the night, Agatha had woken up to Rio pressed tight and her breath warm against the back of Agatha’s neck. She might’ve pretended to still be asleep if Rio hadn’t been grazing soft fingertips up the slope of her stomach. “Oh yeah?” she asked, a little breathless, despite herself.

Agatha stood on the porch facing the lake, elbows resting on the railing. Her coffee was perched beside her, steam curling lazily into the morning air, and a cigarette balanced between her fingers as she alternated between sipping and smoking. The light off the water was too bright, the quiet too suspicious. The house sat raised on a slope, built into the hill above the shoreline.

 

Rio had disappeared down the stairs nearly twenty minutes ago, to dig around in the storage area, claiming she needed “a thing.” That was all the explanation Agatha got. She hadn’t pressed. “That’s totally fine,” Rio said, nodding.

 

“Wonderful,” Agatha replied, her voice clipped.

 

“Great,” Rio returned.

 

“Fucking spectacular,” Agatha muttered.

As she moved down the dock, she pulled the cap over her head, adjusting it with one hand. Without turning around, she added, “Also cigarettes and something that won’t bore me to death.”

 

Rio’s reply came fast. “Aye aye, Captain.”

She dropped into the empty chair at the end of the dock and let herself sink into it with an exaggerated huff. Crossing her arms tightly, she pulled the cap lower over her eyes like a curtain.

Rio had returned earlier, barefoot and smug, with a fresh cup of coffee in one hand. Between her fingers that held the cup, she had Agatha’s old purple lighter and a pack of American Spirits. Under her arm was a crossword puzzle book with only a few pages filled in, and she had a dull pencil tucked between her teeth. She didn’t say anything, just handed Agatha the coffee first, then the cigarettes and lighter, then set the crossword and pencil in her lap.

Now Rio kissed her on the cheek in broad daylight and went back to rigging a purple rubber worm like they were an old married couple who did this every summer.

 

All she could do was sit there for a moment longer than necessary, staring at the carton of cigarettes in her hand as she tried not to let herself sit in that thought too long. She blinked, pulled the cigarette free, lit it with her old lighter, took a long drag, and stared out at the lake instead.

 

The bait situation, at least, was less offensive than expected. Agatha had been braced for worms. Actual, wriggling, nightmare fuel worms. But Rio, apparently, had the decency -or the self-preservation- to use soft plastics instead. Some kind of fake worm, rubbery and purple with flecks of glitter in it.

 

Agatha watched her thread it onto the hook with practiced fingers, rigged so it wouldn’t catch on the brush at the bottom, and tried very hard not to look impressed.

 

Now, Agatha was sunk into the chair with one foot tucked beneath her. A cigarette in one hand and the pencil in the other, the crossword book open across her legs. The ashtray and her coffee sat on the small table between the chairs, along with her lighter and the pack of Spirits. She wasn’t paying attention to the puzzle.

Rio hummed like that didn’t bother her at all. She reeled in a little, her eyes still on the water. She looked relaxed. Self satisfied. Stupidly pretty in the sun.

 

Agatha rolled her eyes. “Twelve across,” she said aloud, voice flat but just loud enough to carry. “‘Too bright. Four letters.’”

 

She knew the answer. She’d known it before she even finished reading it. She just wanted to hear Rio try. Wanted her to talk. Wanted to keep her voice in the air.

 

There was a pause. Agatha didn’t have to look to know what Rio was doing. She could picture the way Rio tilted her head, tongue pressed into the inside of her cheek, overthinking it.

 

“Flash?” Rio offered, casual.

 

Agatha made a noncommittal noise. “Four letters, babe. Try again.”

 

She glanced up as she said it and caught the exact moment Rio’s head turned -just slightly, not all the way- like she needed to make sure she’d heard that right. Agatha could see her ear, the edge of her jaw, nothing more. Rio didn’t say anything at first. She just turned back to the water and cast again, smoother this time.

 

“Noon,” Rio said, no hesitation. She could hear the small smile in Rio’s voice.

 

Agatha smirked to herself, took another drag, and filled it in without responding.

 

The rod tip twitched. Rio shifted her grip, reeled in a little quicker, muttering something under her breath that Agatha couldn’t make out.

 

“If you pull out a fish, I’m going inside,” Agatha said, blowing smoke from her lips as she kept her eyes on the page.

 

“If I pull out a fish,” Rio said, adjusting her stance, “you’re going to be extremely impressed and possibly a little turned on.”

She kept tension on the line, reeled in fast and steady, moved her feet to shift with it, and dragged the thing closer to the dock with her mouth set and eyes narrowed.

 

Agatha sat upright without meaning to.

 

The fish hit the deck of the dock with a heavy thud, tail slapping the boards once, twice, before Rio kneeled down and pinned it with one hand.

 

Rio looked up, grinning, out of breath and completely pleased with herself.

 

Agatha stared at the fish. Then at Rio. Then back at the fish.

 

She dropped the pencil into the open crossword book and reached into her pocket for her phone. Rio crouched over the flapping mess of a fish, muttering to herself as she worked the hook free. 

 

Agatha watched her fingers grip and adjust,  Rio pulled back slightly, avoiding a fresh spray of lake water to the face as the fish flopped aggressively.

 

“What is it?” Agatha asked, mildly horrified, though she didn’t look away.

 

Rio didn’t glance up. “Dinner eligible.”

 

Agatha rolled her eyes, stubbed out her cigarette in the tray, and opened the camera on her phone.

 

“It’s a bass,” Rio clarified, one hand now gripping the base of the fish’s tail, the other pinching its jaw open between thumb and forefinger. The damn thing was huge- thick through the middle, brown-green with a dull shimmer, and long enough that it nearly spanned the width of Rio’s torso.

Rio huffed -half amusement, half disbelief- and turned the fish to face Agatha. “You want to give it a kiss?”

Rio stood, fish still in hand, and looked back at her. “Admit it. You’re impressed.”

 

She tossed it back into the lake before Agatha could answer, the splash echoing across the water. When she turned again, she was smiling- broad and bright, cheeks high with satisfaction.

 

Agatha tried not to smile back. She failed. “Definitely wrong.”

 

“Mhm.” Rio stepped toward her.

 

Agatha sank back into her chair and kicked her leg out, bare foot stopping Rio mid step. 

 

“Rio.” A warning. 

 

Rio’s hands raised in mock surrender, but she didn’t stop. She only moved forward until her stomach pressed fully into Agatha’s foot. “I’ll let you decide,” Rio said, and the smirk blooming on her face was all edge, all intent, something so deeply familiar it could have broken Agatha apart. 

 

Rio wanted to play.

She kept going, dragging her foot lower until the ball of it pressed against Rio’s front, Agatha added just enough pressure to make a point.

“Or?” Agatha prompted.

 

“Or,” Rio repeated and leaned into Agatha’s foot slightly, voice dropping to something quieter. Something not meant for anyone but Agatha. “Go on a date with me tonight.” She paused, eyes still teasing, but there was something softer tucked under it now.

“I feel like I should say you do have the choice to say no and not get slimed. But I don’t want you to,” Rio added.

Rio’s eyebrows lifted slightly, her hands still hovering somewhere between flirtation and defense. She didn’t say anything else.

 

And Agatha- God, Agatha hated her.

 

She hated Rio so much in that moment she could barely hold herself still. Hated that Rio had the nerve to look at her like that, with fish slime probably still drying on her shirt, with that crooked little smile still warm from the sun and absolutely full of herself. She hated that Rio made her laugh. Made her smile without meaning to. Had made Agatha consider, even for one fucking second, that she would be happy for the rest of her miserable fucking life as long as Rio was standing in front of her.

 

And- well. She’ll deny it later. She’ll scrub it from her memory and pretend it never crossed her mind. She’ll push it back behind her ribs where it’s lived quietly for years, where it waits for her to acknowledge it and hopes she never will.

 

But this is the part Agatha never ever had the balls to admit- except to you. 

 

Yes, you.

 

You’ve been here this whole time, haven’t you? Sitting behind a screen, breath held, waiting to see how this would go. 

 

So let’s not lie to each other now.

Obviously.

 

It had been there for nearly two decades. Unnamed, unspoken, coiled beneath every conversation and every silence between them. She’d buried it until it built like sediment over the years, layer after layer, until you forget where it started and only know weight it leaves behind. Agatha had been carrying it forever, pretending she wasn’t.

 

And now, here it was. The thing Agatha had always refused to name, standing barefoot on a dock with lake water and fish slime dripping from her hands and asking, so plainly, for something Agatha could no longer pretend she didn’t want.

 

This part -no matter how much Agatha might try to rewrite it later- will always remain true.

 

Agatha blinked once. Hard. She could lie, if she wanted to. She was good at that. Could laugh it off. Could scoff and make some snide remark and go inside and pretend none of this ever happened.

 

But Rio Vidal was still here. Still standing. Still asking. Still trying. There was a slight indent where she bit against the inside of her cheek- barely noticeable, but Agatha knew it was there. Her brown eyes were wide, nervous, trying not to be.

 

And Agatha -despite herself, because of herself, maybe always for herself- was done pretending.

 

“I hate you,” Agatha breathed.

 

It came out so soft it barely qualified as a sentence. It had no venom behind it. No sarcasm. Just breath and longing disguised in old habits. It was full of everything she didn’t want to say and everything she couldn’t stop feeling.

 

It was so full of shit. And Agatha had never been any good at saying what she meant.

 

Rio’s face softened instantly, like she could feel every cracked open part of Agatha behind those words. There was something steady in her expression now, something tender. Something that had been waiting a long time. She lowered her hands.

 

“Go on a date with me, Agatha,” Rio said again, quieter this time. There was no teasing in it. No smirk. It wasn’t for her own sake anymore. She wasn’t asking to win. It wasn’t a performance.

 

It was just her. Just Rio.

 

Agatha opened her mouth, tried to speak, found nothing. Then she exhaled, “Why the hell not.” 

 

Rio smiled then- so wide she looked like she might combust, and then she tried to hide it, like she didn’t want to scare Agatha off. She nodded once, bit the corner of her lip like she needed somewhere to put her joy. Then she pointed at Agatha, squinted one eye like she was lining up a shot.

 

“Fishing impressed you,” Rio said. “You like fishing.”

 

Agatha almost choked. “Shut the fuck up.”

 

“No. I don’t think I will.”

 

“I will throw you in the lake.”

 

“No, you won’t,” Rio said, stepping in again.

 

Agatha didn’t stop her this time.

 

Rio knelt slowly in front of her, lowering herself with a sure confidence. She sat back on her heels and placed her hands gently on the armrests of Agatha’s chair. She didn’t lean forward. She didn’t reach. She just waited.

 

Agatha shifted forward until she was close enough to see every flicker of expression on Rio’s face. She reached out, brushing a piece of hair behind Rio’s ear, and felt her lean into her touch without hesitation. So Agatha slid her fingers back through her hair, threading it slowly until her hand rested at the base of Rio’s skull.

 

She tugged gently enough to pull a sound from Rio.

 

Rio laughed. Entirely breathless, delighted, wicked. 

 

“I won’t?” Agatha asked, her voice low.

 

Rio’s eyes narrowed, and she tilted her chin up just enough for their mouths to touch, for the softest press of their lips.

 

 “You won’t,” Rio muttered, against her lips.

 

Agatha felt her world tilt sideways.

 

“I won’t,” Agatha whispered back, and kissed her.

 

Rio responded with her whole body. Her lips parted instantly, a whimper fell from her mouth, her hands still gripping the arms of the chair like she might collapse without them. 

 

Agatha kissed Rio like she meant it, like she had never meant anything more. She brought her other hand up to Rio’s cheek. Tilted Rio’s head, controlled the depth, let her thumb press firmly into the hollow of her cheek, her other hand still tangled in Rio’s hair. 

 

She kissed Rio to claim her. To mark every inch of Rio’s mouth with her name.

 

Mine, Agatha thought.

 

They broke for air, their foreheads pressed together, chests rising with the same breath. Rio turned her head just enough to kiss the corner of Agatha’s mouth, then nodded like she was answering a question.

 

“Yours,” Rio whispered.

 

Then Rio’s mouth was everywhere- her cheek, her jaw, her throat, all the places Agatha had never known she so desperately needed to be kissed by Rio. Agatha closed her eyes and let her. Let Rio’s mouth find every inch. Let the truth live in that silence.

 

Rio kissed her way back up to her mouth, slow and firm, like she was steering Agatha into something that had always belonged to both of them. 

 

Agatha opened her eyes just long enough to let Rio see it. The answer was there. She nodded. It was all she could give. It was everything.

 

And maybe Rio could read her mind, or maybe Agatha had whispered it into her mouth. Maybe it was written across her skin by now. Maybe it had always been there.

 

It didn’t matter.

 

There was only one word left in her.

 

Rio.

 

-

 

Agatha had already showered. Now she was curled in the middle of the bed in an old, oversized t-shirt, legs tangled in the blankets, scrolling idly through the New York Times app on her phone, pretending she wasn’t waiting for the bathroom door to open.

 

She wasn’t entirely sure what they were doing tonight.

 

A date. It was a date. And Agatha, in her infinite wisdom and emotional grace, was handling that news with the calm, measured stability of someone not at all in denial.

 

Which meant she was refusing to think too hard about it. That was easier, honestly. Especially when she could convince herself that not much between them had really changed.

 

Sure, they were now having sex. With feelings, probably. Sort of.

 

But everything else was the same. Still Rio. Still Agatha. Still a connection between them that made sense in a way nothing else had in her entire life.

 

They could talk or not talk. Sit in silence. Fall asleep near each other. Bicker. Laugh. Touch. That had always been easy.

 

Now they were just fucking. That was the only new variable. And it had slotted itself in almost too easily.

 

So she wasn’t spiraling. Agatha was fine.

 

To keep herself from doing anything stupid -like thinking too hard about the outfit she’d already hung in the closet, the one she very deliberately packed a day ago under the guise of practicality- she focused instead on the NYT app, which had become her newest form of quiet masochism. She hadn’t brought that outfit because she thought she’d be going on a date. Obviously not. It was just... a possibility. Something she threw in last minute. Just in case.

 

Agatha had already played Wordle and had gotten it in three guesses. The Mini crossword had taken her longer than it should have, and she wasn’t proud of it. Now she was playing Spelling Bee, the game where they gave you seven letters in a little honeycomb and asked you to build as many words as you could out of them, always including the center letter. She’d made it to “Amazing,” but hadn’t reached “Genius,” and it was pissing her off more than she’d admit.

 

Still, it gave Agatha something to do while she waited for Rio to stop being attractive in a shower out of her line of sight.

 

The bathroom connected to this room and another, one of those weird Jack-and-Jill setups. Agatha had learned pretty quickly that neither room was meant for guests. Only Rio and Sage.

 

Which was all to say: Agatha very clearly heard the water shut off about ten minutes ago through the door and now Rio was brushing her teeth.

 

So when her phone buzzed and a notification banner popped up with Rio Vidal sent a photo, she barely reacted.

 

Probably a meme. Maybe even her Wordle score, though Agatha was pretty sure Rio hadn’t played yet.

 

Agatha tapped the notification open.

 

And she was immediately proven wrong.

 

So incredibly, devastatingly, violently wrong.

 

Agatha’s jaw slackened and the English language narrowed itself down to a very small pool of vocabulary, none of which she was proud of.

 

Boobs. Nipples. Boobs. Rio’s boobs. Nipples. Rio.

 

A picture of Rio’s chest. Just her chest. Just boobs. Perfectly, carelessly centered in the frame. The photo was angled slightly, Rio had one arm raised -brushing her teeth still, presumably- while the other held the phone out, snapping the picture. Her face wasn’t in it. Just skin. 

 

Shoulders. Collarbones. Boobs. Nipples. Naked.

 

Agatha could still hear Rio humming faintly, probably doing one of her annoying routines where she counted how long she brushed each quadrant of her mouth.

 

And here was Agatha, blinking down at a full screen, high quality image of Rio’s bare tits. Sent with zero context.

 

Her mouth watered and her pulse hammered like it had somewhere to be. 

 

Agatha had no idea how long she’d been ogling the photo. It could’ve been thirty seconds or five entire minutes; time had collapsed into one long, boiling loop of boobs, nipples, Rio. 

 

She was still staring -phone inches from her face- when the bathroom door creaked open. 

 

Agatha startled so hard she nearly threw the phone across the room. Instead, she slammed it facedown against her stomach like she’d been caught doing something illegal.

 

Which was ridiculous. Because Rio had sent the photo. Rio had started this.

 

But that didn’t matter now.

 

Rio walked out of the bathroom with a confidence that made Agatha want to scream. She was wrapped in a towel, skin still dewy from the shower, hair wet and tucked behind her ears. She looked radiant. Effortless. Unbothered. And when she looked over at Agatha and she greeted her with a single breathless, “Hey.”

 

Agatha didn’t respond. Couldn’t, really.

 

She was too busy tracking Rio’s every step to form a coherent thought. Rio crossed the room, made her way to her duffle bag near the dresser, and bent slightly as she unzipped it, digging through it. Agatha watched her pull out a worn t-shirt and underwear, then straighten back up- and without the slightest pause, without even looking in her direction, Rio unwrapped the towel from around her body and let it fall to the floor.

 

Agatha’s soul left her body.

 

It wasn’t just the view. It was the ease of it. The casualness. The audacity . Rio wasn’t flaunting anything. She simply existed, comfortable in her skin, wholly aware of what that skin did to Agatha and absolutely not acknowledging it.

 

Every inch of Rio’s body was accounted for. The hickey’s Agatha had left stood out in shades of red and plum, scattered across her chest, the line of her jaw, the slope of her throat. Her ears -ears Agatha had pierced- were on full display, wet hair tucked neatly behind them. Her thighs flexed as she stepped into a pair of underwear. She looked calm. Soft in the golden light of the room.

 

Agatha was sure that if she weren’t so stunned, she’d be barking. Foaming at the mouth. Chewing the bedframe. Instead, she just stared in total silence. She could barely remember how to blink.

 

Rio turned away from the dresser and hung the towel neatly on the closet door handle, still gloriously, obscenely topless. Then she pulled the t-shirt over her head as she started walking toward the bed.

 

She was saying something, Agatha had seen her mouth moving, but none of it registered. Words floated in one ear and out the other. All she could hear was static. All she could see was Rio’s hips, the hem of the t-shirt sliding down her torso.

 

Agatha hadn’t moved. Her phone was still pressed on her stomach, screen face down now, though the picture was permanently burned into her retinas.

 

Rio was approaching, still talking, still pretending like she hadn’t just turned Agatha into a fucking disaster with one photo and a towel drop.

 

And Agatha, to her credit, was doing everything in her power not to explode.

 

“Huh?” she asked, blinking out of her trance just as Rio climbed onto the bed and settled into a cross legged position, facing her. 

 

Rio tilted her head slightly, eyes dropping down to where Agatha’s phone was still clutched protectively to her stomach. Agatha could see the realization hit her. Watched it travel across her face in real time- She pulled her lips into her mouth, worked her jaw as if physically chewing back the smirk already trying to form, and then looked back up at Agatha with an expression so falsely innocent it practically screamed caught you .

 

Rio cleared her throat, still biting down a smile. “Okay,” she said. “I have two options you can choose from for tonight. Or, if you’re still impressed by the end of the night, maybe we can make it a two-part thing. Carry it into tomorrow.”

 

Oh.

 

The date.

 

Fuck.

 

Agatha blinked slowly, her pulse stuttering as the words sank in all over again. They were going on a date. She’d already made peace with the word internally. Sort of. Just that hearing Rio say it out loud, casually pitching date plans like they did this all the time, knocked the breath from her lungs in the stupidest possible way.

 

She forced herself to swallow, tried to ignore the way her eyes kept locking onto Rio’s mouth, and finally asked, “What’d you have in mind?” Her voice came out low, slightly hoarse, and she narrowed her eyes at Rio’s lips like maybe if she squinted hard enough, she’d be able to look literally fucking anywhere else. 

 

Rio didn’t comment on it. She just shrugged and said, “Well, there’s a place in town we could go for dinner. Or, if you’re feeling brave, I know a good trail. We could go on a hike.”

 

Neither option sounded terrible. In fact, the idea of hiking -which would’ve been an automatic no any other time- surprised her with how not-awful it sounded. She hadn’t been to the gym in weeks, which she was pretending was due to her schedule and not the fact that she was now apparently obsessed with skipping every adult responsibility in favor of playing house with an infuriating brunette who had a gap between her teeth and knew exactly how to use it.

 

Agatha opened her mouth to tell Rio to just choose whichever she preferred but Rio, naturally, beat her to it.

 

“Just so you know,” Rio said, still maddeningly casual, “if you pick the hike, it’s actually the law that I, Rio Vidal, am legally required to check your butthole after.”

 

Agatha stared at her.

 

“Why the fuck would you need to check my butthole?”

 

“For ticks.”

 

“I can check my own goddamn butthole.”

 

Rio raised a hand, feigning apology. “I don’t think that’s how it works, sweetheart.”

 

“No, I’m pretty sure that’s exactly how it works. You just want to see my butthole.”

 

“That’s an added bonus,” Rio agreed, nodding like she was being generous, “to saving you from potential Lyme disease. Which, by the way, is very serious.”

 

“You’re not checking my asshole for ticks.”

 

“Dinner it is, then.” Rio’s grin stretched wide, goofy and entirely pleased with herself, like she’d known from the start which option would win but still wanted to play it out.

 

And Agatha looked at her with a stunned little smile she didn’t bother hiding.

 

It wasn’t just the conversation, or the nude, or the fact that Rio was somehow making a date feel like a game instead of a trap. It was the way she asked. The way she didn’t force it. The way she sat there, patient and smug and open, like she’d keep sitting there no matter what Agatha said.

 

And somewhere in the middle of it all -this conversation, this day, this date, this cursed offer of anal pest inspection- Agatha had the dreadful realization:

 

She wasn’t going to be able to walk away from this.

 

Not now. Not tomorrow. Probably not ever.
