lastly, next update might take a bit longer to get out. i’m gonna be a busy bee for the next two weeks, but i swear i’ll be working on it.

i literally love you little gay people in my phone!! thank you for the music!!

Chapter 12: moderation

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

The last two days defied explanation. They hadn’t been extraordinary. That was the unsettling part. Time didn’t feel linear. It expanded, doubled back, folded in on itself. Every hour bled into the next, and somehow, none of it felt wasted.

 

They’d moved with a softness Agatha wasn’t prepared for. Slower. Looser. Intimate in the places she used to guard. Long mornings, bottomless coffee, too many cigarettes, and something that felt suspiciously like peace.

 

Rio kissed her good morning every time Agatha blinked awake, and never just once. It was always slow, always drawn out, always a little smug about how easily Agatha gave in. Not that Agatha complained. There wasn’t a single bad thing she had to say about Rio’s mouth… Agatha had checked. Thoroughly.

 

They touched constantly. Hands slipping beneath shirts, along hips, around shoulders. Mouths brushing foreheads, collarbones, the stretch of skin just beneath a jaw. Kisses that didn’t rush. Kisses that asked for nothing but were always answered. They woke up tangled. Slept in. Made coffee. Ate only what was within reach.

 

Agatha kept catching herself watching Rio. The way Rio hummed through toothpaste, tapped her fingers against the counter like she had too much energy and nowhere to put it. The way she sat cross legged on the counter, eating cereal straight from the box, reading the back like it was the newspaper. She was everywhere- quietly, stupidly everywhere. And in the afternoon, sun drunk and entirely too pleased with herself, Rio pressed a cold bottle of beer to the inside of Agatha’s thigh just to hear the way she gasped. Agatha rolled her eyes. And let Rio do it again.

 

They had sex, yes. Several times. Each time different. Sometimes lazy, like it was just a way to pass the time. Sometimes urgent with want, mouths and hands overlapping until it all collapsed in on itself. Sometimes slow, careful, like they were building something from the bones outward.

 

On their final afternoon, Agatha -against every protest- ended up with a fishing pole in her hands. She’d said no. Several times. But Rio had tilted her head and said, “Just once. For me.” So she’d cast the line. Immediately regretted it. Within minutes, something pulled hard enough to nearly yank the rod straight from her grip. She screamed. Rio cackled. Then ran to help her haul in the world’s most pissed off bass.

 

Rio wanted a picture. Agatha told her to fuck off. Rio threatened to pout. Agatha held the fucking fish. It thrashed wildly, and she screamed again, dropped it, watched it flop itself back into the lake. She refused to speak to Rio for twenty minutes. Then Rio kissed her and- well… So much for the silent treatment.

 

Their last morning was quieter. Not sad. Just unmistakably not the same. The light looked different through the windows. The air was too still. The world had started up again somewhere outside the walls of the lake house, and neither of them knew how to rejoin it without shattering whatever they’d built in its absence.

 

Agatha leaned against Rio’s car, smoking a cigarette, while Rio locked up the house- her eyes fixed on the lake. She expected it to look different. But it didn’t. It looked exactly as it had for the last six days, unmoved by the fact that everything else had changed.

 

Agatha didn’t blame it. The lake hadn’t asked to hold their pause, hadn’t agreed to bear witness to what almost felt like a life together. It had just been there- quiet, constant, letting them believe the world outside could wait a little longer. But it hadn’t. And now, standing at the edge of departure, even the water refused to say goodbye.

 

On the drive back, Rio reached for her constantly. Fingers brushing Agatha’s thigh, her wrist, the back of her neck at a red light. She didn’t say a word.

 

And Agatha leaned into every touch.

 

-




Agatha pulled into the employee parking lot of St. Rita’s at exactly 6:25 p.m., which left her ten whole minutes to sit in the car and pretend she wasn’t unraveling. Technically, she was early for Huddle- an infuriatingly cheerful name for the pre-shift meeting where the charge nurse handed out assignments and reminded everyone, through teeth gritted politeness, to restock the isolette drawers. Agatha’s only plan was to sit in her car, finish Connections, and summon enough willpower to give a passable impression of someone who gave a shit.

 

She and Rio had said goodbye yesterday afternoon in her foyer, and the memory made her nauseous. 

 

It had been awkward in a way that didn’t make any sense. It felt too casual. Grossly casual… like they hadn’t just spent six uninterrupted days in each other’s skin. They stood a little too far apart, said too little. Rio had gone in for a hug, then stopped halfway through- grimaced at herself like she’d forgotten how to be a person. Agatha might’ve found it endearing if it hadn’t made her want to commit a crime. 

 

It wasn’t that Agatha needed fanfare. She just couldn’t wrap her head around how two people could spend six days sharing a bed- waking up tangled, falling asleep with a face tucked into a neck- and then suddenly forget how to touch each other. 

 

Rio had checked her asshole for ticks, for fucks sake. That wasn’t metaphorical. That actually happened. And now they couldn’t even make eye contact? Please.

 

Agatha pulled Rio in out of spite. Hugged her with more force than necessary. Rio’s arms came around her immediately, and they both went still the second they made contact. They held each other longer than they should have, only breathing, not moving. Then Rio leaned back and let out a shaky breath that brushed against Agatha’s mouth. And then, as if rehearsed, they both let go. 

 

Rio made it to the sidewalk before turning around, walking straight back through the door, and kissing Agatha like she couldn’t help it. Agatha kissed her back, open mouthed and already annoyed at how much she’d missed it.

 

It was messy and ridiculous and briefly obscene before settling into something slower. Softer. Familiar in the worst way. Agatha pulled away first. Rio lingered just long enough to whisper, “See you at work tomorrow,” and pressed one more kiss to the corner of Agatha’s mouth before walking out again.

 

That was the last time they spoke. No texts. No calls. Agatha hadn’t opened their text thread since, and she didn’t plan to. Not because she was heartbroken- she wasn’t. She was just adjusting. A little out of step.

 

Six days of closeness had shifted Agatha’s center of gravity, and now everything was tilted half a degree to the left. She didn’t fall apart. She still liked her space. She still liked her own company. But waking up alone after that many mornings full of Rio’s limbs and Rio’s warmth and Rio’s dumb laugh wasn’t easy. It wasn’t ruinous. Just absolutely fucking irritating. Like the absence of that stupid gap toothed smile had drained the color from her world a little bit. And Agatha had to pretend she hadn’t noticed.

 

Now, Agatha was halfway through grouping four words she was almost positive described patterns when an unexpected knock against her window startled her so violently she let out an undignified yelp, dropped her phone, and screamed “FUCK” loud enough to rattle her own eardrums. Her heart slammed against her ribs as she whipped her head- already halfway into a scowl she assumed would be aimed at Rio, who had a chronic habit of scaring the shit out of her.

 

Except it wasn’t Rio.

 

It was Jen. Which, frankly, was absolutely worse. 

 

Agatha groaned and cracked the window an inch and glared out at her very pissed off best friend. “Jennifer,” she said flatly. “To what do I owe the jump scare?”

 

“Out of the car.”

 

So much for hello.

 

Agatha blinked up at her. “Absolutely not. I have six more minutes to sit here and rot in peace, and I plan to savor every last one. You’re encroaching on sacred time.”

 

Jen didn’t respond. Just stepped back half an inch, clearly waiting, clearly not going anywhere.

 

Agatha sighed, opened the door with unnecessary force, and made sure it bumped Jen’s hip on the way open. She climbed out with theatrical annoyance, slung her bag over her shoulder, and locked her car with a single, accusatory beep.

 

“Is there a reason for all of this,” Agatha said, motioning vaguely at Jen’s entire existence, “or did you just feel like showing up and making me miserable today?”

 

Jen squinted at her. “Hilarious,” she said dryly.  Then, without missing a beat, “No actually, this is about you being an asshole and ignoring my calls and texts all week.”

 

Agatha tilted her head. “What?” Her tone was light, drawn out, and clearly performative. She didn’t wait for a response before turning toward the hospital  building. 

 

Jen followed without hesitation. “Don’t play dumb, Agatha.”

 

Agatha shrugged, still playing dumb. “Well- sorry abou-”

 

“Nope. Not letting you squirm out of this one.” Jen grabbed her elbow and tugged her to a stop. “What the hell happened? And don’t say ‘nothing,’ because you and Rio both called out last week, and I may be tired but I’m not stupid.”

 

Agatha pulled her arm free, roughly. “You’re reaching.”

 

“Are you being serious right now?” Jen said. “Your ex-wife showed up to the bowling alley and caused a whole scene, you left with Rio - thank god , by the way. We all literally cheered the second you were both out of sight and Wanda started screaming at security.”

 

Agatha scoffed, and Jen threw her hands up.

 

“You left with Rio! You both called out! And now you’re seriously not going to tell me what happened? I want the entire rundown. Every single detail. Starting now.”

 

“Oh, I’m sorry,” Agatha said, stopping dead in the middle of the sidewalk, forcing two people to step around them. “Did I forget to give you a play by play of my entire personal life imploding in the middle of a fucking bowling alley?”

 

Jen raised an eyebrow. Agatha didn’t give her the chance to speak, “I saw Wanda. I saw Rio. I used my one functioning brain cell and left with the hotter option.”

 

“Why are you downplaying this?”

 

“I have no idea what you’re talking about,” Agatha said, already walking again.

 

“Bullshit.”

 

“Correct,” Agatha said, not even bothering to fake it.

 

Jen scoffed. “So what, you vanish for a week and I’m not supposed to ask? Are you two dat-”

 

“Are who two what now?”

 

Rio appeared mysteriously at Agatha’s side, and it took no effort at all for Agatha to remain unfazed. She didn’t flinch, didn’t pause, only instinctively took the coffee Rio held out in front of her.

 

Agatha may have made her own coffee at home, stared at it, and then left it sitting on the counter. Not an oversight- a choice. A minor sacrifice, really, in the off chance that a certain insufferable person might take the admittedly unreasonable hint… and bring her one instead. 

 

Jen glared at Agatha for the fact that she had enough respect not to keep asking real questions in front of company, and clearly hated herself for it. She didn’t say anything, but her eyes dropped to the cup in Agatha’s hand and narrowed. There was no mistaking the pointed expression that followed.

 

Agatha didn’t offer an explanation. She just took a long, obnoxious sip and kept walking.

 

Rio glanced at Jen, completely unfazed. “Tell your wife her gym bag’s still in my car. It’s been a month.”

 

Agatha clocked it instantly- Rio redirecting the conversation without blinking. Whether it was to spare Agatha or herself, she wasn’t sure. Either way, it worked. And the coffee didn’t hurt.

 

“Tell her yourself. You’ll see her more tonight than I will, considering you work ten feet away!”

 

Agatha kept her focus forward, jaw set, pace steady. She didn’t look at either of them, didn’t engage, but she did let her fingers drift ever so slightly against Rio’s. 

 

Rio, still talking to Jen, extended her middle finger and pressed it lightly against the back of Agatha’s hand.

 

Agatha’s stomach flipped. She didn’t react beyond the faint curl of her index finger as it caught on Rio’s. It was a small, deliberate contact- unremarkable to anyone else, but enough. 

 

They walked the rest of the stretch like that, Rio keeping up her end of the conversation with Jen. Her finger staying loosely caught around Agatha's and neither of them pulling away. 

 

When the entrance doors came into view, Rio stepped ahead, fingers slipping away from Agatha’s, and pulled the door open for them. 

 

Agatha went in first.

 

Jen kept close behind, leaned in just enough to make it annoying, and muttered under her breath, “Don’t think you’re off the hook just because your guard dog showed up. I still want every detail, and I’m not above dragging it out of you.”

 

“Details? About what?” Agatha shot back in a sharp whisper. “The coffee? It’s a little sweet, but I’m coping.”

 

From a few steps behind, Rio called out, casually and infuriatingly tuned in, “Too sweet?”

 

Agatha didn’t answer. Not because she didn’t want to- she did. The words were right there. ‘ No, it’s perfect.’ She could’ve said it easily, could’ve thrown it over her shoulder. She even opened her mouth to do it. But Jen cut back in with purpose.

 

“Alright,” Jen said. “You still wanna play dumb? Cool. Let’s play.”

 

Rio was closing the gap now, falling into step behind them. Jen didn’t wait. She glanced sidelong at Agatha, then raised her voice just enough to carry. “Hey, Rio,” she called, tone light and loaded, “is Agatha a good kisser?”

 

Agatha stopped walking. “Oh, you’ve lost your goddamn mind.”

 

Jen turned on her heel to face Agatha and crossed her arms.

 

Rio was already stepping past them, moving smoothly toward the ER doors. She turned to walk backward, coffee in one hand, head tilted. “Sorry, Jen,” she said, shrugging. “A lady doesn’t kiss and tell.”

 

Agatha nearly laughed. For one blissfully naïve second, she thought Rio might leave it there.

 

Then she saw it. 

 

The press of Rio’s tongue against the inside of her cheek. Her eyes dragged slowly down Agatha’s body, then back up again without apology. 

 

The shift in energy was immediate, unmistakable. Jen glanced at Agatha and then back at Rio, waiting for the hit.

 

“Gun to my head, though?” Rio continued, barely containing the grin that stretched across her face. “She’s incredible. Excellent technique. Very generous with-”

 

“Stop talking!” Agatha snapped, pointing after her. “You are willfully selling my soul to the fucking devil.”

 

Rio laughed, all teeth and triumph, and raised her hands in mock surrender without missing a step. She reached for her badge, scanned it against the reader, and the doors swung open on cue.

 

And instead of just walking away like a normal human being, Rio gave an exaggerated, theatrical bow, turned on her heel, and skipped a few steps through the doors. Without looking back, she tossed a casual wave over her shoulder. “Can’t wait to see you tonight,” she called out before vanishing down the corridor, whistling some absurdly cheerful tune with zero goddamn shame.

 

Agatha stared after her, positively fucking dumbfounded. She tossed a useless hand in the air, exasperated. “Can someone remind me why I haven’t filed an HR complaint against her already?” She didn’t wait for a response. “Oh, right. She gives phenomenal head.” Then she turned and walked toward the elevators like she hadn’t just intentionally blown Jen’s brain out of her ears.

 

“WHAT?” Jen shouted as she stood frozen in the hallway. Then immediately scrambled and rushed after Agatha, nearly tripping over her own feet as the elevator doors slid open.

 

Agatha stepped inside unbothered, hit the button, and took another sip.

 

“You can’t just say that and walk away with zero explanation!” Jen shouted again, diving in after her.

 

“Hmm?” Agatha said, casually. “Oh. Sorry. I thought you wanted details.” She glanced at the strangers around them and asked, far too loud and far too sarcastic, “Sisterhood of the Traveling Kegels? No? No?”

 

Someone near the back of the elevator snorted. Another jabbed a button for the next floor with increasing desperation.

 

“You’re awful,” Jen hissed.

 

“The worst,” Agatha agreed sweetly. The elevator dinged. She stepped out smoothly, tossing over her shoulder, “Feel free to direct all further complaints to literally anyone else.”

 

-

 

Agatha had lucked out- only a two baby assignment tonight, both feeder/growers, both practically packing their bags waiting to be discharged. No micro-preemies, no frantic admits. She was stashed in one of the postpartum overnight rooms- normally reserved for parents, now repurposed as NICU overflow since the unit had exceeded its capacity.

 

She was starting to think Westview -and every town within a twenty-mile radius- had put a little too much faith in the pull-out method. And judging by the state of the NICU, it wasn’t going well.

 

Whatever her personal opinions on the town’s ongoing battle with birth control, Agatha couldn’t complain about the assignment. The room was quiet and blissfully removed from the main unit. No pod chatter, no alarms screeching, no babies trying to flirt with the Woman upstairs. Just two bassinets, both occupied by sleepy, stable babies who had no interest in anything but their next bottle.

 

Agatha had just finished her first hands-on time: four scheduled windows in a shift to get everything done: assessments, diapers, feeds, vitals. and all the ritual baby maintenance wrapped in a thirty minute window. 

 

One down, three to go.

 

Now she was swaddling the smaller baby of the two -Lennie- who had taken her bottle like a fucking champ, belched without shame, and was now staring at her with the blank, mildly betrayed expression of someone who had not consented to being burrito-wrapped.

 

“You do know this is temporary, right?” Agatha said, folding the blanket over with one hand and tucking it. “The room service ends the minute you graduate.”

 

Lennie let out a small, indignant huff that Agatha chose to interpret as backtalk. 

 

“Okay, first of all, rude. Second of all, if you spit up in the next three seconds, we’re fighting.”

 

Lennie let out a soft grunt, eyes already drifting closed like she knew she could get away with anything, and Agatha would let her.

 

Agatha exhaled slowly and watched her settle into sleep before crossing the room to the computer- what they all called a WOW, short or “workstation on wheels.” 

 

She logged in and started charting. The only drawback to this cushy setup was that neither of her babies had x-rays ordered tonight. No excuse for an x-ray tech to wander in. Good news for her patient. Bad news for her odds of seeing Rio.

 

Not that she was thinking about that.

 

Agatha kept her eyes on the monitor and told herself the silence was nice. Peaceful. Efficient.

 

She was just finishing up when the door creaked open wider and her two hours of peace came to a swift, inevitable end.

 

“Hello, Agatha,” came Jen’s voice -flat, pointed- as she dragged a parent lounger across the room and plopped into it like she owned the place. She crossed her arms and sighed dramatically. 

 

“If you wake either of these babies, I’ll kill you,” Agatha said calmly, fingers still tapping at the keyboard. “And I won’t be quick about it.”

 

“Relax,” Jen whispered, settling in. “I’m being respectful.”

 

“You’re being annoying.”

 

Jen shrugged. “Tell me what happened between you and Rio.”

 

“Absolutely not.”

 

“You don’t have to tell me everything. I’m just saying… if you wanted to talk, I’d listen.”

 

Agatha sighed and pressed her fingers to the bridge of her nose, specifically, to keep her from throttling her best friend. 

 

“We went to Sybil’s-“

 

“Her hot aunt,” Jen cut in, too fast.

 

The look Agatha gave her was nothing short of venomous- teeth clenched, chin tilted forward, every muscle in her jaw visibly restraining itself. “Are you going to let me finish?”

 

Jen held up her hands. “Sorry. Please. Continue.”

 

“We went to Sybil’s lake house for a few days. We didn’t kill each other. That’s it.”

 

“But you slept together.”

 

Agatha didn’t even blink. “We’ve been sleeping together.”

 

Jen sat forward like she’d just heard a gunshot. “SIN-”

 

Agatha cut her off with a harsh shushing noise and a quick glance toward the babies.

 

Jen froze, then slowly leaned back into the chair, visibly trying to regulate her face into something less feral. Her voice, when it returned, was quieter- but still far from neutral. “Okay. Since when?”

 

“The night before the bowling alley.”

 

Jen leaned in again, practically vibrating with energy. “So let me get this straight-”

 

“You want straight answers, ask a straight lady.”

 

Jen blinked, unimpressed, then continued.

 

“You called out last week so you could spend days uninterrupted being thoroughly, repeatedly, fucked by Rio Vidal? That’s amazing. I’m so proud of you I could cry.”

 

Agatha rolled her eyes and sank deeper into her chair, arms crossed, legs stretched out. She didn’t dignify that with a response- which, unfortunately, only encouraged Jen.

 

“Now- tell me. Is it everything you thought it’d be? Are you actually together now? Because I’ll be honest, I never thought I’d live to see the day you two finally got your shit together.”

 

‘Is it everything you thought it’d be?’

 

What a stupid fucking question. 

 

Because no. Not even close.

 

It felt like Rio Vidal -with her stupid green thumb- had planted something in Agatha’s chest.

 

A garden. Wild and alive and completely outside Agatha’s control.

 

She could feel it constantly, this thing Rio had made in her. Roots coiled around her ribs. Vines threading through her lungs. Flowers blooming behind her teeth every time she tried to speak. She couldn’t open her mouth without fucking petals falling out.

 

It was beautiful. And it belonged to her. Grown for her. She loved it completely.

 

Agatha shrugged. “It’s sex,” she said flatly. “We’re good at it.” Her eyes stayed on the monitor of her WOW, unmoving. Hoping if she focused hard enough on it, she could will the screen to erase the question. Or maybe just her reaction to it.

 

Jen waited, brows raised. “Agatha.”

 

God. That voice. That tone. The one Jen used when she made it painfully clear she wasn’t the fool Agatha sometimes pretended she was, and they might as well cut the bullshit and get on with it.

 

Jen said nothing else. She didn’t push. Didn’t dig. Just let the silence stretch- long enough for Agatha to get annoyed, which was half the strategy.

 

Begrudgingly, Agatha pressed her lips together and finally looked at her- still silent, but no longer pretending this was a conversation she wasn’t going to have. It was a choice. A reluctant, defensive, unspoken fine, but only because it’s Jen kind of choice.

 

Jen’s earlier amusement cooled, just slightly, into something more careful.

 

“Are you seriously about to reduce seventeen years of pining and psychological warfare down to just sex ?” she asked, voice dropping to a hiss. “Because that’s what it sounds like. And that would be -frankly- fucking deranged.” She threw a mindful glance at the sleeping babies and then back at Agatha, voice still furious and hushed, “Seriously, do you hear yourself? You and Rio blue balled each other through the most spectacularly doomed friendship in recorded history, and now that you finally did something about it, this is what you’re going with?”

 

And there it was. Jen, dead-on as always. Holding up a mirror and telling Agatha to look. 

 

Agatha resisted the urge to roll her eyes because Jen was infuriatingly right , and she wasn’t even being smug about it. 

 

She could’ve lied. Could’ve thrown another joke at it. But what was the point? Jen had already seen the worst of it.

 

Jen was the only person Agatha had ever admitted anything about it to. Years ago, after she tried to kiss Rio, and Rio hesitated, then Agatha bolted like her skin was on fire. She’d gotten in her car, heart in her throat, shame like static in her mouth, and driven straight to Jen and Alice’s place. She didn’t knock on the door. She pounded. Over and over until Jen answered, bleary and backlit, took one look at Agatha, and didn’t ask a single question. Just stepped aside.

 

Agatha made it to the couch and completely lost it. Couldn’t breathe, couldn’t stop crying, couldn’t pretend it hadn’t meant anything. And somewhere in the middle of it -curled into Jen’s side, soaked in her own embarrassment- she said it. Quiet, hoarse, pathetic.

 

“I can’t keep doing this to myself,” she had choked out, “If she loved me back… I’d know. I would’ve known.”

 

Jen didn’t react. Just held her through it. One arm around her shoulders, hand in her hair.

 

And Jen, to her credit, never brought it up again.

 

Agatha scoffed now. “Can you not say it like that? You make it sound like we’ve been edging each other since the Obama administration.”

 

“You literally have!” Jen hissed. Then, more gently: “Look, I’m not trying to poke at it, okay? But are we seriously gonna sit here while you lie to my face and then go cry in your car later because ‘it’s all moving too fast and your nervous system wasn’t built for this level of functional communication’?”

 

Agatha shot her a withering look. “You’re not funny.”

 

“I’m hilarious. And you’re in lo-”

 

“Jesus Christ,” Agatha hissed, sitting up fast. “Can we not?”

 

“No. Because I’m your voice of reason and gay panic management.”

 

“I’m not doing this with you right now.”

 

“Why not?”

 

“Because it’s mine.” Agatha snapped. “It’s mine ,” she repeated, quieter this time. “And I don’t- It’s too much. I feel like I’m running at capacity and I’m trying not to fuck it up just because I feel everything too hard. So yeah- if telling you it’s just sex keeps me from collapsing into a fucking puddle of unresolved feelings and poor life choices, then that’s what I’m calling it. It’s mine. Let me deal with it how I need to.”

 

“Have you told her that?” Jen asked, voice gentler now, but still cutting straight through her.

 

Agatha exhaled, sharp and disbelieving. “Told her what exactly? That it’s easier to lie when she’s not standing in front of me? That I don’t know how to be inside something without controlling it or pretending it doesn’t matter just to avoid the risk of ruining it?” She stood, crossed the room, and leaned back against the counter. Arms crossed tight over her chest.

 

“We went on one date,” she muttered. “And played house for a week. After over a decade of- ” she broke off, shaking her head. “Of nothing. It felt real, and it was good, and I wanted it. But wanting something that bad doesn’t make it sustainable. And I’m not betting everything on a fluke or a break in the goddamn weather.”

 

Jen didn’t respond right away. She just watched her- quiet, steady, hands folded in her lap like she knew better than to move too fast.

 

“You know breaks in the weather still count as weather, right?” Jen said finally. 

 

“Don’t do that.”

 

“Do what?”

 

“Make it poetic and feel safe.”

 

Jen stood, but kept her distance. “I’m not trying to make it safe. I’m telling you that just because it wasn’t in the forecast doesn’t mean it wasn’t real.”

 

Agatha scoffed. “I’ve driven myself up the fucking wall picking all this shit apart. And I’ve decided that it’s not actually that serious. So we don’t have to do all this, okay?”

 

Jen gave her a long, flat and unimpressed look. “You’re so full of shit.”

 

“I know that.” Agatha said, biting it out like it was obvious. “And more importantly? She knows that.” She shifted, jaw tight. “But talking about it like this, it doesn’t help. It makes it worse. So forgive me for wanting to keep her to myself for five fucking minutes without dissecting it like it’s a goddamn case study on emotional repression.”

 

“That’s a hell of a coping strategy.”

 

“It’s better than buying a gun.” 

 

That startled a laugh out of Jen. Lennie stirred.  Both of them fell still, watching as the baby settled.

 

Once the quiet returned, Agatha looked at Jen and said, “I’m not leaving again. If that’s what you’re worried about.”

 

Something in Jen’s shoulders relaxed, the tension easing just slightly. “Good,” she said simply. Then added, “I’m going to hug you now.”

 

“Don’t-”

 

“Too late.”

 

Agatha didn’t resist. She let herself lean into it- let her chin fall to Jen’s shoulder, her arms loose at her sides.

 

After exactly one minute, Agatha sniffed and pulled back with a grimace. “God. That was awful.”

 

“I’m nauseated.”

 

“Don’t make this a thing.”

 

Jen raised both hands. “This? Never happened.”

 

“Perfect.”

 

They stood in silence for a beat too long.

 

“... But if my car is mysteriously keyed again, I promise I will tell everyone in this hospital-”

 

Agatha groaned, “I said I was sorry! And we were twenty-three. Let it go, Jen.”

 

“You keyed the wrong car, Agatha.”

 

“I was drunk and pissed Rio beat me in pool. It could’ve happened to anyone.”

 

Jen scoffed. “It didn’t. And afterward, Rio let you key her car because you were still mad at her for winning.”

 

Agatha rolled her eyes. “She only did that so I wouldn’t feel like an idiot.”

 

“No. She did that because she was more worried about you still being upset with her than watching you key her car.”

 

“Alright. That’s enough. We’re done here.”

 

“Still the most romantic thing anyone’s ever done for you.”

 

“Stop talking, Jen.”

 

-

 

Jen didn’t have an assignment tonight -just tasking- so Agatha asked if she could sit with her babies while she took her lunch. Asked was generous. She told Jen, actually. Told her the exact time, too. Not around 4. Not after a feed. Four o’clock, sharp.

 

There might’ve been a reason for that.

 

Rio, even now, was still a creature of habit. She still counted the seconds brushing each quadrant of her teeth. Still kept her keys in the same front pocket of that same beat up backpack. Still ordered her beers undressed. Still used the back of her knuckles to flip light switches. 

 

And unless the earth had tilted off its axis, Rio was probably still taking her lunch  breaks at 4 a.m. sharp.

 

Jen showed up eleven minutes early. She made a whole performance of telling Agatha not to go over her thirty, but Agatha just smiled, because no one showed up eleven minutes early unless they expected you to run long. Jen knew exactly what this was. She didn’t ask why Agatha was being so precise, didn’t point out the way her eyes kept flicking to the clock.

 

Agatha pressed a kiss to her cheek -loud, obnoxious, sloppy on purpose- and Jen shoved her off with a grimace. “You’re disgusting,” Jen muttered, already settling in.

 

Agatha didn’t look back.

 

-

 

Agatha made her way down to the radiology department on the ground floor, tucked at the furthest end of ER. She took a left into the alcove where five x-ray portable machines were lined up. The space wasn’t labeled, but Agatha knew it was where the portables lived when they weren’t being dragged upstairs or wedged into patients' rooms.

 

She didn’t text Rio. Didn’t wait at her usual smoking spot, or theirs, or whatever it was now. Just showed up. Quietly. Casually. She figured it was a nice thing to do- thoughtful, maybe. Proof she was trying without making it a big deal. She wasn’t going to humiliate herself… not that the bar was especially high.

 

Past the portables and a right turn led into a hallway where the x-ray control booths were. It was the only section of imaging without a proper door, just a wide cutout in the drywall and a scattering of rolling chairs in the hallway outside of it, always in the way. Rio had once called x-ray the ugly redheaded stepchild of the hospital and rattled off a list of reasons so long that Agatha had no choice but to actually listen.

 

She was halfway down the hallway when screaming started- loud, chaotic, and completely unexpected. Then came a voice yelling “SHOT!” and the piercing beep of the x-ray machine firing off an exposure.

 

Agatha slowed.

 

That wasn’t nothing.

 

Agatha paused just before the opening to the control booth, tucked herself to the side where she couldn’t be seen, and listened. Voices drifted from inside- one of them unfamiliar, a woman’s voice, tired and apologetic. “We have to get one more. I’m so-”

 

The woman didn’t finish. A second later, someone -presumably a patient- let out a furious, guttural yell that echoed down the hall. Agatha flinched. It was nearly 4 a.m., and while she was used to infants wailing and monitors shrieking, grown adults screaming in close quarters threw her. The sound didn’t just break the quiet- it tore straight through it.

 

The woman again, less gentle now. “Rio, I need you to hold again.”

 

And then Rio’s voice- steady, almost bored. “Sure.”

 

More conversation followed, low and clinical. Instructions exchanged, a strained explanation offered, the patient clearly irritated that another image needed to be taken.

 

Agatha inched forward and glanced into the booth, just enough to see.

 

To the left, a nurse sat at one of the computers, charting without looking up. On the right, Sage was sat posted at the main console, one hand resting on the exposure switch, the other adjusting the monitor in front of her. The live camera feed showed the patient's pelvis. 

 

From where Agatha stood, she could barely see into the exam room through the control booth’s lead-lined window. She stepped in a little further and reached out, poked the back of Sage’s shoulder. The girl flinched, quick and reactive, twisting in her seat like she was ready to tear into whoever had the nerve- until she saw who it was. Her whole expression changed, irritation dissolving into something entirely far too amused. 

 

“Well,” Sage said, leaning back in her chair, “You’re awfully far from home. Babies are on the fourth floor.”

 

Agatha shrugged. “Was in the neighborhood,” she mumbled, already distracted, trying to peer through the glass for a better view of the exam room.

 

Inside, Rio was geared up in lead, gloves on, standing at the head of the stretcher. There was an orthopedic resident at the foot of the bed- making adjustments, focused, fiddling with something Agatha couldn’t see from this angle.

 

Agatha stepped back slightly out of view, careful not to draw attention. Rio had a habit of always finding her without even trying. But right now, she didn’t want to be found. She just wanted to watch Rio- quiet, selfish, unseen.

 

Sage gave her a once-over, then pressed her lips together and kept watching, like she was deciding how much she felt like starting something.

 

 “Sure.”

 

No questions. No follow-up. Like Agatha showing up down here didn’t need an explanation. Like it wasn’t strange at all.

 

Agatha felt herself exhale.

 

Thank fuck. 

 

“What the hell are they doing in there? Torture?” Agatha muttered, arms crossed as she leaned against the wall, eyes locking on the window- even though she couldn’t see Rio from here. 

 

“Close,” Sage said, tilting her head just enough to be annoying. “Traction.”

 

Agatha glanced down at her. “You gonna explain, or am I just supposed to guess based on the screaming?”

 

“Patient’s got a proximal femur fracture,” Sage said, turning to the monitor and pulling up a previous image. She pointed to the break. “The bone fragments are overlapping, so Ortho applies traction -pulling in line with the leg- to temporarily realign them. It reduces the overlap enough to get a clearer image of the break. Looks awful, sounds worse, but it gives them a better idea of what they’re dealing with before they take the patient into surgery.”

 

Agatha blinked at the screen, then glanced back toward the exam room. “You all just… do that? While the patient is awake?”

 

Sage didn’t answer. She just smirked.

 

“Sage, get ready on the rotor,” Rio called out through the glass.

 

“My time to shine,” Sage whispered, already turning back to the console.

 

Agatha shifted closer to the window, careful to keep herself out of Rio’s eyeline. She leaned over slightly, one hand on the counter, craning for a better look. 

 

The resident leaned in, adjusting her grip on the patient’s ankle, while Rio stepped forward and locked her arms under the patient’s shoulders. Agatha watched the way her feet shifted slightly, grounding her weight, her gloved hands already hooked in place.

 

“One!” The resident called out. “Two!”

 

Sage immediately started rotoring, the mechanical hum of the x-ray machine kicking in as the resident began pulling on the patient’s leg. There was nothing subtle about it. She used her whole body, leaning backward with controlled force, and Agatha watched, equal parts horrified and intrigued, as Rio countered the movement without flinching like she was used to taking the brunt of the resistance.

 

The patient screamed. Loud. Awful. 

 

“Shot!” the resident shouted. The machine beeped. The pulling stopped. Rio let go of the patient and straightened, still calm, already speaking- soft, even, trying to talk the patient down.

 

The patient, for their part, did not give a fuck. They were swearing impressively, hurling every profanity Agatha had ever heard and a few she hadn’t.

 

Agatha didn’t blame them. If someone had pulled on her leg like that while another person held her down like a sandbag, she would’ve kicked, sworn, cried, probably bitten someone- then made it everyone’s problem, loudly enough to get security involved.

 

The resident came around behind the control booth a moment later and began flipping through the images on the monitor, squinting at the alignment. After a beat, she nodded. “We got it!” she called out through the glass.

 

“Thank fuck,” the patient shot back, their voice strained and shaky, still sharp with pain.

 

The resident offered an apology and Agatha felt the nurse beside her rise from her chair, already heading into the exam room to take the patient back to their room.

 

Agatha eased back out of sight, pressing her spine lightly to the wall inside the booth. She told herself it was about being polite. Giving them space. Not hiding. Definitely not hiding.

 

It was inconvenient, how attractive Rio managed to be in the middle of something objectively horrifying. 

 

She was all muscle memory and quiet force, wrapped in lead like it had been custom-fitted, holding her ground while someone screamed directly into her ear. It was ridiculous. Unnecessary. Kind of devastating.

 

Agatha was still trying to shame herself into sanity when the resident spoke again. Her tone had shifted- subtle, but there. Not that Agatha noticed. Not that she was listening. Not on purpose, anyway.

 

“You held perfectly,” the resident said. “Most techs don’t hold traction like that without complaining.”

 

Sage didn’t look up from the monitor, but her eyebrows rose by at least a centimeter. “Bitch,” she whispered.

 

Rio said nothing.

 

“You must work out,” the resident added, tone just professional enough to stay out of HR’s jurisdiction.

 

Agatha’s hand flew out and clamped down on Sage’s shoulder before she could think twice about it. Definitely harder than necessary. 

 

Sage flinched, looked at her, and immediately turned back around like she’d decided surviving the day mattered more than getting involved. She started working faster, dragging labels and slapping Rio’s initials on the screen -standard post-processing, every x-ray needed it- but Sage was acting with an urgency like her life depended on it. Which, to be fair, was a valid read of the room. Agatha knew exactly what she looked like- and maybe Sage wasn’t dumb enough to make eye contact twice.

 

Out in the hallway, Agatha heard the squeak of wheels and the nurse’s voice trailing back through the open door.

 

“Good luck. Seen a lot of folks try to rein the bad boy of x-ray in. Never ends well.”

 

Agatha’s jaw locked. Her hand tightened on Sage’s shoulder, uselessly, like that was going to do anything. Her whole body was buzzing, trapped somewhere between walking out and seriously considering the fallout of throwing hands in a hospital. A nurse. An ortho resident. Both. She hadn’t decided yet.

 

She heard the door shut. The patient was gone. The resident, unfortunately, wasn’t. Still inside, still talking- apparently immune to rejection, silence, or common fucking sense.

 

“No pressure or anything,” the resident said, lightly like it was a fucking joke, “but if you have a night you’re free... we should grab dinner.”

 

Agatha heard the rip of Velcro as Rio peeled off the lead apron. “No thanks. I’m seeing someone,” came Rio’s voice- calm, even. “Not really looking to complicate that.” A beat. “She also bites. Last person to try this needed stitches.”

 

Silence followed.

 

Then came a low, guttural sound -half snarl, half bark- and the unmistakable snap of teeth.

 

Agatha froze, her face was surely caught between horror and disbelief. The stitches comment was bad enough. But the sound effect? The fucking visual effect? That was theater. Completely unnecessary, painfully on brand… and unfortunately, kind of hot. Which only made everything worse.

 

Agatha was going to commit murder. Maybe two. Depending on whether Rio kept talking or the resident kept breathing.

 

She hadn’t even landed on a name yet when Sage twisted around so fast it looked medically inadvisable. Her entire face was lit up- eyes wide, mouth open, jaw twitching like she was about to say something that would absolutely get her slapped. And given who she was related to, it was guaranteed to be bold. Bold and wildly ill-advised.

 

Agatha didn’t give her the chance. She pinched her shoulder, hard, and Sage let out a strangled noise between a gasp and a curse. Then she lunged at Agatha, looking absolutely feral, but Agatha shoved her back into the chair with one hand and zero patience. Sage stayed put, seething, practically vibrating, but wisely didn’t try again.

 

Then the resident’s voice- thin, a little breathless, like she wasn’t sure if she should apologize or run.

 

“Right. I- I didn’t mean- never mind.”

 

The door opened. Agatha couldn’t see her leave, but she heard the rushed footsteps, fast and uneven, like someone trying not to look panicked while absolutely panicking.

 

Agatha didn’t smile. But she was close.

 

Then she heard it- Rio’s footsteps. Getting closer.

 

Agatha turned to leave, fast, trying to get ahead of the moment before it turned into something, but her foot caught one of the rolling chairs scattered around the booth.  She didn’t fall, but it was a mess- one arm shot out for balance, her other shoulder clipped the wall, and her heel caught on the chair causing it to rattle loud enough to announce her presence.

 

“Agatha?”

 

Agatha straightened and pivoted slowly, already composing a lie she wouldn’t believe if the roles were reversed. Something about needing to check on an order. Or tripping on air. Or Sage- yes, blame Sage. That seemed like a solid fallback.

 

But Rio was already there, standing just inside the booth. Her eyes flicked to Agatha’s heel, then the chair, then back to her face- nothing but cool amusement and the faintest twitch of her mouth, like she was trying very hard not to smile.

 

Agatha cleared her throat, nodded once, and said, “Sup.”

 

Sup?

 

SUP?

 

The word landed between them with the elegance of a brick smashing through a window.

 

Agatha felt her ears burn. She kept her face still, but it was a fight. Whatever expression wanted out didn’t belong in public. She didn’t look at Sage. She didn’t have to. That kind of glee didn’t need an audience. It announced itself.

 

“Hey,” Rio said, not smug but maddeningly soft. “What are you doing down here?”

 

Any excuse Agatha might have had evaporated on the spot. She felt her shoulders give slightly, and she felt the corner of her mouth betray her with the start of a smile- but then her eyes landed on Sage, seated directly in front of Rio, teeth sunk into the back of her hand like she was physically holding herself back from saying something stupid. 

 

Agatha looked back at Rio with a small shrug, “It’s four a.m.”

 

Sage immediately dropped her arms and slapped her palms against the desk. “Awww!” she whined, grinning now, turning toward Rio. “She knows what time you take your-”

 

Rio cut her off with a sharp smack to the back of the head.

 

“OW,” Sage barked, rubbing the spot and glaring at her, “I do not get paid enough to be physically assaulted by the both of you!”

 

Rio ignored her completely and stepped past, stopping in front of Agatha.

 

“Let’s go,” Rio said, nodding toward the hallway.

 

Agatha followed Rio out, and from behind them, Sage called out, loud and clearly offended, “Yeah, no, totally fine- I’ll just hold down the entire department alone. Love that for me!”

 

Neither of them looked back.

 

Just outside the department, they passed Teen hauling a portable back toward the bay. Agatha groaned. His eyes lit up.

 

“Agatha! Were you looking for me-”

 

“Not now, Teen,” Agatha snapped, not breaking stride. Neither did Rio.

 

The walk felt longer than usual. Not tense, exactly, but not easy either. Eventually, Rio spoke.

 

“I didn’t see you when I came up to do morning x-rays.”

 

“They’ve got me in a postpartum overnight room,” Agatha said. “We’re running out of space to store the babies.”

 

Rio nodded, and held the door open for her when they reached it.

 

“Bad boy of x-ray, huh?” Agatha said, dry as anything, as they crossed the parking lot.

 

Rio barely turned her head. “Didn’t realize I had an audience.”

 

Agatha hummed, not bothering to hide her lack of enthusiasm. “Didn’t realize you still had a reputation.”

 

That earned Agatha a smile. Predictable. Effortless.

 

“Did you miss the part where I said I’m seeing someone?” Rio asked.

 

No, Agatha definitely didn’t. She heard it. Logged it. Pretended it didn’t make her chest feel stupid.

 

So instead, she said, “You said I bite,” breaking off to lean against the wall of the old administration building. She crossed her arms, waiting.

 

Rio stopped in front of her, the street lamp buzzing faintly around them. “You do,” she said simply, then softer, gaze steady. “Are you upset with me?”

 

Agatha wasn’t upset. She was nowhere near that simple.

 

Because Rio looked hot doing her job. Ridiculously so. She looked hot in those black scrubs she’d chosen to wear tonight. She sounded hot when she snapped her teeth at the resident: unhinged, dismissive, unbothered- as if the idea of anyone else asking her out was beneath consideration. And maybe Agatha should’ve been irritated by the reputation, by the way it still lingered in every room like smoke, even now. Maybe she should’ve rolled her eyes at how easily Rio let the world assume she was reckless, available, untouchable.

 

But she remembered what Rio had told her in confidence. That no one else touched her. That she didn’t let them. That she hadn’t wanted them to. That she only wanted Agatha.

 

And Agatha, for all her pride and reason and pathological need to stay in control, was decidedly not fucking angry. Not even close. She just wanted to kiss Rio- terribly, inconveniently, with an urgency that made her feel foolish for pretending she ever had the upper hand.

 

She pressed her tongue to the inside of her cheek and shook her head, slow and helpless. She couldn’t speak. Not like this. Not with petals threatening to spill out of her mouth, soft and stupid and meant only for Rio.

 

Agatha uncrossed her arms and reached out. Rio took her hand without hesitation, let herself be pulled in like it was the only thing she’d been waiting for all night.

 

Their mouths crashed together. 

 

Rio melted into her, shameless. She whimpered into Agatha’s mouth the second Agatha let go of her hand, brought both up into her hair, nails dragging against her scalp. She opened her mouth like she was begging for Agatha’s tongue. 

 

And Agatha gave it to her. She licked into Rio’s mouth like it belonged to her, dragged her tongue across the roof, the back of her teeth, the soft inside of her cheeks- every part she could reach, just to prove she could. Because Rio had asked for it with everything she had and Agatha wasn’t about to say no to that. 

 

They didn’t stop kissing so much as break it in pieces- barely pulling apart before finding each other again. It was all tongue, all friction, all of Rio’s soft, desperate sounds caught in Agatha’s mouth like confessions she had been all too willing to give. They kissed until they couldn’t. Until breathing became a problem and their mouths were too swollen to ignore it. Even then, Agatha barely pulled back- just enough to catch her breath, just enough to hear Rio laugh, soft and wrecked, head tilted forward against hers.

 

“I missed you,” Rio said, voice shredded, smile twitching at the corners of her mouth.

 

Agatha didn’t flinch. She didn’t soften. She stared at her, panting and flushed, and whispered, “I hate you,” just before dragging her back in.

 

And Rio kissed her again like she knew exactly what Agatha meant. Like she didn’t believe a word of it. It wasn’t gentler the second time. They went right back to it, mouths colliding, hands grabbing, like they hadn’t wasted a second apart.

 

Agatha only hated one thing- that no matter how many times she said it, no part of her had ever, even for a second, been capable of truly hating Rio Vidal.

 

-

 

Agatha had made it through one entire shift without caving. Without inviting Rio over. Without suggesting they crash at the same place, even though they were both working all weekend and could’ve easily justified it as practical. 

 

After their Friday night shift, Rio got pulled into a trauma and texted her sometime around sunrise to say not to wait, that she was going to be stuck there forever. It was short. Casual. Practical. Agatha didn’t respond. She just went home alone and pretended that it didn’t bother her that Rio hadn’t walked her out to her car.

 

She told herself it was fine. Reasonable, even. They were adults. Not everything had to be dramatic. Besides, Agatha figured it was healthy not to spend every second together. 

 

After seventeen years of emotionally compartmentalized bullshit, they hadn’t exactly eased back into each other. One kiss outside a bar and suddenly Agatha was waking up in a lake house, a crash course in domesticity, every moment ripe and blooming and too much. And when they returned to the real world, it showed. Agatha tried to be normal about it, but the silence of her own home after Rio was its own kind of violence.

 

And when Agatha woke up Saturday afternoon, hours before her shift, she was inexplicably, irrationally furious. She dragged herself out of bed angry at the world. Angry at her sheets. Angry at the silence in her house. Angry at how cold her room felt without Rio pressed against her like some living furnace.

 

Agatha told herself it had nothing to do with the fact that Rio hadn’t been there to kiss her awake, the way she had every morning at the lake. Nothing to do with the fact that she had gotten used to it far too quickly.

 

That would be ridiculous.

 

Outrageous, really. Especially considering how precarious this whole situation was.

The rhythm of their breathing helped. It reminded her that softness wasn’t something she had to earn. That she could be tender and tired and still be good.

 

By the time her shift ended, she was barely holding it together.

 

And Rio was there.

Agatha took the soda. She said thank you. She smiled, barely.

 

She tried, genuinely, to hold it together.

Rio didn’t say anything. She didn’t move, didn’t flinch, didn’t even look upset. She just blinked, slowly, as if trying to make sense of a sentence in a language she hadn’t heard in years.

I’ve spent years trying to unlearn the shape of you in my life, and now here you are- my safest place and the reason I spent entire seasons trying to silence the answer. No.

She liked being around Rio. Still did. Still felt better for it. Rio was strange, meticulous, sometimes fucking infuriating- but never dull. And somehow, Rio had beaten her to it.

Rio nodded once. “Good. Now get your fine ass in my car.” She shut Agatha’s door for her with one hand, already turning toward her own. “You can take yours back when we get off in the morning. I’m driving.”

When they pulled up outside Agatha’s house, Rio circled to the backseat and pulled out her work backpack along with a small duffle bag.

 

Agatha glanced at her, skeptical. “Were you planning on staying over?”

 

“No. It's the spare scrubs I keep in my car in case someone decides to bleed directly on me, or if I have to deal with fluids that should’ve stayed inside people. You know, fun working in healthcare stuff.”

 

Agatha gave a low, unimpressed hum as they made their way inside. Shoes were left at the door. Upstairs, Rio talked through most of the walk- something about a patient who got flagged for an exam and refused to explain why he had a fork shoved up his ass.

She didn’t say much in return. Didn’t need to. Rio filled the space between them like she always had, and for once, Agatha didn’t feel the urge to take it back.

 

They ended up in the bathroom without saying much. The walk in shower was already running, steam curling out into the open space. Rio stood with the door half open, one arm outstretched under the water, testing the temperature with her fingers.

 

Agatha stayed at the mirror, brushing through her hair, watching Rio’s reflection more than her own.

 

She let her eyes track the line of Rio’s spine, the shape of her ass-

 

Rio spoke- her voice lifted just enough to be heard over the water, but she didn’t turn around.

 

“When did you start hanging eucalyptus up again?”

 

Agatha looked at the bundle hung around the showerhead.

 

She knew this wasn’t the first time Rio had noticed it. She also knew Rio had chosen not to say anything before now, which meant this moment had weight to it, even if Rio tried to pass it off casually. 

 

There had been a time when Agatha picked up the habit from Rio without thinking. Even after everything, she never stopped. She didn’t feel the need to lie.

 

“I never stopped,” Agatha said.

“Nope.”

Rio crossed her arms, tongue pressing into the inside of her cheek as she caught Agatha’s eyes in the mirror. She didn’t say anything right away- then let a slow, amused smirk pull at the corner of her mouth.

 

“Fake ‘I don’t give a fucker,’” Rio said under her breath.

 

Agatha frowned slightly at the reflection. “What?”

 

Rio didn’t bother answering. She turned without hurry and stepped fully into the shower, letting the steam swallow the rest of her expression.

 

“Nothing, sweetheart,” she said over her shoulder, voice light. “Come shower with me.”

 

And Agatha did, without argument.

 

-

 

They spent too long in the shower. It started with Rio reaching around her to adjust the water and never really stopped. At some point, Agatha stopped pretending it was about getting clean. They kept kissing  -slow, greedy, mouths slipping over skin and steam like they'd both forgotten how to let go- and every time one of them pulled away, the other found a reason to start again. By the time they got out, Agatha had no idea how much time had passed. Only that she didn’t care.

 

After, Agatha stood in front of the mirror with the blow dryer, brushing out her hair in sections while Rio wandered off to dig through her drawers and eventually tugged on one of Agatha’s oversized t-shirts and nothing else before climbing into bed.

 

She was already flicking through movie options by the time Agatha finished up.

 

“For the love of god,” Agatha muttered, catching sight of the screen. “Are you seriously about to put on The Land Before Time ?”

 

Rio looked over at her, slightly offended, from under the blanket. “It has dinosaurs, Agatha. It’s a fucking classic.”

 

Agatha didn’t fight it. She threw on boxers and one of the thin strapped tank tops she slept in, then crawled into bed and sat back against the headboard, adjusting the pillows behind her. She didn’t even get a full second to adjust before Rio rolled over her, unapologetically claiming the space between her legs and leaning back against her chest like she belonged there.

 

She didn’t roll her eyes. She didn’t make a joke or shift uncomfortably like it was too much. When Rio finally stilled, Agatha wrapped her arms around her waist and pressed a kiss to her shoulder. Then she rested her chin there, quiet.

 

And sure, maybe Agatha tasted a little bile at the back of her throat from how disgustingly soft she was letting herself be- but honestly, what else was new.

-

 

Needless to say, Agatha regretted every decision that had led her to this moment.

 

By the time Littlefoot’s mother died, Rio was already sniffling audibly. Agatha stared at the TV in horror, her gaze flicking again and again to the remote still clutched in Rio’s hand, trying to devise a strategy for stealing it before this got any worse.

 

“How the fuck is this a children’s movie?” Agatha whispered, incredulous.

 

Rio didn’t answer. Probably couldn’t- her sniffling had fully taken over. Agatha just sat there, slack jawed, arms still around Rio, willingly being held hostage in her own bed by a grown woman crying over The Land Before Time.

 

And then it happened.

 

The shadow scene.

 

The part where Littlefoot mistakes his own shadow for his mother’s -runs to it, hopeful, before realizing the truth- was, somehow, even worse than her actual death. And Rio, this absolute fucking menace, lifted her arm, waved the remote weakly in the air, then let it drop uselessly against Agatha’s leg as she muttered, “Oh no fucking shot,” and burst into tears.

 

“Turn it off! Turn it off, you fucking sadist!” Agatha yelled, crying now too and beyond the point of reason, while she tried to wrestle the remote from Rio.

 

But Rio wouldn’t let go. She clutched it tighter and wailed, head thrown back dramatically against Agatha’s shoulder. “No! It’s so good! ”

 

Eventually, when the storm of tears finally started to subside, Agatha -still hiccupping and snotty- asked, somewhere between a laugh and a gasp, why Rio even liked this goddamn movie in the first place.

 

Rio turned her head slightly and, with the utmost seriousness, whispered, “I fucking love dinosaurs.”

 

Agatha let out a broken laugh and wiped her eyes on Rio’s shoulder, still sniffing, still barely composed.

 

Rio grabbed her phone and snapped a picture: both of them flushed and puffy, tear-streaked and mid laugh. Agatha’s eyes were squeezed shut, her face red and blotchy from crying. Rio looked feral- mouth open, nose running, hair stuck to her forehead. Her shirt was crumpled from where she’d wiped her face with it, and the shoulder was soaked from Agatha doing the same. It was a disaster. A perfect one.

 

 

Chapter End Notes

hope you all enjoyed this chapter!!

as always, thank you for the music (kudos, comments, etc.) !!!!

Chapter 13: tomorrow, maybe

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

It had been three months since Agatha suffered through The Land Before Time , woke up with Rio in her bed, got dressed beside her, and rode to work together without making it a conversation.

 

In the grand scheme of things, it hadn’t been that long. But apparently it was long enough for Agatha to forget where the line had been- if she had ever actually bothered to draw one at all. Or maybe she just stopped looking for it. Maybe it blurred so slowly she convinced herself it never existed. Softened under the persistence of someone who used to, and still somehow did, know Agatha better than anyone else.

 

They were in each other’s space more often than not. No plan. No routine. Just a trail of evidence neither of them bothered to hide:

 

Rio’s shoes by the door. A phone charger plugged in on the side of Agatha’s bed that Rio slept on. Agatha’s lotion in Rio’s bathroom- showing up out of nowhere after she’d complained about forgetting it. Agatha’s laundry folded and sorted in a way Agatha never folded it. An extra toothbrush in each of their bathrooms. Rio’s shampoo nearly empty in Agatha’s shower, replaced by Agatha -not that she was admitting it- without comment.

 

They worked. Came home. Not always to the same place, but often enough. They didn’t have sleepovers every night. Agatha was glad for that- though she wouldn’t have known how to explain it if asked. It gave her the illusion of control. She still went to the gym alone. Still met Jen for drinks. Still came home some mornings and crawled into bed by herself, which was, if anything, mildly fucking irritating. 

 

But when she stayed at Rio’s -or Rio stayed at hers- sleep came easier. Quieter. Like her body had finally stopped bracing to wake up in Chicago and find it had all been a dream. Like it hadn’t forgotten, this time, where she was.

 

Being this close to Rio wasn’t theoretical anymore. It used to come with boundaries- close enough to memorize every detail, never close enough to touch any of it. There were parts of her Agatha had never been permitted to know. Not when they were only best friends.

 

But now, cautiously, like she didn’t quite trust the generosity of it, Agatha was learning.

 

It didn’t happen all at once. Rio handed herself over in pieces, in habits she didn’t know she was revealing. Agatha learned that Rio always reached for her fingers when she fidgeted- tracing the joints, tugging gently, twisting Agatha’s rings without seeming to notice. Like Agatha was the thing her body trusted first. Her hand would settle over Agatha’s chest when they kissed too long, too deep, like she was trying to memorize the rhythm of what lived beneath it. That she bites the inside of her cheek when she’s trying not to say something sweet.

 

Agatha didn’t know when she started memorizing it all. Only that now, if any of it disappeared- if Rio stopped reaching for her hand, if she stopped tripping over Rio’s shoes every time she walked through the door of her own house. Agatha would notice. Would ache for it, probably.

 

It would’ve been easier if she didn’t notice. If she could keep pretending this was physical, manageable, on her terms. But Agatha had always been observant, especially when it came to Rio. And now there were too many details, too many small things stitched into her days now to stop. 

 

There was no milestone. No conversation. Just three months of quietly getting away with it- whatever it was. Rio kept showing up. Agatha kept letting her. Nobody labeled it. Nobody pushed. And Agatha, who hated explaining herself more than she hated most things, didn’t have to. They didn’t talk about what they were. They just… were. And that was enough.

 

-

 

Most of their mornings off together blurred into each other over those three months. Agatha would sit at the kitchen island during staff meetings with laptop open, her camera off, pretending to listen while flipping through the Westview Weekly , which now came out monthly for reasons no one had ever adequately explained. She had only put herself back on the mailing list for the crossword- a fact she refused to unpack, even privately.

 

In the beginning, Rio would wander in wearing socks, an oversized t-shirt, and no underwear, muttering that the Keurig brewed coffee so flavorless it always tricked her into thinking she was coming down with a sinus infection. Over time, the complaints softened into a grimace. Then a squint. Sometimes, if Agatha was lucky, Rio would take a sip, wrinkle her nose, and spit it back into the mug- only to set it just within Agatha’s reach. Then Rio would stare at her- completely silent, clearly waiting.

 

Agatha drank it every time. Of course she did. And Rio would watch, unblinking, like it didn’t count unless she saw it happen. Like watching Agatha drink it was the whole point. Which was, objectively, disgusting. And weird. And, somehow, very Rio- the exact kind of thing Agatha should have put a stop to.

 

But Agatha never did. She drank it, made direct eye contact, and quietly got away with it- paid the small, revolting price of drinking coffee Rio had spit back into a mug, without admitting she only did it to see the gap between her teeth when she smiled at Agatha afterward.

It wasn’t obvious at first. Just a few familiar moves, spread out over three months- a game Agatha had started seventeen years ago circling back like it had never ended.

 

Rio snooped the way Agatha stole her things- compulsively, competitively, and -only recently- with enough creativity and deranged flair to turn petty theft into foreplay, complete with framed evidence and a fucked up sense of hospitality.

 

Agatha had always stolen Rio’s things. Not anything important- just stupid, obvious shit Rio would definitely notice was missing. 

 

That was the fun of it. There was comfort in possession, sure, but also in chaos. A younger, less dignified version of herself used to hide things in increasingly deranged places just to see what Rio would do about it. 

 

Back then, Rio never said a word. She’d just find whatever she was supposed to find and move it somewhere painfully obvious- on purpose, obviously. Agatha took it as a challenge. So she escalated. Started stashing things in her underwear drawer, her box of sex toys, the bottom of her dirty laundry basket. Places no one should be. Places she wanted Rio to be.

 

And of course Rio snooped. Agatha had made sure of it. At twenty-four, she used to check afterward- not because she was nervous, but because she wanted proof. She wanted Rio to take the bait. To slip, to steal, to be a freak. But she never took anything. Not once. Not even when Agatha made the message loud and perverse and impossibly fucking clear.

 

Or so Agatha thought.

 

Five weeks into it -whatever they were doing- Agatha noticed the first photo after coming home from hanging out with Jen. It was resting on the credenza beneath her television- framed, angled just enough to be intentional. One of the pictures she’d stolen from Rio’s apartment. The one of all four of them -Rio, Jen, Alice, and herself- curled on Rio’s old couch, crammed into a single frame like nothing could ever touch them. She’d hidden it at the back of a kitchen cabinet, behind a stack of things she never used. And now it was back. Out in the open.

 

She ignored it.

 

A week later, another one surfaced.

 

On her nightstand this time. Just the two of them- young, pressed together on Rio’s old fire escape, laughing at nothing. She’d buried that one in the back corner of her underwear drawer, under a few pairs she never wore, like that somehow made it easier to forget.

 

Agatha responded by doing the only thing Rio wouldn’t expect. She left the frames out where Rio put them. Didn’t move them. Didn’t speak. Just let them sit there like they belonged.

 

But she saw how Rio looked at them when she came over. Quick glances. Cheek dented just slightly from where she was biting it- trying not to smile, trying not to say something so insufferably fucking sweet.

 

Seven weeks in, Rio upped the ante. 

 

Agatha came home and found a pair of a underwear folded neatly on her pillow. Familiar, but wrong. It took a second to click. She hadn’t seen them in fifteen years. They weren’t misplaced. They were gone. Stolen. Forgotten. And now returned, with no explanation, no shame.

 

All that time, she’d been trying to provoke something that had already happened. Rio had stolen her underwear- just like Agatha always hoped she would. She just hadn’t noticed.

It was disgusting. Obviously. But it was also romantic- in the most specific, personal, deeply fucked up way imaginable. And undeniably, the most deranged gesture of affection Agatha had ever received.

 

This was just the latest round. She stole. Rio found. And now, apparently, Rio curated.

 

And because Agatha was still Agatha, she did the next logical thing.

 

She stole all of Rio’s butter knives. Hid them in increasingly inconvenient places around her house- under her mattress, inside her current box of sex toys, buried just beneath the soil in the flower bed out front. Pointless sabotage. A silent little tantrum.

 

And the final knife, Agatha wrapped in a pair of her own dirty underwear. Still reeking of the night before on the couch, when Rio had done nothing but dry hump her- one hand cupped over cotton, fingers pressed firm, unmoving. No dirty talk. Nothing theatrical. Only Rio’s breath- hot and shallow against her ear, the side of Rio’s face pressed close, lashes brushing Agatha’s temple.

She buried the wrapped knife in a basket of her dirty laundry and moved the fuck on.

 

It wasn’t forgiveness. Or closure. It wasn’t even about winning.

 

It was maintenance. Something to trim back the vines curling around her ribs. To swallow the petals behind her teeth instead of saying what she meant- just for a little while longer. 

 

Agatha offered cutlery and cotton and the faint suggestion of a threat.

 

And if Rio didn’t see it for what it was, Agatha would try again tomorrow.

Rio kept up with Agatha’s front yard. Not just once- every time it needed it. Mowed. Watered. Dragged the hose back into place without being asked. She never said anything. Never announced it like a favor. It was just upkeep- quiet, consistent, annoying in the way that made it impossible to tell her to stop.

 

Then, on a random Wednesday, she spent the entire day on Agatha’s backyard. Showed up before noon, kissed Agatha hello, and got to work- raked, trimmed, cleared out the corners no one else saw. At one point, she looked up and asked if they should stain the deck before it got cold. Agatha shrugged. 

 

That night, Agatha ordered new outdoor furniture. Overbuilt, overpriced, meant for people who hosted things. A long table. Heavy chairs. Lights she didn’t need. It arrived two days later.

 

Sometimes they sat out there, just the two of them. Smoked. Shared a blanket even when it wasn’t that cold. Rio would pass her the lighter without looking, always somehow knowing when she reached for it. Their knees would bump. Their hands would stay close. Every now and then, Rio would tilt her head and say something stupid just to make her laugh. And it worked. It always worked.

 

And sometimes, Rio would lean over and kiss her- soft, thoughtless. A brush of her mouth against Agatha’s cheek, or the corner of her mouth, or wherever she could reach without moving too much. No lead up. No comment. Just a kiss people gave when they already knew it would be returned.

 

Agatha never stopped her. Never made a joke out of it. She just leaned in, kissed her back, and let it happen.

 

It wasn’t a big deal.

 

-

 

They both went to game nights. They kept their distance in the ways that counted. No lingering touches. No hovering. Agatha kept her hands to herself, and Rio mirrored the restraint. There were no questions. No stares. They weren’t obvious. Not really.

 

Still, they found each other. Always. In the middle of a loud table, over a losing hand, across a crowded room- Agatha would glance up and Rio would already be looking. Sometimes with a smirk. Sometimes with nothing more than a stare that lingered too long. They moved around each other the way they always had: easy, unthinking, intimate. Close enough to feel it. Careful enough to make sure no one else did.

 

Sometimes they snuck off. A hallway, the bathroom, anywhere that felt far enough away to breathe. There was one night Agatha had spent the entire time trying not to look at Rio. Or, more accurately, trying not to notice that Rio wasn’t looking back. She could feel it. The ache of attention not being paid. And when Rio’s eyes finally met hers -brown turned a shade darker- Agatha got up without a word and walked straight to Rio’s car.

 

Rio followed. They fucked in the back seat.

 

They came back separately. A few minutes apart.

The others were caught in the middle of a loud debate over whether Teen had cheated during the last round, and no one looked up when she slipped back into her seat. Her drink was still sweating onto the table, the condensation pooling at the base, untouched. She reached for it and kept her eyes on the game, letting the noise wash over her until her pulse slowed to something manageable.

 

A few minutes later, Rio sauntered back in- shirt wrinkled, expression lazy, like she'd only stepped out for fresh air and not sex that had left Agatha biting the inside of her cheek to keep quiet. She dropped into the seat beside Sage, still chewing the last bite of a brownie.

 

Sage barely looked away from the game when she asked, casually, “Where’d you go?”

 

Rio didn’t bother with words. She held up two fingers and flicked her tongue between them obnoxious and smug and deeply proud of herself.

 

The color drained from Sage’s face so fast it was almost impressive.

 

Agatha didn’t even blink. She reached for the nearest Jenga block and whipped it across the table. Rio ducked easily, the block sailing past her head and bouncing against the wall behind her.

 

She grinned, teeth bared, eyes cutting toward Agatha with the same look she’d worn ten minutes ago in her backseat.

 

Later that night, in the kitchen, Jen leaned against the fridge like she’d been waiting all night to get Agatha alone. 

 

“So. Car sex?” Jen asked, already smirking. “Rate it. One to ten.”

 

Agatha rolled her eyes and reached for the whiskey.

 

“Eleven.”

The group hangouts kept happening. Birthdays, game nights, the occasional special breakfast cobbled together after work. Sometimes they arrived separately. Sometimes they didn’t. Maintained the illusion of moderation in between. They were careful. Enough space to pretend. Enough heat to make it interesting.

 

At some point, Agatha started treating it like a game.

 

She started paying attention. Started keeping score. How long it took for Rio to crack. Whether she’d get a look across the table or be ignored entirely. Whether touching Rio’s wrist in front of everyone would earn her a shiver or a shrug.

 

Sometimes Rio cracked early, gave her a look across the table that made her forget what she was saying mid sentence. Other times it took longer. More work. A hand on Rio’s wrist, a whisper too close to her ear, a smile that said don’t you dare pretend you’re not thinking about it. Agatha kept going until something gave. Until she saw it: the slip, the shiver, the way Rio would bite her bottom lip and try not to grin.

Out front, everyone lingered. People hugged Jen. Laughed. Took one last round of blurry, overexposed photos. Agatha waited her turn, half listening to Sage complain about Billy forgetting his card inside.

Agatha blinked. Her heart thudded once, annoyed.

“Don’t drive like a crazy person stalking her,” Jen said into her ear.

 

Agatha grunted. Bolted anyway.

It didn’t.

Of course it was.

They didn’t talk about it.

She didn’t linger when Rio talked to her adoptive mother, didn’t ask what they’d discussed, didn’t offer to say hi. And Rio, mercifully, didn’t push.

 

Because what was she supposed to say? That the thought of showing up to Lilia’s house with Rio - with her- made her want to peel her skin off? 

 

Agatha missed it. Of course, she missed it. Missed Lilia’s food, the music that always played too low to be noticed, the way it had once felt easy. Like she belonged. But then everything happened. And she stopped showing up. And no one chased her. And now she couldn’t stomach the thought of going back- of seeing Lilia’s face, of hearing her say it’s been a while with too much softness. Or worse- ask something. Or say nothing. Or look at her like she already knew the answer. Like she had opinions about Agatha’s life choices. Or the time it took.  

 

So no, Agatha didn’t go to Tuesday night dinners. Rio didn’t ask her to. And they both pretended that wasn’t its own kind of conversation.

 

Because it wasn’t about dinner.

 

It was about showing up to a place she used to call home, standing in that kitchen again, and knowing full well what she left behind. What might still be waiting for her if she could just get over herself and go.

 

But not everything had to happen all at once.

 

She stayed home. Let Rio go alone. Told herself she’d be ready eventually.

Then she hears the steady hush of rain come next, soft against the glass, like it’s been falling for hours.

It’s too bright in the way cloudy afternoons can be- muted, gentle, but still too much when you’re made of sleep. She squints for a second, then shuts her eye again.
