Goosebumps rise along her arm. Agatha tells herself it’s the breeze from the window.

 

With a sigh that borders on dramatic, Agatha peels herself out of bed. She shuffles to the bathroom, does what she needs to do, and makes no attempt to be graceful about it. When she returns, it’s with the singular goal of reclaiming what she lost by getting up.

 

This time, she doesn’t ease back under the covers. She throws them off Rio entirely, climbs on top of her, knees on either side of her hips, and buries her face in the warm space between Rio’s neck and shoulder.

 

Rio laughs softly -just a puff of air in her hair- and wraps her arms around her without hesitation.

 

“Good morning to you too, goose,” Rio said, voice soft. 

 

It was four in the afternoon, but Agatha didn’t bother correcting her. She just grunted softly and pressed closer, letting the warmth of Rio’s body and the softness of her voice distract her from the clock and everything waiting on the other side of it.

 

“I’m not going to work,” she murmured into the curve of Rio’s collarbone. The words came out half hearted, more complaint than plan, her mouth brushing skin like punctuation.

 

“Yes, you are,” Rio said, tilting her head to give Agatha more of her neck. “But I’ll act surprised when you complain about it for the next two and a half hours.”

 

Agatha didn’t respond. She pressed her face in harder, mouth warm against Rio’s neck, hands sliding beneath the hem of Rio’s -no, her- shirt like that distinction still mattered. She let her fingers roam slowly, tracing the shape of ribs she already knew, like knowing them wasn’t the point.

 

Rio’s hand came up slowly and brushed her hair back from her face with a care that always made Agatha feel a little off balance. Not because it was tender, but because it wasn’t hesitant. Her fingers lingered under the curve of Agatha’s ear, just resting there, like she was grounding them both in the touch.

 

Agatha pulled back a little. Not far- just enough to look at Rio.

 

Her eyes dropped to Rio’s mouth first, because that was always where they went. There was the start of a smile there, barely formed, like Rio was in on some joke Agatha hadn’t realized she’d told. But it wasn’t smug. It was quiet.

 

Their eyes met.

 

Then Rio exhaled, and the sound that came out wasn’t a laugh and wasn’t a sigh. It caught somewhere in between, like something had almost slipped out and gotten caught at the last second.

 

And Agatha watched the smile fade- not dramatically, not all at once. Just slowly, like Rio was stepping back into a space she had been circling for a long time. Her gaze moved across Agatha’s face as if searching for something.

 

There was no fear in it. No nervousness. But it was serious in a way that made Agatha feel every part of herself go still.

 

Rio’s thumb brushed her jaw once, soft but steady, and Agatha recognized the look in her eyes before she had to name it. Rio looked the same way she had at the lakehouse- the last time she’d come close to saying something that would change everything. And Agatha had shut it down with a kiss because it had been too much. Too big. Too soon. Or maybe not too soon. She didn’t know anymore.

 

But now, Agatha didn’t stop her.

 

She didn’t move at all.

 

If Rio was going to say it, Agatha would let her. Whatever it was. Maybe she was too tired to interrupt the moment. Maybe she just didn’t have the energy to pretend she didn’t want it.

 

Rio’s mouth parted.

 

Agatha saw the tiny, familiar gap between her teeth that she had always thought about far too often. Rio closed her mouth again, opened it, and nothing came out. Not a sound. Not even a breath.

 

Her brown eyes flicked to Agatha’s lips.

 

Then her hand slid from her jaw to the base of her neck, fingers curling slightly, pressing just enough to guide Agatha in.

 

And maybe Rio didn’t say it because she thought Agatha wasn’t ready. Maybe she didn’t say it because it was already here, in the room, in the space between their bodies and breath and the stupid mug still sitting on the nightstand. 

 

But it didn’t matter that Rio hadn’t said it.

 

Because the second their mouths met, Agatha felt it. All of it.

 

In the way Rio kissed her- deep, slow, like her mouth had been waiting for this and didn’t mind the time it took to arrive. No performance. No rush. Just a certainty that folded around her like a secret she didn’t have to protect anymore.

 

Agatha let her. 

 

She kissed Rio back with aching ease. Let herself be touched, explored- Rio’s hands sliding over her like a map already memorized but still needed to trace. Her shoulders. Her hips. The soft inside of her thigh. Her spine. 

 

It wasn’t about want. It never had been. 

 

It was about a truth that had rooted itself quietly between them, growing in the dark like something that had learned patience. Not loud, not sudden- just steady, stretching through every silence they never touched, winding around every glance they refused to hold too long. It had weathered years without light, without language, without proximity.

 

Agatha, even now, wasn’t sure if the ache in her chest came from how long it had lived there, or from how impossible it suddenly felt to keep pretending she didn’t recognize its shape.

 

Rio’s hand moved again, slower now, until it settled over Agatha’s chest. Her thumb traced idle patterns above the bone.

 

Agatha didn’t stop kissing her, her pulse thrumming beneath Rio’s palm, painfully aware of every inch of her body that had softened beneath this touch. 

 

And maybe Agatha should’ve been annoyed by that. Or unnerved. Or anything but this.

 

But all she could think about was how, of course, this was the spot that Rio’s hand always reached for. How, this time, Rio had reached for Agatha’s heart -carefully, deliberately- and held it like she meant to keep it. Cradled it. Spoke to it like it was something alive. Whispered to it promises Agatha was beginning to believe. 

 

She could almost laugh at the audacity of it- of Rio always knowing where to press. As if it were natural to return there, to coax bloom from bone. 

 

When Rio pulled back, Agatha followed- without thinking, without meaning to, chasing her mouth. Craving the taste of blossom on her tongue, the impossible sweetness of something finally in full bloom.

 

Their lips met again- gently this time. Less kiss, more confirmation.

 

Agatha pulled back, slow and careful, their faces still close. Rio’s eyes opened like she’d forgotten they might- fluttering once, then fixing on her. And when she saw Agatha already looking, her lips lifted into the smallest smile. Breathless. Honest.

 

“Hi,” Rio whispered.

 

Agatha almost smiled.

 

“Hey,” she said, just as quietly.

 

Then Rio moved in, not to kiss her again, but to press her face into Agatha’s neck. Her arms slipped around her waist like she was giving herself something to hold onto before she said too much.

 

Agatha’s arms came up without thinking. One around her shoulders, the other curling around the back of Rio’s head, holding her close.

 

Rio didn’t move for a long time. Just breathed against her neck like it was the only place she still made sense.

 

Then without pulling away, Rio turned her head- resting her cheek against Agatha’s shoulder, eyes angled toward the window.

 

Her voice came soft. Barely a breath.

 

“The rain sounds nice, doesn’t it?”

 

Agatha didn’t answer right away. Just kept holding her, eyes drifting toward the window, where the rain tapped soft patterns across the glass.

 

It did. But that wasn’t why Rio said it.

 

Agatha knew her too well for that.

 

But still, she didn’t call Rio on it. Didn’t say you don’t need to protect me anymore . Didn’t say stop treating me like I’ll disappear if you breathe too hard. Didn’t say please, I want you to say it.

 

Instead, she held Rio a little tighter. And eventually, quietly, Agatha said, “Yeah. It does.”

 

-

 

Three months of letting it happen. Three months of getting away with it. Three months of Rio being hers in every way that didn’t require saying so. And three months of Agatha not saying it. Not when she should. Not when she wanted to. Not even now.

 

The rain would speak for them both a little while longer.

 

Tomorrow, maybe, Agatha would try again.

 

 

 

Chapter End Notes

ALSO, i see some of y'alls fanart inspired by this fic and I'm giggling and kicking my feet every time I come across one!!! LOVE YOU ALL DESPERATLEY!!

Chapter 14: you built this cage

Chapter Notes

Warning: the last 4k words of this chapter contains lots of angst, emotional damage, and questionable coping mechanisms. Read at your own risk.

Everything will be okay, I promise!!!

Happy reading ;)

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Agatha had spent the last two nights in the postpartum overnight room again. Tonight made three, her last shift of the week. The babies were different this time, twin girls with round cheeks and heavy eyelids, nothing to worry about. They would be going home in the morning.

 

She was halfway through her charting, about to start her second hands-on time, when a soft knock tapped against the already open door. Her head turned without thinking. The moment Agatha saw who it was, a small smile tugged at the corner of her mouth before she could stop it. She pressed her lips together, turned back to the screen.

 

“You’re up here early,” Agatha said, eyes narrowing slightly as she squinted at the screen.

 

Behind her, Rio’s voice floated in. “Heard you guys were having a party. Didn’t want to miss out on the fun.”

 

“Wildest party in town. Open bar’s all formula.”

 

“There’s nothing going on downstairs,” Rio said as she wandered in and dropped into one of the loungers beside Agatha’s workstation. “Figured I’d come up and harass you while I could.”

 

Agatha stopped charting. Her fingers stilled on the keyboard, then slipped away. She swiveled slowly in her chair to face Rio, arms folding over her chest like she wasn’t already smiling a little. “How generous of you,” she said, and this time, there was no hiding the warmth in her voice.

 

“How’s your night been so far?” Rio asked, leaning back like she planned to stay awhile.

 

Agatha shrugged, pushing back from the workstation. “Alright. I’m about to start feeds.” She stood and stretched slightly before glancing down at Rio. “You wanna help?”

 

Rio blinked. “What?”

 

“Do you want to feed a baby, Rio?”

 

There was a beat of silence, then: 

 

“I mean… is that even allowed?”

 

Agatha rolled her eyes as she pulled a bottle of milk from the warmer, “We let nursing students do it all the time. You’ll be fine.”

 

“But what if something happens?”

 

Agatha turned slightly, giving Rio a dry look.

 

“I don’t know. What if it chokes? Stops breathing? I drop it?”

 

“Good thing you’ve got a certified NICU nurse standing right here. Also,” she gestured toward the row of glowing monitors above the bassinets, “They’re hooked up to monitors.”

 

Agatha reached into the bassinet and lifted the smaller of the twins- arguably the sweeter one, though she’d never say so. She adjusted the baby against her chest, then turned toward Rio.

 

“Come on,” she murmured, keeping her voice quiet. “Put on a gown. Let’s see if you’re brave enough to hold her first.”

 

Rio gave her a look like she’d just been asked to disarm a bomb. Still, she stood, grabbed the hospital gown draped over the back of the second lounger, and slipped it on. She sat back down and held her hands out, stiffly, palms up.

 

Agatha stared at her for a long second, the corner of her mouth twitching despite herself. She was trying to be serious, but Rio in an oversized gown with that vaguely panicked look on her face was making it difficult. She stepped closer and eased the baby into Rio’s arms.

 

“Support her neck,” Agatha said gently, hoping softness might somehow compensate for Rio’s very visible alarm.

 

Rio glanced at the crib card, clipped to the edge of the bassinet. “Delilah,” she said, mostly to herself.

 

Delilah responded by squirming in Rio’s hands, letting out a faint, suspicious whimper, and kicking one tiny foot free of the swaddle- like she could already tell this woman had no idea what she was doing.

 

And Rio -brave, sure, but absolutely not a natural- held the baby at arm’s length, elbows awkward, every muscle in her body overthinking it.

 

“Jesus Christ,” Agatha muttered, staring down at Rio, a little mortified. “Can you relax? You’re holding a baby, not a bomb.”

 

Rio looked up at her with wide eyes and a tense jaw. “That’s basically the same thing,” she hissed, furious and defensive, as the baby made another soft, unsettled sound.

 

Agatha sighed, grabbed the bottle she’d set on the counter, then bent down and yanked the lever on the side of the lounger. The chair squeaked as it kicked back, the footrest sliding out beneath Rio’s legs.

 

“Bend your knees,” Agatha said, already pulling up her chair next to it.

 

Rio blinked at her. “What?”

 

“Just do it. It'll help.”

 

She did, albeit stiffly, clearly skeptical of everything.

 

“Good,” Agatha said, sitting down. “Now rest her against your thighs. One hand under her neck, let her settle into your legs. You don’t have to keep her in a death grip.”

 

Rio followed her instructions, bending her knees and settling the baby onto her thighs. It took a second, but once she got her hands in the right place both she and the baby seemed to relax a little.

 

Agatha handed Rio the bottle, uncapped and warm, and leaned in beside her to guide her hand. “Tilt it just a little more,” she murmured, gently angling Rio’s wrist. “There.”

 

Delilah latched on the first try, sucking steadily like she’d been waiting all night for it.

 

And Rio exhaled. Her hands were still a little tense, but her grip had softened.

 

“See?” Agatha said, quiet, leaning back in her chair with just the faintest trace of smug. “Not so bad.”

 

Rio side-eyed her without turning her head and grunted. 

 

Agatha didn’t say anything else. She just kept watching- Rio’s hands, the way her thumb brushed unconsciously along the baby’s neck, like she didn’t even know she was doing it. The crease in her brow had eased, and her breathing had synced up with the baby’s in that hypnotic way newborns can make the whole world slow down.

 

It was stupid -definitely stupid- but Agatha couldn’t look away. There was something about Rio in that ridiculous oversized gown, hunched over a baby she’d sworn she didn’t know how to hold, suddenly all soft hands and careful movements.

 

It hit Agatha in some deep, inexplicable place she didn’t have the tools to process. It was hormonal, or existential, or both. Her chest went weird. Her stomach dipped. And the longer she watched, the worse it got.

 

“Okay,” Rio said after a minute, barely above a whisper. “You can stop staring now.”

 

Agatha blinked. She cleared her throat, scooted her chair back to the workstation a little too aggressively, and dragged the monitor closer to make a show of clicking through tabs.

 

Right. She was here to chart feeds, not spiral into some full-body hallucination about domestic bliss. Her ovaries weren’t doing anything weird. She wasn’t feeling things. Certainly not things about Rio holding a baby. That would be clinically fucking insane, if Agatha had anything to say about it. Which she didn’t. Obviously. 

 

And just as she was mentally lecturing herself back into sanity, Rio spoke again.

 

“This is harder than it looks,” Rio muttered, adjusting the bottle a little. “You guys make it look so easy.”

 

“Comes with the job,” Agatha said flatly, even though her own mouth had gone dry, which felt unfair.  She glanced back -because of course she did- and immediately regretted it. Rio was still feeding the baby. Still not dropping her. Still looking way too much like someone who could do this again tomorrow and be fine.

 

Agatha wrenched her attention back to the screen, pretending it might have the power to save her.

 

And then -because Rio was a menace and had no interest in letting Agatha live- she added, far too casually:

 

“You ever think about having one?”

 

The answer formed instantly, in layers, contradicting itself on arrival. 

 

No. Yes. Absolutely not. With you, maybe. Yes. But definitely no. And still, somehow, yes again.

 

Agatha said none of it.

 

“Sure,” she replied instead, flat and casual, eyes still fixed on the screen in front of her.

 

“Why didn’t you and Satan ever…?” Rio didn’t finish the sentence. She didn’t have to. Agatha could hear the rest of it in her voice, the hesitation, the distaste, the way she practically gagged on the image of her and Wanda procreating.

 

It would have been funny if it weren’t so bleak.

 

The truth was, Agatha had done many regrettable things in her life, had made choices that bordered on self destruction more often than not. But even at her worst, she had never been foolish enough to bring a child into the world with Wanda.

 

Wanda had brought it up. Of course she had. With her wide-eyed optimism and her relentless conviction that love could fill every crack and hold it all together. She talked about it like it was inevitable, like it was the next logical step.

 

And every single time, Agatha had shut it down. Not kindly, not delicately, and certainly not in any way that left the door cracked open. She hadn’t offered compromise or comfort or even basic human softness. No, she had ended those conversations with finality. Vehemently. Swiftly. Expeditiously. Other SAT words that meant absolutely the fuck not.

 

She’d told herself it was because the timing was wrong, because the marriage needed to be more stable, because they hadn’t figured enough out yet. But the truth had always been quieter, deeper, and infinitely more uncomfortable.

 

Agatha had known that marriage wouldn’t last. Not just suspected. Known . And maybe, though she’d never admit it aloud, not even under threat, she’d known even then that she would end up right where she was now. Back in Westview. Back at the center of her orbit.

 

“Wanda wanted one,” she said finally, her voice cool, measured. “Talked about it all the time. Picked names. Had entire Pinterest boards.” She paused, lips twitching into something a little evil. “I told her no. Every time. Loudly. Repeatedly. In several languages, I think.”

 

Rio let out a laugh. “Good. Those kids probably would’ve come out ginger and ugly as fuck.” She looked down immediately after, eyes landing on the baby in her lap, and her voice softened as she mumbled an apology. “Sorry. That wasn’t very nice.”

 

Delilah didn’t seem to mind, still sucking lazily at the bottle, perfectly content.

 

Agatha looked at Rio without meaning to. And for a moment, forgot to pretend otherwise. Her mouth parted slightly, not enough to speak, just enough to betray her. On her face, it probably read like disgust, but it wasn’t that. Not even close. It was the opposite. Completely, dangerously the opposite.

 

“What about you?” Agatha asked, without meaning to, and immediately hated herself for it.

 

Rio looked up. Her brows lifted slightly, not in confusion but in cautious interest, like she could already sense the terrain shifting. 

 

Agatha could feel the heat in ears instantly, and before Rio could respond, she rushed to clarify, tripping over her words as they came. “I mean… kids. Babies. Having one. Eventually.” She cringed inwardly, heard herself fumbling and made it worse by trying to course correct, “Not that you and I-  I didn’t mean it like that. Obviously.”

 

Another breath, another second of silence. Her cheeks were hot now, her thoughts spiraling, but she forced herself to finish it. “I’m asking if you ever picture yourself as the kind of person who wants that.”

 

Rio didn’t answer right away. She blinked, like she was trying to decide whether Agatha was serious, or if this was one of those moments she was supposed to laugh off. Her eyes dropped to the baby in her lap, her fingers adjusting the bottle without needing to. Delilah was still drinking, her small hand curled against Rio’s wrist.

 

“I don’t know,” Rio said finally, her voice lower now, smaller than it had been all night. “I used to think no. I… I worry a lot. About everything. Obsess over stupid shit. I convince myself something’s wrong even when it’s not.” She paused, her eyes still on the baby. “I think it’d be hard on me. The mess of it. The noise. Not knowing what’s normal and what’s not. It’d be a lot for my brain.” Another pause, and this time she looked up. Her eyes found Agatha’s and didn’t look away. “But lately, I don’t know. I think about it sometimes.”

 

Agatha hadn’t expected her to answer like that.

 

She’d expected a joke, maybe a brush off, something dumb and self protective that she could match with her own deflection and move on like the question had never happened. But instead, Rio said it softly. Thoughtfully. Like she’d been turning it over in her head for a while.  

 

And Agatha felt something catch low in her chest.

 

She didn’t know what to do with the image of Rio like that- vulnerable, self aware, and impossibly gentle with a baby pressed against her thighs. She looked at ease and completely out of her depth at the same time. Agatha didn’t realize she was staring until Rio’s eyes met hers again.

 

Agatha looked away fast, back to the chart, suddenly wanted to fucking vomit all over the place.

 

“You’d probably be better at it than you think,” Agatha managed to force out, eyes still locked on the screen in front of her. “You’re good with her.”

 

There was a beat of silence after that -too long, too charged- and Agatha could feel Rio looking at her.

 

Abruptly, Agatha stood.

 

“Okay, give her back,” Agatha snapped, reaching out with both hands. “She needs to be burped.”

 

Rio blinked, startled. “What?”

 

“Bottle’s almost empty, which means she needs to burp, and you’re holding her wrong for that anyway, so-” Agatha made an impatient grabby motion. “Give. Her. Back.”

 

Rio held tight to the baby for half a second too long, eyes narrowing as something clicked behind them. Then her face changed completely.

 

Her mouth fell open, and the smirk that followed was slow, predatory, and downright radiant . Her tongue did that fucking thing where it poked into her cheek.

 

“Oh my god,” Rio breathed. “Agatha Harkness. Do you want me to put a-”

 

“Stop talking!”

 

Agatha snatched the baby out of her arms, cradling her with dramatic efficiency, like the baby herself had been complicit in the crime. “Look,” she snapped, cutting Rio off before she could get another word out. “I don’t know what you’re about to say, and I don’t want to know.” She adjusted the baby with practiced hands- Delilah now upright in her lap, back to Agatha’s chest, one hand cradling her chin and chest in a perfect C-hold, while the other began patting between her shoulder blades with determination.

 

“Whatever you think just happened,” Agatha continued, her voice dropping into a harsh whisper, “ did not happen. It didn’t. And if you plan on staying in this room, you’re going to keep your mouth shut. Am I clear?”

 

Delilah let out a tiny burp. Rio looked like she was seconds away from bursting into song.

 

Agatha didn’t look at her.

 

She just resumed patting the baby’s back, firmer this time, like that would somehow burp whatever the fuck just happened out of existence.

 

-

 

“What do you want?” Agatha answered flatly, tucking her phone between her shoulder and ear as she placed a bottle of laundry detergent into her cart.

 

It was the exact brand Rio used- though that was, of course, entirely coincidental. A subconscious grab. An unconscious betrayal of self. She hadn’t meant to reach for it. It simply found its way into her hand, as if summoned by scent memory and unresolved issues. Smelling faintly of Rio didn’t make her miss Rio. Or want Rio. It was just a familiar smell in an unfamiliar store on an otherwise forgettable Tuesday. She’d tell herself that until it was true.

 

“So I’ve been thinking,” Rio said, with an evil casualness that made Agatha want to hang up immediately and throw her phone across the store.

 

She exhaled hard, pressing the heel of her palm to her forehead. “That’s never good.”

 

“About our conversation the other day.”

 

There it was. The premonition. The dread. The faint drumbeat of regret echoing in Agatha’s temples. She could feel the humiliation creeping up her neck already, as if her body remembered it more vividly than her mind allowed. She didn’t need to hear the rest to know exactly where this was headed.

 

“I don’t know what you’re talking about,” Agatha said briskly, veering down another aisle. She stared down the shelf, eyes landing on the Diet Coke display, and immediately started loading them in, box after box, mechanical and wildly deranged.

 

Something about aspartame and emotional suppression just made sense. Like if she stacked enough silver aluminum, perhaps it would barricade her from the rest of the conversation. Or her feelings. Whichever was louder. 

 

And if that failed, Agatha would settle for a self administered lobotomy. Nothing too drastic.

 

“Oh, you know,” Rio drawled, and Agatha had to physically restrain herself from javelin-throwing her phone into a shelf of cokes. “That part where you said you want me to-”

 

“I didn’t say I wanted you to do shit,” Agatha hissed.

 

“Agatha, there is nothing wrong with you wanting to be dicked down, I promise.”  Rio replied, maddeningly composed. “I’m just saying, if that’s where you’re at, I’m happy to oblige.”

 

Agatha froze in the middle of the aisle and looked around- not out of embarrassment, but out of pure survival instinct. She was, blessedly, alone. That was the only reason she allowed herself to lean forward, press her forehead against the handle of the cart, and silently scream into the void. She stomped once, twice, then stood up and tried very hard not to want to commit a felony.

 

She swept her hair out of her face, took a breath sharp enough to bruise her lungs, and said through her teeth, “Dicked. Down?”

 

“You want me to put my dick in you,” Rio clarified, as if she fucking need to.

 

“I know what it means, Rio. Thank you for the vocabulary lesson.” Her voice came out clipped, seething. “And also, absolutely not.”

 

“Why not?”

 

Agatha rolled her eyes. She could hear the pout in Rio’s voice, which was unfair. Weaponized. Possibly actionable in court.

 

The problem wasn’t that she didn’t want to. It was that she wanted to too much . That was the entire issue. She’d already surrendered more of herself to Rio than she’d ever intended to give another human being. She would, without protest, do so again. Had done so, in various forms. Would keep doing it, probably forever. That was fine. That she could live with. But not this. Not this conversation. Not after the baby conversation, and the way Rio had looked holding her, and how Agatha had sat there watching, not even remotely disgusted by the possibility of that kind of permanence.

 

She couldn’t admit it. Not now. Not aloud. Not while she was still pretending to be the one with the upper hand.

 

Because the truth -the horrifying, embarrassing, soul destroying truth- was that if Rio so much as crooked a finger in her direction, Agatha would fold. Would bend over, cheeks spread, offering up every last shred of pride she had like it was a sacrifice to the gods of lesbian debauchery. No ifs, ands, or butts.

 

Pun fully fucking intended.

 

And there was nothing dignified about knowing that and still answering the phone.

 

“Because I have standards,” is what Agatha decided to say.

 

“Do you?” Rio asked, and Agatha could hear her smiling. 

 

She clenched her jaw. “Yes.”

 

More silence. Smug, unbearable silence.

 

Agatha cleared her throat, trying to sound level. “Anyway. I’m hanging up now.”

 

“Sure,” Rio said. “I’ll see you tonight.”

 

-

 

Agatha : I hate you.

I hate you so much it’s actually making me nauseous. 

I hope you trip over your own dick.

Don’t come over. 

Actually, I don’t care. 

I’m not even home. 

I am. 

 

Rio : this would be so much easier if you just admit you want it

 

Agatha : I don’t want it. 

 

Rio : sure. 

 

Agatha : I’m serious. 

 

Rio : no i know. 

you don’t want it. 

you just think about it constantly, text me about it unprovoked, and make yourself sick over the idea of how much you want it…

totally different.

Rio : oh, i’m not denying that

 

Agatha : I was insulting you. 

Be insulted. 

 

Rio : you were imagining it

very vividly, apparently 

 

Agatha : Shut the fuck up. 

 

Rio : you think about it a lot, huh? 

 

Agatha :  I will block you.

 

Rio : cool

 

-

 

Whatever irritation Agatha had been nursing dissolved the second she heard the jingle of keys in her front door- familiar enough now to bypass suspicion, but still carrying that little thrill of someone letting themselves into her life.

 

Moments later, Rio appeared in her the living room entrance- take-out in a brown paper sack dangling from her hand, eyebrows doing that smug little dance, and a grin showing off that infuriating, perfect gap between her teeth. 

 

Agatha ate cross legged at the coffee table while Rio lounged in the corner of her L-shaped couch, still full from her usual Tuesday dinner at Lilia’s. Survivor reruns played in the background- episodes they’d both seen enough times to talk over and still know exactly who got voted out.

 

After dinner, Agatha cleared the mess, took her time in the shower, and came back barefoot in an oversized t-shirt and underwear to find Rio exactly where she’d left her.

 

As she rounded the couch, Rio reached out a hand, palm open, that easy beckoning she did now without thinking. Routine. And, if Agatha was honest, something she’d come to rely on.

 

If Rio ever stopped reaching for her like that -in all the subtle, thoughtless ways she did now- Agatha figured she’d come apart faster than she’d admit. If Rio hadn’t made herself at home here, and Agatha in hers, the loss would feel like someone had stolen half her heart and left the rest beating just to be cruel. Not that it mattered. Not that she’d ever admit it.

A swing sat in the far corner of Agatha’s backyard, its iron frame nearly swallowed by late summer blooms and greenery left to do as it pleased. The morning was still cool- thin light, damp air, the smell of cut grass drifting in from down the block.

 

Rio had been angling for mornings like this ever since she noticed the sun slipping away earlier each evening. She’d always been that way, for as long as Agatha could remember- always chasing the tail end of summer. She craved the slow days, the air softened by heat, the way the sun took its time leaving. Now, with the season waning, Rio treated every minute outside like a borrowed thing, something she’d have to give back before she was ready.

 

And Agatha, quietly, was relieved to find that hadn’t changed. 

 

They were still in what they’d woken up in- sweatshirts and boxers. Rio still had her socks on. Agatha’s feet were bare, toes pressing into the grass, cool and damp enough to make her feel awake.

There was a softness in Rio’s face now, an ease Agatha doesn’t remember from when they were younger. She didn’t know when that had happened, only that it hadn’t always been there. 

 

Her eyes flicked down to the lighter in Rio’s hand. The initials carved into the side -A.H.- were worn to a dull impression, like something pressed into memory rather than metal. Faded, but still there.

Years had passed, whole lives had been lived, and still Rio had kept pieces of her from another time. As if the girl Agatha had been back then was still worth keeping in her pocket.



She had done the opposite. Agatha erased Rio from her life, stripping away anything that might pull her back into memories that never once gave her what she wanted. No photographs. No keepsakes. Nothing to make her stop and remember. Only one exception: a sweatshirt, buried in the back of a dark closet where she could pretend it was safe. Then, one day, even that was gone, torn from her before she could close her fingers around it.

“Why do you still have my lighter?”

 

“Because it’s mine.”

It could be sharp as anger, as steady as devotion, as consuming as love. It was all felt for Rio, and only for her. She was the single constant Agatha had ever trusted, the one person she’d been certain she could never lose.

 

But she had. And still, Agatha carried her- in Chicago, even married to someone else, even through the long famine of silence- lodged in the back of her mind, as constant and relentless as the beat in her own chest.

“Would you have even stayed if I asked?” Rio cut in before she could finish.
