“You never would’ve asked,” Agatha said without hesitation, her voice soft but laced with a disappointment she made no effort to hide.

 

Rio’s breath faltered, and when she looked away, the sound she made was somewhere between a laugh and a breath that hurt. She didn’t argue. Didn’t bother trying to defend herself. 

 

That, alone, told Agatha she was right.

 

Rio stubbed her cigarette out in the ashtray beside her, slipped her hand from Agatha’s, and slouched deeper into the bench. Her eyes had gone glassy, and Agatha could tell she probably pushed it too far.

 

Without a word, Rio brought both hands to the hat on her head and pulled it down until her face was hidden.

 

And Agatha knew that habit by heart. Rio didn’t cry often, but when she did, she shut it down fast, tucking herself out of sight like her tears were something to be ashamed of.

 

Even after all these years, Agatha still hated seeing Rio cry; it hurt in a place nothing else could touch. And the worst part? Rio still hid it from her, like Agatha hadn’t spent half her life wanting to catch those tears, to keep them safe before they could water the earth.

 

“I hate when you do that,” Agatha said, softer than she meant to.

 

“Do what?” Rio asked, voice muffled under the brim of her cap, the attempt at indifference was brittle and pointless.

 

“Hide from me when you’re hurting.”

 

Rio didn’t move. Her fingers just tightened on her cap like she could pull it farther down, like it offered more protection than it did. Agatha didn’t say anything else. Her hand stayed where it was, resting in Rio’s lap, unmoving.

 

She watched as Rio let out a breath through her nose, quiet and shaky, and slowly pulled the cap from her head.

 

Rio stared at it for a moment before letting it fall slack in her hands. One hand raked through her flattened hair, brushing it back in a motion that might’ve looked careless if it weren’t for the way her fingers trembled.

 

When Rio finally looked up, it was like being let in on something no one else was meant to see. Her lashes were wet and clumped, her cheeks flushed, the skin beneath her eyes raw.

 

It hurt to see and every instinct in Agatha told her to look away, her heart couldn’t bear it, but she didn’t.

 

Agatha swallowed hard and her voice still caught on its way out, “Rio.”

 

“I’m sorry, okay?” Rio said, desperate now. “It was the worst decision of my fucking life, and I’ve lived with it every day since.” She paused, jaw tight, breath catching. When she spoke again, her voice dropped- quieter, but still shaking. “I’m so fucking sorry. I’m sorry I knew exactly what you meant to me- I still let everything happen the way it did.”

 

The pressure in Agatha’s chest built until it was almost unbearable, a hot, tight ache that made it hard to breathe. It wasn’t just anger- it was grief, and years of swallowed words, and the nastiest reminder of everything they’d been before it all went to absolute fucking shit.

 

“I’m still so angry with you,” Agatha whispered through clenched teeth, her eyes burning. “You were my best friend, Rio. You weaseled your way into my fucking life, you brought me into your home and gave me a home, and then you shut me out of it.”



“I never meant to take that from you.” The words rasped out of Rio as if she’d been holding them in her mouth too long, rough-edged from disuse and bitter from being swallowed back too many times. She hesitated, jaw working again, and Agatha saw the shallow rise and fall of her chest before she forced herself to go on. “I just… I couldn’t be around you. Not when you chose someone who hated me as much as she did.”

 

Her gaze dropped to her hands, twisting in her lap, thumbs pressing into each other hard enough to blanch the skin. “It got to my head,” Rio said, softer now, “made everything feel ugly.” She let out a shaky breath that seemed to deflate her. “I kept thinking I’d find a way to be near you without it eating me alive. I thought I had time to figure it out. I never thought you’d leave before I could.”

 

Agatha wanted to scream, to rip something out of herself just to stop the ache. Loving Rio had never been gentle. It grew wild in her, sprawling into every corner until there was no room left for anything else. She could feel it even now-  roots knotted deep, climbing through her ribs, refusing to be cut back no matter how hard she tried.

 

But some things don’t stop growing, not even when you’re gasping for air. The same roots that anchored Agatha had begun to wind tighter, the same vines that had drawn her close were now pulling until she felt stretched thin. And she couldn’t separate the beauty from the hurt. Every petal was edged with a thorn.

 

It shouldn’t have been this hard. Not then. Not now. And yet, they’d both chosen the easier pain: distance, silence, the false mercy of leaving things untouched. Maybe they hadn’t meant to hurt each other. Agatha could almost believe that. But what did intention matter when the damage was already done?

 

She wasn’t innocent in it. She’d hurt Rio, too. She’d stayed with Wanda knowing exactly how she felt about Rio. She’d married someone who made it impossible for Rio to be part of her life, and then acted surprised when she disappeared. She had let the distance settle like dust and pretended she didn’t know how to sweep it away.

 

And now Agatha was tired. Tired of carrying something that refused to get lighter. Tired of tending to a wound that would not heal, of loving something that only grew heavier the longer she held it. The truth she didn’t want to face was that she didn’t want to lose Rio -not at all- but she also couldn’t keep going like this, circling the same pain until it hollowed them both out.

 

Her voice came flat, almost against her own will. “You know what? If it’s going to be like this -if it’s going to keep feeling like this- maybe we should just break up.”

 

“Break up?” Rio repeated, face twisting like the words didn’t belong to either of them. “Wait we’re…” Her gaze dropped, tracing the sweep of the grass under them like she was searching it for proof of something she’d missed, some detail that might make the words make sense. When she looked back at Agatha, her voice was smaller. “We’re dating?”

 

Oh, Jesus fucking Christ. Of course. They hadn’t slapped a label on it, but if it walks like a duck and quacks like a duck, it’s a fucking duck.

 

“What do you think we’ve been doing this whole time?” Agatha’s voice rose, her hand cutting through the air as if she could point to the last four months and make Rio see it.

 

Rio sat back slowly, like she'd just been told something she thought she wasn’t  allowed to want. Her eyes scanned Agatha’s face, searching, stunned. “You’re my girlfriend?” she whispered, almost disbelieving. “And I didn’t know?”

 

Agatha’s stomach turned. Rio was looking at her with those wide, miserable brown eyes, like she couldn’t understand how she’d missed it, didn’t know exactly where it had gone wrong, only that it hurt. Agatha hated how familiar it felt, her own heart in Rio’s hands, still beating, while Rio turned it over like she was trying to figure out when it had gotten there.

 

And okay. Maybe Agatha would take the blame for this one. Rio had been patient, moving at Agatha’s pace, never asking for more than she was ready to give. And now here Agatha was, blurting out words Rio hadn’t even known she’d named, blindsiding her with a definition she’d never been told they were living by.

 

But that was the thing about silence- it could keep the peace for a while, even in good faith, but it always came back to bite them in the ass. It was a habit Agatha hadn’t managed to break, and cowardice had always been her easiest refuge. 

 

So Agatha didn’t explain. She pushed herself off the swing, the chains clattering in protest, and crossed the yard without looking back.

 

“Hey!” Rio’s voice cut through behind her, followed by the sound of footsteps closing in.

 

In seconds, Rio was in front of Agatha, moving into her path, both hands coming up to catch her by the shoulders to stop her. “You don’t get to drop that and not tell me what I did wrong.”

 

Agatha turned her head, refusing to meet her eyes. “Move, Rio.”

 

“I won’t,” Rio said, lifting her hands and placing them gently on either side of Agatha’s face. She tilted Agatha’s head toward her, thumbs brushing just beneath her cheekbones. “Tell me what to fix, and I’ll fix it.”

 

Agatha’s eyes slammed shut. She couldn’t look. Couldn’t let that be what broke her. Her throat locked, everything in her chest felt like it was tightening all at once. Rio’s hands were too familiar, too warm, too easy to lean into- and Agatha could already feel herself losing ground.

 

She shook her head and grabbed Rio’s wrists, pulled her hands away. She tried to step around her, ready to put space between them while she still could. But Rio moved with her, sidestepping easily, her body closing off the path again. 

 

“Tell me,” Rio said, breathless. “What do I need to do? Be softer? Be louder? Pretend it doesn’t matter to me? Just- tell me what version of me you want, and I’ll be her.”

 

The absurdity of it almost made Agatha laugh. It had never been about Rio being too loud or too afraid or too far gone to reach. Agatha had loved her through every version- through fear, through silence, through the years that turned them into strangers. Even now, with Rio standing in front of her, desperate to change something, Agatha still couldn’t find a single part of her that was wrong.

 

And that fucking sucked.

 

Because if there had been something broken- something ugly or evil she could point to and say this, this is why - then maybe she could have let go. Maybe she wouldn’t have carried it for so long, a grief without a cause, growing wild and utterly rooted inside of her.

 

But there had never been anything wrong with Rio. Not then. Not now. Not ever. 

 

Rio took a step closer, her voice shaking but certain. “I’ve kept quiet because that’s what you wanted. And that’s fine. That’s- fine. But I won’t do it anymore, Agatha.”

 

Her voice shook, but Agatha saw it anyway- the shift in her eyes, the weight gathering there like she was about to step somewhere they had never stood before. She knew what was coming. She could feel it as clearly as she did when Rio’s hand pressed against her chest when they kissed.

 

“Don’t,” Agatha snapped, then stopped herself, breath unsteady. “Don’t,” Agatha said again, quieter this time, pleading, because she couldn’t let her say it. Not here. Not now.



Rio’s mouth twitched, holding the words behind her teeth. But then her gaze shifted, like she was choosing a version of the truth Agatha wouldn’t be able to run from.

 

“We’re not breaking up,” Rio said, and it sounded less like a decision and more like a fact carved in bone.

 

Agatha’s head snapped back, her brows drawing in. “Excuse me?”

 

“If you’re going to break up with me, then I’m going to know I was your girlfriend for longer than five fucking minutes.”

 

Agatha blinked, and just like that, Rio was walking away from her.

 

Her chest seized, her breath catching before she could mask it. “Where are you going?” Agatha asked, already moving, her steps quick and uneven behind Rio’s.

 

“My apartment.”

 

The word landed like a door slamming shut, and Agatha stopped cold. She stared at Rio’s back, at the space growing between them, and felt the panic rise so quickly it bordered on instinct. It hit her too fast to make sense of, too sudden to contain. So she did what she always did- reached for the first weapon she could throw- something that might make her stop, even if it was the wrong thing entirely.

 

Rio couldn’t walk away from her again. She wouldn’t survive that twice.

 

The words tore out of her before she could catch them, jagged and unguarded, before she could think better of them. 

 

“If you walk away from me again, I will hate you forever!”

 

Rio stopped like she'd hit a wall. For a breath, she didn’t move, didn’t turn, didn’t speak- just stood there, her back to Agatha, the weight of her stillness louder than anything she could have said.

 

Then she turned, and the distance between them vanished. Her mouth crashed into Agatha’s with a hunger that didn’t build, it detonated. One hand locked around Agatha’s jaw, angling her just right, the other fisting hard in her sweatshirt and dragging her closer.

 

Agatha let her in without hesitation. Tongue, teeth, heat- every kiss a collision, every breath stolen and given back. Her fingers curled into Rio’s hair, pulled, and Rio moaned low into her mouth like it was the only answer she had left.

 

When Rio finally tore away, Agatha chased her mouth, dazed, breathless, desperate to find her again- but Rio held her still, her grip firm, her forehead resting against Agatha’s like she couldn’t quite bear to lose the contact.

 

“Don’t ever fucking say that to me again,” Rio breathed out, the words pressed against Agatha’s mouth like a vow, or a warning, or both.

 

Agatha opened her mouth -ready to throw it back at her, to say then don’t walk away from me again - but Rio had already stepped back, swiping at her face, breath still coming uneven. And Agatha whimpered at the loss before she could stop herself.

 

“I’m going to my apartment,” Rio said, her voice steadier than it had any right to be. “And then I’m coming back. Because that’s what we do now. You can say whatever you want, swear you’ll hate me forever- I’ll still come back. I’ll always come back. And sooner or later, you’re going to believe me when I say I’m not losing you again.” She cleared her throat, wiped at her nose, tried to make it sound casual. “So yeah. I’ll be home later.”

 

And then she was gone.

 

Agatha didn’t move. She just stood there, heart pounding, trying not to fall apart over syllables.

 

I’ll be home later.

 

The smell of Rio’s cigarette still clung to her sweatshirt.

 

Home.

 

Oh.

 

-

 

Agatha didn’t know what she was expecting, only that she couldn’t sit still long enough for Rio to come back.

 

Her knuckles grazed the door once, then again, harder. She stepped back, heart thudding in her throat.

 

The door swung open.

 

“Lilia,” Agatha breathed.

 

 

Chapter End Notes

eh?

Thank you for the music <3

Chapter 15: far away

Chapter Notes

howdy,

literally spent the last month pouring my blood, sweat, and tears into this chapter just for YOU... i still hate it.

See the end of the chapter for more notes

The door swung open.

 

“Lilia,” Agatha breathed.

 

For a moment Agatha forgot herself, forgot that she had been bracing for this for years.  Lilia’s eyes moved over her, sweeping across her face as if to take inventory of time itself- every new line, every mark of age, every trace of damage that absence might have left behind. Lilia didn’t look surprised. She didn’t even look angry, exactly. Just… like someone who’d been expecting her eventually, though maybe not today.

 

Agatha dropped her gaze to the porch planks, suddenly absorbed by the way the stain had faded into softer shades, worn smooth where countless shoes had passed- a much safer study than the way Lilia was peeling her apart with her eyes. Agatha never liked being read like that, like every thought she had shoved down was written clear across her face. Her chest tightened; she sniffed, cleared her throat, and tugged up a crooked smile that didn’t fool either of them.

 

“So… Lilia. Been a long time.”

 

“Fourteen years,” Lilia reminded her. “And now you’re on my porch like it’s been fourteen minutes.”

 

Agatha tilted her head, letting her smile slip toward something more sardonic. “Figured we could skip the part where you slam the door in my face.”

 

Lilia gave a small, humorless scoff. “Uh-uh. Beat it, Harkness!”

 

Agatha might’ve believed her if Lilia had actually shut the door, but instead Lilia had turned on her heel and strode back inside.

 

The door stayed open behind her. 

 

Typical Lilia- no welcome, no smile, just the wordless assurance that Agatha still had a place here, whether she deserved it or not. And Agatha would follow her in because for all her pride, she wasn’t stupid enough to walk away twice from a door Lilia had left open for her.

 

Crossing the threshold, the smell hit Agatha first- incense, thick enough to sting the back of her throat and threaten to burn every last nose hair she had left. She kept her eyes forward, refusing to be pulled toward the framed pictures on the walls and mantle, the sagging sofa that still wore the same crocheted throw, the corners where a younger version of herself had once laughed or sulked or stayed too long. Every inch of it pressed against her like a hand around her throat, and she had to keep moving before she lost her breath entirely.

 

“Oh, come on, Lilia,” Agatha called after Lilia’s retreating footsteps. 

 

Lilia answered with nothing more than a low, unimpressed grunt.

 

She trailed the muffled clatter of cupboards into the kitchen, shouldering through the bead curtain that clicked and snapped against her. And there it was. That table. That chair- hers, still sitting in its spot like it had been holding its place for her. She didn’t go near it. No. She slid into a safer seat, putting space between herself and the past Lilia’s house kept trying to hand her.

 

Agatha sat there, restless, eyes fixed anywhere but on Lilia as she moved through the kitchen without a word, not even a glance in her direction. The silence wasn’t accidental. It never was. It settled over them the same way it used to when Lilia had wanted Agatha to think before she spoke.

 

Still, her eyes betrayed her, landing on Lilia when she hadn’t meant them to. Her hair was grayer now, pinned up so the light flashed off its strands. The mustard jacket, the wide blue pants, the glint of jewlery when she moved. She was older now, but in a way that made her more herself- honed, solid, like the years had deepened her instead of wearing her away.

 

It hit harder than Agatha told herself it would. Fourteen years gone, and she’d just stood off to the side while they vanished. She thought about every chance she’d had to cross this threshold and didn’t, all the versions of herself that had kept their distance. 

 

And the feeling it left her with shoved itself up under her ribs until Agatha had to look away.

 

Agatha cleared her throat, quick and too loud. Her fingers tapped against the table, restless, buying her a second before she had to open her mouth. “You look good,” she said finally. “How old are you now, four hundred and ten? Four hundred and fifteen?”

 

Lilia spun, hand on her hip, eyebrows arched high. “How dare you,” she snapped, then crossed the kitchen and swept through the curtain, the bead strands clacking in her wake.

 

Agatha had only enough time to smirk before the beads clattered again and Lilia returned, a bundle of sage already smoking in her hand.

 

“Oh, for fuck’s sake-”

 

“You need it,” Lilia said, moving the sage in slow circles around her, sending curls of smoke into the air. “You’ve brought nearly two decades of bad energy into this house, and I’m not living with it.”

 

Agatha coughed, waving the smoke away. “You could just say you missed me.”

 

“If I missed you,” Lilia said evenly, “you’d know.” There was the faintest twitch at the corner of her mouth before she turned away.

 

Agatha leaned back in her chair, still swatting half heartedly at the smoke. “So that’s it? Fourteen years and you’re just gonna fumigate me?”

 

Lilia set the sage in a chipped ceramic dish, then turned with that same assessing stare. “Tea or coffee?”

 

“That depends. Is this you being nice or you trying to poison me?”

 

Lilia ignored her, pulled the coffee pot from the counter and walked it over to the machine. “When did you last eat?”

 

Agatha rolled her eyes. “I’m fine, Lilia.”

 

“Sure you are.” Lilia shoved the pot into the warming plate and turned from the counter, already fishing something from the fridge. “I’ll heat up some leftovers.”

 

“I’m fine, really. I’m not hungry.” And Agatha was telling the truth, at least in that moment. The thought of chewing, swallowing, forcing food down- it was almost enough to make her gag.

 

Lilia stilled, the fridge door hanging open for a moment before she shut it with a quiet thud. She didn’t bother reaching again. Instead, she crossed her arms and leaned into the counter, eyes locked on Agatha. “So,” she said slowly, “what did she do this time?”

 

Agatha’s jaw tightened. “I don’t know what you’re talking about.”

 

“Mm-hm.” Lilia’s hum was thick with disbelief. “So you just wandered over here on your own accord.”

 

“Yeah,” Agatha said, meeting her gaze now with a flicker of annoyance. “Not everything has to do with her, Lilia. I missed you. Fourteen years was a stupid amount of time to stay away.”

 

Lilia’s brow lifted, but her gaze didn’t waver. “You think saying it now makes it any less stupid?”

 

Agatha huffed out a laugh that had no humor in it. “No. But it’s the best I’ve got.” She shifted in her seat, fingers drumming against the table before stilling.

 

Lilia held her gaze a moment longer, something unspoken flickering there before she finally turned back to the coffee machine. “Yeah,” she said, almost too low to catch. “Took you long enough.”

 

“I know. I’m sorry,” Agatha said, and the words tasted strange in her mouth. “I shouldn’t have waited this long. I should’ve… I don’t know. Shown up sooner. Done something different.” She started worrying at an invisible stain on the table, nails tracing a pattern that wasn’t there, just to give her hands something to do.

 

Lilia stayed at the counter, pouring two cups of coffee, a loud laugh slipping out before she lifted a hand to cover her mouth, like she’d been caught misbehaving. “I’m sorry, Agatha,” she managed, her voice still warm with amusement. “I don’t mean to laugh. It’s just-” she glanced over her shoulder, lips quirking, “you apologizing? Didn’t see that one coming.”

 

She turned away from the counter, crossed the kitchen and set a cup in front of Agatha.

 

Agatha gawked at her, brows raised. “I apologize!”

 

“Mm.” Lilia slipped into the chair across from her. “Anyway. Doesn’t matter.”

 

Agatha shot her a look over the rim of the cup before taking a sip. Lilia’s coffee was exactly as she remembered- rich, dark, and unreasonably fucking good. She let herself hold it there on her tongue, forcing herself to savor it instead of spitting it back out just to prove she could.

 

Lilia settled in her chair, elbows on the table, eyes studying her. The longer it went on, the more Agatha squirmed, heat crawling up her neck under it. If anyone else tried studying her like that she would’ve torn into them without a second thought. But this was Lilia. So she swallowed it down, the retort sitting bitter on her tongue.

 

Respect your elders, Agatha reminded herself.

 

“You’ve got some of yourself back,” Lilia finally said. “I can see it.” Her eyes narrowed, and the corner of her mouth twitched again. “I figure it has something to do with you being done playing house with Wanda.”

 

Agatha didn’t bother faking shock. What would be the point? That marriage fooled absolutely no one. Wanda was never the grand romance, just the slowest, most exhausting pit stop she could’ve chosen on the way back to where she belonged. Hell, the whole town probably knew it. Everyone did. Everyone except Rio. 

 

The only person who ever needed to, didn’t.  

 

Agatha nodded her head a little bit, lips curling into a grin that didn’t quite reach her eyes. “Yeah. Probably. Or maybe I just got better at faking it.”

 

“No, love. You’ve never been good at faking anything.”

 

The word sat warm in Agatha’s chest and tight in her throat, it felt too generous, too kind. She cleared her throat, her voice lighter than she meant. “No?”

 

“No.” Lilia huffed a small laugh, like the answer had always been obvious. “Especially not when your heart’s in the room.”

 

Agatha wanted to roll her eyes, scoff, make a joke just to push them somewhere safer. But she knew exactly what Lilia meant. She always had. “Your heart” had been Lilia’s little code for Rio back then, slipped into conversations in private, soft enough to pass as teasing about a best friend. She hadn’t said it often- just enough for Agatha to feel seen in a way she couldn’t stand and couldn’t shake.

 

“Yeah, well… she’s not here, so my odds just got a whole lot better.”

 

Lilia hummed, like she’d just fit a piece into place. “Still think you can outsmart everyone, huh?”

 

Agatha blinked at her, mouth falling open. Her face couldn’t decide what it was doing- somewhere between a grin and pure confusion. It was funny, actually. Because what the fuck?

 

“Outsmart? Please. Who the fuck-”

 

“Language.”

 

“Sorry. Who the hell have I outsmarted? Honestly.” Agatha swept a hand toward the empty room, to the audience of everyone she’s supposedly fooled. “Because if memory serves, everyone’s been in on the joke. You literally just said I’ve never been good at faking it.”

 

“If everyone knew, love, then what made you think you couldn’t come home sooner?”

 

Agatha swore she heard tires screech across her skull with her thoughts slamming to a stop.

 

“I don’t know,” She answered before she could think better of it.

 

“Well.” Lilia’s palms landed on the table with a decisive smack before she pushed herself up. “You’re only lying to yourself.”

 

“Where are you going?”

 

Lilia didn’t answer right away; she let the bead curtain rattle under her hand, forcing Agatha to follow the sound. “If you’re not going to be honest, there’s no point in sitting here. I’ve covered for the both of you long enough, and I won’t help it drag on any further.” 

 

“Honest?” Agatha squeaked, twisting in her chair. Her eyes darted around the kitchen, then snapped back to Lilia. She gritted her teeth. “What- you want me to tattle on myself? … In broad daylight?”

 

Lilia sighed and let the beads slip back into place, then crossed the room to sit down again. The chair creaked as she lowered herself into it. With her elbows on the table again, Lilia dropped her face into her hands and shook her head slowly, fingers pressed at her temples. 

 

Agatha bit down on her tongue, lips pressed tight, refusing to fill the silence. She could handle being yelled at. But disappointment- that was harder. The heavier cross to bear, Agatha would say.

 

When Lilia finally lifted her head, her palms landed against the table with a dull smack. She looked at Agatha with an exhaustion that was almost worse than an accusation. “You know when I knew?”

 

“Tell me.” Agatha heard the bite in her own voice, caught it, coughed, rolled her shoulders in a shrug, tried again. “I mean- you’re going to, anyway.”

 

God forbid she admit it: she wanted to know. Wanted to gather every scrap of the them from someone else’s mouth to catch the softness she’d missed, to remind her it hadn’t all been awful.

 

Lilia gave her a look between pity and are you serious right now? Then she shook her head. “It was maybe your fourth time here. By then, you were comfortable enough to be, well… yourself.”

 

“What the hell is that supposed to mean?”

 

Lilia ignored her interruption. “And Rio- Rio was pacing my kitchen like she always did when she didn’t know what to do with herself. Nervous as anything, wearing a path into my hardwood. But the moment you pulled into the driveway, and she bolted. Grabbed the umbrella and flew out the door before you even killed the engine.” Her gaze drifted toward the bead curtain, her voice turned softer, 

 

“That girl hated rain, Agatha. Always did. Couldn’t stand her clothes sticking to her skin, couldn’t handle the mess. I’ve seen her throw fits over a splash of water on her sleeve. But that night? The second you pulled up, she forgot all about it. Walked straight out into a downpour without a second's hesitation. And I swear I thought- hell must’ve frozen over.”

 

Agatha almost snorted. Yeah, well, if it had, she’d like to file a complaint, because somehow she’d missed the part where heaven or hell ever bothered lifting a finger for her.

 

But now all she could think about was Rio barreling out the front door tearing across the yard with an umbrella clutched in both hands- like if the wind caught her just right, she might actually take flight. By the time she reached Agatha’s car, she was drenched, umbrella flailing until she yanked the car door open. 

 

Agatha had gotten out laughing, only to be pulled under that umbrella and forced to watch Rio beam at her. She looked like she’d been waiting her whole life for Agatha to pull into that driveway. Again. Rio. Who had chosen to run out into the middle of a storm and smiled through it anyway. For Agatha. All for Agatha.

 

How the fuck was Agatha supposed to not fall in love with her? Good question. The answer : there was never a version of Agatha’s life where that wouldn’t happen.

 

Every time Rio had laughed, every time she barreled headfirst into something she swore she couldn’t survive, every time she looked at Agatha like she was the only thing in the room- it stacked up. A few months into their so-called friendship and Agatha was staring down the massive, steaming pile of shit called realizing you were in love with your best friend. Rio, of course, noticed. What’s wrong with your face? she’d asked, like Agatha wasn’t in the middle of having her entire brain chemistry rewritten. 

 

Agatha figured she must’ve looked horrified. Or constipated. Which wasn’t far off- she was emotionally constipated, and nothing clogged the system worse than a feeling she hadn’t asked for.

 

The softness of Lilia’s voice cut straight through her thoughts.

 

“I watched from the window. The two of you standing out there, rain pouring down, crammed under that umbrella and laughing like the rest of the world didn’t exist. That was the first time I think I ever saw Rio exist outside of her own head- like all that noise she usually carried around looked quiet. And you-” Lilia’s eyes didn’t waver, “your feet were set. Planted, like you weren’t going anywhere as long as she was standing there.”

 

“That was the plan,” Agatha muttered, dragging her thumbnail along the edge of the table. “Westview was always the plan.”

 

She  didn’t look up, but she could feel Lilia’s eyes on her, heavy with pity. The taste of it sat like bile in her throat.

 

“When did that change,” Lilia asked softly. 

 

It hadn’t been Wanda, though she made a convenient scapegoat.

 

Being best friends with Rio wasn’t enough. It had never been enough, and Agatha had tried to make that clear. She thought she’d left enough hints. Maybe she said too little, maybe she counted too much on implication, but everyone else seemed to catch on. 

 

Everyone except Rio.

 

So really, it was every question left unanswered, every silence that stretched too long, every time Agatha realized she wasn’t being seen anymore. Rio, who used to look at her like she was quite literally impossible to ignore, started turning away. The same woman who once treated Agatha as a challenge, an invitation, began to flinch like she was a threat.

 

That was when it changed.

 

And now, nearly two decades later, Agatha still couldn’t give anyone a straight answer to the question she dreaded most: Was Rio in love with you too? If she was honest, she leaned toward no. Not because of the way things ended, but because it hadn’t felt like love. It felt like being stripped for parts, hollowed out and left begging for scraps of something she should never have had to beg for in the first place.

 

“Everyone’s got a limit, Lilia. I hit mine. I couldn’t keep wasting my time on it anymore,” Agatha said, her nail digging harder into the table. 

 

Agatha wouldn’t admit the only thing she’d ever seemed to be consistent about was wasting her own time.

 

“You still sound angry when you talk about it,” Lilia pointed out. 

 

And wasn’t the sky fucking blue?

 

“I am angry,” Agatha snapped as her fist slammed the table, mugs rattling on the table. Lilia didn’t so much as flinch. She pressed her curled fist to her mouth and bit down on her pointer finger like she could chew the feeling down to size. Her eyes stung. “Your daughter pisses me off,” she muttered into her fist.

 

“Agatha, please. Forgive her. Her head was constantly running interference. She could keep pace with her feelings. She was always battling the ground under her feet, like she had to earn every inch of it just to exist, you know that. She did it with me. She did it with you. And by the time her heart moved, her body would stall. It left her a step behind, every single time.” Lilia’s tone was soft, but not gentle- more like she was tired of watching them hurt themselves.

 

The thing about Rio was she always showed up- when Agatha needed her, when she didn’t. But sometime before Agatha even met Wanda, a switch flipped. Everything Rio did felt late. Like she was scrambling to catch up to something. And Rio was never late. If you looked up punctual in the dictionary, you’d find Rio Vidal’s face staring right back you.

 

To this day, Agatha swears that period of time was the most off-balance she had ever seen Rio- and watching it happen had been fucking brutal. Agatha tried to help -stopped nudging things out of balance, left her carefully counted silverware alone- but it only seemed to make things worse. Even just Agatha’s presence managed to magnify it all.

 

And maybe that was the first time Agatha really understood heartbreak: watching the person you loved fight themselves bloody, and realizing your hands only added to the damage.

 

“Oh, here we go- poor Rio.” Agatha raised and dropped her arms in defeat. “What was I supposed to do, huh? Sit around until she screwed her head on straight? Newsflash: it wouldn’t have made a damn difference” She jabbed a finger at the table to punctuate it. “She has OCD, Lilia. We all knew it, and yet we still talk around it like she’s gonna kick down the door and chew us out for saying it out loud. Which is actually fucking insane!” Agatha laughed in disbelief. 

 

“And then I come back and -poof- new Rio. I don’t even recognize her. Suddenly she’s fine, suddenly she’s functioning, and what’s the big takeaway? That I was the problem holding her back?” She leaned back into her chair, arms folding tight across her chest. “Do you know what that feels like? To come back and see that? It’s a slap in the fucking face.”

 

Lilia’s brows jumped, almost cartoonish in their disbelief. “She went to therapy, Agatha. You moving away wasn’t some magic cure.”

 

Agatha dropped her arms, her mouth twisted. “Therapy?”

 

“Yeah. Therapy.” Lilia leaned back, a smile tugging at her mouth. “You might want to try it sometime.”

 

“Gross,” Agatha muttered, but there was no real disgust there. Her fingers drummed against the table before she narrowed her eyes at Lilia. “Though I suppose the silver lining is that I can blame you for not getting her the help she needed when she was a kid. Maybe that’s why we didn’t work out the first time around. Poor case management on your end.”

 

Lilia rolled her eyes. “I did try,” she said finally, matter of fact. “She bit every therapist I sent her to. Told me she’d keep biting them until I got the message and stopped pushing.”

 

Agatha barked out a laugh despite herself. It was too perfect. Too Rio.

 

“But let’s be honest,” Lilia continued, and now her voice carried the weight of someone who had thought about this far longer than Agatha ever wanted her to. “Even if she hadn’t, even if she sat there politely and smiled through every session, it wouldn’t have mattered. She wasn’t ready. Therapy only works if you decide you want to get better, and she didn’t- not then. No one could’ve forced her into it. Not me, not you, not anyone.”

 

Lilia leaned back, “You weren’t her cure, Agatha. You were her wake-up call. When you left, it shook her. She realized she couldn’t stay frozen in the same place, not if there was any chance you’d come back. She wanted to change. She wanted to be enough. And she believed, like the rest of us, that sooner or later, you’d come back.”

 

It wasn’t funny anymore. 

 

Agatha leaned back in her chair, forcing the corners of her mouth into something that pretended at amusement. A villain knew when she was being cast as the lesson. She’d been playing that part her whole life.

 

Lilia caught it instantly. “No. Don’t do that.”

 

Agatha didn’t even blink. “Do what?” The word came out flat, brittle.

 

“That,” Lilia pointed at Agatha’s face. “Acting like you're the villain. You were hurt. Rio hurt you. Whatever else she had going on doesn’t excuse it. She’s not a saint, and you don’t get to erase your own feelings just because hers were complicated.”

 

Agatha’s jaw twitched, but she didn’t speak.

 

“You have got to quit turning it into some blame game. Neither of you were enough for the other because you couldn’t be. You were kids. Two kids who didn’t know what they were doing. That’s not a crime, it’s just what it was. And you can’t keep picking it apart like you were supposed to know any better.”

 

Agatha felt her vision blur a little with unshed tears. “But I loved her,” she breathed out.

 

Lilia reached across the table and caught her hand, holding it like a parent catching a child in the middle of a fall. 

 

Agatha let her, even as Lilia’s pity-laden eyes never flinched.

 

“Of course you did. And she loved you. None of that changes the fact you still lost each other. You think love should’ve been enough to stop it. It never is. That’s just a lie we all tell ourselves- that if we love hard enough, we get to keep it. You don’t. Love guarantees grief, Agatha. That’s the bargain. You can’t separate them.”

 

And wasn’t that the truth? 

 

That loss didn’t just go away. Agatha carried it into every room, every choice, every pause between words. Love wasn’t enough. People walked away. Time didn’t heal a damn thing. “Moving on” was a complete fucking joke. She had tried. She changed everything she could -the scenery, the people, even herself- it didn’t make a fucking difference. She couldn’t escape it.

 

Lilia’s thumb swept across Agatha’s knuckles, “The only way through it is forward. You wake up tomorrow, and you try again. And if you can’t that day, then you try the next. And the next. Tomorrow is all any of us hope to ever get, Agatha. You don’t need to carry the end of the world in your chest. Not when what you want is right in front of you.”

 

I’ll try again tomorrow. 

 

At least Rio’s favorite slogan wasn’t something she picked up in therapy. If it was, Agatha might’ve actually had to buy a gun, just to put herself out of her own misery. What a relief, knowing Agatha had been spared that indignity.

 

She gave Lilia’s hand a quick squeeze before slipping free, swiping at the tear that slipped down her cheek.  It didn’t do much. The second she pressed both palms hard into her eyes, she still felt it leaking through, burning. “God, I hate it when you’re right,” she muttered, voice trying for humor.

 

“I’m always right,” Lilia shot back, smug as ever, and Agatha didn’t need to see her face to know she was smiling.

 

When she finally lowered her hands, there it was: Lilia looking at her like she hadn’t just dragged Agatha through seventeen years of emotional bullshit. That smile wasn’t pity- it was recognition. A warmth that said you finally made it back home. 

 

“She loved me back?” The question came out hesitant, soft in a way that pissed her off. It betrayed just how many nights she’d spent tearing herself apart over it.

 

“You’re a dumbass for ever questioning it.”

 

Agatha huffed.

 

Then Lilia tilted her head like she was tired of watching Agatha dance around the obvious. “Do you still love her?”

 

Double homicide, Agatha thought. And if she’d had the energy, she might’ve laughed at her own gallows humor.

 

Her throat tightened, but the answer was easy, “Of course I do.”

 

“There you are,” Lilia whispered, her smile softening the words. “Welcome back. Now how about we take a break, get out the dominoes, and see if you’ve finally figured out how to play without humiliating yourself?”

 

Agatha watched Lilia push back from her chair and head out of the kitchen. She wanted to stay. They’d wasted many nights like that before, Lilia crowing at every slip as if clowning Agatha was a personal hobby. And maybe Agatha needed that right now- the comfort of something ordinary.

 

But Rio was still seeping into every corner of her mind.

 

Lilia reappeared with the battered tin box in her hands, its paint scratched and its corners dented from years of use. She popped the lid and poured the dominoes out on the table in a rush of clattering noise. 

 

“Lilia, I should probably get back to Ri-”

 

“Nonsense.” Lilia cut her off without looking up, already dragging the dominoes into a heap with both hands. “She’ll be fine.”

 

Agatha eyed Lilia. She didn’t know about the argument they’d had earlier, didn’t know how badly Agatha wanted to fix it, and with haste. She didn’t want Rio thinking she’d bolted or done something stupid. Yet Lilia sat there with that unnerving composure, like she had a sense for things before anyone else did.

 

“Should probably shoot her a text anyway,” Agatha mumbled, digging her phone out of her back pocket, still side eyeing Lilia with suspicion. 

 

Lilia only hummed, bent over the table, still flipping the dominoes face down.

 

Agatha unlocked her phone. No flood of missed calls, no string of panicked texts from Rio. That was… a relief, actually. Either she wasn’t home yet or she was, and she hadn’t worked herself into a frenzy thinking Agatha had bolted. 

 

Still, she thumbed out a quick text: left the house for a bit. I’ll be home later. That was it. No mention of where she’d gone. She wasn’t about to casually lob, ‘Oh hey, by the way, after months of avoiding it, I finally waltzed into your mother’s house without you’, into Rio’s lap over text. No. That conversation demanded more than a casual text. It demanded Agatha’s face, her tone, and possibly her groveling.

 

Her eyes flicked up to Lilia- bent over the dominoes, sleeves shoved to her elbows, stirring the pile in wide, careless circles. The noise was loud as shit, but familiar, like the echo of a life Agatha thought she’d lost. 

 

Agatha tilted her phone up and snapped a picture. 

 

It wasn’t a whim. It wasn’t vanity. It was need. She had nothing left of this- no pictures of this table, no scraps of this house, no trace of the woman across from her. Ten years of proof had been deleted, burned, shredded in a dozen midnight purges. At the time it felt righteous, necessary even. If she cut the past out root and stem, maybe it couldn’t grow back and strangle her.

 

But sitting here now, watching Lilia shuffle dominoes like nothing had changed at all, the certainty of those choices curdled in her stomach and all Agatha could think about was how stupid she’d been. She hadn’t protected herself by erasing the past-  she had gutted her own history, carved out years until there was nothing left but memory, and her memory had always been a treacherous fucking liar.

 

She looked at the picture: crooked, grainy, Lilia’s face half hidden. Nothing special. And still, it mattered. It was proof that she had come back, that she’d walked through the door she swore she’d never open again, and found it waiting for her. Finally, Agatha held more than a memory in her hands.

 

“Pick seven,” Lilia said as she settled into her chair, pulling Agatha out of her head.

 

Agatha locked her phone, set it face down on the table, and picked her dominoes without protest.

 

-

 

Agatha couldn’t say how long they’d been playing when she heard the front door creak open. Her whole body went rigid, eyes snapping to Lilia like she’d just been caught in a crime.

 

“Don’t look at me like that, Agatha,” Lilia said, unbothered. “My children come and go as they please. They don’t owe me a notice every time they want to step foot in their own home.” Her gaze flicked to the bead curtain, then back to Agatha with the faintest curve of a smile.

 

“Children? They’re both here?” Agatha hissed, leaned closer, hands gripping the edge of the table. “Also, it’s pretty fucked no one thought to mention the family expansion that happened while I was still living down the goddamn street!”

 

Voices spilled down the hallway- quiet, heated. They tangled, broken up by footsteps that kept starting, stalling, starting again. A thud echoed, followed by a muttered curse, then a louder shush that only sparked more whispering.

 

Agatha’s head whipped toward the sound, then back to Lilia. But Lilia was the picture of calm, elbow braced on the table, chin in her palm, idly studying her dominoes. She glanced up at Agatha and said, “Judging by the racket? That’s definitely both of them.”

 

Agatha groaned, sliding down in her chair and covering her face with one hand. 

 

This was a fucking nightmare. She hadn’t exactly planned on staying long- just long enough to air out over nearly two decades of grievances, which, in Agatha’s case, were the same thing as her feelings. That was already more emotional labor than she’d signed up for in one lifetime. 

 

She’d come here prompted by the fact that sitting in her own house, waiting for Rio to come home after their blowup that morning, felt excruciating. And now, because the universe loved irony, Rio was here. With Sage in tow- the little sister no one had thought to mention until recently. Six months ago? Maybe less. Agatha couldn’t even keep track anymore, and frankly, she didn’t care to. All she knew was that the timing was fucked up, and she was trapped right in the middle of it.

 

The whispering in the hall was getting louder, sharper- snaps and hisses tangled with the sound of shoes scuffing against the floorboards. And Agatha shot another glance at the bead curtain. She couldn’t see through it, but she could make out two pairs of feet pacing, bumping, squaring up like fucking idiots about to brawl.

 

Before she could even blink, Sage came barreling through the curtain. The beads clattered wildly as she tripped, landing flat on the floor with a thunk that made Agatha jump in her chair.

 

Lilia didn’t so much as flinch- still propped on one elbow, chin in her palm, the only reaction she gave Agatha was a long suffering glance like none of this was unusual.

 

Agatha’s eyes flicked back to Sage, sprawled on her back. “That fucking hurt, you bitch!” she barked, kicking a leg blindly through the beads.

 

A muffled yelp cut behind the curtain. Followed immediately by silence, which Agatha assumed was Rio slapping a hand over her own mouth before she gave herself away like they hadn’t already just made an entire fucking scene out of their arrival.

 

“Sage, stop trying to cripple your sister. Rio, grow a spine and get in here,” Lilia said, sounding more bored than bothered.

 

Sage sat up straighter on the floor, eyes wild, pointing an accusatory thumb over her shoulder. “I’m sorry- are we all just going to ignore the fact that I was body slammed into the kitchen?”

 

From behind the curtain came Rio’s muffled voice.

 

“You tripped over your own damn feet!”

 

Sage immediately kicked back toward the beads.

 

Lilia set down a domino with a sharp click. “Wonderful. At this rate one of you will be dead before dinner. Saves me the trouble of cooking for four.”

 

“You know, Agatha, I think now’s a great time to mention -at that first game night-” Sage declared, starting to crawl across the floor toward the table. “After Rio and I left, she forced me to play Lips of an Angel by Hinder on repeat for-”

 

Sage didn’t get any further. Two hands shot out from beneath the curtain, seized Sage by the ankles, and yanked. Sage let out a strangled scream as she was ripped backward, disappearing under the curtain in one violent pull.

 

All Agatha could do was stare at the empty patch of floor where Sage had been a second ago. Honestly, she wanted to hear the rest of that story, but she didn’t even have much time to catch the thought before the bead curtain snapped open again and Rio stormed through it, chest heaving.

 

“That never happened,” Rio announced, pitching it to the room as though volume could make it true. But the second her eyes landed on Agatha, everything in Rio’s posture stalled- shoulders locked, breath snagged, the fight that had carried her into the kitchen cut short in an instant.

 

Agatha swallowed, hard, forcing herself not to squirm. Rio had ditched the boxers and sweatshirt she’d left the house in that morning, now in jeans and a gray sweater vest with nothing under it. Agatha’s eyes fell fast, traitorous, to Rio’s boobs and- of course. No bra. Her nipples poked taut against the fabric of the knit, and Agatha’s mouth watered like she had been starved of Rio for years.

 

It wasn’t fair. Rio wasn’t fair. Gorgeous, cocky, so blindingly herself it felt like mockery. Agatha had to tear her eyes away because her brain kept handing her the most deranged thought imaginable- herself, crawling across the table on all fours like some feral animal, mouth open.

 

Agatha’s eyes flicked to Lilia, who was rubbing her temples, already exhausted by the circus of her daughters. 

 

When her eyes slid back to Rio, Agatha found her still watching her with unnerving focus. She tipped her chin up a fraction, her posture tightening, and her words came out flat with an observation only she would think to make:

 

“That’s not where you usually sit.”

 

No, it wasn’t. 

 

Before Agatha had the chance to even open her mouth, the bead curtain clattered violently again. Sage shoved through it with all the grace of a wrecking ball, one shoulder catching Rio’s with a deliberate roughness as she passed. “Try not to bite anyone’s head off about it, Roo. You’re retired from losing your shit over a piece of furniture, remember?”

 

Rio flushed, her words stumbling out, “I… that’s not… I was just stating an observation.”

 

Bullshit. 

 

Rio had never once been casual about the chair Agatha was currently sitting in. 

 

It had always been Rio’s. She guarded it so viciously it stopped being a seat at the table and turned into a household rule. Everyone knew it- friends, family, anyone who thought about sitting there learned fast that Rio would raise hell until they moved. She’d go on about balance, about how things had to stay a certain way, and maybe that sounded convincing once, but mostly it was just Rio being… Rio.

 

Which made Rio’s attempt at brushing it off nothing short of ridiculous. Sage gave a short, mocking laugh without looking up from where she was pawing at the pile of dominoes, and the look Lilia cut her eldest was just as damning. 

 

And Agatha… well, she kept her mouth shut. Instead, she stared hard at the scatter of dominoes, elbow braced on the table, fingers tugging at an ear that burned hotter by the second. Because she wouldn’t keep pretending her choice had been random.

 

The moment she walked back into this kitchen Agatha had bypassed her old chair without a thought and dropped into this one. Rio’s. Because Rio’s had felt safe. Familiar. Like Agatha could still believe there was a place for her here, if only because Rio had once made it so.

 

Agatha snapped back to reality the second Rio dropped into the chair beside her, shoulder brushing her own.

 

“No!” Rio snapped, smacking Sage’s hand away from the boneyard. “Put ’em back- we’re starting over.”

 

Sage, of course, slapped her hand right back, and the two of them were bickering again as Lilia sighed and began turning them over from the game she and Agatha had been playing.

 

Agatha turned her own hand of dominoes face down and shoved it into the pile, then leaned back in her chair. She didn’t help with the reshuffle. Didn’t bother pretending to care. Instead, she bit at her thumbnail, her eyes glued to Rio next to her. 

 

Agatha Harkness had learned how to read people the hard way. It wasn’t instinct, it was survival- catching the tells, the hesitations, the things no one meant her to see. And Rio Vidal? That had taken fucking work. So much work that, now, Agatha could chart every tell without thinking, could map the entire shape of Rio Vidal from the smallest detail. 

 

Except tonight. Tonight, Rio’s attention was anywhere else -on Lilia, on Sage- and for the first time in a long time Agatha felt like she was staring at a book she’d worn the spine out of, only to find the sentences turning gibberish.

 

They hadn’t exactly ended on a high note this morning. Well- it wasn’t a total disaster, but it wasn’t fine either. It was both, somehow. A fight that ended like a truce, except the mess was still there- shoved into a corner where it still fucking reeked. Now this was the first time they’d faced each other since, and it was at Lilia’s kitchen table with Sage right there too. Too many eyes, no way for Agatha to grab Rio by the face and say: tell me what you’re thinking before I lose my fucking shit.

 

So instead she sat, restless, unsure if Rio was angry, or hurt, or exhausted with her. If she was disappointed. If she was sad. Any of it, all of it- each possibility worse than the last. Because those things didn’t belong on Rio's face, not when they came from Agatha’s mouth. 

 

By all accounts, Agatha should’ve felt lucky- surrounded by her people, even the strange add-on of Sage, the easy noise of a game on a table. But she couldn’t stomach it. Not when Rio sat inches away, untouchable, unreadable, her silence heavier than any argument.

 

Leaning in, Agatha kept her voice low, just for Rio. “Do you want to switch seats?”

 

It wasn’t a jab, wasn’t a test. It was as close to an offering as Agatha knew how to make in front of an audience.

 

Rio’s hands slowed, the dominoes she’d been turning slipping flat against the table. She looked at Agatha then, and for a second the kitchen noise fell away.

 

“No,” Rio said gently, shaking her head. “Stay.”

 

Rio’s eyes dipped to where Agatha’s thumbnail was still near her teeth. For a second, Rio’s hand twitched on the table like she might reach over and stop her, but she didn’t. She gave Agatha a small smile -quick, real enough- before turning back to Lilia and Sage instead, dropped back into their conversation, even laughed like it was easy.

 

Fine. Whatever. Maybe Rio didn’t get worked up over little things anymore. Agatha could live with that. What she couldn’t live with was being ignored. She wanted Rio’s attention -plain and fucking simple- and she didn’t care if it made her seem childish. Her leg bounced under the table, thumbnail still at her mouth, eyes darting anywhere else so she wouldn’t look like a lunatic burning a hole into Rio’s profile.

 

It took all of two seconds before Agatha leaned into Rio’s space again, watching as she counted seven dominoes and pulled them in front of Agatha. Only then did Rio start pulling seven for herself.

 

“Lips of an Angel, huh?” Agatha said, voice casual.

 

Rio’s head snapped toward her, jaw tight, like she couldn’t decide whether to sputter out a defense or crawl under the table. “It’s a popular song,” she muttered with a shrug, eyes darting back to the table. “Sage, grab a few beers from the garage, yeah?”

 

Agatha pressed her lips together. “I just think it’s interesting, that’s all.” She gave a lazy shrug, mirroring Rio’s.

 

Sage groaned but shoved her chair back, heading for the garage where they kept the spare fridge. Lilia pushed up from the table a beat later, muttering about chicken in the freezer out there, and followed after her.

 

The kitchen quieted as their footsteps faded, the clatter of the bead curtain in the doorway the only sound left behind.

 

Rio finally looked over, her brow furrowed a little, but Agatha caught the upward twitch of her mouth. “Intresting?” Rio repeated, her voice pitched higher now, dragging the word out as she stood her dominoes in neat rows in front of her.

 

“Yeah, it’s just- don’t you think it’s weird? You hadn’t even kissed me yet, and you went with the song every middle-aged single father butchers at karaoke night?”

 

Rio stared at her, her face fighting bewilderment and amusement, before she pressed her tongue into her cheek.

 

Now, why the fuck was she doing that? 

 

Agatha felt her jaw clench before Rio even spoke. 

 

“Is that something you’ve thought about a lot?” Rio asked, her head tilting slightly. 

 

Agatha shook her head, her voice flat. “I only just found out you did that today, so no.” She wanted to leave it there, but Rio was still watching her closely, eyes bright, a little too entertained.

 

Rio shifted in her chair, turning toward her until her knee bumped against Agatha’s thigh. “That’s not what I meant,” she said. “I mean songs in general. You clearly have opinions about mine, so what would you have picked instead?”

 

Agatha wouldn’t pretend otherwise- she had an entire playlist dedicated to her deranged friendship with Rio Vidal. She could give a serious answer, something cool and bulletproof like Silver Springs by Fleetwood Mac. She could dodge the question completely. Literally anything. Instead, her brain served up the one answer guaranteed to get her eaten alive until the end of time.

 

“Far Away. Nickelback.”

 

Rio’s jaw dropped, her eyes wide with horror and amusement. “Nickleback?” she demanded, the word itself was an accusation. 

 

Valid, Agatha thought. 

 

Rio didn’t waste a second before she broke into a laugh that wouldn’t stop. “You’re gonna give me shit about Hinder and you went with Nickleback. That’s- oh my god- that’s fucking hilarious.”

 

“Hey,” Agatha snapped. “It wasn’t your music taste that offended me- it’s your inability to apply context correctly.” And yet, despite herself, the smile tugging at her mouth betrayed her.  

 

“Right, right,” Rio said, nodding along. “Because Lips of an Angel was more your vibe, yeah?”

 

Yes. 

 

For a second Agatha sat in the silence that followed, simmering with the very subtle urge to throttle Rio.

 

But Rio only leaned in closer, her voice dropping into a taunt that pressed right against Agatha’s temper. “How’s my context application look now, sweetheart?”

 

Agatha wanted to kiss her desperately.

 

She nodded slowly, eyes narrowing at Rio. “Funny,” Agatha murmured. “Projecting onto me doesn’t make your choice any less stupid.”

 

“Funny,” Rio echoed, tilting her chin up like a dare, eyes fixed on Agatha’s mouth. Her tongue swept over her own lips, deliberate. “You don’t look too mad about it.”

 

Agatha tried to glare, and her voice slipped out soft, almost pleading. “I am.” Pitiful defense, thin as paper, and she hated how unconvincing it sounded even to her own ears.

 

The slam of the garage door jolted them both, their heads snapping apart too quickly to look casual. Though Rio stayed angled toward Agatha.

 

Agatha caught the flick of Rio’s eyes toward the bead curtain, She cleared her throat, pivoted fast, like she needed to get the words out before Lilia or Sage came back. “Look, I hope we didn’t ruin your afternoon. Sage said her car was acting up, and wanted a ride over here. And when we pulled in and saw your car, she wouldn’t let me leave. I wasn’t trying to intrude.”

 

“It’s okay,” Agatha shot back too fast, because she meant it. “Lilia was acting strange earlier too. I even tried to leave because I didn’t want you thinking-” She broke off, the rest of it catching in her throat.

 

Rio nodded in understanding, biting the inside of her cheek like she always did when she was fighting the urge to say something sweet. 

 

The sight of it left Agatha wanting to tell Rio to say whatever it was she was chewing holes into her mouth to keep down.

 

The bead curtain clattered, and Agatha’s head whipped around. Lilia slipped back into the kitchen without so much as a glance in their direction, moving straight to the sink. She dropped a frozen chicken into the basin, the thunk of it echoing, and carried on as if Agatha and Rio weren’t even there.

 

Agatha turned her head back, and Rio was already watching her. Their eyes caught, close enough to make Agatha lean in further, her voice dropping to a whisper. “Do you think we were set up?”

 

“No doubt,” Rio murmured, the corner of her mouth twitching. “Lil’s got that creepy intuition thing. Probably staged all of it with a candle and a spell.”

 

Agatha let out a soft huff, shaking her head. “Could be worse setups. At least I don’t mind the company.”

 

Rio let out a scandalized little gasp, leaning in closer to Agatha with her arms folded on to the table. “Agatha Harkness,” she murmured. “Are you seriously flirting with me at the dinner table?” Her eyes deliberately flicked toward Lilia at the sink, then back to Agatha again, “And in front of my mom? You dog.”

 

Agatha bit her bottom lip and rolled her eyes. “If that’s what you want to call it.”

 

And because the universe had impeccable timing, Sage’s voice cut through the air, muffled slightly around the black Juul clamped between her teeth: “Oh, she wants that cookie bad.” She strolled up to the table with four beers tucked against her chest, her shit eating grin flashing wide even as the vape bobbed in mouth.

 

They both jolted again like kids caught passing notes in class, whipping back into their seats as if they hadn’t just been leaning into each other.

 

Rio shoved her chair back so abruptly the legs scraped against the floor. She leaned across the table, sending half her domino stack face-up as she yanked two beers out of Sage’s arms. And because Rio was Rio, she hissed at Sage like an angry cat while she did it. 

 

Sage only jerked back a little, eyes delighted with the thrill of getting a rise out of Rio.

 

Rio dropped back into her chair with a huff, clamping the bottle between her teeth and snapping the cap off like it was nothing. The sound made Agatha flinch; she hated when Rio did that, hated anything that put metal near enamel. But she still took the beer when Rio pressed it into her hand, eyes watching -transfixed and faintly horrifed- as Rio pulled the same trick again for her own.

 

Meanwhile, Sage unclipped the carabiner from her belt loop, the cluster of keys and other shit jangling as she used the bottle opener clipped on it to crack open Lilia’s beer and then her own. 

 

“Gay carabiners a generational curse in this family?” Agatha muttered against the lip of her beer before taking a sip.

 

It was a dig, sure- but a useless one, because her chest still did something stupid every time she saw her house key hanging off Rio’s carabiner. Worse was being there when Rio used it, watching her unlock Agatha’s front door like it had always been theirs to walk through.

 

Once seated, Sage tugged the black vape from between her teeth and waved it lazily at the pair of them. “Don’t stop on my account. I love a good slow burn.”

 

Agatha nearly choked on her beer.

 

Rio leaned forward, eyes narrowing on Sage across the mess. “Oh, I’m sorry- how long did it take you to pull your head out of your ass before you and Yelena started dating, huh?”

 

Agatha winced. 

 

Rio never seemed to remember that if anyone held the record for the longest slow burn in the history of fucking ever, it was the two of them- seventeen years and counting. So it wasn’t surprising when Sage snapped back, fast and sure, like she’d been waiting for the chance:

 

“A hell of a lot faster than you and your girlfriend.”

 

Oh.

 

Agatha didn’t hate that. 

 

Rio froze, jaw slack like she couldn’t believe Sage had actually said it- as if she hadn’t set herself up for it.

 

“Oh, you little-” Rio started to surge across the table, but Agatha slammed her beer down and caught her by the back of her sweater vest, yanking her down into the chair before she could launch herself any further.

 

“For fucks sake- not over the dominoes,” Lilia snapped, striding back to the table like it mattered more than the potential brawl seconds away from happening. She flicked her gaze between them. “Sage, stop being an asshole. And you-” her eyes cut to Rio, “try lunging across my table again and you’ll regret it.”

 

Sage snorted, clearly pleased with herself. Rio jerked against Agatha’s hold like she might actually try again, so Agatha dug her fingers deeper into the fabric.

 

“I wasn’t gonna do anything,” Rio ground out through her teeth. “Just wanted to give Sage a hug. You know, love her up a little bit.”

 

Lilia dropped into her chair and leveled a finger at Rio in warning. Rio threw up both hands like she was finished, smoothing both over her sweater vest as if that settled it.

 

“Perfect,” Lilia muttered, eyeing the dominoes scattered across the table. “Now we have to reshuffle the whole damn thing.”

 

Rio slumped back with a huff, her hands still smoothing over her sweater like she could iron out the urge to lunge again. Agatha’s hand moved without thought, rubbing slow across her back, in a thoughtless attempt to settle her. She wasn’t even sure Rio noticed, but the tension beneath her palm loosened all the same. She kept her hand there until Lilia dragged the scattered dominoes back into a pile, and only then let it slip away. 

 

Agatha drew seven.
