The game started well enough and then absolutely went downhill from there.

 

Agatha couldn’t fucking stand losing and every round only ratcheted her competitiveness higher. Her blood was hot, teeth grinding, fingers hooked into Rio’s thigh under the table before she even realized her hand landed there. 

 

So when a couple of dominoes appeared in her hand, exactly the ones she’d been silently cursing for, she didn’t so much as blink. Rio had slipped them to her smooth as anything, tucked under the palm resting on her thigh, her other arm sprawled across the back of Agatha’s chair like it had always belonged there.

 

Sage, of course, caught on. She jabbed across the table, swearing Rio was sneaking her pieces. Agatha scoffed, swore she wasn’t, even as she slid one of the incriminating dominoes neatly into place with a little too much satisfaction. 

 

Rio called Sage insane, which only made Agatha’s shoulders shake as she fought not to laugh outright. 

 

Sage nearly launched across the table after her, and Agatha had to bite down on her cheek to stop from encouraging it. Lilia smacked the back of Sage’s head to force her into her seat, and Sage collapsed with a dramatic scoff.

 

It ended the way it always did: with Lilia winning. Calm, ruthless, unstoppable. She swept her last domino into place while Agatha sat back, fist jammed against her mouth to stop herself from pounding the table in defeat.

 

Agatha turned to snap at Rio for no real reason other than being a sore loser, but the words caught in throat when she found Rio already looking at her, wearing that smug little smirk that said they’d pulled one over on the world. And a smile broke across Agatha’s face before she could stop it. 

 

-

 

Rio didn’t ask right away. She stayed beside her through the lull that followed- while the dominoes were put back into their tin, while Lilia gloated, while Sage sulked and the conversation wandered off into nothing. 

 

It was long enough that Agatha almost forgot she was holding her breath for it. Then Rio leaned closer, still in the chair next to her, “You wanna go upstairs for a little bit?”

 

The exhale left her before she could stop it. She forced a thin smile and managed, “Sure.”

 

Rio didn’t hesitate- she nodded once, laced their fingers together and hauled her up, already announcing, “We’ll be upstairs.”

 

When they passed the sink, where Lilia and Sage were talking, Lilia lifted one hand in a lazy wave of permission not even bothering them with a glance.

 

Agatha let herself be dragged out of the kitchen and toward the stairs. When Rio’s foot landed on the second step, the wood let out its familiar creak under her weight. The sound was small, ordinary, yet it struck through Agatha with the force of memory. After nearly two decades that second stair still sang the same tired note, as if no time had passed at all. 

 

Something in her chest tightened, and before Agatha could stop herself she caught herself on the banister and gave Rio’s hand a small tug. 

 

After all the years she’d spent refusing, after rushing past it the moment she stepped inside, she couldn’t move on without facing it. She wanted to look. She needed to.

 

Rio turned back, one foot balanced on the second step, and she seemed to understand. She made no move to drag Agatha forward. She only stood there, holding still, her patience always so complete it felt like her hand pressed to Agatha’s chest.

 

Agatha made herself stand still, to let her eyes linger where they wanted to run. The living room was exactly as she remembered, yet changed by the years she had been gone. 

 

Sunlight spilled through the windows, caught in new curtains she didn’t recognize, patterned and bright. A different crocheted throw sagged over the same worn chair. A deck of tarot cards was left half shuffled scattered across the same battered trunk that doubled as a coffee table. Even the stairs behind her sang the same weary sound she remembered.

 

Picture frames crowded the mantel and along shelves- some new with Sage’s grin, others older, ones Agatha had forgotten until they stared back at her. She spotted herself in more than a few, and in some it was only her and Rio. Her fingers twitched with the usual urge to steal one. She dug her nails into the banister, smothered it, and told herself fine. 

 

Told herself she would definitely be raiding Rio’s apartment at a later date- penance for the nuisance of a conscience that refused to let her loot Lilia’s living room.

 

And still, even with the thrill of robbing Rio blind, she made a mental note to circle back later. Her moral compass, as it turns out, has always been a little… flexible.

 

“Oh, would you look at that, I need to tie my shoe,” Rio declared, loud enough to jolt Agatha out of her scheming.

 

Agatha’s head snapped toward her just in time to notice Rio slip her hand free and plop down on the stair. She bent forward, fingers working the motions of someone tying their shoelaces- if not for the fact Rio wasn’t wearing shoes at all. Only socks. Still, she kept at it, tugging tight, cinching down, double knotting air. She was busying her hands, her gaze, her whole restless body- looking anywhere but at Agatha.

 

It was almost insulting in its transparency. And yet there was something in the way Rio bent herself to the task -so earnest in her nonsense- that made Agatha want to kiss her. But she swallowed it down, took the distraction Rio handed her, and ran with it shamelessly. 

 

She moved to the mantel and scanned the pictures until one made her stop. It was the three of them- Lilia in the center, Agatha and Rio flanking her. They couldn’t have been more than twenty-two. Lilia’s smile was easy, Agatha’s a little guarded, and Rio- Rio, for once, wasn’t being ridiculous. No crossed eyes, no middle fingers, no goofy faces. She wasn’t even looking at the camera. She was looking at Agatha, her mouth tilted in that genuine smile that had only ever belonged to Agatha.

 

Agatha’s fingers moved before she gave herself time to argue. She lifted the frame, slid the back open and slipped the photo free. And for a second she just held it, staring too long. 

 

Anyone else might’ve slipped it into a pocket, but she knew herself. Agatha had standards, even when it came to stealing. And she couldn’t stomach the idea of that smile creased. 

 

So she mumbled something vague about needing something from her car, slipped outside, and tossed the photo onto the passenger seat like evidence she couldn’t be caught holding. She shut the door hard, exhaled once, and went back in.

 

Agatha returned to the staircase and found Rio still planted on the second step, sitting there- knees drawn up, chin resting in her hand.

 

“Okay,” Agatha said, a little short of breath though she tried not to sound it.

 

Rio smiled at her, that same gap toothed fucking smile that was now trapped in the photograph sitting safe in Agatha’s car. It was almost unbearable, seeing it alive and right in front of her after she had just stolen proof of it on paper.

 

Again, Agatha felt it like Rio’s hand pressed to her chest.

 

Rio stood, gave her a satisfied nod, and held her hand out like it was the most obvious thing in the world. 

 

Agatha took it without thinking, let herself be hauled up step by step, until they reached the top and the familiar door at the end of the hall.

 

Rio pushed it open and Agatha lingered in the doorway.

 

The room smelled faintly of old incense and dust warmed by sunlight. The bed sat in its same spot beneath the window, a black comforter faded by time. The desk was clear but not empty: single neat stack of CDs sat on top of it, a chipped mug that held only pens. Above, the corkboard still carried its weight- ticket stubs lined up like a ledger, Polaroids fixed square and orderly instead of curling at the corners. Even the posters- Rocky Horror, Little Shop of Horrors, Sweeney Todd- every gruesome musical Rio had obsessed over until she knew the lines and lyrics  by heart. They were still intact, their edges pressed flat, colors a little dulled but still unpeeled from the wall.

 

It didn’t feel lived in, but it didn’t feel abandoned either. Just… paused.

 

Agatha let out a faint hum, almost a laugh. Figures, she thought. Rio’s past always had better posture than most people’s present.

 

“You gonna come in?” Rio’s voice cut through her thoughts again- for what felt like the hundredth time in the last half hour. “Or are you just gonna stand there looking pretty.”

 

Agatha smirked, tilting her head. “You think I’m pretty?” She played it light, feigned innocence she knew Rio wouldn’t buy.

 

Rio smirked back, unbothered. “You’re fishing.” She tipped her chin toward Agatha’s feet, still rooted in the doorway. “And stalling. Any time now.”

 

Agatha scoffed under her breath. “Don’t tell me what to do.” She slipped inside, shut the door behind her with a quiet click. 

 

When she turned around, Rio hadn’t moved. She was still standing in the center of the room, watching Agatha like there was nothing else she wanted to do. 

 

“Are we still in a fight? Because I’d like to know. The lines feel a little…” She let her gaze flick away, pretending to search for the word, then dragged it back to Rio, taking the chance to look her up and down- yup, nipples still on clear display through that fucking knit she was wearing. “Blurred,” she finished.

 

Agatha sure as fuck didn’t miss the way Rio’s gaze slid down her body before finding her eyes again. “Blurred,” Rio echoed, nodding slightly, as if repeating it counted as an answer.

 

She let out a hum, casual as she could make it, though Agatha didn’t have the slightest fucking clue where they stood. They could be fine, not fine, still fighting, already over it- fuck if she could tell. And the look Rio had just given her wasn’t helping. It pressed against her until her skin prickled and her body wound itself tight, ready for something her mind kept second guessing, too caught on the possibility that she was misreading the entire situation.

 

Rather than stand there trying to decipher it, Agatha let her attention shift, eyes catching on the desk pushed up against the wall. She crossed the room toward it. 

 

Her fingers trailed along the edge, catching on dust motes and grooves in the wood before sliding over to the neat column of stacked CDs. She tapped the one on top, some random Swedish rap album she didn’t recognize. It shouldn’t have made sense, but it screamed Rio anyway, and Agatha wasn’t about to fry her brain trying to figure out why. 

 

She could feel Rio’s gaze trailing after her, hot and relentless, like being watched through the scope of a rifle. 

 

When Agatha finally turned and looked up, brown eyes were already waiting for her blues, steady and unblinking.

 

“So,” Agatha said, holding Rio’s gaze like a dare, “any reason you dragged me up to your angsty teenage bedroom?” 

 

She leaned her knuckle into the stack of CDs, nudging until the symmetry broke. The cases leaned, just slightly, but the shift was enough to light something in her chest- petty, reckless satisfaction.

 

Rio’s gaze flicked to the disruption for a split second before snapping back to Agatha. “No reason,” she shrugged, not bothering to fix the CDs. 

 

Agatha’s brows shot up. “Try again.”

 

Rio started toward her, and Agatha leaned back against the desk. Her hands clamped onto the edge, holding herself there. 

 

Rio pressed closer until there was barely an inch left between them- Agatha lifted a hand to her shoulder to keep her steady, to keep herself steady.

 

Rio’s attention had dropped to the waistband of Agatha’s jeans, brushing the button with her thumb. A fidget, maybe. Or maybe not. Agatha couldn’t decide.

 

And then Rio’s gaze lifted. For a moment she looked caught off guard, lips parting slightly like she’d forgotten how to school her face.

 

“We shouldn’t,” Rio whispered.

 

Her finger hooked into the waistband of Agatha’s jeans, the tip resting just behind the button. It was barely contact, almost nothing- and still it tore a soft huff from Agatha’s chest, unbidden. Her hips pushed forward before she could stop herself, chasing more.

 

Agatha found herself nodding before she’d even decided to. “We shouldn’t,” she echoed. “It sounds-” Whatever she meant to say cut short when Rio’s finger started moving, tracing the inside of her waistband from the button to the edge of her hip and back again. 

 

Rio dipped her chin in a small nod, wordlessly urging Agatha to finish. At the same time she leaned in, close enough that the tilt of her mouth felt like bait, like she was daring Agatha to break first.

 

Agatha swallowed hard, tried again. “It sounds an awful lot like you dragged me up here for a quickie.”

 

“No.” Rio’s head gave a small, deliberate shake, her tone lifting just enough to sound certain. Serious, almost tender- but somehow it landed warm and suggestive all the same, like she couldn’t help herself.

 

“That didn’t sound convincing. Try again,” Agatha said, nearly breathless. 

 

Somebody had to be the adult, to remind them that sneaking off for a quick fuck in Rio’s childhood home was absolutely not the point of coming up here. 

 

That adult, however, was not Agatha- not with Rio’s fingertip hooked just behind the button of her jeans again in a way that had Agatha wetting her lips before she even realized it.

 

Rio’s gaze followed instantly, dropping to her mouth and staying there. 

 

“No,” Rio tried again, it fell out breathy and whined, a contradiction that sounded far too much like she was rethinking it.

 

That was worse. A hundred times fucking worse.

 

“Oh my god,” Agatha muttered, shaking her head. “If that’s the best you’ve got, we’re fucked.”

 

Rio didn’t bite. No grin, no comeback, not even a flicker of amusement. She just stayed there, finger still hooked in Agatha’s waistband, eyes glued to her mouth like she hadn’t heard a damn thing.

 

Agatha’s stomach twisted as Rio finally, reluctantly, dragged her gaze upward. The shift was slow like she was pulling herself through quicksand. When their eyes met again, Rio’s mouth parted, and the word fell out in a single needy breath.

 

“Baby.”

 

One word. Rio could reduce Agatha to putty with two fucking syllables, sounding like that, and it was beyond fucked up the way Agatha’s hips betrayed her again- jerking forward into the hand sitting at her waste band.

 

“You-” Agatha’s tongue darted out to wet her lips, stalling for ground she didn’t have. Her eyes burning into Rio’s. “You are such an asshole.” 

 

“Am I?” Rio asked, her voice dipped in false sweetness.

 

Well, fuck. 

 

Maybe Agatha was going to have to be the adult here -god help them fucking both- because there was no version of reality where they banged one out in Rio’s childhood home with her family downstairs. 

 

It simply could not happen… still didn’t mean Agatha couldn’t toy with Rio a little first.

 

Agatha peeled her hand from the desk, her grip stiff from holding on so tight, and let it drift down between them. She dragged her palm up the inside of Rio’s thigh,  stroking once, twice, right over the place where Rio’s dick would’ve been if she were wearing it- where it had been the night before, when she’d shown up at Agatha’s house with it strapped on like it was nothing.

Her eyes fluttered shut, her forehead tipping forward until it rested against Agatha’s. “Are you seriously… feeling for my dick right now?”

 

Agatha’s mouth curved, a low hum slipping out- confirmation, provocation, both. Rio’s hand slipped from where it had lingered at Agatha’s waist and slid beneath her shirt, curving around to the small of her back. 

 

She pulled away from Rio’s forehead, tilting to brush her mouth against Rio’s ear. And the faint scrape of Rio’s nails down her spine made Agatha shiver. 

 

“I want my mouth on it.” Agatha said it as her hand moved, cupping between Rio’s legs hard enough to jolt her upward.

 

Rio broke with another gasp, a thin moan tangled in it, and her body collapsed forward so suddenly the desk rattled against the wall. She clutched at the desk with one hand, the other gripping into Agatha’s bare back like she couldn’t stand upright on her own.

 

The collapse of Rio, the give of her- made Agatha’s head tip back, mouth falling open at how completely Rio poured herself against her. One hand still pressed firm between her thighs, the other buried in Rio’s hair, tugging at the nape until Rio’s face tilted just where she wanted it. 

 

Agatha’s lips brushed the flushed skin of Rio’s cheek as she murmured, “What’s the matter, baby? Can’t fuck my throat without your toy?”

 

Rio made a strangled sound and wrenched herself out of Agatha’s grip. She staggered back, then spun, throwing herself down on her old bed face first, fists knotted in the blanket.

 

Agatha leaned against the desk, chest heaving, lips parted on a laugh that never quite came. She tipped her head back, grinning anyway, tasting victory sweet on her tongue.

 

Rio pounded the bed with both fists, yelling into the fabric before she shoved away from the mattress. She stumbled off the bed, tore the blanket back, and crawled beneath it. Then she snapped the blanket over her head, shutting Agatha out.

 

Agatha pushed off the desk, still breathless, and crossed the room. She sat herself on the edge of the bed, not bothering with the fact that Rio had buried herself beneath the blanket, and pulled open the drawer of the nightstand. 

 

Not her first time snooping here- probably not even her tenth. She knew what lived in there- probably hadn’t changed in years. But Agatha had missed over a decade of snooping through Rio’s old things, and she wasn’t about to waste the chance she had now.

 

Inside, everything sat just where she expected: a pair of wired headphones wound into a knot, an old pipe scrubbed clean, silver wire rimmed glasses, and two photographs tucked beneath them.

 

Agatha’s heart squeezed. One photo showed Rio as a baby, cheeks soft, her parents’ arms holding  her in front of the house they’d barely had time to live in together. The other was only her parents, younger than Agatha liked to think about, smiling like the future wasn’t already written against them.

 

She knew the story. At nine, Rio had been thrown into the system with almost nothing. Those pictures were the one constant she carried. And she carried them everywhere. Every new house, every new set of strangers. Different kitchens, different rules, different beds she wasn’t meant to get comfortable in.

 

Seven placements in all, and somehow those pictures survived each one. Rio never risked putting them on display, never left them where they could be taken or torn. They lived pressed between clothes, hidden in drawers, stashed at the bottom of bags, always ready to move when she was told to.

 

When she landed at Lilia’s, she finally stopped moving. And when she left as an adult, she left the photos here. Told Agatha once that it was safer than anywhere else. 

 

This drawer was the first place Rio allowed herself to believe something precious could actually stay put. The first place she trusted the world not to tear away from her. 

 

Rio’s first safe place.

 

And that fucking drawer should’ve been Agatha’s first clue into how Rio loved: careful, controlled, never reckless. Rio didn’t gamble with what mattered. She didn’t take risks she couldn’t recover from. Not with the photos. Not with herself. Not with Agatha.

 

Somehow, Agatha missed it. Too much noise in her head, too much fury in her chest, too much certainty in her own genius. 

 

Rio’s love had been right there- patient, careful, stubborn. Safe as the photos in that drawer. And Agatha, always moving too fast for her own good, never slowed down enough to notice.

 

Which was the real fucking irony- Agatha had spent a long time raging that Rio never actually saw her, never understood the quiet ways she tried to say love me back. All the while, she’d been blind to Rio’s. Demanding to be seen while refusing to look.

 

Agatha’s thumb brushed over baby Rio’s face- soft, untouched, before the world had made her flinch at every corner. She lingered there for a moment, then reached past it, fingertips catching on the bent wire of the glasses.

 

She climbed onto the bed without a word, knees sinking into the mattress until her hips bracketed Rio’s. The blanket still covered her head, a pathetic shield, and Agatha tugged it down slow, savoring the reveal. 

 

Rio didn’t resist. She lay there stiff and waiting, arms crossed over her chest, glaring up at her.

 

Agatha only laughed under her breath. She reached down, thumb brushing the deep crease in Rio’s brow, smoothing it flat. “Always so dramatic,” she murmured. Then  she unfolded the wire frames in her hands and slipped the glasses onto Rio’s face. 

 

She grinned at how wrong they looked on Rio, how right it felt to be the one to put them there. 

 

“How long did you even wear those?” Agatha asked, her voice quiet.

 

“A year. Maybe less. I was eleven.” Rio mumbled, her hands moving to rest over Agatha’s thighs, thumbs brushing across the denim.

 

Agatha arched a brow. “And then what? Your vision just magically fixed itself?”

 

“I tanked my eye exam on purpose.”

 

Agatha blinked at her. “You mean you pretended to need glasses?”

 

Rio gave a small shrug, thumbs still moving against her. “Yeah. Thought they would make me look cool.”

 

“You’re unbelievable.”

 

“What? Eleven-year-olds are allowed to have phases.”

 

“Phases?” Agatha echoed. “You conned a doctor because you thought glasses would make you interesting.”

 

Rio grinned. “Worked, didn’t it? You can’t stop staring.”

 

“Whatever,” Agatha muttered as she slid the glasses off Rio’s face. She folded them with care and placed them back in the drawer where she’d found them. Then she turned her attention back to the woman beneath her.

 

Agatha’s hands slipped under the edge of Rio’s sweater vest to tug it higher. She pushed the fabric out of the way until Rio’s chest was bare.

 

Boobs.

 

Agatha lowered herself carefully, pressing her cheek to Rio’s chest.

 

Rio let her. More than that, after a moment, she wrapped her arms around Agatha, one hand dragging up into her hair, fingers threading through strands and holding her close. 

 

Agatha let her eyes fall closed and -stupidly, selfishly- thought: there it is. Rio’s heartbeat. The same one Agatha had dragged with her everywhere, even when she swore she was done with it. Still alive in the same place she had left it. 



Proof she hadn’t lost everything. Proof something of Agatha’s had survived- guarded in the body of the only person stubborn enough to keep it safe.



The loudest constant in Agatha’s life. 



She had left, disappeared for years, trashed every chance she got- and somehow, against all odds, it was still there when she came back. Still beating. Still waiting. Still hers.



And if that drawer had been Rio’s first sanctuary, then Rio herself had been Agatha’s. 



The first place Agatha could set something precious and trust it would still be there tomorrow.



“It beats for you, you know.” Rio’s voice carried the shape of a smile, soft enough to be a joke.



Agatha buried her face deeper, nose crushed to bone, eyes squeezed shut until they ached. Because of course Rio would lead with something like that- something so stupid it had no right to matter. 



Except it did. It always fucking did. Like Rio had been listening in on every selfish thought rushing through Agatha’s head and gave it a voice.

 

Agatha felt a hot tear slip from the corner of her eye, slide down the bridge of her nose, and fall against Rio’s chest. “I’m sorry,” Agatha whispered, and it wasn’t nearly enough.

 

I misunderstood you. And I built years on that mistake. Fucked everything up just to prove myself right.

 

I misunderstood.

 

“You’re already forgiven.” Rio’s lips pressed into her hair. She didn’t even bother asking what the apology was for. And Agatha knew Rio still meant it. She always meant it. “Are you okay?”



A noise broke out of Agatha that wanted to be a laugh but fell short. She shoved her hand up, knuckles grinding against the eye not buried in Rio’s chest. “I just feel like shit,” she admitted. It took effort to keep going, to push the words through the tightness in her throat. “And I’m not trying to ignore what happened this morning. I don’t want you to think that.”



“I know,” Rio said, and her hand slid beneath Agatha’s shirt, rubbing slowly up and down her back. “We’ll get through it. Today’s been a lot, for the both of us. And right now, all I want is this- just us. A place to breathe together for a little while, yeah?”



And Agatha felt Rio’s words like a crack of light through the weight of the day. The fight that morning, the gauntlet of Lilia’s house, tearing herself open piece by piece until there was nothing left to hide. She was still on her feet, fragile as glass, almost waiting to break… And she hadn’t even made it to dinner yet.

 

But here was Rio, holding her, asking for nothing more than this moment. No apologies demanded, no fixes chased, no pretense that the day hadn’t chewed them up and spit them out. She was offering a pause. A place to breathe together. 

 

“I’ll try again tomorrow,” Agatha promised.

 

“I’ll be there when you do. Always.”

 

 

Chapter End Notes

i love night shift agatha, please be gentle with her.

had a super difficult time writing this (fuck writers block and FUCK dominoes- me and all my homies who hate having to math to play a game HATE dominoes) so i hope it was worth the wait.

finally made an actual night shift specific playlist on my spotify account linked below. check it out if you'd like.

some disturbing news for you- i feel we are nearing the end. i can't give an exact chapter count because who knows? i might think of something to derail it (unlikely) because i'm obsessed with this agathario... like genuinely i've loved every second of writing them. anyway, just don't be surprised if by the next update there's a set chapter count.

lastly, thank you for the music <3

Chapter 16: in time to face it

Chapter Notes

listen. i was in the mood to write smut... so smut is what i wrote. they talk about feelings after- trust.

See the end of the chapter for more notes

After the day Agatha had, she figured she’d drag herself through dinner half dead, smile where she had to, and leave feeling like she had been hit by a fucking bus carrying nearly twenty years of emotional baggage. Old photos came out, stories told across the table, Sage and Rio tore into each other like always, and somehow, somewhere in the middle of all that, Agatha forgot she was supposed to be tired. And Rio, ever the opportunist, had at some point thrown her keys at Sage with a “figure it out tomorrow.”



Rio slid into the driver’s seat of Agatha’s car and turned the key, the engine starting as the dash lights blinked on. Rio called it damage control- Agatha’s driving, according to her, being an “ongoing threat to public safety.” Agatha let it slide. If Rio wanted to chauffeur her around for the rest of her life, she wasn’t about to complain. 



Being a passenger princess wasn’t exactly a hardship, not with the way Rio backed out of the driveway with one hand on the wheel and the other stretched behind Agatha’s seat. It shouldn’t have been that distracting, but apparently she’d hit the stage of life where a woman who could drive her home without incident was the sexiest thing alive.



Agatha had been staring at the side of Rio’s face for so long she was surprised she hadn’t burned a hole clean through her skull. It wasn’t subtle -she knew that much- but brain kept offering up unhelpful ideas, like leaning over and dragging her tongue up the side of Rio’s face.

Three seconds that felt like an eternity, all while Agatha begged the universe for a fourth.

“Did you know?”

Back in their twenties, she, Rio, Alice, and Jen would waste entire nights there, stretched out on the hood of someone’s car, talking shit and pretending they had time to burn forever.

From the overlook, Westview didn’t shrink or swell; it just sprawled like a lit map, blinking and unpretentious. Highway lights carved a crooked line through the dark, their rhythm broken by gas stations, chain restaurants, the strip mall parking lot buzzing under fluorescent lamps. Downtown showed itself in a line of brick buildings, bar signs that flickered, the faded marquee of the old theater refusing to go black. Neighborhood porch lights scattered like constellations.

 

It wasn’t stunning in any objective sense, wasn’t the kind of view people wrote about, and Agatha knew it. Still, something in her chest swelled. She wanted to resent the years she’d spent away, wanted to remind herself she had every reason to keep her distance.
