Agatha’s gaze followed, and the sight embarrassingly made her stomach flip.

 

The trunk was open, blankets thrown across the back, pillows stacked, and a mess of battery powered fairy lights clinging to the ceiling. It was absurd, overdone, unbearably sweet. Agatha should’ve rolled her eyes at- except she couldn’t stop staring.

 

Her fingers clenched into Rio’s shirt, the cotton straining under her grip.

 

Rio leaned close, voice dropping into a mocking, courtly drawl. “Ma’lady.”

 

“You’re disgusting,” Agatha whispered, eyes still fixed on the car.

 

“I don’t think you really believe that.” 

 

Agatha could hear the smirk in Rio’s words.

 

“You’re right.” Agatha flicked her eyes toward Rio, finally uncurled her fist from Rio’s shirt, and moved toward the car. She sat on the bumper of the trunk, legs dangling.

 

Rio strolled after her, dragging out the last pull of her cigarette. She exhaled slow, ground the stub between her fingers, then reached past Agatha for the jar of sand she always carries around.

 

Because Rio Vidal was nothing if not committed to saving the earth- one cigarette at a time.

 

Rio shoved the jar into the side pocket of the 4Runner’s trunk, right up against the emergency kit she always kept- jumper cables, poncho, flares. She called it her “just in case kit.” Agatha had been extremely disappointed to learn it wasn’t code for anything remotely sex related.

 

She stepped in front of Agatha, and even perched on the edge of the trunk, Agatha was nearly eye level with her. Both of Rio’s hands came up, warm against her face, tucking strands of hair behind her ears.

 

Agatha’s hands slipped beneath the hem of Rio’s shirt, nails scratching lightly down her back.

 

Rio’s thumb caught on her cheekbone, tilting her chin until she couldn’t look anywhere else.

 

“You okay?” Rio asked.

 

Agatha gave a small smile and a nod, “Yeah. Just worried I’m gonna rot a tooth with how sweet this all is.”

 

Rio laughed under her breath, rolling her eyes. “That’s awful.”

 

“Sorry,” Agatha murmured, letting her eyes roam over Rio’s body. “Must be distracted by the view.”

 

Rio narrowed her eyes, tongue caught in her cheek. “So you drag me out here just to out-flirt me?”

 

Agatha blinked at her, then looked back at the trunk setup like she needed to confirm it was actually there. “Out-flirt you? I’m trying to keep up. I ask you on a date, and you show up with fairy lights, pillows, and blankets? And you expect me not to think about letting you rail me in the back of your 4Runner? Who even does that?”

 

“Wait- so you didn’t ask me to drive you out here just to get railed in the back of my 4Runner?” Rio teased, her hands sliding down to rest against Agatha’s thighs.

 

Agatha knew she was joking. She always knew. But suddenly, Agatha wasn’t.

 

She hadn’t picked this spot for the view, or for the privacy, or even for Rio’s stupid car. It was just… here. The scene of the crime. The place that had been gnawing the back of her skull since yesterday’s conversation with Lilia. 

 

Unfinished business, Agatha thinks.

 

Rio caught the shift instantly. “What?” she asked, her voice was softer, no longer teasing.

 

“Nothing. I just… Talking with Lilia yesterday reminded me of one night we were up here is all…” Agatha’s voice faltered, trailing off. A beat passed before she let the rest out, her face flushing at the memory. “You asked me what was wrong with my face.”

 

Rio’s head pulled back a little bit, her brow furrowed deeper, “That was shitty... Nothing’s ever been wrong with your face. It’s perfect. Always has been.”

 

Agatha might have smiled if it didn’t feel like her stomach was about to fall out of her asshole. “It was a valid question. I was actually doing something stupid with my face,” She huffed.

 

Constipated, her brain, ever the asshole, corrected. She yanked Rio’s shirt up just enough to duck under it, grateful as always Rio never bothered with wearing a bra. She pressed her ear hard against Rio’s chest, chasing the thud there like it might settle the riot in her own.

 

Rio’s hand came up, settling on the back of her head and held her there. Her other hand slipped from her thigh, pulling at the collar of her shirt wider. She pressed a kiss into Agatha’s hair, her voice gentle against her head. “Agatha.”

 

Agatha grunted into her chest.

 

“This whole skin to skin boob obsession you’ve got going on- it’s very sweet,” Rio teased, pressing another kiss into Agatha’s hair.

 

Agatha had the urge to hiss and yank the collar shut, like she could physically slam a door on Rio’s voice vibrating through her ribs. 

 

She also wanted to correct Rio, rudely and at length. Yes, fine, she had what some might technically classify as a borderline unhealthy obsession with Rio’s boobs- sue her. Every time she looked at them she lost the ability to form a coherent sentence. But that wasn’t the point.

 

The point was the sound. It was a terrible thing to be addicted to. She buried herself in it like she could siphon it all for herself, greedy for every beat. She didn’t even know she’d been chasing it until she found it here, under her ear, like the finish line to a race she hadn’t realized she’d been running her whole life.

 

Rio shifted a little, maybe impatient with Agatha’s silence. “Feels like you’re trying to crawl inside me.”

 

Agatha rubbed her cheek deeper against her chest. “Maybe I am,” she murmured.

 

Rio huffed a laugh. “You’d hate it in there.”

 

“No,” Agatha nearly whined, horrified that Rio could say something like that with her heart right there. She turned her head, pressed her lips to Rio’s chest. “I wouldn’t,” she whispered, needing to correct Rio’s words- like Rio’s heart might believe them if she didn’t.

 

And Agatha went rigid, mortified by how pathetic she must seem. It sent heat racing up her chest to her throat and ears. She turned her head again, pressing her ear back to Rio’s chest- where she immediately clocked the slight uptick in its pace.

 

She nearly scoffed. Figures- Rio’s heart would take pleasure in Agatha humiliating herself. 

 

Rio inhaled unsteadily, exhaled just as shaky, and Agatha’s head moved with the rise and fall of her chest. “Agatha,” Rio said, and Agatha was grateful for the pause between words- grateful she could catch the stutter in that heartbeat again when Rio spoke her name. “You have no idea what you’re doing to me.”

 

If it was anything like what Rio did to her, Agatha thought she should apologize- because what heavier, sweeter burden could there be than wanting someone so completely that your heart refused to rest unless it beat against theirs?

 

In hindsight, that sounds dramatic. Agatha knew that. But when it came to Rio, everything always felt bigger than it should’ve. Too much. Too dramatic. Always more than Agatha knew what to do with.

 

“Sorry,” Agatha mumbled.

 

Rio’s hand pressed firmer against that back of her head. “Don’t be. I like it. I like you like this.”

 

Agatha finally lifted her head, pulling herself out from the warmth of Rio’s shirt. Her hair was a mess across her face, but Rio’s fingers were already there, pushing it back with infuriating gentleness, like she couldn’t help herself.

 

With her hair out of her face, Agatha leaned in, pressing a quick kiss to Rio’s mouth just because she felt like it. It still messed with Agatha’s head sometimes- that she could just do that now, when there’d been a time it wasn’t nearly that simple. She pulled Rio closer, chin resting on her shoulder while her legs swung lightly as she stared out at Westview.

 

“Crazy, huh?” Agatha said, offhand. “Last time we were up here, we were too chickenshit to even hold hands.”

 

Rio pulled back just enough to kiss her cheek, then let the side of her head rest against Agatha’s. “That’s not entirely true. Sometimes you let me hang on to your pinky.”

 

Agatha smiled, rolled her eyes. “Woah. Be still, my heart.” Pressing her mouth into Rio’s shoulder. 

 

She said it like a joke, knowing damn well every time Rio’s pinky reached for hers it felt like her heart was halfway up her throat.

 

Rio leaned back just far enough to catch her face, a smile on her mouth. “I happen to think it was romantic.”

 

“We were pussies,” Agatha shot back, no venom in it. She only wanted to hear how Rio would counter her.

 

“Maybe,” Rio said, licking her lips- something Agatha clocked instantly, because why wouldn’t she? “I get it, at the end of the day we dropped the ball- spectacularly. But even then, I think we were doing our best to be careful with each other. Even when we got it wrong, the effort was there. That’s important.”

 

Agatha could probably rattle off a thousand examples of how they’d managed the exact opposite. But she didn’t. The fact Rio could look at all that shit, and still see two people trying to take care of each other… that alone burned warm in her chest.

 

“I’m glad we figured it out,” Agatha said, though she felt the wind knocked out of her a bit. She leaned in, letting her forehead rest against Rio’s.

 

Rio’s smile widened, her forehead pressing firmer against Agatha’s. “Me too. Took us long enough.”

 

“Yeah,” was all Agatha could manage. Rio’s hand found her cheek, easing her back from where their foreheads touched. Agatha knew it wasn’t about moving her- it was about seeing her. And she didn’t mind. She wanted to look at Rio too. Wanted to memorize the way her face went soft, the way she looked like she was seconds away from letting herself drown.

 

“Agatha,” Rio murmured, her thumb stroking slowly across her cheek.

 

Agatha loved it when Rio said her name. Ironic, considering she’d spent her whole life despising it. But Rio had ruined that for her too- always saying it just to say it, like the sound of her name alone was worth loving.

 

She opened her mouth to tell Rio to say her name again.

 

“I love you,” came out instead.

 

...Well. About nearly two decades late, but better than never, Agatha supposed.

 

She wouldn’t take it back- not even with Rio staring at her now, frozen, like she couldn’t have possibly heard Agatha right.

 

Because she still meant it. She’d meant it for years. Every day she carried it, and every day she kept it to herself was a mistake. She should’ve said it the first time she felt it- back when Rio caught her staring and asked what was wrong with her face. She should’ve said it then, and every day after. She should’ve never let Rio spend a single moment not knowing.

 

“I’ve- uh,” Agatha started, breathless. She tried again. “I’ve swallowed that sentence more times than I can count.”

 

Rio’s hand was suddenly at her mouth, trembling fingers brushing against Agatha’s lips as if the touch could prove she hadn’t imagined what she’d just heard.

 

“Say it again,” Rio whispered, the word breaking like a plea, her gaze locked on Agatha’s lips.

 

“I love you… so much, Rio,” Agatha said. Her voice shook, because she needed Rio to believe her. She needed her to hear it the way she meant it.

 

“You do?” Rio asked, so soft it almost disappeared.

 

“I do,” Agatha said, nodding quickly. “I always have.” 

 

And then Rio was kissing her, and Agatha could taste it everywhere- on Rio’s lips, on her tongue, in her breath, in the way every pause between kisses carried the same desperate confession. Each break was another insistence, another vow, love pressed into Agatha’s mouth over and over: I love you, I love you, I’ve only ever loved you. 

 

And in her chest, Agatha felt the garden she’d tried so long to ignore- sprawling, insistent, every root reaching for Rio. All of it planted by her, tended by her, grown wild under her green thumb. Under all of that, Agatha was grateful. Grateful she would never again have to wonder, never again have to dream about what Rio’s voice might sound like saying those words. She had them now, real and alive, blooming from her skin.

 

“I love you,” Rio told her again, like she finally understood she could spend a lifetime saying it.

 

Agatha could live a lifetime on nothing else.

 

 

 

Chapter End Notes

if you don't remember Agatha thinking about Rio asking what was wrong with her face- it's in the last chapter if you need a recap.

i'm thinking probably two chapters left *very sad*... i thought that i might write a dedicated flashback chapter, but i don't know if i will. for multiple reasons, the main two being : 1. i don't think that i could stomach it- it would be too painful. 2. i have no impulse control and would inevitably make them dry hump even though, per this entire fic, they didn’t do shit back then.

fun fact any tv show/movie i mention in this- it's what i have on as background noise while i write. and i will say this with my entire chest- julia louis-dreyfus deserved every single one of those six consecutive emmy wins for veep.

lastly, thank you for the music <3

Chapter 17: part one: i'm putting all my bets on you

Chapter Notes

Howdy, partners. It’s been a minute.

The last two+ months have been busy as fuck, but since my last update I’ve spent more time writing than not. So fear not- this fic always was, and still is, taking up entirely too much space in my head. And after being away for so long, this is the chapter I’m giving you. Fair warning: it’s an extremely long one. Take your time with it. I certainly did.

More good news, maybe- I didn’t want to post this chapter without the next one being mostly finished, so that one should be up in a few days… hopefully. For better or worse, it carries on in much the same vein.

You’ll also notice the chapter count still isn’t updated. There are chapters left. How many? Still unclear. Maybe three? I’m known to lie about these things. I don't know.

Lastly, for anyone (if any of you) who saw Let’s Love! on Nov. 4th- surprise? You were in the same room as Aubrey Plaza and the night shift author. Happy reading!

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Reasonable.

 

Defined as, according to the internet, as much as is appropriate or fair; moderate.

 

Agatha understood the concept. Her execution, however, was a bit questionable. 

 

Reasonable people followed events in the correct order. They let things settle. They exercised patience.They did not rearrange their lives around another human being simply because that human laughed a certain way, or had an infuriatingly specific gap between her teeth, or looked at them like they were already home.

 

Agatha had spent a significant portion of her life learning how to look like one of them. Reasonable, she’d discovered, was less a feeling and more a presentation.You paused before responding.You didn’t say the first thing that came to mind.You waited an acceptable amount of time before wanting something too much.

 

Rio Vidal was Agatha’s girlfriend now. That part mattered.Enough that Agatha had decided -very firmly, very maturely- that she would behave accordingly, reasonably. She would apply logic. She would pace herself. She would treat this like something that required care rather than speed. 

 

Agatha would believe, with every fiber of her being, that all of this was manageable. Moderation, Agatha decided, would now be her way of life.

 

It was an attractive theory. Entirely incompatible with Agatha’s reality.

 

Because reason, in Agatha’s experience, had always been a flexible concept. One that bent under pressure and collapsed entirely when confronted with feeling. She could be reasonable in emergencies. She could be reasonable when lives were on the line. She could be reasonable when exhaustion hollowed her out and left her running on instinct alone.

 

Love, unfortunately, had never responded well to Agatha’s reason.

 

And the more Agatha tried to convince herself that she could do this correctly -slowly, in the proper sequence- the more obvious it became that she was already rearranging herself around Rio in ways she pretended not to notice. Thinking in advance. Adjusting without being asked. Accounting for another person in every decision that used to belong solely to her.

 

This, Agatha suspected, was the part where reasonable people would have paused.

 

Agatha did not pause.

 

Agatha told herself a lot of things.

 

She told herself she was fine.That this was normal.That wanting someone this much did not automatically mean she would ruin it. That intensity was not the same thing as recklessness.That she could love deeply without consuming the object of her affection whole.

 

Agatha told herself a lot of things.

 

And she told them convincingly enough that, for a while, they almost sounded true.

 

-

 

Agatha was currently at work, assigned to one micro-preemie- a 1:1 ratio that every nurse in a hospital setting knew was code for this kid is in deep shit. 

 

A twenty-three-week micro-preemie, furious at being forced into the world before his body was even close to ready. His skin was translucent, his organs were still undecided on whether they wanted to participate at all, and every breath taken was absolutely a threat. He was tiny, pissed off, and completely unwilling to tolerate any of it.

 

And honestly, Agatha respected the hell out of that. She’d been born pissed off too, and thirty-eight years later, her mood hadn’t improved much.

 

What absolutely made things worse was the pharmacist on the phone, who appeared determined to make life harder for Agatha and the fetus she was, at this very moment, trying to keep alive.

 

Every time he muttered, “I don’t know what you want me to do about it,” Agatha felt her own fucking blood pressure spike. And she was one more useless non-answer away from dropping the whole act of being reasonable and reminding everyone within earshot that reasonable was a department she’d never once staffed.

 

Agatha inhaled one long, pointedly inconvenienced breath through her nose, angled directly into the phone, making sure the pharmacist heard every single second of her irritation before she spoke.

 

“I’m going to tell you one more time,” Agatha warned. “And I’m going to speak very slowly so you understand. Verify the surfactant order so I can pull it from the Pyxis. It isn’t complicated.”

 

“I already told you. The patient’s weight has to be entered in the chart before I can do that.”

 

Agatha yanked the hospital-issued smartphone from her ear, gripping it with both hands. She closed her eyes, silently mouthing oh my fucking god while resisting the urge to bash herself in the head with it just to see if she could knock her own IQ down to match this pharmacist’s.

 

After another slow, murderous inhale, she pressed it back to her ear.

 

“I’m literally staring at the chart,” Agatha said, her laugh cracking close to manic. “The weight is in there. Five hundred sixty-two grams. Entered. Documented. Done. What exactly is your PhD for if you can’t manage to read what’s on a fucking screen?”

 

“Excuse me?” the pharmacist said, scandalized.

 

“Look, buddy,” Agatha snapped, “I’d love nothing more than to come down there and personally point out this kid’s weight until it’s fully burned into your retinas. But as it stands, he’s busy trying to die, and my hands are full.So tell me what I can possibly do to make this easier for you.”

 

“I need you to enter the patient’s weight into the chart,” the pharmacist repeated  for what felt like the hundredth fucking time.

 

“It’s in the chart!” Agatha roared. “Five hundred and sixty two grams! Right here, in front of me! Stop telling me it isn’t there!”

 

Agatha’s chest heaved, her eyes burning holes through the computer monitor as she stared at the patient’s weight, glowing in the chart exactly where it had been the entire fucking time.

 

Silence stretched on the other end of the phone in the wake of her shouting, broken only by a single cleared throat.

 

“Okay. There it is. Must’ve been a delay. I’ll verify it now.”

 

A delay. 

 

The baby had been born before shift change. There was no delay. The man -like every other useless man who thought the burden of his incompetence should be hers- was just a miserable, fucking dumbass.

 

“Thank you!” Agatha barked into the phone.

 

“Can I get your name? You’ve been entirely disrespect-”

 

She hung up before he could finish, and slammed the phone down on the desk.

 

For the first time since Agatha had made that stupid call, she let herself look away from the monitor. A few nurses, a couple of RTs- every one of them was staring at her. 

 

“Pharmacy,” Agatha said flatly.

 

The room broke into groans of recognition, a chorus of “ohhhhs.” Someone actually muttered, “That makes sense.” Another shook their head and apologized on behalf of the poor bastard who had been on the other end.

 

Everyone did it eventually. Nurses screamed at doctors, doctors screamed at nurses. Agatha wasn’t the first to lose her shit, and she as fuck wouldn’t be the last. The difference was, she didn’t care. There was no shame burning in her cheeks, no worry about who had heard. Just the raw, bitter satisfaction of knowing she’d been right.

 

If the Pyxis gave her even a hint of trouble tonight, she was ready to put her head through the damn thing and rip the surfactant out herself. Thankfully, for everyone involved, it didn’t. The drawers slid open without protest, and she moved on, her blood pressure still through the fucking roof, and the preemie still wanting to play patty cake with the Woman Upstairs.

 

Agatha had both arms in the isolette with Sherry, the RT, helping draw up a blood gas when the familiar rumble of x-ray wheels cut into the pod, and without meaning to- Agatha looked up.

 

Rio. 

 

Her girlfriend of exactly one day- well… one day officially acknowledged out loud for the first time instead of implied. She was steering that big, clunky portable x-ray machine.

 

Agatha snapped her focus back to the baby, because the last thing she needed was to look like an idiot caught drooling. She listened like a hawk while Rio parked the portable in the neighboring bedspace next to hers. God forbid she have to murder one of her own coworkers for thinking it was acceptable to so much as look at Rio the wrong way.

 

Not that Agatha had screamed it through the hospital intercom or anything- but it should be understood. Branded into everyone’s skulls. The infamous “bad boy of x-ray” -a stupid fucking nickname, if Agatha had anything to say about it- was officially off the market… Permanently. 



“Well, if it isn’t my favorite x-ray tech,” Sheryl screeched, her voice far too high pitched for how close she was standing. She was directly across from Agatha, both of them with their arms in the isolette, the preemie between them.

 

Agatha bit down on the inside of her lip and focused on her own patient. She steadied the baby’s heel between her fingers, quick with the lancet, then guided the drop of blood into a capillary tube. She handed it off to Yelena- also an RT lingering at her bedspace, probably under the pretense of supervising but more likely making sure Agatha didn’t blow up at Sheryl. Which, to be fair, Agatha appreciated.

 

“You know,” Shirley said, voice still fucking piercing even at a whisper. Agatha flicked her eyes up briefly to show she was listening while she blotted the baby’s heel with gauze. “When you first started working here, Rio told me she had a crush on you.”

 

“Oh?” It came out strangled, and Agatha cleared her throat, eyes cutting right back to the baby. 

 

Yelena laughed -too entertained for Agatha’s liking- and earned herself a glare.

 

“Isn’t that sweet?” Sharlene added cheerfully, fucking beaming.

 

Agatha forced a shrug, the best she could manage with both arms buried in the portholes of an isolette. “Yeah,” she muttered, clearing her throat again. “Sure. Cool.”

 

“Did you know?”

 

“Did I know what?” Agatha asked flatly, eyes fixed on the baby, not on Sharon.

 

“That Rio has a crush on you?”

 

It was too easy- the opening, the stupidity of the question.

 

Agatha muttered, “Judging by the noises she was making this morning when my tongue was halfway to her cervix, I had my suspicions.”

 

Silence followed.

 

Yelena cut through it with a loud, unapologetic laugh. Agatha smirked, eyes flicking up to Shelly, whose face had gone pale white, her horror written plainly across it.

 

“Agatha…” Sheila swallowed hard, voice shaky. “Is there something clinically wrong with your head, dear?”

 

Agatha’s smile tightened. “Oh… So much.”

 

She heard the clunk of the portable’s tube head closing, followed by the janky rumble of its wheels turning in their direction. Agatha realized -annoyingly late- that she had started holding her breath. She forced herself to exhale and keep her eyes on the baby.

 

“Yelena,” came Rio’s voice as she parked the portable at Agatha’s bedspace.

 

From across the isolette, Sherry’s grating whisper, “You being nervous around her is very endearing, dear.”

 

Agatha glared, daring Sheryl to keep talking.

 

“How are you?” Rio asked Yelena, oblivious- or maybe pretending to be.

 

“Annoyed,” Yelena replied, her accent flattening the word.

 

“I’m sorry?” Rio’s laugh followed, soft and genuine, and Agatha could see the exact face she was making without looking- the faint crease between her brows, the small smile tugging at her mouth, the flash of that damn gap between her teeth.

 

“Tell your sister she’s the reason,” Yelena said.

 

“Nothing would make me happier,” Rio shot back.

 

Agatha rolled her eyes. They did this every time Sage’s name came up, and Agatha knew it was a bunch of bullshit. Both of them adored Sage, even if they pretended otherwise. Yelena went soft the second she was mentioned, and Rio always played along like she didn’t sound proud every time she said her sister’s name.

 

“Hey,” Rio said, suddenly right beside Agatha.

 

“Shit-” Agatha startled, jerking slightly before snapping her eyes toward Rio.

 

Rio’s smile was easy, teasing. She held up the small plate, ready to slide it into the isolette’s tray. “You ready?”

 

“Yeah,” Agatha said, too dumb. Her mouth had gone dry, and her words weren’t exactly cooperating, which was inconvenient considering the literal infant in front of her.

 

Rio nodded toward the tray, and it took Agatha a second to realize she hadn’t moved, her arms still inside the isolette portholes, blocking the slot.

 

“Oh.” Agatha exhaled a quiet laugh, stepping back. “Right. Sorry.”

 

Her ears were on fucking fire.

 

“You’re good,” Rio said, still smiling- soft and unfairly kind.

 

Agatha wanted to reach out and cover that smile with her hand, like maybe that would muffle the I love you sitting on her own tongue, insistent and stupidly new despite already being said. Instead, forced her eyes away, and caught Shannon staring. 

 

The woman looked seconds from passing out, hand to her chest like she was watching a goddamn proposal instead of the baby currently plotting to extubate himself.

 

Agatha mouthed a clear don’t, then lifted a gloved hand and dragged it slowly across her throat for emphasis. Sherri only laughed, waving Agatha off. “Oh, don’t be ridiculous.”

 

Rio’s head turned toward Agatha, brows raised in question.

 

Agatha only shrugged, expression flat. “She’s got dementia.”

 

“That right?” Rio said, and Agatha sure as fuck didn’t miss the way brown eyes flicked down to her mouth before she turned back to the portable. She lifted a lead apron from the cart, gave it a shake, and held it out in front of Agatha. Without thinking, Agatha stepped forward, sliding her arms through the loops while Rio moved the heavy fabric over her shoulders.

 

“Gotta protect those loins, you know?” Rio said under her breath, the smile in her voice impossible to miss.

 

Agatha didn’t answer. She couldn’t. Her throat had gone tight, and she could feel the heat crawling up her neck, spreading fast.

 

Rio turned to Sheryl, offering her the second apron. 

 

Sharlene declined in that overly polite tone she used when she wanted to sound gracious, and for reasons Agatha didn’t care to think about, it made her want to bite the woman’s head off. 

 

Probably because Agatha still remembered that very first night Rio had shown up in this NICU and Sherry had gone on a fucking tangent about the importance of radiation safety. The hypocrisy was fucking blinding.

 

Agatha forced the thought away and refocused on the baby, steadying her hands as she and Sheryl positioned his tiny body for the image. Rio and Yelena fell into easy conversation as they worked. The exposure was made; the image was done. And Rio was gone.

 

The whole interaction had felt like it lasted forever and ended all in the same breath. She and Shandra adjusted the baby’s position, waited for him to settle, and by the time the monitors finally evened out, Agatha had almost convinced herself she was fine- until she turned back to her workstation.

 

A single pink flower sat on her keyboard. No stem. Just the bloom.

 

Agatha stared at it, a stupid lump forming in her throat, and she wondered how she’d ever gone so long without this- without her. Because now, even the idea of a life without Rio felt inconceivable.

 

She slid the flower behind the computer monitor where it would be safe until she could tuck it away properly, and pulled her phone from her pocket. An unread text waited, sent a few minutes earlier.

 

Rio: i love you

 

Jesus Christ, could they not go five fucking minutes without being sappy lesbians? Agatha huffed, thumbs already moving. 

 

I love you too. 

 

Safe to say Agatha’s 4 a.m. lunch break was spent with her tongue down Rio’s throat at their usual smoking spot.

 

-

 

“Thanks for coming with me tonight,” Rio said, reaching for Agatha’s hand as they crossed the parking lot.

 

“You should feel honored. This is a big deal for me, you know. Goes against my core values.” Agatha said, tangling their fingers together.

 

Rio glanced over, smiling. “Because of the names?”

 

Agatha stopped walking, dragging Rio to a halt. “Do you realize,” she began, “this town has two rec centers? Two, Rio.” Agatha paused for effect. “Both proudly bearing names so offensively fucking bland that I can only assume a roomful of men were involved.” She then stared at the sign on the building, appalled.

 

Westview Recreation Center.

 

Or that was the intent, once. Now the white neon letters flickered, a few letters completely burnt out. 

 

Agatha lifted a hand toward the flickering sign. “Wetview Recratio enter,” she read, then tilted her head. “Where hope goes to die.”

 

Across town sat its equally uninspired counterpart, Westview Community Center- identical brick, identical fucking mediocrity.

 

So on the drive over, Agatha had done what any reasonable woman would do when confronted with incompetence… She looked up who was in charge of Westview’s Department of Parks and Recreation.

 

The search led her to a woman named Leslie Knope, and Agatha immediately began drafting a strongly worded email about the town’s chronic lack of creativity in naming public buildings and how the matter needed to be corrected… immediately.

 

She made a mental note to take a picture of the sign later and attach it to the email for emphasis.

 

And Agatha couldn’t exactly explain why she’d worked herself up over something as trivial as the names of two buildings- only that it begged the question of why she’d been at this shithole in the first place.

 

The answer, of course, was her girlfriend. 

 

Rio Vidal. 

 

The only person on earth who could convince Agatha to spend a Wednesday night in a gym that smelled like sweat and despair.

 

Rio, as it turned out, played on a recreational basketball team that started up every fall. She had, apparently, been doing this for years. The details were unimportant. What mattered -at least what Agatha could bring to herself to care about- was that tonight was the team’s first practice of the semester…  Or maybe the quarter. Agatha didn’t fucking know, and she had no interest in finding out.

 

What Agatha did know, with unsettling clarity, was that Rio had asked if she wanted to come along, and Agatha had said yes with absolutely no follow up questions. Which was genuinely concerning but unfortunately, not the point.

 

The point was that Rio playing basketball gave Agatha a socially acceptable reason to yell at strangers. That it also involved Rio in a uniform was just… one of the more aggressively difficult facts to ignore.

 

Short gym shorts that left nothing to the imagination. A bright red jersey with Pistol Shrimps stamped across the chest in bold, white lettering. A black sports bra visible beneath it, knee high socks, white sneakers, her hair pulled into a messy bun that looked like it was seconds from falling out, with a gym bag slung over her shoulder.

 

And Agatha -despite her many, many strengths- was powerless against this level of visual attack.

 

Before they’d even left Rio’s apartment, Agatha had insisted -no, demanded- that Rio stand still long enough for her to take photos. “For humiliation purposes,” she’d claimed, though her attempt at indifference was betrayed by the way her smile kept threatening to show itself. 

 

Agatha took far too many pictures, all while trying not to look directly at Rio’s legs or the way that stupid jersey hung off her shoulders, because if Agatha did, she might accidentally reveal that the real humiliation wasn’t Rio’s at all- it was hers.

 

“You realize most people don’t care about that kind of stuff, right?” Rio’s voice pulled Agatha out of her thoughts.

 

“What?” Agatha blinked, finally tearing her eyes from the blinding white neon letters in front of her. “Sorry, I think I disassociated somewhere between looking at this place and losing my will to live.”

 

Rio laughed, and Agatha smiled, because she never could seem to help it when Rio did. She liked being close enough to hear it- liked knowing she’d done something, however small, that made the world sound like that laugh for a moment.

 

“I suppose that’s valid,” Rio said, turning her head to take in the full atrocity before them.

 

And truthfully, besides the sign, it wasn’t even that bad. The building was aggressively mediocre at best, absolutely. But Agatha knew she was overreacting. The problem, she knew, wasn’t the brick or the lighting. 

 

She’d been restless for days, unable to sit still in her own skin, working herself into frenzies over nothing. For no reason in particular, she told herself. Definitely not because she was now officially dating Rio Vidal, which was, objectively speaking, the most disorienting joy she’d ever experienced.

 

Agatha loved Rio, was stupidly, irrevocably in love with her, and there wasn’t a force in the world -or any of its minor bureaucratic failures- that could convince her she wasn’t meant to spend the rest of her life with this woman. But still, sometimes loving Rio seemed to flip some manic switch inside herself, like her heart didn’t quite know how to handle getting what it wanted.

 

That’s what Agatha told herself, anyway. 

 

“You don’t have to come to this stuff if you don’t want to, you know. I don’t want you to feel obligated,” Rio said after a moment, squeezing her hand gently.

 

Agatha stared at her, a bit insulted. 

 

Obligation, Agatha thought. 

 

As if Agatha had ever thought of Rio as an obligation. If anything, Rio should’ve known by now that Agatha would endure much worse than a night trapped in a stinky rec center if meant being near Rio at all. 

 

Seventeen years of loving Rio in every iteration -friend, stranger, friend again, almost, finally- should’ve made it obvious there wasn’t much Agatha wouldn’t do just for proximity- but Agatha, as always, digressed.

 

“And let you parade around unsupervised in that?” Agatha asked, gesturing at Rio’s uniform. It was the least nauseatingly romantic response she could manage. “Fuck no.”

 

Rio only smiled- gap toothed and annoyingly charming, which was frankly offensive given the circumstances. Then she shook her head, cheeks pink even in the dim parking lot light, and Agatha felt a sudden rush of affection crash through her chest.

 

She tugged at Rio’s hand with a little more force than necessary -she couldn’t wait another second- and when Rio stumbled into her space, looking pleased and unsuspecting, Agatha kissed her.

 

It was soft. Unbearably soft, considering the velocity of Agatha’s feelings behind it. Her hand came up to Rio’s face automatically, as if her palm knew better than the rest of her how to cradle something precious. And for a moment, Rio didn’t move.

 

Agatha could feel it -Rio’s surprise- could feel it in the way her eyelashes brushed against her own, the way her mouth stayed still under Agatha’s like she was holding very, very still inside the center of a daydream.

 

And then, waking into it, Rio kissed her back.

 

Just the smallest pressure, the smallest exhale against Agatha’s mouth, the gentle weight of a hand curling around the back of Agatha’s neck, a thumb brushing along the hinge of her jaw.

 

Agatha pulled away first, enough to catch her breath, her forehead resting against Rio’s. She stayed there for a moment before leaning back in, pressing another soft kiss to Rio’s mouth.

 

“You think I need supervision, huh?” Rio said, voice teasing in a way that didn’t match the shapes of hearts currently bulging out of her eyeballs at all. She slid her arms around Agatha’s waist, pulling her in until their bodies met.

 

Agatha hummed as she went. She wrapped her arms around Rio’s shoulders, her nose brushing against Rio’s cheek. “No,” she said. “I just needed an excuse to stare.”

 

Rio huffed a laugh and leaned back slightly, her smile so sweet Agatha felt it in her teeth. “I love you,” Rio said quietly.

 

There they were again- the words Agatha had heard a hundred times in the short time they’d been saying them, and she still wasn’t remotely close to being desensitized to it. 

 

Every time Rio said them, something in Agatha’s chest went bright, and all she could think about was getting Rio to say them again- once, twice, forever. 

 

“I love you,” Agatha said, because she did- helplessly endless.

 

Rio kissed her once more, smiling against her mouth. “We should go in,” she murmured. “I’m gonna be late.” She pressed another kiss to the corner of Agatha’s lips.

 

Agatha grumbled, but she didn’t resist when Rio’s fingers found hers. She let herself be tugged toward the rec center, pretending it wasn’t exactly where she wanted to go. 

 

Inside, the rec center was bigger than Agatha had expected. The smell hit her before anything else, heavy with chlorine instead of the sweat she’d braced for. Long hallways stretched out in every direction, signs pointing toward Gyms A through D, racquetball courts, and something optimistically labeled Wellness Studio.

 

Agatha was willing to bet that it was a front for a pyramid scheme, judging by the eight hundred bottles of pressed juice lined up behind the glass window.

 

Rio’s hand stayed in hers as they walked past the racquetball courts- players inside lunging at the walls with a level of enthusiasm Agatha could only describe as deeply concerning.

 

Agatha caught the shift in Rio’s shoulders, the way her steps picked up pace. She glanced to look at Agatha, teeth bared in a grin that was all nerves and excitement, eyebrows lifting like she could barely contain herself.

 

The doors to Gym C were propped open, and the smell hit her immediately- sweat, wood polish, the tang of metal from the bleachers. Agatha grimaced, pressing her fingers to the bridge of her nose. 

 

“It’s like Eau de Adolescent Boy in here,” Agatha muttered.

 

Rio laughed under her breath and nodded toward the bleachers lining the far wall, where a few people had already gathered. “See you when it’s over,” she said, giving Agatha’s hand one last squeeze before letting go.

 

Agatha hummed in acknowledgment and scanned the stands, spotting Jen almost immediately, waving Agatha over. With a resigned sigh, she made her way across the court.

 

She climbed the bleachers to where Jen was sitting and dropped down beside her with another sigh. “Jennifer.”

 

Jen elbowed her lightly, a grin tugging at her mouth. “Sooo,” she sing songed, “how are you and your girlfriend?”

 

She had filled Jen in on everything at work a few days ago. Gave her shit for keeping Rio from moving to Chicago, called her a meddling pain in the ass, and Jen, naturally, wore it like a badge of honor. Said it all worked out, didn’t it? 

 

And it had. Agatha hated admitting it but thanked her anyway- for knowing her better than she knew herself most days. She’d even let Jen pull her into a hug she absolutely did not start. Jen had squeezed her back, and whispered, I’m glad y’all figured it out. You deserve to be happy. 

 

Agatha had rolled her eyes then too, her only reliable defense against sentiment. Still, the words had stuck with her, echoing in the places she didn’t usually like to visit for too long. 

 

Now, sitting beside Jen, watching Rio across the court, she felt that same ridiculous warmth climb up her throat again, and promptly shoved it down before it could get too comfortable. 

 

Sappiness was overrated anyway, and Rio looked unfairly fucking hot in red.

 

“Still dating her. Still haven’t murdered her. Progress.”

 

The word dating made Agatha’s eye twitch a little. Felt too small for what they’d gotten themselves into.

 

Jen scoffed. “Oh, come on. Don’t act like you haven’t been waiting seventeen years for this.”

 

Agatha gave her a sideways glance. “Don’t make it sound so pathetic.”

 

“It is pathetic,” Jen stated as a matter of fact. “But also romantic.” A pause. “You know, if you ignore the part where you married another woman and fled the state for a decade.”

 

Agatha whipped her head toward her best friend. “Thank you very much for the reminder, Jennifer. But I’d argue that only makes it more romantic.” She didn’t give Jen time to gloat. “How long do these things last?” she asked, watching as Sage and Yelena stepped through the gym doors- Sage veering toward the team clustered at the far end of the bleachers, Yelena heading their way.

 

“Usually about an hour,” Jen said.

 

“An hour? Jen, that’s sixty minutes of marinating in this smell. Seriously, the fumes are literally touching my brain.”

 

“That actually makes a lot of sense,” Jen muttered, eyeing Agatha a little weirdly. “Also, practice doesn’t start for another thirty minutes, so... good luck surviving it.”

 

“Thirty minutes?” she repeated, staring at Jen.  

 

Rio’s words from the parking lot replayed in Agatha’s head- we’re going to be late. Thirty minutes wasn’t fucking late. Thirty minutes only counted as late if you were Rio Vidal. Agatha knew that. Had always known that. 

 

And if Agatha had bothered to use her fucking brain and connect even the most obvious dots, she would’ve realized they had a full half hour to spare.More than enough time to suggest a quickie in the car- an offer Rio had never once managed to refuse Agatha.

 

Agatha exhaled through her nose. “I’m going to kill her.”

 

Yelena made her way up the bleachers. “Good evening, ladies,” she said, settling onto the row above them. 

 

Jen looked up and smiled. Agatha grunted, still nursing the irritation of a missed opportunity.

 

“Agatha, it’s good to see you here,” Yelena said, resting both hands on Agatha’s shoulders. “Welcome to WAGs.” The blonde gave her shoulders a quick, enthusiastic shake, both in greeting and silently apologizing for what Agatha was about to endure.

 

Agatha twisted to look at Yelena. “WAGs?”

 

“Wives and girlfriends of professional athletes,” Jen explained.

 

Agatha snarled. The acronym alone was enough to make her want to set something on fire, though she decided not to unpack why it got under her skin as much as it did. Her eyes drifted across the gym, landing on John Walker who worked in the ED at St. Rita’s, ambling over with a grinning baby perched on his hip while his wife, Olivia, headed for the players.

 

“That doesn’t even make sense,” Agatha muttered. “There are men here.”

 

“Hey, Walker!” Yelena called across the gym. “Would you consider yourself a WAG?”

 

John didn’t even pretend to think about it. The baby on his hip was shrieking with laughter, tiny fists in his shirt, and Agatha caught sight of Rio crossing the court toward them, hands already reaching out.

 

“I don’t give a shit what I am,” John said, handing his baby off to Rio.

 

“You know, it’s always refreshing to see you, John. You’ve got this rare, natural talent for sucking the life out of any space you enter. It’s honestly impressive,” Yelena said, smiling sweetly at him.

 

The baby let out a delighted squeal as Rio took him, small hands immediately grabbing at her jersey. 

 

“See?” Yelena said, pointing triumphantly toward the baby. “Even your son agrees with me.”

 

John gave her the finger without missing a beat and turned back to Rio. He dropped the diaper bag and sat down on the first row of bleachers. Rio laughed at something he said, adjusting the baby easily against her hip as she sat down next to him.

 

From where Agatha sat, she could only see her side profile, and the baby staring up at her like he’d been waiting his whole short life to find her face.

 

“I think I’m gonna be sick,” Agatha whispered, staring in horror. 

 

“What?” Jen asked.

 

Agatha didn’t answer. For the second time in her life, she was fairly certain something hormonal was happening to her. It felt biological in the very worst way- like her own anatomy had turned against her, whispering that. That’s what you want. Which was absurd. Agatha was a grown woman with a fully functioning prefrontal cortex; she didn’t fall apart over maternal displays and Rio’s naked biceps. 

 

Rio must’ve been doing something dumb with her face- judging by how hard the baby was laughing. He had both fists clutching her jersey, leaning back far enough to build suspense before crashing forward into her chest and tucking his head there like he meant to hug her. Then he pulled back, checking for her reaction, clearly pleased with himself, and did it again.

 

Then Rio laughed, one hand coming up to cradle the back of his head as she said something to John. The baby pulled away just to check her face again- pure joy, waiting for more.

 

“She can’t keep getting away with this,” Agatha whispered, unable to tear her gaze away from her girlfriend holding a baby. 

 

“Are you good?” Jen asked, loud enough to yank her back to earth.

 

“No, Jennifer,” Agatha said in a harsh whisper. “Someone needs to get that thing away from her before I do something incredibly humiliating and irreversible.”

 

“Are you talking about the baby?” Jen asked carefully, which was a mistake because careful meant concerned, and concerned meant Agatha might actually have to explain herself. Jen’s eyes flicked toward Rio- still holding the baby. 

 

“Yes,” Agatha bit out. “Get it away from her.”

 

“Why are you calling him it?”

 

“Get him away from her. Does that help?”

 

Yelena leaned forward. “Agatha,” she began, “are you feeling… how do you say this- womb ache?” 

 

Agatha froze.Her head turned slowly, mechanically, until her gaze met Yelena’s. “I don’t know what you’re talking about,” she said slowly, every syllable wrapped in the effort of not committing homicide.

 

Yelena’s eyes widened. “Yes,” she said, nodding as though she’d solved an equation. “This is what that seems to be.”

 

She watched Yelena stand, brushing invisible dust from her jeans before making her way down the bleachers with the self importance of someone who’d just declared herself part of the solution. 

 

“Hello, little baby! I would like to hold you now,” Yelena announced.

 

Rio passed the baby over easily, still talking to John.

 

Agatha felt her lungs expand. Air. Actual oxygen. 

 

It lasted about two seconds before she turned to find Jen watching her- elbows on her knees, lips pressed together, like she was sitting on top of a small volcano made entirely of commentary.

 

Agatha lifted her brows- a warning. “I would appreciate it if we didn’t turn this into a whole thing.”

 

Jen lifted her hands, a picture of innocence, though the effort it took not to laugh was written all over her face. “No clue what you’re talking about.”

 

“Good,” Agatha said, because that was the sort of thing a composed adult said when her girlfriend was sitting at the bottom of the bleachers actively conspiring against her sanity. 

 

Rio had stopped pretending to listen to John and Yelena entirely, turned halfway in her seat, tongue in her cheek, watching Agatha like she already knew exactly what was happening in her head.

 

It was the look she always got followed by Rio saying something outrageous- typically like “you want me to put a baby in you so bad,” delivered with the confidence of someone who’d never once considered the emotional consequences of her own mouth.

 

Agatha narrowed her eyes and mouthed, Don’t. 

 

Rio only smiled wider, clasped her hands like she was praying, closed her eyes, and- shaking her hands with desperation, mouthed, “Please, let me put a baby in you.”

 

Agatha was already ripping off her shoe, fully prepared to it hurl at Rio’s face, when a whistled blared, signaling the start of practice, saving them both from public spectacle and probable assault charges.

 

She sank back onto the bleachers, exhaled slowly, and told herself she was fine. 

 

Totally, completely fine.

 

-

 

Today, Agatha was irritable, and not in any fun, productive way. Nothing had technically gone wrong; if anything, the morning had started exceptionally well. She’d woken to the feeling of Rio’s mouth at her neck, soft and lazy, followed by the progression of kissing, touching, humping, and inevitably, sex.

 

Morning sex had, somewhat against Agatha’s better judgment, become her favorite kind of sex with Rio. The irony wasn’t lost on her. When she and Rio had first started sleeping together -months and months and what felt like several lifetimes ago- the whole concept had made her vaguely uneasy. There was something too exposed about it, too honest. It left her with nowhere to hide. And Agatha, historically, did not handle that sort of honesty well.

 

But Rio, as usual, had ruined that preference by existing. Rio’s voice was always rough then, her face unguarded and a little puffy from sleep, her laugh quiet and sincere in a way it never was once the world was awake. And the way she looked at Agatha in the middle of it -like she’d been waiting her whole life to memorize this exact version of her- was just another insultingly perfect detail.

 

It was, by all accounts, the best possible start to her morning- if Agatha had any authority over such matters. 

 

Now, she sat at her kitchen counter in a white tank top and underwear, camera off, enduring a virtual unit meeting that could have been said in an email.

 

Across the kitchen, Rio was making an increasingly personal enemy of her espresso machine. Agatha watched her fiddle with buttons, mutter under her breath, and glare at it.

 

The machine had only ended up in Agatha’s kitchen because well- Agatha had stolen it. An impulsive act of pettiness Agatha had justified on the grounds of Agatha fucking wanted to. Rio, ever trusting and far too in love with Agatha for her own good, hadn’t noticed a thing. Not until the drive to Agatha’s after basketball practice, when the blanket wrapped evidence started clinking around in the trunk.

 

Every time Rio’s head whipped back toward the noise, Agatha had kept her lips pressed together, staring out the passenger window like a woman with absolutely nothing to hide. By the time they’d pulled into the driveway, the sound had become a full blown percussion, and Agatha was seconds away from bursting into laughter.

 

Now, watching Rio stand over the same machine- hair a mess, brow furrowed, muttering about something Agatha wouldn’t even pretend to understand. She couldn’t help the smile that was clearly on her face. Rio looked ridiculously domestic: too beautiful, too comfortable in Agatha’s space, too unaware that she was the stolen thing Agatha could never bring herself to give back.

 

Agatha figured this was about the time her day had officially taken a turn for the worse- or, more accurately, her mood had. 

 

Rio’s phone sat on the counter beside hers, close enough that the corner of the screen caught her peripheral vision. It pinged with an email- one innocent, unassuming sound. 

 

Agatha had never pretended not to be nosy. The subject line might as well have been highlighted in the same neon that was the rec center’s pathetic sign.

 

Lease Renewal - Apartment 69 (Tenant: Rio Vidal)

This is a courtesy reminder that your current lease term is set to expire in thirty (30) days. To continue your tenancy, please complete the renewal documentation via your resident portal or contact the leasing office directly.  

 

Agatha stared at the words longer than her ability to reason allowed. Her rational mind reminded her that it was just an email. Her irrational mind -how often she tripped over Rio’s shoes, or how much of Rio’s clothes had found their way into her laundry- wanted to throw the phone straight out the fucking window.

 

Rio cursed softly at the espresso machine, unaware of the fucking existential crisis she’d unintentionally just triggered.

 

Agatha stared at her for a long moment, affection rising first, then hurt, and then an anger that covered both.

 

Because of course Rio -her girlfriend of exactly one week today- had a lease waiting to be renewed.

 

And Agatha -a fully grown, reasonable adult- was unreasonably, spectacularly fucking irritated about it.

 

Agatha’s eyes drifted to the kitchen window- specifically, to the sill just past where Rio stood, still tinkering with the espresso machine that didn’t belong to Agatha. A neat row of plants lined up along the sill- also not Agatha’s. Not at first. She couldn’t even pinpoint when they’d arrived- only that one morning they existed, and now Agatha watered them as if they’d always been there. It had just… happened. The slow invasion of Rio Vidal, one houseplant and stolen thing at a time.

 

So really, it wasn’t that insane to think about asking Rio to move in. It would almost be efficient at this point. Except- no. That thought was insane. Completely diabolical. Because even if they were basically living together already, that didn’t mean they should make it official. And even if they did, it implied something Agatha hadn’t fully allowed herself to consider: that Rio would want to move in with Agatha. Into Agatha’s house. Into Agatha’s world.

 

That would mean Rio giving up her own place- the apartment Rio had built piece by piece until it finally felt like a home she felt settled in. 

 

Agatha loved Rio’s apartment. Loved the smell that lingered in the walls, the sound of her record player, the way every surface looked touched by Rio’s hands. It was Rio’s in every sense, and maybe that was the point. Rio had made her own corner of the world, and Agatha was sitting here trying to absorb it into hers like some sort of emotional tax.

 

She snapped her laptop shut with a violent slap that felt more satisfying than it should have. It wasn’t a solution, but it was something to hit- and at the moment, that counted as progress.

 

“Everything okay over there?” Rio asked without looking over, finally shoving the portafilter into the espresso machine. 

 

“Peachy!” Agatha replied, her voice a few decibels too bright to be believable. “Need a cigarette.” She didn’t wait for a response. 

 

Instead, Agatha grabbed Rio’s pack of American Spirits off the counter, along with the purple Zippo that, at this point, belonged more to Rio than it ever had to herself.

 

Passing the couch on her way to the back door, Agatha snagged Rio’s hoodie- a soft dark green one Rio had either left or Agatha had stolen. She couldn’t remember anymore. 

 

Agatha pulled the hoodie over her head, marched down the hall, and went to wrench open the back door- only for her foot to collide with something solid. Pain shot through her toes as she stumbled forward, catching herself against the door with one hand.

 

“Fuck!” Agatha barked. She twisted awkwardly, still clutching the cigarettes and lighter, and looked down.

 

Rio’s black Converse.

 

Of course. At Rio’s apartment, Rio’s shoes were always lined up in perfect rows. But here? They spawned in front of every single exit of her house. The front door. The back door. The goddamn garage. Always one shoe, never a pair.

 

Agatha stared at it for a long moment, breath catching in her throat. It was silly, really- how something so small could feel like a message. Like Rio was leaving reminders scattered through her house that said I was here. Or worse, Don’t forget me when you go. 

 

It made Agatha feel violently fucking ill. 

 

She exhaled hard, made a sound between a growl and a sigh, and kicked the shoe aside just to prove a point she couldn’t quite articulate. And if Agatha stayed still for another second, she’d start crying or yelling or both, and neither option felt reasonable.

 

So Agatha swallowed it down, yanked the back door open, and slammed it behind her hard enough to feel the vibration run up her arm.

 

The air was colder than she expected, biting at her bare legs. Early fall in New Jersey- too warm for frost, too cold to be outside in underwear, not that that stopped her. The boards beneath her feet were rough and chilled, and every step sent another shiver up her spine.

 

Agatha bent into the flame, the heat brushing her fingers as she lit a cigarette. “Un-fucking-believable,” she muttered, dragging on it. The smoke hit her lungs too hot, too harsh, but she didn’t stop. She exhaled through her teeth, furious at the air, at the sky, at the fucking concept of thirty days.

 

She tossed the lighter onto the table. The cigarette burned low between her fingers, each drag harsher than the last- smoke scraping her throat, stinging her eyes, doing absolutely nothing to calm her. Her hand found the back of the patio chair,  cigarette still between her fingers, knuckles whitening as she tried to breathe through it. One breath. Two- 

 

“THIRTY DAYS!” Agatha screamed, voice cracking as she ripped the chair off the ground and launched it. It skidded across the patio with a violent, echoing crash.

 

“Fuck!” She pressed the heels of her hands into her eyes, cigarette still clutched between her fingers, the embers flaring dangerously close to her skin.

 

After a moment, she dropped her hands and glared at the patio chair. “Courtesy reminder, my ass,” she snapped to no one, flicking ash at the fallen chair. “You’re fine, Agatha,” she muttered. “Totally. Completely.” She shoved the cigarette back between her lips. “Fucking fine.”

 

She crouched, grabbing the bent leg of the chair, metal scraping against the wood as she hauled it upright again. It wobbled, uneven, like it was mocking her, and she gave it a hard shove back into place anyway. Then Agatha stubbed the cigarette out in the ashtray, grinding it down until nothing but ash and filter left. After that was finished, Agatha straightened, smoothed her hair with a shaky hand, and turned back toward the house.

 

Agatha stormed through the backdoor and immediately tripped over Rio’s fucking shoe- again. This time without breaking stride, she went straight to the front door. She yanked it open, stomped down the porch steps, and crossed the sidewalk. 

 

The rolled-up Westview Weekly newspaper sat at the edge of her yard, wrapped in its usual plastic sleeve. 

 

Agatha snatched it up, shaking it for good measure. “They need to change the fucking name of this goddamn newspaper,” she muttered. She turned on her heel, marched back inside, and slammed the door behind her. 

 

She stood in the entryway for one long, furious breath, trying to find her composure and coming up empty. Then she went straight back into the kitchen, didn’t look at Rio, and dropped into the barstool again. 

 

The still bagged newspaper hit the counter with a wet slap. Agatha shoved her laptop a few inches across the counter. When she looked up, Rio was still exactly where she’d left her but now she was leaning against the counter,  watching her with a look that wasn’t quite concern but close enough to piss Agatha off anyway.

 

“You don’t seem peachy,” Rio said, and there wasn’t any judgment in it, just observation.

 

Agatha stilled, her hand tightening around the plastic of the newspaper. “No?” she asked, voice flat.

 

Rio’s mouth tightened. “Considering the assault on the patio chair, I’m going to take a wild guess and say no. But maybe I’m reading it wrong.”

 

Agatha lifted her chin, one finger raised in threat. “You are reading it wrong. I’m fine. Fantastic. Mentally stable, emotionally thriving.”

 

Rio hummed, even nodded. Her gaze flicked down to the newspaper, then back up again. “Yeah. Totally. Though maybe hold off on the crossword.”

 

“Why?”

 

“Because you love the crossword,” Rio said. “And right now, you seem a bit homicidal,” she shrugged, “Maybe just give it an hour.”

 

Agatha narrowed her eyes and pulled the newspaper toward her. “No, I don’t think I will.”

 

“Okay, Agatha,” Rio said, unbothered. She turned away, reaching for the mug on the counter before she crossed the kitchen and set it down in front of Agatha.

 

Rio opened a drawer to her right, pulled out a pen, and held it out.

 

Agatha snatched it from her. “Thank you,” she bit, slamming it down on the counter. 

 

“You’re very welcome, my love.”

 

Agatha froze. For a second, she almost felt bad about the general shittiness of her mood, then she remembered the lease renewal sitting in Rio’s inbox, unsigned and waiting, and her sympathy went out the fucking window.

 

Rio still hadn’t mentioned the email to Agatha. Therefore, Rio must hate Agatha. Simple math.

 

Agatha ripped the plastic sleeve open. When she looked up, Rio was still standing there, just watching her.

 

“You’re being weird,” Agatha said. 

 

Rio leaned forward, elbows braced on the counter like she was settling in. “Am I?” she asked.

 

“Yes,” Agatha snapped, glaring at her. “And you’re terrible at hiding it.”

 

“So are you.” Rio tilted her head, studying her. “Want to tell me what that crash out on the patio was about?” 

 

“I don’t,” Agatha said, snapping the paper open with a crisp flick and flattened it against the counter with her palms. “But thank you for your concern.”

 

Rio didn’t respond but Agatha could feel her eyes on her while she flipped through the paper. “Something you want to tell me?” Agatha asked without looking up.

 

“Not really.”

 

Agatha huffed out a breath and turned another page. When she reached the crossword section, she stopped, brow furrowing. Something about a boy named Eddie. Or Eddie’s friend. Or Eddie’s friend’s dog- Teen’s storytelling was, as always, optimistic at best. He jumped between topics faster than she could keep up with. Agatha had memorized every I love you Rio had ever given her so far. Every pitch, every texture, every tiny inflection Rio gave those three syllables.

 

The soft, drowsy hum of I love you that came right before sleep took them. The scratchy I love you in the morning that followed, when Rio’s voice was still gravel and honey. The trembling I love you that caught on the second word like it was still learning to be said out loud. The quiet I love you that followed, spoken again for no reason except that it finally had somewhere safe it could live.

 

Every time, it sounded a little different. Seventeen years of imagining it hadn’t prepared her for the noise of it- for how it invaded her ears and spread through her limbs, rearranging her insides, her heart shifting to catch each one. 

 

Her body already knew; her left hand pressed into Rio’s shoulder, ring finger twitching like it was trying to hold onto the sound of forever.

 

“I love you more,” Agatha said, easily. It wasn’t thoughtless, just something her heart had finally taught her mouth. 

 

She suspected it would always feel that way now, words and feeling fused so tightly that it would surely outlive her body.

 

“Not likely,” Rio whispered, trying to sound teasing- but she could tell Rio had noticed the sudden change in Agatha’s demeanor.

 

If Agatha looked anything like she felt, it was probably like a woman seconds away from heaving her heart up and out of her throat and into Rio’s waiting hands. 

 

Not exactly an unfamiliar sensation for Agatha.

 

She could’ve argued. She should’ve argued. But the realization hit her- here, of all places. A grimy bar where they’d had their first kiss outside. In a bathroom that smelled like piss and spilled bleach. Rio’s hands shoved down the back of her jeans, gripping her ass checks over her underwear (deeply lame). Only minutes ago, Agatha had wanted to see how fast Rio could come from nothing but the grind of her palm against denim.

Leave it to Agatha to feel like this now- at what was, objectively, the worst possible time, and somehow, in an even worse place.

 

Leave it to Agatha to stand on the precipice of saying something that would make Rio look at her differently. Something unreasonable, in an already catastrophically unreasonable place. Because of course it wouldn’t happen anywhere else in the world that might’ve made slightly more sense.

 

So Agatha didn’t say what she wanted.

 

Not that silence was new to Agatha. She’d had seventeen years of practice- of biting her tongue until it bled, of swallowing words that had clawed their way up her throat with bloody nails. You’d think it would stop hurting after that long. It didn’t. Or maybe it just hurt differently now- because the words were no longer unsaid out of fear, but fucking reason.

 

Her eyes began to sting anyway. Not from sadness, exactly, but from the pure frustration of it all. Of standing in a bathroom that smelled more like piss than it did bleach. Of knowing she was one wrong word away from throwing a fucking fit. Of realizing that the universe really did have an unrivaled sense of humor.

 

Agatha could feel her mouth starting to twist- petulant, childish, as if she were being told “no” again by something cosmic and cruel. She huffed out a pitiful breath.

 

It’s fine. She’d blame it on being drunk.

 

Too bad she wasn’t. Maybe she could pass for tipsy, given how absurdly weepy she suddenly felt.

 

“Hey, it’s okay. What’s-”

 

Rio’s voice came soft, hesitant. She’d started to pull her hands from the inside of Agatha’s jeans, froze halfway through, then slipped them around her waist instead. 

 

Agatha understood the pause- Rio’s first instinct had been to touch her face, to cradle her cheeks, but she’d stopped herself, always so thoughtful, so careful about not putting dirty hands on Agatha’s skin.

 

And somehow that gentleness, that goddamn consideration, made Agatha’s throat tighten- akin to swallowing a rock.

 

“What’s wrong?” Rio murmured, fingers curling into the back of her shirt.

Hated that it was so stupidly endearing. Hated that if she had been even a little braver, she would’ve married Rio yesterday.

 

“Did I do something wrong?” Rio asked quietly.

 

“No,” Agatha said, shaking her head, willing her eyes not to blink to keep more tears from falling. “It just smells like fucking piss in here.”

 

Technically not a lie, which was the best she could offer at the moment.

 

“We can leave, if you want,” Rio said softly. Her voice was careful, worried, her eyes flicking toward the sink.

 

Agatha didn’t care if Rio thought her hands were dirty. She wanted them. Needed them. She reached for Rio’s wrists, tugged her arms upward, and placed them firmly against her own face.

 

Rio froze for half a second, then softened, her thumbs brushing along Agatha’s cheeks catching what tears they could. Rio cradled her face with such tenderness that Agatha let out a shaky exhale- and kept her fingers tight around Rio’s wrists, pressing into the skin in search of Rio’s pulse.

“I’m fine,” Agatha said, even though she sounded anything but. “I’m just- so fucking in love with you, and this bathroom smells like piss, and it’s overwhelming.”

 

More tears fell. She refused to think about how ridiculous she must look: crying over love and piss soaked linoleum. She dropped Rio’s wrists and rubbed her face with her own hands- filthy fingers, be damned.

 

“I love you so much,” Rio said, rushing the words out. “Let’s be in love with each other outside of the bathroom that smells like piss, please. Seeing you like this is torture.”

 

“No! I want to stand in this piss soaked bathroom and feel ashamed about standing in this piss soaked bathroom like a reasonable adult!” Agatha bit out, though her voice trembling, beyond fucking serious. “Don’t steal my struggle,” she shouted, incredulous, pulling away from Rio.

 

Rio blinked at Agatha, confused, affectionate. “Okay?” she offered cautiously, stepping closer anyway- closing the space Agatha had tried to create. Which, to be fair, was absolutely the correct decision if Agatha had anything to say about it.

 

“I, um-” Rio started, voice still gently confused. “I got something for you today. Well- it’s not exactly-” 

 

“Will it make me feel better?” Agatha interrupted, wiping her face with the back of her hand, sniffing hard. She lifted her chin, reasserting pride even through her own mess.

 

“I hope so?” Rio whispered, visibly second guessing herself the instant the words left her mouth.

 

Agatha’s eyes narrowed. “You don’t sound sure.”

 

“Well, now I’m not!” Rio blurted, panicked. “Now I’m worried it’s going to make everything worse, and I’m still a little lost here!”

 

“Now you have to show me,” Agatha said, crossing her arms in challenge. “Because if you don’t, I’ll cry again, and that will be your fault.”

 

Immediately, Rio turned around, facing away from her. There was the sound of a zipper, metal teeth parting, and Agatha frowned.

 

“What are you doing?” Agatha demanded. 

 

Rio didn’t answer. She shoved her jeans and underwear down in one motion, and Agatha instinctively leaned back so she could stare. Sue her. Her girlfriend had her pants around her ankles, and her ass was on display for Agatha. Of course she was going to stare.

Agatha froze.

 

Her name -Agatha- was there in delicate, black cursive, still gleaming beneath a fresh layer of Saniderm. The skin around it faintly pink. Thin lines. Beautiful script. Not crude. Insanely intimate, actually. 

 

Agatha felt her throat tighten- akin to swallowing a second, even more jagged rock. 

 

Rio -Agatha’s endlessly exasperating, breathtakingly sincere Rio- had gotten Agatha’s name tattooed across her lower back. Not even on her ass. Worse. 

 

A tramp stamp. A stunning, elegant, fucking tramp stamp. 

 

Agatha was fairly certain no subject of poetry had ever been more thoroughly outmatched.

 

“You-” Agatha’s voice cracked, utterly defeated. “You got that so you could put your dick in my butt?” It came out pitifully, she was almost on the verge of tears again.

“What?” Rio gasped, baffled. “No!”

 

The word tore out of Rio. She let the fabric go, the shirt and jacket dropping back over her hips, and stumbled to pull her jeans up halfway before waddling across the bathroom.

 

“Agatha- oh my God, no,” Rio said, breathless. One hand landed on Agatha’s shoulder, the other came up to the side of her neck. “I didn’t do it for that. I did it because it’s not something you’d think I’d go through with-” Her sentence died. Agatha could see the exact moment Rio’s footing slipped- her mouth parting, closing, trying to chase the rest of her explanation.

 

But Rio wasn’t wrong. If anyone had ever asked Agatha whether Rio Vidal would willingly let something permanent touch her skin, she would’ve bet every dollar she had on- absolutely the fuck not. 

 

Tattoos were impulsive by definition, according to Rio. They were permanent, too- another thing Rio’s brain struggled to trust. She hadn’t trusted permanence in places, in people, and definitely not in ink that claimed it could last forever.

 

And yet- here they were.

 

“I wanted to show you I wasn’t- I don’t know-” Rio said, swallowing hard. “That I’ve never been this certain about anything in my life. I love you, Agatha. I’ve loved you forever. And that never changes for me. That much I know.”

 

“Rio-” Agatha started. 

 

But apparently, Agatha’s breakdown had opened the floodgates, because Rio’s brain clearly decided it was her turn to completely fucking lose it. 

 

“And I know it’s just a tattoo and it’s… stupid, or whatever. I just-” Rio stepped back, palms pressing to her forehead. She exhaled a frustrated laugh, shaking her head. “God, I sound fucking crazy!” she snapped at herself. “You hate it,” she breathed out, eyes going wide in horror, absolutely sure of a conclusion she’d built from nothing. “Which is fine-” her hands shot up like she needed Agatha to know that part was also true, “That’s totally fine! I don’t regret getting it. I just- fuck, I didn’t realize I’d take it this personally-”

 

“I don’t hate it!” Agatha snapped, cutting Rio off. It sounded defensive, but only because it was. “You think I’d hate that you got a sexy tramp stamp of my name? No, Rio, this is so much worse!”

 

A fist banged against the bathroom door, startling them both.

 

“Fuck off!” Agatha yelled at the door at the exact same time Rio shouted, “Not now!”

 

Longest fifteen minutes of Agatha’s life. Easily.

 

“Worse?” Rio echoed, voice cracking. Mortified. “This made you feel worse?”

 

“Yes!” Agatha shouted, throwing her hands up. “So much worse! Because now I have to stand in a bathroom that smells like piss and be overwhelmed by both the smell and how much I love you and your stupid sexy fucking tramp stamp!”

 

Rio only stared at her, blinking, lips tight.

 

Agatha jabbed a finger toward her. “Don’t you dare laugh at me! I am not being funny- that is an unreasonable number of emotions to process at once!”

 

“Hey, um… guys?” Teen’s voice floated through the door, wary. “I was told to come get-”

 

“Give us a fucking minute!” Agatha barked just as Rio screamed, “Go away!”

 

They both stood there, breathing hard, staring at each other.

 

From outside the bathroom door, Teen shouted, “Should I- like… go get someone?”

 

Agatha and Rio, in unison: “NO!”

 

“Okay. Reset,” Rio said, palms up, eyes flicking to the floor like she could find their sanity somewhere near the floor drain. “You’re overwhelmed. I’m overwhelmed. And the fumes in here are clearly poisoning us.”

 

Agatha swallowed hard. Fine. Sure. She’d take that excuse. It was easier than admitting the truth- that she’d spiraled because she wanted something she absolutely could not ask. 

 

She wasn’t drunk. Two whiskeys and a sip didn’t justify the way her brain had launched itself off a cliff. She could blame the idea of ass play. She could blame her conversation with Jen. She could blame the bar bathroom. She could pretend she was still “reasonable,” still following some imaginary responsible timeline she owed the universe.

 

Now she was in an actual relationship with Rio. Now Rio was moving in with her. Now Rio had Agatha’s name tattooed on her lower back. And Agatha had waited seventeen years for this. She should be savoring it. Letting it be enough. 

 

But even while she acted sane, she was hoping Rio would beat her to it, because this whole ‘I’m totally reasonable’ performance was paper fucking thin and burning fast.

Agatha blinked, and suddenly Rio was in front of her, palms soft against her cheeks again.

She reached for Rio’s wrists and tried to pull back. 

 

Rio chased her mouth.

 

Agatha was going to kill whoever walked in. No fucking question.

Sage was on her knees, Rio’s NY Liberty hat turned backward on her head, a bobby pin pinched between her fingers, post breaking and entering. Her face was twisted in absolute horror. Teen hovered behind her, eyes wide- but nowhere near as traumatized. He blinked and shook himself out of it.

 

“Uh… hey guys,” he said, giving a weak wave, shifting awkwardly on his feet. 

 

“I think I’m going to throw up,” Sage muttered. Then she turned, slowly, murderously, toward Billy. “And I’m going to kill you.” 

 

“I was worried! There was shouting, and then the shouting stopped, and I thought-”

 

“Stop talking,” Sage snapped, climbing to her feet. She spared one more glance toward Agatha and Rio, her face contorting. “And it smells like piss in here, you sick fucks,” she said before storming off down the hall.

“I think it’s really cool,” Billy offered from the hallway, still standing there.

 

“Do you mind?” Agatha snapped.

 

He flinched. “Oh! Yeah- sorry!” And Agatha watched him literally scamper off.

 

Agatha huffed, flicked the water off her hands, and reached for paper towels. As she stepped aside for Rio, she said, “I lied earlier about the proctologist comment.”

 

Rio dispensed soap into her palms. “Oh yeah?” She shot Agatha a quick sideways look and rinsed her hands.

“Agatha!” Rio called, breathless.

 

Agatha stopped, turned, and caught Rio’s hand as she reached her. She laced their fingers together, face perfectly blank.

“Meant what?”

 

Rio leaned closer, lowering her voice. “Do you actually want me to do that to you?”

 

Stupid question. 

 

“Desperately,” Agatha answered.

“I’m not upset, I’m horrified!”

Sage muttered under her breath but complied with a stiff, defeated pat. Rio plucked her hat off Sage’s head, ruffled her hair with unnecessary enthusiasm, and said, “Thank you for keeping it safe.”

And, sure- Agatha had that old familiar pinch of Fuck, I should’ve been there for that. She’d wished Rio had told her, wished she’d seen it happen instead of hearing about it after the fact.
