Agatha was just getting home from work, which would’ve been fine if it weren’t 9:30 in the goddamn morning. Night shift was one thing. Night shift followed by a required Delivery team meeting was another. Everyone on nights hated those morning meetings; they never lined up with anyone’s sleep schedule, and they turned a long shift into a stupidly long one.

 

It was also exactly why she and Rio drove separately. Rio had offered -four times- to just wait for her, said she didn’t mind hanging around until Agatha was done. But Agatha shut that down immediately. She wasn’t making Rio sit through the two and a half hours between shift change and mandatory bullshit just because Agatha had to.

 

Walking through the door, Agatha’s body did the usual automatic brace for tripping over one of Rio’s shoes. Except her foot didn’t snag on anything. That alone was strange enough to make her pause.

 

The shoes. Every pair -hers and Rio’s- tucked perfectly into the cubby space under the entryway hall tree. Not half in or kicked to the side, but pushed all the way back, toes aligned, nothing out of place. No rogue shoe lying in wait the way there always, always was. Even Rio’s backpack was sitting on the bench above them, not dropped or slumped, but set down intentionally. 

 

It wasn’t dramatic, but it was enough to tell Agatha something was off.

 

She slipped off her own shoes, tucked them into the nearest open slot. Her bag hit the bench with a soft thud as she headed for the laundry room, already peeling off the night, and pulled on her robe before heading upstairs.

 

Their bedroom door was cracked open. 

 

Agatha almost corrected herself -her bedroom- for half a second before letting that thought die out. Rio hadn’t moved all her things in yet, and they still had an unfinished list of what they needed to sort through, what to toss, what would get swapped out for Rio’s stuff. But none of that mattered. This house hadn’t felt like just Agatha’s in months. It was theirs- no question. Even if the logistics hadn’t caught up yet.

 

She eased the door open and heard a frustrated jostling from inside. Agatha went still for a moment. She didn’t need to see Rio to understand what she’d walked in on; she knew this particular sound, the way it meant Rio’s attention had snagged on something small and wouldn’t let go.

The drawer’s contents sat on the floor beside her. Not spilled. Not messy. Laid out with a purposeful order that made Agatha’s stomach tighten. An extra charger. Rio’s weed pen. An unopened pack of cigrettes. The purple Zippo. A handful of individually wrapped Warheads she kept for sour candy cravings. A couple of pictures. Even the framed photo of them, the lamp, and the alarm clock she only ever used to keep track of time had been unplugged and lined up beside each other.

 

The only thing out of place was the screwdriver, abandoned right next to Rio’s knee.

 

“Fucking stupid thing,” Rio muttered, frustration slipping through each word as she fought the drawer back into place.

 

Agatha’s heart just… dropped. If she’d been paying attention, she swore she would’ve heard it shatter against the hardwood. She hadn’t seen Rio like this in well over a decade, and trying to remember the last time only made her want to projectile vomit. Most of those memories were forgotten on purpose; Agatha had stopped keeping track back when things between them had gotten messy in ways it was never meant to. Back when every attempt to help had seemed to only make things worse.

 

Every instinct Agatha had told her to move carefully, to not crowd Rio, to not step right back into the same stupid mistakes she made years ago. She’d spent so long being terrified of doing the wrong thing with Rio -saying the wrong thing, stepping in too fast, stepping in at all- that her body wanted to freeze in place just to avoid repeating history.

Agatha stepped around the corner and leaned her shoulder against it. “Hey,” she said quietly.

 

Rio’s head snapped back toward her. She opened her mouth, closed it, then turned right back to the drawer like it hadn’t happened. “How was your meeting?” she asked, voice too bright, jostling the drawer hard enough that the wood thunked.

 

“Definitely could’ve been an email,” Agatha said, easing her way into the room.

 

“Oh yeah?”

 

“Yeah.” Agatha nodded, even though Rio wasn’t looking. “Was the drawer acting up?”

 

“Screws were loose,” Rio muttered. “Sounded like it was gonna fall off the tracks every time I opened it.” She paused, like she expected Agatha to argue, then added, “Sorry the room’s a mess.”

 

Agatha nodded again. Rio still wasn’t meeting her eyes. And none of what she said made sense. The drawer didn’t make that noise. The room wasn’t a mess. Everything was lined up so neatly it made Agatha’s chest hurt.

 

“No worries,” Agatha said instead. She stepped around the neatly arranged pile, careful not to nudge anything out of place, and sank onto the floor behind Rio, her back braced against the bed.

 

“This isn’t what it looks like,” Rio said over her shoulder- too fast, too defensive, the same tone she used years ago when she was trying way too hard to pretend she was fine.

 

“Looks like you’re fixing a drawer,” Agatha said softly, giving a small shrug. Her fingers drifted toward her own hand, picking at a bit of skin around her nails. “Did you eat when you got home?” she asked, trying to sound casual.

 

“No,” like the word had gotten stuck around something in Rio’s throat.

 

“Do you want me to make something?” Agatha asked quietly, her chest tightening at the sight of her heart on the floor, fighting a drawer. 

 

Rio only gave the tiniest shake of her head. She yanked the drawer free, sat back on her knees, and twisted around looking for the screwdriver. 

 

Before she could work herself up over not finding it, Agatha reached for it and held it out. 

 

Rio’s hand hovered for a beat before she took it without meeting Agatha’s eyes and started working on the tracks, loosening each screw.

“Shit,” Rio said immediately. “Forgot my badge at the house and it went downhill from there. The list was 23 patients each between the three of us. Trauma after trauma came in. The Ortho resident working was a giant dick. It just… never let up.” Her voice wobbled on the last word, and when she blinked, a tear clung to the bottom of her lash, refusing to fall.

 

Agatha wanted to set the fucking hospital on fire. Or the nightstand. Or anything that had piled onto Rio’s night and pushed her over the edge.

 

“That sounds like hell,” Agatha said instead.

 

One tear escaped; Rio swiped it away like it offended her. “It wasn’t-” Rio shook her head, jaw tight. “It’s stupid. I’m just tired.” She finally set the screwdriver down.

 

Rio was crying, and every instinct in Agatha’s body demanded a target. She curled her hands into fists, reminding herself to stay still. She wasn’t twenty-four anymore; she didn’t need to let the flood of “fix it” impulses run her ragged. The urge to destroy something was just her oldest reflex, not her only one.

 

“It’s not stupid,” Agatha whispered. She swallowed hard, steadying her voice so Rio wouldn’t hear the wobble in it.

 

“I don’t want you to think I’m… I don’t know.” Rio sniffed hard, swiping at her face again like she was double-checking for evidence.

 

“I think you had a shit night,” Agatha said gently, eyes flicking across the perfectly placed items on the floor. “And I think you’re fixing the nightstand.”

 

Not accusing. Not pretending. Just opening the door enough for Rio to walk through if she wanted.

 

She wouldn’t hold it against Rio. She’d play along, let Rio keep her walls up where she needed them. Rio hadn’t mentioned the therapy or her OCD diagnosis- not to Agatha, anyway. Lilia had been the one to tell Agatha. And she knew Rio wasn’t hiding it; this was just the sort of thing Rio had never known how to hand over. She’d struggled with it long before they were ever in each other’s lives.

 

Agatha understood that. Rio would come to her when she was ready. And Agatha would be there when she did.

 

Still, if Agatha could’ve taken the nightstand outside and beaten it to splinters on Rio’s behalf, she absolutely fucking would have.

“Rio,” she whispered. “Let me get you some water. Or I can run a bath for us, if you want. I-”

Rio swallowed once, tapped the drawer still resting in her lap, and nodded toward the nightstand. “Can you help me get it back on the tracks?”

“Are you upset with me?” Agatha asked softly.

 

“Not at all. I just… I couldn’t handle talking about it back then. It controlled every inch of my life. I already knew I was fucked up in the head- I didn’t need anyone confirming it. I hated it. I still hate it- I hate how much space it takes up, how loud it gets, how small it makes me feel. I worried myself fucking sick over everything and none of it touched the shit that actually happened.”

Rio nodded, but not confidently- more like she was admitting something she wished she didn’t feel. “I was already having a terrible night. And when Jen said it I couldn’t unhear it. And then traumas kept rolling in, and my brain… it just went there. It convinced me that something awful was going to happen to you, and I’d be the last to know.”

Oh. 

 

Of course.

Agatha wasn’t blind to the implications of it. She knew that, by anyone’s standards, keeping the people she trusted closest while she was married to someone else wasn’t exactly admirable. It painted her in a horrible light -selfish, careless, probably evil- and she never pretended otherwise. 

 

More importantly, Agatha didn’t give a fuck. She didn’t care how it looked or what it said about her that she’d arranged things to ensure they would always be notified, always know, always be the first ones called into the room if the worst ever happened. She just needed the assurance that the people who loved her would never be left in the dark.

“You know now,” Agatha murmured, hoping it gave Rio a little more ground to stand on.

 

Rio’s gaze dropped to the floor. Her brow furrowed, her mouth opened and closed, her head gave the smallest shake- too many thoughts were ricocheting around her skull, Agatha knew.

 

“How did you get away with that in Chicago?”

 

“Very intentionally,” Agatha said, her voice soft but sure. “And with absolutely no guilt.”

 

Rio let out a breathy, disbelieving laugh, and the sound was the prettiest thing Agatha thinks she’s ever heard. 

 

Agatha reached up, tucking a loose piece of hair behind Rio’s ear, letting her fingers trail along the line of her jaw. “Tell me what else you need,” she murmured. “Whatever it is, I’ll give it to you.”

 

Rio’s forehead fell against hers, eyes fluttering shut. “I- I don’t know,” she exhaled. “I’m exhausted.”

 

“That’s okay,” Agatha whispered, sliding her hand to the back of Rio’s neck and guiding her just a little closer. She pressed a soft kiss to the corner of Rio’s mouth. “Come lie down with me.”

Rio froze, shoulders tight, looking like she wanted to crawl straight out of her skin. But she didn’t argue.

She took care of it too fast for Rio to think about stepping in again. She climbed into bed when she was done, adjusting the pillows and settling back against them.

Even teary and wrung out, she wouldn’t let herself lean into Agatha’s comfort without tensing first, like letting herself have it meant giving something away. Agatha never knew exactly what that meant.

 

But she remembered the way it always ended: the two of them on Rio’s old couch, Real Housewives of New York playing on the TV, Agatha gently pulling Rio’s head into her lap, fingers stroking her scalp until Rio’s breathing finally eased.

 

Agatha reached for the remote and placed it in Rio’s hand. They were older now, different, and Agatha didn’t want to risk turning on RHONY herself only to learn it reminded Rio of a time that hadn’t been good for her. Even if, for Agatha, the memory carried a comfort she had never allowed herself to look too closely at.

 

She let her fingers drift through Rio’s hair and the sigh it pulled from Rio settled straight into her bones. “Are you hungry?” Agatha murmured. “I can order food.”

 

Rio shook her head, and Agatha wasn’t surprised. She never wanted food after; pressing the issue had never helped. She watched Rio take over the scrolling, flicking through shows until she stopped on Real Housewives- a small mercy Agatha hadn’t expected to receive.

 

Proof that some part of what she’d tried to give Rio back then had landed in the way she’d hoped, even if neither of them could hold onto it at the time.

 

“Are you hungry?” Rio asked quietly. She set the remote on the far side of Agatha and reached for the hand resting idle in Agatha’s lap. Her fingers fidgeted gently with Agatha’s- tracing her knuckles.

 

“No,” Agatha said, honest about it. She’d eaten the lunch Rio packed for her later in her shift.

 

Rio rolled her head back on the pillow until she could look up at her. Agatha was already staring down at her.

 

“I’m sorry,” Rio whispered. A tear had slipped across the bridge of her nose and was sliding down her other cheek. 

 

Agatha eased her hand out of Rio’s fidgeting hold and used her thumb to sweep the tear from her cheek. “You have nothing to apologize for,” she said, and Agatha meant it.

 

Rio’s mouth trembled, her eyes darting away. “I’m embarrassed,” she whispered. 

 

“You shouldn’t be. It wasn’t an unreasonable thing to worry about.” Agatha let her hand fall back to her own lap, watching as Rio’s fingers immediately resumed their fidgeting. “But for the next time you’re determined to fix something to feel better, there’s a drawer in the guest bathroom begging for your attention. It sticks. And unlike the nightstand, it won’t punish you for your good intentions.”

 

Rio blinked up at her, letting out a quiet, flustered little huff. The smile that followed was small but real, tugging at the corner of her mouth like she couldn’t stop it even if she wanted to.

 

Agatha moved the hand still threaded through Rio’s hair, letting her knuckles graze the curve of her cheek before cupping it, brushing her thumb across the skin. Rio leaned into her touch.

 

“You’re allowed to lose your shit, you know,” Agatha said quietly, looking down at her. “There’s nothing wrong with that. I lose my shit constantly and you still look at me like I’m doing great.”

 

Rio ducked her head, laughing under her breath. Her smile this time was crooked, guilty. She tugged lightly at Agatha’s fingers. “I like when you do,” she said. “It’s one of my favorite things about you. It’s…” She hesitated, her mouth twisting. “It's a lot less endearing when I do it.”

 

Agatha would have to disagree with that. Rio wasn’t being dramatic; she’d spent an entire night tearing herself up over something as painfully earnest as who Agatha’s emergency contact was. The concern itself was sweet. But Rio wasn’t the problem. And what she was dealing with now was nothing like before. 

 

Just as Agatha drew a breath to tell her exactly what she thought, Rio spoke first.

 

“I don’t want you walking through the door after a twelve-hour shift and finding me like that,” Rio said quietly. “You shouldn’t have to shoulder it.”

 

“If you think I want to be spared from any part of you, you’re wrong,” Agatha said. “The most wrong you’ve ever been in your life, actually.” 

 

Rio’s gaze started to flick away, and Agatha caught it with her thumb brushing at her cheek before it could stray completely. 

 

“I love you, Rio,” Agatha said, utterly unashamed. “All of you. And I want to walk through that door and find you. However that looks. If it’s easy, great. If it’s a disaster, even better. I want all of it. Taking care of you isn’t a burden, it’s… it’s the thing I didn’t get to do the way I wanted to before. But we’re here now, and I can. I want to. So you’re going to let me.”

 

Brown eyes stared up at her, lips parted- which, conveniently, was when Agatha noticed.

 

Rio fidgeting with Agatha’s left hand. Rio’s fingers. Agatha’s fingers. More specifically- Rio’s thumb. More specifically still- Rio’s thumb on Agatha’s ring finger.

 

Dragging up. Pushing down. Proximal phalanx. Pausing. Pressure. 

 

An exquisite ache, really. One that made Agatha want to crack open her sternum, pull her own heart out, and lay it at Rio’s feet like an offering.

 

“Whatever you want, my love,” Rio murmured, nodding, no fight left in her- except for the pressure of her thumb pressing into Agatha’s finger. “You have all of me.”

 

Perfect. Fantastic. Get it the fuck together. 

 

She reminded herself -rather aggressively- that this was about Rio, not about Agatha’s insatiable, catastrophically ill timed desire to marry Rio.

 

Agatha cleared her throat, tried her best to sound reasonable. “Good. I’m- …” She cut herself off, sniffed, looked anywhere but at those soft, hazy brown eyes. “I’m gonna hold you now.”

 

Rio nodded, her voice soft, “And kiss me,” while tugging Agatha closer as she eased herself lower into the bed.

 

“And kiss you,” Agatha echoed, because the alternative was inconceivable. 

 

Agatha brushed a strand of hair away from Rio’s cheek, letting her fingertips trail along her jaw. Rio’s eyes followed the movement, heavy lidded, and Agatha felt herself soften instinctively. When Rio tipped her head the slightest bit, meeting her halfway, Agatha leaned in and let her lips skim Rio’s in a soft, testing brush.

 

Rio lifted her hand, her fingers grazing Agatha’s cheek before they slid into Agatha’s hair, guiding her mouth closer. When Rio exhaled into the kiss -a small, trembling huff she didn’t seem aware she’d made- Agatha caught it like it was something precious and impossibly important.

 

It wasn’t long before Rio ended up curled into her, knocked out cold with her face tucked into Agatha’s neck. One of Rio’s hands had slipped inside Agatha’s robe and settled on her ribs, and once Agatha was sure Rio was fully out, she very carefully reached for her phone. 

 

Agatha logged into the hospital portal, changed her emergency contact from Lilia to Rio, then swapped the secondary to Jen. Lilia was getting old anyway; Agatha figured it was time to stop giving her responsibilities that involved, you know, being alive and alert. 

 

She woke up before Rio. Neither of them had budged an inch. Rio was still fitted against her, desperately clinging to Agatha despite being unconscious. Agatha, meanwhile, was overheating to a truly offensive degree because Rio ran unreasonably hot and had the audacity to be sweaty about it. 

 

None of that stopped Agatha from lying there for fifteen whole minutes more, staring at the ceiling and letting herself enjoy it because she could… and because she wanted Rio more than she wanted to escape Rio’s heat.

 

After nearly cooking herself alive, Agatha eased herself out of bed and went downstairs, where she googled a six minute instructional video on how to operate Rio’s espresso machine. By the third minute she was questioning why any rational adult would voluntarily choose such a machine, but she committed and managed to make something that resembled coffee. 

 

When Agatha came back upstairs, she set the cup on the nightstand and sat on the edge of the bed, leaning in to press a soft kiss to the corner of Rio’s mouth. When Rio’s lashes finally lifted, there was that warm, unfocused look that Agatha always  pretended she wasn’t waiting for. Sleep still clung to brown eyes, Rio’s hair was an absolute wreck, and her skin was on fucking fire. Rio reached for Agatha automatically, hands pushing into Agatha’s robe, arms sliding around Agatha’s waist.

 

Rio drank about half the coffee before her eyes narrowed over the rim at Agatha. She pulled the mug away, held a mouthful far longer than anyone with even a shred of decorum would, let it fall back into the cup, and handed it over as if it were simply the natural order of things- which, unfortunately, it was. 

 

Naturally, Agatha took the coffee. Naturally, Agatha drank the coffee. Naturally, Agatha didn’t look away from Rio- she never would. Naturally, the very thing Agatha pretended she wasn’t stupidly invested in earning every single time followed: the gap between Rio’s teeth.

 

And naturally, that was how Agatha discovered the coffee she’d made tasted like absolute dog shit.

It remains unclear if I'll end up writing actual butt stuff.

I missed you.

As always, thank you for the music <3

Chapter 18: part two: i hope they never understand us

Chapter Notes

i lied- here's 14k of butt stuff.. see you all in hell, i guess.

i don't actually know those two people over on the bird app- cait and phoebe. but i -begrudgingly- dedicate this chapter to them. whomp. whomp.

See the end of the chapter for more notes

To be clear, Agatha was very aware she was compensating for something.

 

There had been a wildly impractical idea circling her brain like a hungry fucking vulture, getting louder and more obnoxious by the day. And since ignoring it wasn’t working, she’d done what she always did- picked a direction and committed. Even if that direction had taken a rather dramatic left turn that she was annoyingly, very enthusiastic about.

 

The whole thing had started innocently enough. Rio mentioned in passing that there was a new exhibition at the Eastview Museum of Art she wanted to see. Spoken as barely a blip in the conversation. But Agatha heard it, and given even the smallest opening, decided she wanted to take Rio on a date.

 

Conveniently, it also served as a distraction. A distraction she had thrown herself into the logistics of, hoping momentum could drown out the louder, more intrusive parts of Agatha’s heart.

 

So Agatha had planned this date with an almost alarming level of enthusiasm. Tickets? Purchased immediately. Schedules? Cleared. And because she was leaning into the whole romantic gesture thing, she’d even insisted on taking public transportation- the same route they used in their twenties, when the museum was just one of the places they both liked enough to keep going back to. It had been easy, familiar, and one of the few things that felt right no matter how complicated the two of them managed to be.

 

The artist being exhibited was known for sculptures and paintings of flowers that looked like… well, flowers, but only in the loosest, most vaginal sense. Close enough to botany to count, and close enough to pussies to feel intentional. Which given their most recent change in plans seemed to turn the idea of cute museum date into the territory of curated lesbian debauchery- tastefully framed, of course.

 

The worst part was that Agatha had no one to blame but herself. Because she was the one who opened Rio’s package yesterday -the second she read the label- only to confirm, with her own depraved eyes, that Rio had ordered a set of silicone butt plugs. Dark green. Same shape. Three different sizes. And because Agatha was completely normal and well adjusted, she’d immediately pretended to be irritated by the fact that it was an odd number.

Agatha, panicking in the way only she could, promptly barked, “Clean them properly,” like she hadn’t just been caught rehearsing the exact lie she planned to tell herself before letting them anywhere near her asshole.

 

Which Agatha couldn’t do anymore. Lie to herself, she meant. At least not with the shameless efficiency she used to. She’d actually spent the last twenty-four hours trying to think of anything but -pun fully intended- and had failed with spectacular consistency.

 

Why? A reasonable person might ask.

 

Well, Agatha had set her alarm long before Rio would wake up, because she had… prep to do. Private, undignified prep. Prep Agatha would sooner commit a felony than let Rio witness. 

 

And as if she hadn’t already dug herself an early grave out of pure shame, she was now exerting an almost heroic level of self control to keep from dry humping her girlfriend awake- after doing all of her humiliating prep and taking a shower to recover from it. Her brain refused to cooperate, replaying two equally disastrous thoughts on a loop- floral art that looked like pussies, and the inescapable reality that she was about to walk around a museum with a butt plug shoved up her ass.

And the second her eyes found Rio’s through the mirror, everything in Agatha reacted instantly.

“Did you get yourself ready for me, like we said?”

 

An unfortunate reminder of how detailed yesterday’s conversation had been- and how perfectly everything so far had followed it.

 

“Yeah,” Agatha breathed, her mouth suddenly dry, gaze locked on Rio’s through the mirror.

 

A soft flush warmed Rio’s cheeks. “You’re already this responsive to me?”

 

Agatha didn’t pretend to fight it. She couldn’t. Every inch of her felt tuned to Rio and the plan they’d agreed on. She wanted this so fucking badly she could feel the heat pooling between her thighs- and they hadn’t even made it out of the damn house.

“Great,” Agatha managed, the word coming out on a shaky breath. A smile tugging at her mouth.

 

Rio’s smile broke instantly, cheeks still flushed, the gap between her teeth making an appearance. “Good,” she said, nodding. “That’s really good.” Her gaze flicked downward -almost shy- and then she turned back to the sink. It was enough for the fall chill that she didn’t regret not layering more.

Jen laughed. “I’ll be sure to let her know. But seriously- concerned or impressed? Because right now I’m leaning toward concerned.”

Jen hummed, considering it, then said casually, “If I didn’t know any better, I’d ask if backdoor activity was involved.”

“If you end up in the right place, does it matter how you got there?” Lilia asked.

 

“No,” Agatha admitted. “I suppose it doesn’t.” 

 

She didn’t bother pushing the point- logic wasn’t why she called, and Lilia definitely knew that. Lilia always knew more than she should, which only made this worse.

 

“Agatha,” Lilia said, and just her tone was enough.

 

Agatha pressed the phone to her forehead, resisting the urge to beat herself unconscious with it, then exhaled and brought it back to her ear.

 

“I’m trying to do this right,” Agatha muttered.

 

“Oh, you don’t need my permission. But humor me. I want to hear you name what you want.”

 

Agatha blew out a frustrated breath, her lips sputtering with it. “You just want to hear me embarrass myself is what it is,” she mumbled, nudging her toe against the pavement.

 

Lilia hummed. 

 

Agatha pinched the bridge of her nose. “I’m calling to let you know I’m about to ask your daughter to marry me… so you don’t unleash whatever witchery you keep for those who forget to inform you.”

 

Lilia laughed, the sound bright with joy.

 

“Don’t keep your heart waiting. You’re home, Agatha. Go on now- go inside. I love you, sweet girl.”

 

“I love you too, Lil. I’ll call you after, yeah?”

 


“Of course,” Lilia said. “I’ll be here. I’ll be thinking of you. Bye now.”

 

 

Chapter End Notes

Chapter 19: the bugs and the dirt

Chapter Notes

idk man i got tired of staring at it in my google doc 😭

See the end of the chapter for more notes

One might have expected Agatha to do something extremely reckless with a realization like this. That she’d tear through the front door with a fire lit under her ass and say too much and say it too fast- say something she could absolutely not take back. That she’d turn certainty into action before fear had the chance to ask her any inconvenient follow up questions.

 

That had always been Agatha’s specialty. Feel first. Launch second. Then deal with the wreckage in whatever order it presents itself.

 

And maybe that was the plan when she walked into their house. Maybe not. Agatha wouldn’t know. Maybe she just felt like it was, which wasn’t the same thing. Rio had been right a couple weeks ago when she said Agatha had fast feet- too fast, sometimes, Agatha thought, for even herself to keep up with. So it wasn’t a stretch to admit that she had never been great at knowing when she meant to do something. Only that, by the time she noticed, she was already in the middle of it. 

 

Because really, she had nothing to show for it: no plan, no ring burning a hole in her pocket, no romantic speech waiting in the wings to ambush her common sense. Still, Agatha was aware, with an odd lack of urgency, that she was going to ask Rio to marry her today. Or rather, make it known that it wasn’t a question so much as a demand- and not one that was open to debate.

 

Rio was stretched across the couch, watching that political comedy she liked- the one Agatha pretended not to follow but somehow always knew the plot of. She looked completely at ease, one arm draped along the back of the cushions, legs curled under her.

 

Agatha stopped just inside the entryway to the living room, staring at Rio- abruptly aware of herself in every uncomfortable way: her heartbeat, the sweat cooling on her skin, the trail dirt covering her clothes, and the fact that Rio was now looking at her without the faintest idea she’d just run six miles home in what Agatha would eventually admit was a minor crash out.

 

“Hey,” Rio said, with a smile that was too sweet to be anything other than genuine. “You’re home.”

 

That alone almost did it.

But Agatha wanted to shower. Wanted to get a handle on the physical buzz still humming through her, making everything in her body louder than it had any right to be. She wanted to be in the moment, not gasping for air because she’d decided to run six miles home.

“Yeah,” Agatha breathed. “I am.”

 

“I missed you,” Rio said, already reaching for Agatha. “Come kiss me.”

“I’m gonna go shower,” Agatha said, standing.

 

Rio looked up at her, eyes still warm, still amused. “Am I invited?”

 

Under any other circumstances, Agatha would have said yes- immediately and enthusiastically and with very little dignity. But this wasn’t a normal circumstance, and Agatha wasn’t reacting to it normally.

 

She wanted this feeling, even if she didn’t entirely approve of it. There was anticipation in it, and something almost foolishly excited too- the thrill of knowing that she was going to ask a question that Rio was entirely unaware of.

 

Agatha tilted her head, made a show of pretending to consider the invitation, and then very deliberately began backing away- careful not to trip over her own smile.

 

Rio squinted at Agatha, her mouth parting as she watched- intrigued, slightly offended, maybe even a little impressed that Agatha hadn’t said yes immediately.

 

“You know,” Agatha offered, stopping at the edge of the living room, “you should probably stay here.”

“Why, my love?” Rio demanded.

“You’re being dramatic,” Agatha said, because that part was true.

“Consider it a consequence for violating house policy,” Agatha said, tipping her chin, and very pointedly flicking her eyes toward Rio’s shirt.

Agatha rolled her eyes, smiling. “Am I free to go shower now?”

 

“You’ll hurry?” Rio asked.

 

“Obviously. You’ll be here when I get back?” Agatha asked, like she didn’t already know the answer.

 

Rio nodded immediately. “You couldn’t get rid of me if you tried.”

 

Agatha let out a huff, suddenly breathless with how easy it was to love Rio Vidal, and how natural it felt to ask and be answered without doubt.

 

“Kiss me before you go,” Rio said, theatrically, both hands cradling Agatha’s face. “It feels cruel to leave me here alone like this. I’ll suffer terribly.”

 

“You’ll survive,” Agatha said flatly. She leaned in and kissed Rio anyway, because she was a hypocrite. Full of shit, truly. “You’re very brave.”

 

Rio’s smile was lazy and lopsided and stupidly fucking sweet. “Thank you for believing in me.”

 

Agatha pulled away before that smile could talk her into jumping the gun.

She sat on the bed with her back against the headboard, pillows stacked behind her, body wrapped in a towel with her hair wrapped in another. Phone in hand, she casually scrolled through county clerk websites, marriage license info, and appointment availability with the focus of someone preparing for a heist.

 

And surprisingly, looking into these logistics was unexpectedly satisfying. It was new, it was hers, and it was about Rio, which made all the difference. Agatha hadn’t handled any of this in a previous marriage that shall not be named, and she took absolute pleasure in the fact that this particular effort had never been spent on anyone else.

 

Across the bedroom, Rio had pushed the sleeves of her hoodie up and kept bumping her elbow against the doorframe every time she went back into the closet to rearrange something that did not, as far as Agatha could tell, require rearranging. 

 

Though she knew long before Rio ever moved in that her idea of “organized” and whatever Rio’s idea of it was were two completely different concepts. Agatha, who had never had a system beyond “wherever it lands,” was super weirdly into it.

 

“I admire your confidence in assuming all of this is necessary,” Agatha said, mostly because she wanted to bother Rio and had grown tired of waiting for a better reason to do so.

 

“It’s absolutely necessary,” Rio said. “You have the organizational skills of a toddler, and I love you too much to let you live like that.”

 

Agatha turned her head toward the nightstand and briefly considered a rebuttal that involved throwing the coffee mug sitting there directly at Rio’s head, but Rio cut in before she could commit. 

 

“You’re going to get sick of me being here all the time,” Rio said, her smile so blindingly pretty it could have burned Agatha’s retinas out if she let herself look at it for too long.

 

“Highly unlikely,” Agatha muttered, mostly to herself, as she continued scrolling on her phone, which was open to the website listing available appointments for marriage licenses.

 

Her thumb hovered over the screen when she saw the earliest available option.

 

Tomorrow.

 

Agatha immediately started scheming on how to convince Rio to take the next two weeks off of work- and whether she could do it within the next twelve hours without resorting to blackmail or throwing a fucking fit.

 

Two weeks definitely felt excessive and completely unreasonable, which was how most of Agatha’s decisions tended to start. But not including time for just-married activities would be objectively fucking stupid, and Agatha had no intention of skipping that part. Which meant that before she could get attached to the idea of tomorrow, she had to Google it.

 

There was, as it turned out, a waiting period.

 

The state of New Jersey apparently required three full days between wanting to marry Rio Vidal (aquiring their marriage license) and actually being allowed to marry Rio Vidal. 

 

Agatha found that rude and irritating… Agatha booked the appointment. 

 

She read the confirmation screen twice before screenshotting the list of what they’d need to bring, pointedly not thinking about the fact that she’d just put herself on a fucking time crunch or that it required a conversation with Rio she had not yet had.

The first text was an apology only by definition- wildly unserious, excessively affectionate. She ended it in a dramatic declaration of love meant to retroactively excuse her hostility that morning and preemptively excuse the damage coming next.

 

Since Jen was a charge nurse -by some merciful act of a god who had to be a woman given Agatha’s luck- she was conviently the one who handled scheduling for the entire NICU. 

 

So Agatha’s second text contained her first actual request- whether there was any universe in which Agatha’s scheduled shifts for the next two weeks could quietly be switched over to PTO. If not, could that universe be created? The details of the bribery that followed were unimportant. If that universe still refused to exist, the flu was imminent.

 

The third text asked Jen to tell Alice to retrieve Agatha’s car from the park and bring it to the house, saving Agatha from the inconvenient questions of a beautiful woman who took entirely too much pleasure in asking them.

 

Long story short, Jennifer Kale must be in love with Agatha Harkness, because Agatha secured the next two weeks off receiving only one very threatening text -that Agatha better provide the date and time of this mysterious event or face consequences she could not fathom- and one follow up question asking whether Jen would be needing to bring her professional camera.

 

Only twenty minutes later, Agatha’s Ring app pinged. Someone was in the driveway. The grainy video showed her car parked neatly beside Rio’s, and Alice flipping off the camera with both hands, smiling proudly.

 

It was annoying how safe that made Agatha feel. That she’d somehow surrounded herself with people who let her be strange and intense and treated it like a feature instead of a flaw.

 

Anyway. 

 

Agatha opened her messages again and found Lilia’s name.

 

She typed something that tried very hard to sound normal- that no, she hadn’t asked yet, that yes, she was going to, that it would be tonight and that Lilia’s witchery was not to interfere under any circumstances. She stared at the text, added a period, deleted the period, substituted it with an lol, and sent it.

 

Lilia replied almost immediately with a string of emojis that made absolutely no fucking sense, which answered exactly one question: Rio hadn’t gotten far in her long running attempt to convince her mother to stop texting exclusively in emojis.

There was something exhilarating about watching Rio fold laundry and hang clothes and exist without the faintest idea that she was going to drop -what Agatha would consider- a small bomb into her lap tonight.

 

That thrill followed Agatha to the grocery store.

 

Rio grabbed a basket and immediately detoured toward the display of twelve packs of Diet Coke by the entrance without checking whether they needed it, whether Agatha was out, or whether it was on the list at all, and Agatha felt her stomach swoop at the confidence of it- the assumption of continuity, of shared resources, of a shared life.

In hindsight, she probably should’ve seen that coming. 

 

There was a sealed package of raw chicken sitting in the fridge with the implication that she would be asked to touch something she very strongly did not want to touch, along with more ingredients than she thought necessary, more steps than she had patience for, and a level of attention being applied to all of it that felt excessive for something that would be eaten in twenty minutes.

 

And still, Agatha found that she wasn’t offended by any of it, which felt like a personal failing, because it meant she was enjoying this absolutely unhinged level of orchestration.

Remember that? I bought that brown hoodie from the gift shop in the airport? You remember.
